webTitle: No way back for Lewis now

fields.headline: No way back for Lewis now
fields.standfirst: Orin Gordon assesses how Guyana-born Chris Lewis has emerged from the match-fixing affair
fields.trailText: The question I am most frequently asked about Cronjegate is whether any West Indian players were ever approached by bookies or took money from them. So far my inquiries have yielded nothing, but one West Indian is emerging as a central figure in the latest round of accusations and counter-allegations: a man from Guyana named Chris Lewis. He has been badly - perhaps terminally - damaged by the storm over his allegations that three England players may have been involved in match-fixing. The weight of the evidence seems to be that the ECB mishandled the affair by apparently disregarding the accusations when he first made them nearly a year ago. Even if that is the case, Lewis looks bad for reheating the stuff when the Cronje affair hit the headlines. fields.body:
The question I am most frequently asked about Cronjegate is whether any West Indian players were ever approached by bookies or took money from them. So far my inquiries have yielded nothing, but one West Indian is emerging as a central figure in the latest round of accusations and counter-allegations: a man from Guyana named Chris Lewis. He has been badly - perhaps terminally - damaged by the storm over his allegations that three England players may have been involved in match-fixing. The weight of the evidence seems to be that the ECB mishandled the affair by apparently disregarding the accusations when he first made them nearly a year ago. Even if that is the case, Lewis looks bad for reheating the stuff when the Cronje affair hit the headlines. But my fellow columnist Kamran Abbasi argued last week, the way he was hung out to dry by the cricketing establishment was disgraceful.

If he thought his goose was cooked after his angry denunciation of ECB administrators last year, itÕs been well and truly digested after the ECB's stern summons and apparent cold-shouldering. There's surely no way back to the England team now for Lewis, who got a taste of how low his stock had sunk when he was booed from the field after being run out for 0 for Leicestershire against Lancashire on Monday. The two-division County Championship, which starts today, should have been his chance to remind the selectors and the public that he is not a spent force, but in fact a better all rounder than Craig White, who has been given an England contract. I wonder about LewisÕs state of mind, especially given his short and ill-advised strike to protest his treatment by Lord MacLaurin and co. For Clairmonte Christopher Lewis, the season looks over before it's properly begun.

Lewis has been accused time and again of not delivering the goods for England. It's a cruel irony that, as he tells it, a bent bookie asked him literally to deliver. The ECB should take a leaf out of the book of the South Africans, who acted swiftly in the case of Hansie Cronje. The three players should immediately be summoned to a hearing along with Lewis. The board should then clear up the question of whether he did make the same allegations last year. If the evidence he presents is credible, they should consider suspending the players pending a full investigation. This in turn should be part of a wider inquiry by the ICC into a) the extent to which bookies pay players for information on pitch conditions and the like, and b) the extent of real match-fixing. We know match-fixing is illegal and players who are found guilty should be banned for life. Tough, uniform new penalties should be introduced for taking payment from bookmakers. It's not criminal, but it tarnishes the sport.

The way it looks, for the moment anyway, is that West Indies appear to be the only one of the major cricketing nations untouched by the whole affair. But it's unlikely that the bookies would have approached the likes of Cronje, Shane Warne, Mark Waugh and, apparently, several Pakistanis and not done the same to West Indies players. When I spoke with Clive Lloyd shortly after the Cronje story broke, he told me that to his knowledge none of his players was approached while he was captain or manager (a job he held until a few months ago). He was sure the players would have told him and in any case, he told me confidently, he was sure such approaches would have been dismissed out of hand. Lloyd is certain the drip-drip of allegations and revelations "is destroying the game of cricket", and is in favour of the ICC holding a full and wide-ranging investigation.

How might a player get tapped? Functions such as sponsors' parties and receptions are now important off-field activities for the players, and Lloyd believes it is not that hard to get their mobile phone numbers. Journalists routinely get the their numbers that way. Unfortunately, it seems we're not the only ones who can. I'm less confident than Clive that everyone who might have approached a player would have been shooed away. Cricketers earn very little compared to other professional sportsmen. Shane Warne will take home £750,000 after his season with Hampshire, but most of that will be in sponsorship. Footballers at the low end of the pay scale in the English Premiership can earn close to half-a-million a year. A footballer who has as much stature as Warne in his game can expect to earn at least five times that. And let's not even talk about what basketball players earn in the NBA. The point is that cricketers are sensitive to issues of pay, as the Windies players showed when they almost wrecked their tour of South Africa before it started 18 months ago, with their Heathrow stand-off. When they finally did face Cronje's men, they lost the Test series 5-0 and the one-day series 6-1. Yeah, I know what you'd be thinking now: how did they win that one match when they were so mind-numbingly awful throughout the tour? I thought and still think Cronje's captaincy was a great example of ruthlessly, even chillingly, professional leadership. His opponents had even begun to inspire pity, but he never let up. As Indian investigators compile their dossier on him, Cronje can point to those matches in his defence.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. His Anglo-Caribbean View appears fortnightly on wisden.com.

Next Wednesday you can read Kamran AbbasiÕs Anglo-Asian View.

fields.headline: Diary of a failed transfer
fields.trailText: Thursday April 20
fields.body:
Thursday April 20

 United's chairman Martin Edwards and financial director David Gill meet PSV Eindhoven officials for 20 minutes over lunch where £18.5m price for Ruud van Nistelrooy is agreed.

 Dutch television announces Van Nistelrooy's transfer in late-night broadcast.

Friday April 21

 Van Nistelrooy holds morning press conference in Netherlands while, in Manchester, United's manager Sir Alex Ferguson complains that PSV have broken a confidentiality agreement by making the deal public. He adds that he will not say anything until the completion of the striker's medical.

Monday April 24

 Ferguson denies that he will have to sell after the striker's arrival: "Have I said anyone is for sale? There are no notices up at this club."

 Van Nistelrooy watches United's 3-2 win over Chelsea.

Tuesday April 25

 Edwards says that Ferguson will have to sell one of his strikers before he can spend again.

 United call a press conference for 4.30pm to parade the new signing. Just before 6pm, Gill reveals that the transfer has been held up by Van Nistelrooy's knee injury.

Wednesday April 26

 PSV fly in their specialist, Dr. Cees Rein van der Hoogenband, who has been monitoring van Nistelrooy's knee since he sustained the injury.

 Van Nistelrooy flies home after a day of medical checks. Both PSV and Manchester United restate their confidence that the deal will go through by the weekend.

Thursday April 27

 United tell van Nistelrooy that he must undergo keyhole surgery to check on his recovery. He is also instructed to make a successful comeback before they will complete the deal.

 Van Raay tells United that PSV will not agree to the extra conditions. United announce that the transfer "cannot proceed at this present time" and the deal collapses.

webTitle: Stagecoach rejig means founders take back seat

fields.headline: Stagecoach rejig means founders take back seat
fields.trailText: Stagecoach, the international bus and train group hit by six months of negative publicity and recent top-level resignations, yesterday announced a boardroom shake-up that will see co-founder Ann Gloag relinquish executive responsibilities and former finance director Keith Cochrane take over as group chief executive.
fields.body:
Stagecoach, the international bus and train group hit by six months of negative publicity and recent top-level resignations, yesterday announced a boardroom shake-up that will see co-founder Ann Gloag relinquish executive responsibilities and former finance director Keith Cochrane take over as group chief executive.

Britain's biggest rail operator denied any intention to take itself private, despite a halving of the share price this year. Ms Gloag's brother and long-standing business partner, Brian Souter, stays on as executive chairman in charge of developing Stagecoach worldwide.

In February, the then group chief executive, Mike Kinski, and Larry King, head of its Coach USA subsidiary, resigned. Despite denials of serious differences between them and Mr Souter, their departures accelerated the slide that had already taken the share price from about 300p in early 1998 to 108p. Since then the price has fallen heavily again, although it was steady last night at 64p.

A share buyback plan already announced is bolstering the price. It will take the total stake of Mr Souter and Ms Gloag to 25% from the present 20%, but a spokesman denied this foreshadowed a move to take Stagecoach back into private hands. That would not make sense, he said.

Stagecoach said Mr Souter would concentrate on business opportunities internationally while Mr Cochrane would run the company. An additional non-executive director would be appointed shortly. All this was seen as a response to City criticisms of an excessive focus on Mr Souter in terms of decision-making.

Former business development manager Martin Griffiths will become finance director.

Stagecoach is a partner with Virgin Trains on the west coast main line and is bidding with Virgin for the east coast service, on which the two companies are pledged to introduce high-speed trains.

Ms Gloag co-founded Stagecoach with Mr Souter in Perth, Scotland, in 1980 with a handful of buses. She is to stay on as a non-executive director, but has been keen to give up day-to-day responsibility. As director in charge of Stagecoach's ventures in Kenya and Malawi, she became involved in charitable activities in Africa.

webTitle: The new BA boss who fires people nicely

fields.headline: The new BA boss who fires people nicely
fields.trailText: Crucial credentials
fields.body:
Crucial credentials

British Airways has found its new chief pilot in Rod Eddington. The 50 year-old Australian might be flying in from an airline few BA customers will have heard of, but he has a rock-solid reputation.

He is intelligent - a Rhodes scholar no less - experienced in the airline world, having run Cathay Pacific and Ansett, the Australian airline, well-connected - a friend of Rupert Murdoch - and perhaps more crucially, has people-management skills - that is, he fires staff nicely.

Unlike his predecessor Bob Ayling, who was distracted by ventures such as the Millennium Wheel, Mr Eddington is said to have a "down-to-earth" manner and conciliatory management skills.

Lord Marshall, the BA chairman, made it clear that the latter were crucial credentials for Mr Ayling's replacement, partly because Mr Eddington will have to live with most of the processes put in place before his arrival on May 1. For instance, orders for smaller planes, implemented as part of the plan to cut 12% of capacity over the next three years, are almost impossible to reverse.

The move to seek out more profitable business passengers is equally irrevocable, although Mr Eddington will try to temper perceptions that the airline wants to turn away all economy passengers as a result. Even if the plans for business passengers are fulfilled, BA's proportion of "premium" customers will increase from 15% to 17%, hardly any thing to get excited about. But where Mr Eddington will be able to show his worth is in repairing staff morale and the airline's reputation.

While BA refuses to confirm the figures - he is expected to axe at least 6,500 staff, around 10% and do so without alienating people by facing staff in cabins and at check-ins. By all accounts he handled ruthless cuts at Ansett, which he turned around by talking in person to the pilots who faced the axe.

It remains to be seen whether such a direct approach will placate British union members. But Mr Eddington will have to hope it does if he is to start winning the confidence of BA staff. If progress can be made at the most basic level, BA will be looking for positive reaction in its languishing share price.

But cost-cutting and morale boosting is only part of the problem: generating profits is in the game, too. While Mr Eddington pushed Ansett from a loss to profit it meant revenue growth of just 6% in the turnaround period. BA investors will be looking for more rapid growth, and if he achieves it they might let him reward himself in the way other foreign chief executives expect to be compensated - with huge expatriate packages and share options schemes.

Renault refocus

There should be joy at Renault headquarters today. The French automotive group has finally tied up an alliance with Volvo, even if the shape is very different from the original proposal for a full-scale marriage, long before Volvo sold its car business to Ford, which was wrecked by Swedish shareholder opposition a few years ago.

To be fair the latest scheme does not look too bad for Volvo either, and will certainly give any lurking predators something to think about. But it is clearly a second-best option after the Swedish group's plans to merge with Scania were thwarted by the Brussels competition authorities.

For its part, Renault gets a 15% stake in a truck business which must have a fair chance of establishing a competitive position in a fast changing industry. Most important, Renault will now be able to devote its full attention to its car business, rather than its focus being weakened by the needs of a truck business that on its own was well short of being a global player. It will need to. Renault has played what seemed a poor hand very well and now appears a much beefier player - and its financial performance has improved dramatically.

The Nissan deal last year gave it a strong foothold in what will be a crucial market when the Japanese economy revives. Now it has the green light for buying into South Korea through Samsung Motors. The Pusan plant will give Renault a splendid manufacturing facility in a market that is expected to recover its pre-crisis capacity. Spotting opportunities is one thing, making them pay another. Renault was able to establish its Asian presence because its partners there had problems. Welding the parts into a whole will not be without difficulties, but it will be easier for Renault now it is able to refocus on cars.

Rover's lesson

Politicians have fired their heavy artillery in a late attempt to save Rover but have not dented BMW's plans. They will claim to have done their best. This may reduce some of the inevitable flak when thousands lose their jobs, but it will not inspire confidence among Ford's workers at Dagenham.

webTitle: 21 players who are shaping the net

fields.headline: 21 players who are shaping the net
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Steve Jobs, the mastermind of Apple Computer's financial turnaround, and Jacques Nasser, who has championed easy internet access for Ford workers and clients, are among the 21 most influential individuals who shaped the net economy last year, according to Industry Standard journal, the monthly bible of silicon valley.
fields.body:
Steve Jobs, the mastermind of Apple Computer's financial turnaround, and Jacques Nasser, who has championed easy internet access for Ford workers and clients, are among the 21 most influential individuals who shaped the net economy last year, according to Industry Standard journal, the monthly bible of silicon valley.

"The Net 21 is our account of the people who have created the businesses, technologies and policies that drive the internet," said editor Jonathan Weber.

Recent trends are signalled by the inclusion of David Boies, leading light of the US government's legal attack on Microsoft, and Dieter Seitzer and Heinz Gerhauser - the men behind the music platform MP3.

Net veteran Jim Clark is top strategist, "having bold ideas, attracting top-flight talent - and knowing when to get out of the way".

Among the start-ups, Joseph Park's delivery service, Kozmo.com, is selected, while on this side of the Atlantic Bertelsmann's Thomas Midelhoff is cited as the man to meet "if a net executive wants to move in to Europe".

 Industry Standard notes that venture capitalist James Breyer of Accel Partners tends to avoid business to consumer projects but is backing Wal-Mart.com - "which is expected to provide stiff competition to Amazon.com.

 Best chief executive of a new internet business: Joseph Park, 28 year-old founder of Kozmo.com

 Most effective big company chief executive: Jacques Nasser, Ford

 Most innovative online retailer: Jeff Bezos, chief executive of Amazon

 Most innovative business to business executive: Ken Fox, co-founder and managing director, Internet Capital Group.

 Most influential new-business strategist: Jim Clark, Netscape, Healtheon

 Most influential international executive: Thomas Middlehoff, Bertelsmann.

 Most powerful investment banker: Frank Quattrone, managing director, Credit Suisse First Boston.

Most influential internet analyst: Mary Meeker, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

 Most influential investor: Masayoshi Son, president and chief executive, Softbank

 Most powerful venture capitalist: James Breyer, managing general partner, Accel Partners.

 Most influential net marketing executive: Steve Jobs, co-founder and chief executive of Apple

 Most influential net advertising executive: Kevin O'Connor, chief executive of Doubleclick

 Most important infrastructure builder: Cisco

 Most influential software developer: Dieter Seitzer and Heinz Gerhauser, directors, Fraunhofer Institute for Integrated Circuits.

 Most important hardware developers: Donna Dubinsky and Jeff Hawkins, Handspring

 Most important policymaker: Robert Pitofsky, federal trade commission.

 Most influential standard bearer: Eric Brewer, chief scientist, Inktomi; professor of computer science, UC Berkeley.

 Most effective financial services executive: David Pottruck, president and co-chief, Charles Schwab.

 Most powerful net media mogul: Steve Case, chairman and chief executive, America Online

 Most influential writer-journalist: Michael Lewis.

 Most powerful adviser: David Boies, prosecutor, US department of justice.

fields.headline: Shiny happy chit-chat merchants
fields.standfirst:
The Butterflies of Love
Monarch, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
The Butterflies of Love
Monarch, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Alternative music is renowned for its dearth of personalities. Most indie musicians who think they have character either cultivate moody silence or project its opposite, a garrulous, usually misplaced arrogance in their limited talent. Both are irritating. The rest are simply too shy to scrape together more than the occasional thank you after a song.

So it's a delight to come across Connecticut's The Butterflies of Love, particularly one of the quintet's two singer-guitarists, Jeff Greene. He realises that bands lost in their own world and concentrating on playing good music don't always perform the best gigs; that a live show can involve communication with the audience, not just a musical monologue. Before they begin playing the second song, Mt Everest, he confesses that he's lost his wah wah pedal, and that "it would really mean a lot to the rest of this set if someone could lend me one". There's something absurd about his request - who goes out with guitar pedals stuffed in their satchels? - but it's heart-warming that he even thought to ask.

Later when he breaks a string, he introduces the band and calls bassist Peter Whitney, a man who looks curiously like Danny the drug dealer from Withnail and I and plays as if he's from that era too, "Peter the Genius". He also tells us that he's having a day of bad luck, but that he's wearing new trousers that he bought down the road in Camden earlier and that makes up for everything. It's all desperately mundane stuff, but that's the point: just sometimes it's nice to watch musicians who act and talk like normal people.

In fact, the Butterflies of Love appear to be so affable that it's upsetting to find that their music is indifferent. It's not that they play badly, more that their pretty, psychedelic pop lacks innovation and a spark of magic that might make their songs really exciting rather than pleasant enough. Like the excellent Beulah, the Butterflies are a rougher prospect on stage than their sometimes fragile album, How to Know, suggests: guitar chords rev and spike through a swaggering Love Can Be Possible; throughout the show, Scott Amore's plinkety keyboards sound bizarrely like steel drums.

But when Jeff closes the set heaping compliments on London's music community, it almost doesn't matter what the music was like; you leave with a contented smile anyway.

 Appearing at the 13th Note Cafe, Glasgow (0141-553 1638), tonight, then touring.

webTitle: Scottish Provident to review mutual status

fields.headline: Scottish Provident to review mutual status
fields.trailText: Scottish Provident is in line to be the next life office to demutualise - giving its 430,000 members windfalls of around £3,000 - after admitting yesterday that it is carrying out a review of its mutual status with a decision expected by late summer.
fields.body:
Scottish Provident is in line to be the next life office to demutualise - giving its 430,000 members windfalls of around £3,000 - after admitting yesterday that it is carrying out a review of its mutual status with a decision expected by late summer.

The life office, which has £10bn under management as well as a 39% stake in rapidly growing Aberdeen Asset Management, took the unusual step of meeting with a carpetbagger's representative, Gordon Hart, on Thursday last week.

Yesterday Scottish Provident issued a statement which confirmed that it is carrying out "a full and thorough review of its options, which include among other things the possibility of demutualisation".

The Scottish Provident Members Action Group immediately proclaimed the move as a victory in its campaign to force the life office to demutualise.

Mr Hart said: "This is very positive news. After the initial rejection of our resolutions we have come across very little resistance."

Mr Hart has also agreed not to submit resolutions calling for the removal of directors pending the results of the review.

Independent life insurance analyst Ned Cazalet puts a value of £1.25bn on Scottish Provident, which is expected to make an attractive takeover target after it pulled out of its loss-making pensions business three years ago and now specialises in more profitable term insurance and critical illness products.

Its stake in Aberdeen is believed to be worth more than £350m.

fields.headline: Start-ups adopt co-op spirit
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: One of the most common complaints among internet entrepreneurs is that despite working 20-hour days and sacrificing their social lives they risk all their savings, are poorly paid and have no way of realising the value of shares that may - or may not - one day be worth a fortune.
fields.body:
One of the most common complaints among internet entrepreneurs is that despite working 20-hour days and sacrificing their social lives they risk all their savings, are poorly paid and have no way of realising the value of shares that may - or may not - one day be worth a fortune.

Even when their companies go public there are usually "lock-in" periods which prevent founders and top executives from selling their shares.

But now the impoverished entrepreneurs are being offered a way of getting hold of some dot.com wealth before their own companies float on the stock market or are bought out.

A San Francisco-based start-up,eFounders, has devised a scheme that allows net entrepreneurs to benefit from each other's success.

It wants them to place between 5% and 10% of their personal equity in a fund along with 11 other entrepreneurs who are running companies of similar strength and valuation and chances of going public.

Each time one of the partners' firms goes public, is bought or merges, everyone in the partnership benefits immediately. It also diversifies their investment portfolio and increases liquidity.

"The perception about Silicon Valley is that the huge equity positions held by founders in their own start-ups translate into an immediate cash position for these individuals at the initial public offering -when in fact the opposite is often true," said Bashir Wada, managing director of eFounders. "Company founders can sometimes wait years to benefit from the stock they hold in their own companies; eFounders was created to provide and innovative means for founders to invest and diversify their personal equity, and seek out financial products and services that have been unavailable until now."

Mr Wada's company plans to offer a range of personal finance products and services to entrepreneurs signing up to the scheme, and eFounders plans to take take 20% of profits after initial return of capital.

Mr Wada said that an experimental fund that was set up 18 months ago, Entrepreneurs Diversification Fund 1, was so successful that it was subsequently established as a separate company.

Analysts believe that the business model could translate to the UK and be of use to networking groups such as First Tuesday.

Media investment specialist Durlacher is already working on plans to offer a personal finance service to entrepreneurs working in hi-tech industries who do not have the time, or often the experience, to look after their finances.

webTitle: Security guards to be vetted for criminal record

fields.headline: Security guards to be vetted for criminal record
fields.trailText: Security guards, club "bouncers", wheelclampers and private investigators are to be vetted to ensure they have no criminal past under legislation to be introduced later this year.
fields.body:
Security guards, club "bouncers", wheelclampers and private investigators are to be vetted to ensure they have no criminal past under legislation to be introduced later this year.

Home Office ministers will publish a draft "police and private security bill" in the next few months and it is expected to be followed by full legislation in the Queen's Speech this autumn.

The state regulation of the private security industry was a longstanding commitment made by Labour in opposition. The Home Office estimates that some 24,000 of the 80,000 people who apply to work in private security companies each year have a record of serious criminal convictions.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said in an introduction to a white paper last summer that private security guards had become a familiar sight, whether patrolling shopping centres, parks, leisure centres or housing estates, and yet there were examples of companies which were owned and run by people with serious criminal records.

Chief constables have been particularly angered by unregulated private security companies who exploit their offer of residential neighbourhood patrols to vulnerable residents, such as the elderly, for criminal purposes.

The home office minister, Charles Clarke, has held meetings in the last few weeks with representatives of Britain's 20,000 bouncers or "door supervisors" to see how licensing could be used to curb the problem of drug dealing in some areas.

It is believed the Home Office will propose a scheme that stops short of total state regu lation. It is expected that private security guards, and the directors of private security companies, will require a personal licence to operate. They will have to be passed as a "fit person" by a new private security industry authority before they can join or run a private security company.

The new authority will carry out a check to see if they have a criminal past but will not disclose the details to a potential employer - only whether or not the applicant has a clean record.

It is expected that regulation will be phased in with licensing initially covering only the manned guarding sector of the industry which includes 'in-house' staff, door supervisors, cash-in-transit, wheelclampers, the use of guard dogs, security services in shops and public areas, those who fit alarms and closed-circuit television systems, and those who provide local or neighbourhood guarding or patrol services.

This will be followed by the regulation of private investigators, those who run electronic monitoring or tagging systems, locksmiths, keyholders and security consultants.

The introduction of the legislation .

Although the private security industry has shrunk slightly in the past few years, it is still worth about £3bn a year, and with 240,000 personnel has already outgrown the police service.

More than 8,000 companies are involved. Most of the industry is reputable but some are little more than "near protection rackets" operated by unregulated private companies who prey on the fears of vulnerable residents by offering local patrolling services at £1 a week per household.

An inquiry by a Commons home affairs select committee concluded that increasing public concern about standards in the industry had followed its rapid growth in the 1990s and the expansion of its role in areas previously the domain of the police.

Attempts at voluntary regulation had failed because too many companies with low standards had not joined the system.

David Dickinson, a director of Group 4 security firm, last night welcomed the prospect of legislation: "Self-regulation has failed. There are too many horror stories around and too many people who are engaging in criminality under the cloak of the private security industry." The larger private security companies have long waged a campaign for state regulation to combat the smaller "cowboys".

Mr Straw has made clear that the state regulation of the industry is essential before any discussion of using private security guards to supplement the patrolling capacity of the uniformed police and to provide a more official visible "law and order" presence in those parts of the country where fear of crime is most acute.

fields.headline: Love among the microchips
fields.standfirst:
If you're young and bright and prepared to work, work, work, Silicon Valley is the promised land. There's just one catch: forget about finding a mate. Jane Martinson reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: If you're young and bright and prepared to work, work, work, Silicon Valley is the promised land. There's just one catch: forget about finding a mate.
fields.body:
Anyone looking for a Silicon Valley success story should look no further than Randy. At 35, he is the head of a hi-tech company that plans to go public next year. He drives a BMW 740 and has just paid $4m for an acre of land in the Valley's swanky Atherton area. One female friend describes him as a "sort of tall Al Pacino".

Randy is about to marry a woman he met via dating agency Kelleher & Associates (slogan: "Beautiful women want to meet Silicon Valley men"). A "lover of people" who says he has been on lots of dates since arriving on the West Coast 10 years ago, Randy was nevertheless ready to pay up to $8,500 for Kelleher's services.

"Most people in Silicon Valley are pragmatic," he explains, "and anything that saves time is good. It's all about maximising time over target. When I'm looking for a senior executive, I go to a search agency and give them my criteria. The chances of finding a long-term match are far higher with such a recruiter than if you try to do it in a scatter-gun fashion."

Randy is not alone in wanting help to find a mate in Silicon Valley. The area around Palo Alto, a magnet for some of the most highly educated, highly paid people in the US, is also a mecca for matchmaking services. Ads for companies such as How About Lunch and Table For Six are constantly aired on local radio and TV networks, while other agencies leaflet entire neighbourhoods. Kelleher has almost doubled its client base in the past two years, to around 1,500.

Last year, the American Singles dating service moved its annual convention from Anchorage to Palo Alto for the first time. The move recognised the fact that men who prospect for oil are no longer as valuable a commodity as those digging for virtual gold, but it also acknowledged the demographic and social factors that have left the most successful part of America, if not the world, one of the loneliest.

The boom in dating services might seem odd to outsiders. Silicon Valley attracts some of the world's youngest, most dynamic people. San Francisco bars are full of twenty- and thirtysomethings at weekends, while launch parties and networking clubs such as Wildcat Wednesday attract thousands every night of the week. What's more, Silicon Valley enjoys one of the highest per capita income levels in the world, with around 64 new millionaires minted every day.

Yet speak to these eligible men and women, and a surprising number talk of a work and wealth-obsessed culture that breeds financial and career success while keeping fun for later. Simon Levene, director of corporate development at Excite@Home, says: "People call it the Joseph-in-Egypt phenomenon. They put up with seven years of famine and hope for seven years of plenty."

There are lots of reasons for the famine in Silicon Valley, the first of which is demographic: there are simply not enough women to go round. In Palo Alto, the heart of the hi-tech machine, there are 36% more men than women - almost the reverse of figures in America as a whole, where there are 43m single women compared with 36m single men.

Added to this statistical anomaly is the fact that the typical Valley man is not known for smoothness when it comes to the opposite sex. Think bad haircuts and an obsession with Tomb Raider. The oft-used line about dating in the Valley is that while the odds are good, the goods are odd.

Hannah, a former comic book publisher who arrived a year ago to become a senior manager at one of the world's biggest websites, says: "I could tell you 10 horror stories about guys I've dated here." The 29-year-old has been to parties where "the geeks walk in two-by-two and sit on the floor to discuss database design".

American Singles fell foul of the techie nature of its target audience when it held its inaugural Valley event during Comdex, the annual convention for tech types. Hardly any men showed up to a ballroom full of women who had paid $35 a head.

Yet demographics based on number and type go nowhere near explaining why Silicon Valley is full of singletons. Anecdotal evidence suggests nobody has any time for sex and its attendant anxieties, and Amber Kelleher confirms this. "People fly in from all around the world. They are suddenly placed in this Valley of Competition and it's all business. Their personal lives are thrown out of the window."

Kelleher & Associates was founded by Amber's mother 20 years ago. Jill Kelleher is used on ads for the agency because of her resemblance to Linda Evans who played Krystle Carrington in Dynasty. The agency has witnessed several changes in that time. Until 10 years ago, new clients tended to be divorcees in their 40s and 50s; now they are more like Randy - in their early 30s and looking to settle down for the first time. "What's happening now is that work takes precedence over relationships and people want a career before they want a family," Kelleher says. This Generation-X behaviour is hardly unusual, but a culture that boasts of 24/7 devotion to work intensifies the phenomenon.

In spite of her bad experiences, Hannah fell for a "tormented genius" when he laughed about her company's well-publicised technical woes. She saw him "once in a while" for six weeks until one too many dates was cancelled because he was working all hours on a new start-up and she was too busy herself to be fitted into his schedule. "There are so many men out here who are good on paper, who my mother would love, but when you meet someone really nice, it's impossible to find the time," she says.

Randy is typical. After finishing a doctorate in electronic engineering, he worked an average of 80 hours per week for seven years. When he became CEO, he slowed down a bit to "between 60 and 80" hours and it was then that he realised he only ever met people to talk about work.

"I tend to be a pretty focused kind of person," he says. "I initially focused on being successful and it was OK to date a bit. But when I felt I'd achieved my career goal, I figured I wanted somebody important to share it with."

As well as the work obsession, there is a concern for wealth that rich Valley dwellers find troubling in a potential mate. Successful, available women like Hannah are in short supply. "People talk about the gold-diggers out here," she says, "but not all of them are women." She tells of phoning a friend of a friend to arrange a possible date. "He asked me exactly where I worked and how long I'd been there. We carried on chatting but I could hear him clicking on his computer. A few minutes later, he told me exactly how much I must have made on my share options. We never met."

An obsession with valuations can spill over into the personal sphere. Simon Levene, who is 29, says some of his peers take a very calculated approach to meeting women. "Lots of guys want to buy their convertible Porsches before they find a girlfriend. Look, many of these men weren't necessarily successful with women at college. They weren't head of the football team. They don't mind putting that part of their lives on hold for a while in the hope that they'll do well financially and at the end of the rainbow there'll be a buxom blonde."

Hannah refutes the suggestion that it is the geek factor alone that is to blame for the dearth of Valley relationships. "Listen, I've met some of the most intelligent, interesting dudes out here. But the thing that makes them those things, the thing that makes them chase dreams in the first place, also messes them up."

In this atmosphere, the apparent popularity of dating agencies does not seem so odd. Gaby Derbyshire, the English business development manager at internet company eGroups, says she laughed when she saw a dating agency leaflet land on the doormat at the home she shares with two male friends. Though they were both attractive and successful, she found it entirely believable that they may have signed up for a service. "They are both incredibly fussy about what they want," she says. "They want someone smart, not just pretty and fluffy, but they don't necessarily have the time to invest in finding someone like that." The leaflets turned out to be unsolicited fliers.

In a report on the area, Business Week recently said: "It's now 100% socially acceptable to sign up for Match.com or Matchmaker.com."

Yet Randy felt the internet itself lowered the chances of meeting a partner. "What the internet has done is disenfranchise people by increasing electronic rather than physical communication. Most people don't end up going to grocery stores any more. Silicon Valley isn't that different from the rest of the world," he concludes. "People everywhere are working hard and focusing on themselves. It just gets more and more difficult to meet the right people at the same time."

There are lots of reasons for the famine in Silicon Valley, the first of which is demographic: there are simply not enough women to go round. In Palo Alto, the heart of the hi-tech machine, there are 36% more men than women - almost the reverse of figures in America as a whole, where there are 43m single women compared with 36m single men. Added to this statistical anomaly is the fact that the typical Valley man is not known for smoothness when it comes to the opposite sex. Think bad haircuts and an obsession with Tomb Raider. The oft-used line about dating in the Valley is that while the odds are good, the goods are odd. Hannah, a former comic book publisher who arrived a year ago to become a senior manager at one of the world's biggest websites, says: "I could tell you 10 horror stories about guys I've dated here." The 29-year-old has been to parties where "the geeks walk in two-by-two and sit on the floor to discuss database design". American Singles fell foul of the techie nature of its target audience when it held its inaugural Valley event during Comdex, the annual convention for tech types. Hardly any men showed up to a ballroom full of women who had paid $35 a head. Yet demographics based on number and type go nowhere near explaining why Silicon Valley is full of singletons. Anecdotal evidence suggests nobody has any time for sex and its attendant anxieties, and Amber Kelleher confirms this. "People fly in from all around the world. They are suddenly placed in this Valley of Competition and it's all business. Their personal lives are thrown out of the window." Kelleher & Associates was founded by Amber's mother 20 years ago. Jill Kelleher is used on ads for the agency because of her resemblance to Linda Evans who played Krystle Carrington in Dynasty. The agency has witnessed several changes in that time. Until 10 years ago, new clients tended to be divorcees in their 40s and 50s; now they are more like Randy - in their early 30s and looking to settle down for the first time. "What's happening now is that work takes precedence over relationships and people want a career before they want a family," Kelleher says. This Generation-X behaviour is hardly unusual, but a culture that boasts of 24/7 devotion to work intensifies the phenomenon. In spite of her bad experiences, Hannah fell for a "tormented genius" when he laughed about her company's well-publicised technical woes. She saw him "once in a while" for six weeks until one too many dates was cancelled because he was working all hours on a new start-up and she was too busy herself to be fitted into his schedule. "There are so many men out here who are good on paper, who my mother would love, but when you meet someone really nice, it's impossible to find the time," she says. Randy is typical. After finishing a doctorate in electronic engineering, he worked an average of 80 hours per week for seven years. When he became CEO, he slowed down a bit to "between 60 and 80" hours and it was then that he realised he only ever met people to talk about work. "I tend to be a pretty focused kind of person," he says. "I initially focused on being successful and it was OK to date a bit. But when I felt I'd achieved my career goal, I figured I wanted somebody important to share it with." As well as the work obsession, there is a concern for wealth that rich Valley dwellers find troubling in a potential mate. Successful, available women like Hannah are in short supply. "People talk about the gold-diggers out here," she says, "but not all of them are women." She tells of phoning a friend of a friend to arrange a possible date. "He asked me exactly where I worked and how long I'd been there. We carried on chatting but I could hear him clicking on his computer. A few minutes later, he told me exactly how much I must have made on my share options. We never met." An obsession with valuations can spill over into the personal sphere. Simon Levene, who is 29, says some of his peers take a very calculated approach to meeting women. "Lots of guys want to buy their convertible Porsches before they find a girlfriend. Look, many of these men weren't necessarily successful with women at college. They weren't head of the football team. They don't mind putting that part of their lives on hold for a while in the hope that they'll do well financially and at the end of the rainbow there'll be a buxom blonde." Hannah refutes the suggestion that it is the geek factor alone that is to blame for the dearth of Valley relationships. "Listen, I've met some of the most intelligent, interesting dudes out here. But the thing that makes them those things, the thing that makes them chase dreams in the first place, also messes them up." In this atmosphere, the apparent popularity of dating agencies does not seem so odd. Gaby Derbyshire, the English business development manager at internet company eGroups, says she laughed when she saw a dating agency leaflet land on the doormat at the home she shares with two male friends. Though they were both attractive and successful, she found it entirely believable that they may have signed up for a service. "They are both incredibly fussy about what they want," she says. "They want someone smart, not just pretty and fluffy, but they don't necessarily have the time to invest in finding someone like that." The leaflets turned out to be unsolicited fliers. In a report on the area, Business Week recently said: "It's now 100% socially acceptable to sign up for Match.com or Matchmaker.com." Yet Randy felt the internet itself lowered the chances of meeting a partner. "What the internet has done is disenfranchise people by increasing electronic rather than physical communication. Most people don't end up going to grocery stores any more. Silicon Valley isn't that different from the rest of the world," he concludes. "People everywhere are working hard and focusing on themselves. It just gets more and more difficult to meet the right people at the same time."

fields.headline: Microsoft issue splits US analysts
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: President Clinton's economic team was yesterday believed to be considering the splitting-up of Microsoft after the abuse of its Windows operating system monopoly, dividing analysts on whether such a move would make the software group more or less valuable.
fields.body:
President Clinton's economic team was yesterday believed to be considering the splitting-up of Microsoft after the abuse of its Windows operating system monopoly, dividing analysts on whether such a move would make the software group more or less valuable.

US justice department officials were understood to be explaining to the presidential panel how Microsoft might be divided into two or three parts: possibly a Windows company, an applications firm and an internet company.

"From a shareholder's standpoint that would have to be a plus," said Chris LeToq of Gartner Group. "If losing happens it would be better for them to lose on a structural basis."

But David Readerman of Thomas Weisel said: "I see it [as being] more likely to result in a destruction of shareholder value, not an unlocking of shareholder value."

Microsoft, which is set to appeal against the ruling that it acted illegally, was in no doubt. "This would be bad for Microsoft, consumers and the entire industry," said group spokesman Jim Cullinan.

"There is nothing in the trial record or in this case that would justify such an extreme and radical remedy."

Gene Sperling, head of the National Economic Council, would not say if the panel intended to make any recommendations to the justice department's lawyers. "We are not going to answer any hypothetical questions," he said.

The government and the 19 states involved in the case are expected to submit by the end of the week proposals to encourage more competition between operating systems.

First word of the plans after the weekend cost Microsoft 16% of its share value, but in early trading yesterday they recovered $1.93.75, or 3%.

But Microsoft employees were told yesterday they will be granted extra stock options equal to the number they were granted in July 1999. Chief executive Steve Ballmer told employees about their options in an internal email emphasising his conviction that the company will not be broken up, the spokesman said.

fields.headline: Standard Life rebels win
fields.standfirst: Insurer admits losing publicity battle as it is forced to hold demutualisation ballot
fields.trailText: Insurance group Standard Life was forced yesterday to conduct a demutualisation poll which could bring a £6,000 windfall for each of its 2.3m policyholders.
fields.body:
Insurance group Standard Life was forced yesterday to conduct a demutualisation poll which could bring a £6,000 windfall for each of its 2.3m policyholders.

A vote in favour of a stock market listing would bring to an end 175 years of mutuality and propel the £19bn company into the FTSE 100.

The decision at a meeting in Edinburgh to give members a say on Standard Life's future came as it was revealed that a poll on demutualisation carried out by the insurer found that more of its policyholders were in favour of conversion to a public limited company than supported it staying mutual.

Standard Life will hold the meeting within the next three months, and said in the coming weeks it would put forward the case for mutuality. "Mutuality works for this organisation and we believe strongly that it can go on doing so for further generations," said chairman John Trott yesterday at the annual meeting.

The announcement of a meeting to vote on the matter and the revelation that the company's poll results represent a significant first-round victory for the rebels co-ordi nating the demutualisation campaign. The Standard Life Members Action Group is led by Australian Fred Woollard, a former fund manager. He estimates that flotation of the company could see it valued at £12bn-£15bn and potentially deliver a windfall of £5,000-£6,500 each to qualifying with-profits policyholders.

The company rejected these valuations and said it was impossible to say how much payouts might be.

Mr Woollard yesterday presented a "members' requisition" containing five resolutions, including one calling on the board to take steps to demutualise and another which would change the company's rules to give policyholders more power in directing the board on particular issues.

Mr Trott said the resolutions appeared to be valid, and provided this was the case the company would call a special meeting to allow members to have their say. This meeting must be held within the next three months and Mr Trott said the company would be contacting policyholders in the next few days.

"We will set out over the course of the next weeks the exceptionally strong case for mutuality."

Details of the research carried out by Standard Life were revealed during the annual meeting's question and answer session. Some 1,500 policy holders were surveyed in February as part of a market research exercise, and 25.5% said they supported demutualisation while 23.3% opposed it. However, 49.6% were undecided and 1.7% said they would not vote.

Group managing director Scott Bell played down the figures: "We haven't begun a campaign yet. We are very hopeful of persuading the vast majority of the middle 50% to support us."

While many of the 300-plus people at the meeting supported the insurer's pro-mutual stance, some accused it of not putting the case strongly enough.

One said that in failing to grapple with the whole issue earlier the board "may have made our company vulnerable to an offer from an outside source, and this might be very difficult to resist". Another said Monaco-based Mr Woollard was "running the show and getting all the publicity".

Mr Bell conceded that the company had not been as vigorous as it should have been in promoting mutuality but rejected suggestions that uncertainty about the company's future could prompt a creditor to pounce. "We don't expect any approaches."

For demutualisation to be given the go-ahead the proposal for a change in rules would require a 75% majority, while that asking the board to take steps to convert would need a 50%-plus majority.

The company said it expected to win the vote by a sizeable margin. If it loses the board will have to produce a plan for flotation which would involve a further ballot. The process of demutualisation would take up to two years.

Mr Woollard, who stands to make £150,000 from second-hand policies he has bought in the company, said he was looking forward to a "full debate" on the issue.

Barclays Global Investors last night confirmed that three endowment funds it manages had backed demutualisation in pursuance of the boards' fiduciary duty.

webTitle: Barclays faces stormy meeting over top pay and closures

fields.headline: Barclays faces stormy meeting over top pay and closures
fields.trailText: The controversial pay deal for Barclays chief executive Matt Barrett and the bank's unpopular branch closure programme are expected to cause an outcry at today's annual meeting.
fields.body:
The controversial pay deal for Barclays chief executive Matt Barrett and the bank's unpopular branch closure programme are expected to cause an outcry at today's annual meeting.

Pirc, the pay consultancy, has advised shareholders not to support the pay deal, and small shareholders are expected to ask the bank to clarify the terms of its complicated performance-related pay deal, which they will be asked to approve today.

While initial anxieties among major institutional shareholders about the potential rewards of the pay deal, calculated to be as much as £30m, have subsided, small investors remain in the dark.

"The level of discussion between Barclays and small investors has been limited so it will be very difficult for them to arrive at the meeting with an informed judgment," one investment source said yesterday.

Mr Barrett, who told MPs that his share price would have to reach £180 if he was to receive £30m, yesterday unveiled one of his first strategic steps since taking the helm in October.

The bank, whose shares rose 42p to £16.70 yesterday, is to raise £269m in cash by selling its vehicle fleet leasing arm, Dial Group, to Dutch bank ABN Amro. Mr Barrett had promised the City at the bank's results presentation in February that he would sell off underperforming businesses and redirect the investment elsewhere.

Chris Lendrum, chief executive of Barclays' corporate bank, confirmed that this was the case with Dial.

"Dial is an excellently run and well-known business but it does not fit with our core activities at a time of competing investment opportunities," he said.

The bank did not indicate how it expected to use the £269m, although it confirmed yesterday that it had been buying back shares. Analysts also expect the bank to build a war-chest in order to make any acquisitions.

New owner ABN Amro has promised not to alter the conditions of its 620 staff for the next six months.

While Dial is the fifth largest vehicle leasing company in Europe, its market share is only 3%.

fields.headline: In praise of coffee mornings
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Maybe it is just that early 21st century life is fuelled by caffeine, but more business meetings seem to be taking place over double tall skinny cappuccinos. In coffee shops, there are as many laptops as mugs of latte.
fields.body:
Maybe it is just that early 21st century life is fuelled by caffeine, but more business meetings seem to be taking place over double tall skinny cappuccinos. In coffee shops, there are as many laptops as mugs of latte. One City firm, short on meeting rooms, is considering giving Starbucks vouchers to staff to encourage them to hold meetings off-site. Starbucks, ever alert to a new trend, have installed boardroom tables in some City outlets. On one level, this should merely serve as a warning against the Starbuckisation of society, but it also says something about the changing nature of work.

Andrew Harrison, a partner at leading architecture firm DEGW, thinks the use of different places for meetings reflects the dispersal of the "office" into the city. He says firms can choose spaces that enhance their brand - trendy Soho hangouts or august art galleries - and believes the move reflects the way organisations are changing how they work. "There are more partnerships now, the lines between companies are less clear. The great advantage of a coffee house is that it provides neutral ground and project space."

The new economy - based on networks, shifting collaborations, rapid start-ups - needs new spaces and many companies and workers are finding them on their doorsteps. Just as the line between domestic and work space is being blurred, so the line between public and corporate space is harder to see.

This trend can be seen as part of the intrusion of work into all other areas of life: the spare room, the train, now the local cafe. The idea of trying to relax with a warming cup and newspaper next to a bunch of braying executives may not appeal but on the whole, the detachment of work from the workplace is to be welcomed. For a start, any meeting is enormously improved by the addition of a decent cup of coffee and cafes avoid tiresome "who should go to whose office" power games.

Most importantly, the use of non-office space for business activities can help revitalise urban areas after decades of corporate and middle-class flight. Traditionally workers trudge from car park or tube to office and back. But if they get out into their neighbourhoods, local services will reap the rewards. Cities are seizing back their mantle as centres of exchange - exchange not just of goods and services, but of ideas. Things happen in cities that can never happen in modular office blocks in suburban business parks. Meetings can happen quickly, naturally, even accidentally.

Cafe culture tends to be associated with literary or philosophical activity, but remember that Lloyd's of London started in a coffee shop. Next time you stop for a latte and muffin, all around you, the wheels of commerce will be quietly turning.

Learning curves

The story of how "quality circles" of workers transformed Japanese manufacturing in the 60s and 70s - and US and European firms rushed to catch up in the 80s and 90s - is standard text for management students. But the idea's genesis is less well-known. Bob Garratt, in a book with the mundane title The Learning Organisation (don't you long for a book on How To Be The Dumbest FTSE 100 Company?), describes how Prof Reg Revans pioneered "learning circles" among miners in the newly nationalised UK Coal Board in the late 40s. The Japanese Productivity Council, visiting in 1950, were so impressed that they took the idea home. Meanwhile we Brits promptly forgot all about it. The rest, as they say, is history.

Gone with the wind

An email from Jamie Saunders includes a helpful link to a conference on Big Body Heuristics, subtitled "Are Corporations Really Alive? Are they now our dominant species?" One session looked unmissable, on Corporate Physiology and Metabolism. This included "paradigms of nutrient/resource acquisition (feeding), processing (digestion) and production/disposal (secretion/excretion)". It is a compelling vision, of big firms as living, belching organisms. But hold on. What about the place of Homo sapiens in Big Bodies? As workers, we are responsible for production, or digestion. But as consumers we are the recipients of the products - excrement or secretions. Mmmm.

fields.headline: Cost-cutter threatens BA jobs
fields.standfirst: Struggling airline may be on collision course with unions as high-flyer replaces ousted chief executive
fields.trailText: The cost-cutter Rod Eddington is to take over as chief executive of British Airways on Monday. The 50-year-old Australian flies in to replace the ousted Bob Ayling at a time when the reputation of the "world's favourite airline" is severely dented.
fields.body:
The cost-cutter Rod Eddington is to take over as chief executive of British Airways on Monday. The 50-year-old Australian flies in to replace the ousted Bob Ayling at a time when the reputation of the "world's favourite airline" is severely dented.

Mr Eddington, who was personally recruited by BA's chairman, Lord Marshall, inherits a major job cutting programme but is seen as more people-friendly than his predecessor, who alienated staff with his management style.

As the new £500,000 a year chief executive, he is charged with returning the airline to profitability. The City expects BA to make a £250m loss this year, its first since privatisation, as it struggles to compete against low-cost airlines.

Since a £474m profit in 1996, BA has been through years of turbulence: a badly handled cabin crew strike four years ago started the nosedive; the disastrous rebranding of its union flag tailfins became an embarrassment; a link with American Airlines failed to take off and attempts to axe staff misfired. But now at least 6,500 jobs could be in danger.

Mr Eddington is no stranger to cost-cutting or tough decisions - characteristics which will help to placate the frustrated City investors who have watched BA's shares slide and endured takeover speculation. After his appointment, shares rose by 4.5p to 305.75p.

He comes from the Australian airline Ansett, which lost A$19m in 1996 when he arrived. Three years later, he had turned the losses into a A$148m profit and readied the airline for sale to Air New Zealand next month. The turnaround was achieved partly through cutting 3,000 jobs, one-fifth of the workforce.

Mr Eddington was brought into Ansett by Rupert Murdoch, who has a stake in the airline. There has been speculation that Mr Murdoch, the chairman of News Corporation, has supported his bid to join BA. Mr Eddington, who is on the board of News Corp, flew in to the UK yesterday to clinch the deal and address the airline's senior management. He said he felt "privileged" to be taking the job.

He was anxious last night to play down his reputation as a cost-cutter."People are the lifeblood of any airline and it is the people of British Airways, both as individuals and as a team, who will deliver its future success," he said.

The Balpa union, which represents 7,500 pilots in Britain whose morale was badly shaken by Mr Ayling, said last night: "We hope industrial relations will continue to improve with this appointment."

Industry experts believe that Mr Eddington, who also successfully ran the Hong Kong airline Cathay Pacific, has had his hands tied by many key strategic decisions taken by Mr Ayling. BA's move to cut its capacity by 12% over three years and target more business travellers will be hard to reverse, given that it has ordered the necessary aircraft.

Height of ambition

Born 1950, Perth, Western Australia

Educated University of Western Australia; Oxford University: 1974 Rhodes Scholar; DPhil department of engineering science; lecturer at Pembroke College (1978/79)

Career Joined conglomerate Swires in 1979, working with Cathay Pacific airways in Hong Kong, Korea and Japan before becoming managing director in 1992; executive chairman Ansett (1997)

Family wife, two children aged six and four

fields.bodyText: The cost-cutter Rod Eddington is to take over as chief executive of British Airways on Monday. The 50-year-old Australian flies in to replace the ousted Bob Ayling at a time when the reputation of the "world's favourite airline" is severely dented. Mr Eddington, who was personally recruited by BA's chairman, Lord Marshall, inherits a major job cutting programme but is seen as more people-friendly than his predecessor, who alienated staff with his management style. As the new £500,000 a year chief executive, he is charged with returning the airline to profitability. The City expects BA to make a £250m loss this year, its first since privatisation, as it struggles to compete against low-cost airlines. Since a £474m profit in 1996, BA has been through years of turbulence: a badly handled cabin crew strike four years ago started the nosedive; the disastrous rebranding of its union flag tailfins became an embarrassment; a link with American Airlines failed to take off and attempts to axe staff misfired. But now at least 6,500 jobs could be in danger. Mr Eddington is no stranger to cost-cutting or tough decisions - characteristics which will help to placate the frustrated City investors who have watched BA's shares slide and endured takeover speculation. After his appointment, shares rose by 4.5p to 305.75p. He comes from the Australian airline Ansett, which lost A$19m in 1996 when he arrived. Three years later, he had turned the losses into a A$148m profit and readied the airline for sale to Air New Zealand next month. The turnaround was achieved partly through cutting 3,000 jobs, one-fifth of the workforce. Mr Eddington was brought into Ansett by Rupert Murdoch, who has a stake in the airline. There has been speculation that Mr Murdoch, the chairman of News Corporation, has supported his bid to join BA. Mr Eddington, who is on the board of News Corp, flew in to the UK yesterday to clinch the deal and address the airline's senior management. He said he felt "privileged" to be taking the job. He was anxious last night to play down his reputation as a cost-cutter."People are the lifeblood of any airline and it is the people of British Airways, both as individuals and as a team, who will deliver its future success," he said. The Balpa union, which represents 7,500 pilots in Britain whose morale was badly shaken by Mr Ayling, said last night: "We hope industrial relations will continue to improve with this appointment." Industry experts believe that Mr Eddington, who also successfully ran the Hong Kong airline Cathay Pacific, has had his hands tied by many key strategic decisions taken by Mr Ayling. BA's move to cut its capacity by 12% over three years and target more business travellers will be hard to reverse, given that it has ordered the necessary aircraft. webTitle: NTL asks for pause in mobile phone auction

fields.headline: NTL asks for pause in mobile phone auction
fields.standfirst: Cable company's plea comes as bidding hits £22.5bn and old technology shows the strain
fields.trailText: NTL, Britain's biggest cable company, yesterday called for a break in the auction for licences to run the next generation of mobile phones, fuelling speculation that the company might be about to drop out of the running.
fields.body:
NTL, Britain's biggest cable company, yesterday called for a break in the auction for licences to run the next generation of mobile phones, fuelling speculation that the company might be about to drop out of the running.

The recess stalled the government-run auction at round 149 with bids on the table for the five licences totalling £22.5bn. Only six companies remain in contention, meaning that if NTL, which is bankrolled by France Telecom, drops out, the new player in Britain's mobile phone market will be TIW, a subsidiary of Canada's Telesystem International Wireless.

One analyst suggested France Telecom had decided it would make better economic sense to launch a takeover bid for Orange, which has a ready-made network and customer base.

The licences on offer will enable the successful companies to offer services including video content and high speed mobile internet access, and the potential for profit has caused bidding to reach extraordinary heights. Services should be available from 2002.

At yesterday's close, TIW was leading the bids for licence A, the largest amount of spectrum on offer, which has been reserved for new entrants, with a bid of £4.38bn.

Licence B was headed by Vodafone with a £5.96bn bid, while licence C was led by British Telecom with £4.03bn. One2One, now owned by Deutsche Telekom, led the chase for licence D with £4bn and Orange was in pole position for licence E with £4.09bn. Bidding will resume tomorrow morning.

TIW was little fancied as the winner of the fifth licence when the auction began eight weeks ago. It has seen off rivals regarded as more aggressive or as having deeper pockets, including MCI WorldCom, Rupert Murdoch-backed OneTel and a Virgin-led consortium.

It emerged two weeks ago that TIW has financial backing from Hong Kong-based conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa, a co-founder of Orange.

The value of a licence to the existing four networks has been underlined as they have continued to outbid the newcomers. For BT Cellnet and Vodafone, it is imperative to win new spectrum simply to keep up with the growth in existing voice call traffic.

Seven of the 13 original bidders for the universal mobile telecommunications system (UMTS) licences have dropped out. Estimates from industry analysts and the government, which set a combined reserve price of £500m on the licences, have all been way outstripped by the bids on offer. The auction will generate a huge windfall for the Treasury.

A spokesman for NTL declined to comment.

 The auction did come to temporary halt yesterday because of a fault in a telecoms landline.

Bidding, which is conducted by fax, was delayed for more than two hours, the radiocommunications agency said, leaving staff with only mobile phones to make outgoing calls.

A spokesman said the exact cause of the fault was not yet known. London and other parts of the UK underwent a change in codes and telephone numbers over the Easter weekend but the spokesman said it was not clear that the auction problem was related to that.

The failure of the old technology appeared to reinforce bidders' enthusiasm.

The auction is being watched closely by governments all over Europe which are hoping to harvest similar windfalls from the sale of their licences. But fears are growing that the huge sums being paid by companies will be recouped through higher charges to consumers.

fields.headline: Corporate seduction
fields.standfirst:
The John Wayne Principle
Pleasance Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
The John Wayne Principle
Pleasance Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Black comedy is clearly Tony McNamara's forte. A few weeks back in Sydney I caught his wonderfully bilious attack on Australian sporting icons, The Recruit. Now the Pleasance has had the wit to import the Nuffield Theatre Southampton revival of an earlier McNamara play, in which he goes for the Australian business ethos with vitriolic glee.

The "principle" of the title is apparently to shoot first and ask questions later. This is anathema to the play's hero, Robbie, a drop-out house-husband who leaves the hard decisions to his clothes-designer wife. But when his tycoon father indulges in a botched suicide, Robbie learns that he will inherit half the family's global investment business if he can run it for a year. You half expect an Oz Mr Smith Goes to Washington in which the naive hero cleans up the Augean stables; what you find is that Robbie adapts, with suspicious enthusiasm, to the cut-throat world of Sydney's business politics.

Capitalism is obviously the target. But, like Hare and Brenton in Pravda, McNamara is enthralled by the world he is attacking: when Robbie tells his doubting wife that in his earlier incarnation, "I was a good man by default," you see his point. McNamara also has the ability constantly to take one by surprise. He reserves his funniest satire for Robbie's linen-suited Harvard MBA sidekick who has no qualms about selling torture instruments to Third World countries but who suddenly asks, "Do you think if I went to prison I'd be someone's bitch?"

Rudely direct in its dialogue, the play is morally disturbing in its portrait of the insidious attractions of corporate life. It is also, as Patrick Sandford's production makes clear, ebulliently funny. There's a nice design by Ti Green, in which the dying tycoon hovers over the action like a suspended mummy, and lively performances from Alan Westaway as the transformed Robbie, from Nicholas Rowe and Lucinda Cowden as the sidekick and his monster wife, and from David Henry as a macho businessman with perpendicular tendencies. Into our suffocatingly Anglo-American theatre, the play comes as a welcome breath of faintly polluted air.

 Until May 21. Box office: 020-7609 1800.

fields.headline: Just enough tomfoolery
fields.standfirst:
The Way of the World
The Royal Exchange, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
The Way of the World
The Royal Exchange, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Written in 1700, William Congreve's Restoration play was so poorly received that he gave up writing soon after. It has since become an acknowledged example of a grandiloquent, lightly moralising comedy of manners which is good for a chuckle and sure to draw an audience. Now the Royal Exchange has turned to its harmless frippery, perhaps to steady the schedule after a couple of programming controversies.

Mirabell and Millamant are lovers whose independent spirits are getting in the way of their marriage; to compound matters, they are also thwarted by intrigues. The undaunted Mirabell is the moralising voice of the play, yet Lloyd Owen's spiritless delivery often suggests a lawyer's summing-up. Though this is appropriate later, his intonation should have been livelier from the outset.

Emily Morgan's Millamant, however, exhibits the right blend of spite, self-knowledge and vanity. With equal measures of wit and derision for those who visit, she languishes on the chaise longue in her rose-satin gown like a genteel coquette.

Involving as much double-dealing as the game of cards in the first scene, the sub-plots mask and then expose the lusts and infidelities of the other characters. The scheming Fainall, played with versatility by Paul Higgins, is in love with Caroline Langrishe's equally assured Mrs Marwood, while Catherine Russell's nicely uptight Mrs Fainall has yet to overcome her desire for Mirabell.

Congreve, though, did not sufficiently develop the sub-plots, and their apparent complexity renders them almost impossible to follow. Instead, it is the fops, Witwoud (Tobias Menzies) and Petulant (Christopher Colquhoun), who provide the most enjoyable diversions.

Powdered and befrocked, and with pink bows on his high-heel shoes, Witwoud delights with his elaborate language and well-timed gestures. Petulant, meanwhile, is the dandy with the northern accent whose extravagant dress also disguises his dubious morals.

By contrast, James Saxon's boisterous Sir Wilfull Witwoud sullies the airs of courtly pretension with his forthright rustic ways, while Auriol Smith gives a fine, shivering performance as Lady Wishfort in her white-faced state of "dyingness".

Although some of the monologues were trimmed, at two-and-a-half hours the play is still too long, and many of the updated puns failed to find their laughs. In the end, there is enough tomfoolery to sustain the spirit of mischief, but only just.

 Until May 27. Box office: 0161-833 9833.

webTitle: Kent run hot on the road to heartache

fields.headline: Kent run hot on the road to heartache
fields.standfirst:
Kent 204-9
Middlesex 127
Kent win by 77 runs
fields.trailText: There were more long faces in the Kent dressing room than you could find on Easter Island after yesterday's resounding 77-run victory over Middlesex left them tantalisingly short of a place in the B&H Cup quarter-finals.
fields.body:
There were more long faces in the Kent dressing room than you could find on Easter Island after yesterday's resounding 77-run victory over Middlesex left them tantalisingly short of a place in the B&H Cup quarter-finals.

They finished behind the group winners Sussex, whose 62-run victory over Essex at Chelmsford was spearheaded by a stunning 271-run stand between Michael Bevan and Chris Adams, and runners-up Hampshire, who had an exciting two-run win over Surrey at the Oval in a match reduced to 10 overs per side.

Two wickets apiece to Hampshire's new boy Shane Warne, who took the gold award, and their in-form old boy Peter Hartley ensured Surrey fell two runs short after they had appeared to be coasting to victory.

Kent did not even make third place in the southern group, Surrey finishing level with them on points but, along with the northern side Durham, edging into the quarter-finals through the back door.

Middlesex's batting yesterday was awful, but at least they could blame a lack of match practice. Their past four matches had been washed out without a ball bowled, and even their pre-season trip to South Africa was hit by rain.

Requiring a modest four runs an over, the captain Justin Langer - who looked in commanding form with an unbeaten 66 from 85 balls - merely needed someone to stay with him. But only Robin Weston reached double figures.

Langer usually plays well against Kent. Last April he hit them for an unbeaten 241 in the championship, and his success has much to do with the fact that some years ago he played for Dover in the Kent League. Despite scoring heavily, his attempt to get a trial with the county was rejected.

Yesterday it was his colleagues who played like club cricketers. They were eight for three inside four overs after Mark Ealham had Owais Shah lbw and Mark Ramprakash caught behind, before Ben Phillips bowled David Nash.

After that, Weston put on 57 with his captain before he was caught in the slips. From there, it was a succession.

Kent had earlier looked likely to score more than their eventual 204 for nine when Rahul Dravid and Alan Wells were at the wicket. But Dravid was bowled by Phil Tufnell, playing for spin that was not there, and Wells was caught at short extra-cover for a fluent 34.

After that their best batting came from the wicketkeeper Paul Nixon, whose muscular 37 and four catches earned him the gold award. But it was little consolation for Kent.
