webTitle: Jeering fans turn on hapless Lewis

fields.headline: Jeering fans turn on hapless Lewis
fields.trailText: Chris Lewis yesterday received an unmistakably graphic insight into the mood of the sporting public, and possibly his own team-mates, when he was run out without facing a ball and then booed all the way back to the Old Trafford pavilion.
fields.body:
Chris Lewis yesterday received an unmistakably graphic insight into the mood of the sporting public, and possibly his own team-mates, when he was run out without facing a ball and then booed all the way back to the Old Trafford pavilion.

The Leicestershire player's descent from English cricket's all-round hope to all-round bad boy was completed in yesterday's one-wicket B&H Cup defeat by Lancashire, when he was jeered to the wicket by fans angered by his refusal to name three England players allegedly implicated in match-fixing.

Three balls later he began the trudge back, Graham Lloyd's pick-up and throw leaving Lewis several feet short at the non-striker's end after Ben Smith had called for a risky second run.

Lewis, who was playing his first game since reportedly receiving £30,000 for a news- paper story claiming the England stars were on the payroll of Indian bookmakers.

He has since said he gave the England and Wales Cricket Board the same details last year and, furthermore, that the board leaked the original story to the News of the World. But, if yesterday's crowd reaction is anything to go by, the public has little time for conspiracy theories.

Lewis later picked up two wickets but even Anil Kumble's four for 28 was not enough to stop Lancashire marching to the quarter-finals courtesy of a 28-run last-wicket stand between Ian Austin and the novice seamer Michael Smethurst.

Lancashire are joined in the next stage by Yorkshire, who beat Nottinghamshire by six wickets at Trent Bridge, and Durham from the northern division. Glamorgan and Gloucestershire will progress from the Midlands/West/Wales group, with last year's champions counting their blessings after Messrs Duckworth and Lewis helped them to a 10-run escape over Somerset at Bristol.

Glenn McGrath's debut brought less luck for Worcestershire. In a match cut to 10 overs their hopes were dashed by a rapid 53-run stand between Nick Knight and Graeme Welch but Warwickshire's win with a ball to spare failed to secure them a quarter-final berth.

Durham defied the sceptics by creeping into the last eight with a 138-run win over Derbyshire. The hero was the 23-year-old Ryan Robinson, yet to play a first-class match, whose scintillating 68 off 38 balls showed there is indeed life after David Boon.

webTitle: Vale of jeers as Horton's men are sunk

fields.headline: Vale of jeers as Horton's men are sunk
fields.trailText: Brian Horton's proud record of never being relegated either as a player or a manager came to an end at the hands of one of his former clubs, sparking a demonstration by angry fans.
fields.body:
Brian Horton's proud record of never being relegated either as a player or a manager came to an end at the hands of one of his former clubs, sparking a demonstration by angry fans.

The Vale manager had said he needed two things from this match against a Town side equally desperate to win to strengthen their play-off hopes. One was a miracle; the other was that his men should go down with all guns blazing if they were in fact going to end their six-year spell in the First Division.

At least his players managed that part, with a tremendous second-half rally. Horton, though, could justly wonder why his team could not have done that more often in a season that has always seemed to have relegation written on it.

So could the fans who made their anger clear. Horton said: "The supporters are not very happy but I cannot talk about that. I do not like relegation but it has happened to better people than me and I have to be big enough to handle it."

Jamie Vincent gave Town an eighth-minute lead with a curling 25-yard free-kick. But they then sat back and Tony Naylor made them pay with a turn and shot that was every bit as classy as Vincent's goal.

Town scored the winner with a Kenny Irons penalty, after Allen Tankard pushed Alun Armstrong.

webTitle: Taylor's century points way to safety

fields.headline: Taylor's century points way to safety
fields.trailText: Bob Taylor scored twice yesterday to reach 100 goals for West Bromwich and, more importantly, edge them towards safety. A first-half header and a scooped shot while prone were the life-belts Albion clung on to as they saw off Grimsby's recovery amid growing tension alleviated only by news of Walsall losing at Birmingham.
fields.body:
Bob Taylor scored twice yesterday to reach 100 goals for West Bromwich and, more importantly, edge them towards safety. A first-half header and a scooped shot while prone were the life-belts Albion clung on to as they saw off Grimsby's recovery amid growing tension alleviated only by news of Walsall losing at Birmingham.

It means West Brom climb out of the bottom three where Saturday's defeat at Walsall had left them fretting over their final three fixtures. Gary Megson's team have a two-point lead now and that should be crucial.

They could have been forgiven for treating Taylor's 14th-minute opener as a prelude to more frustration: they had led in all five previous games and won none of them. Here, against the side with the lowest shot count in the division, there were stronger grounds for optimism.

When Taylor, a bargain £150,000 buy back from Bolton on transfer-deadline day, scored at the second attempt three minutes after half-time, again following a Richard Sneekes free-kick, the Hawthorns let out an audible sigh of relief. But within four minutes Kingsley Black scored direct from a set piece and hearts were back in mouths.

In injury-time Neil Clement and Brian Jensen scrambled another Black curler away from the post. By now Stacy Coldicott had been ordered off for a second yellow card, Walsall were conceding a second and the sun had returned to this corner of the West Midlands.

webTitle: Slipshod City held back by Bradbury

fields.headline: Slipshod City held back by Bradbury
fields.trailText: Joe Royle warned at the weekend of Manchester City's almost unrivalled ability to put their foot in it. And sure enough, his side contrived yesterday to throw away a two-goal lead. One minute they were strolling back to the Premiership. Now they face more of a high-wire walk.
fields.body:
Joe Royle warned at the weekend of Manchester City's almost unrivalled ability to put their foot in it. And sure enough, his side contrived yesterday to throw away a two-goal lead. One minute they were strolling back to the Premiership. Now they face more of a high-wire walk.

If City win their two remaining matches no one can stop them taking the second automatic promotion spot. But games at home to Birmingham on Friday and away to Blackburn do not promise to be easy. Sweaty palms seem the order of the day in Moss Side though, if Ipswich fail to beat Crystal Palace tonight, victory on Friday will suffice.

Royle can hardly have been surprised by the turnaround here. The law of ex-players dictated that Lee Bradbury, one of his cast-offs, would return to haunt him. The striker dubbed Badbuy by City's fans during an unsuccessful spell at Maine Road gave them a nasty Goodbye by scoring twice.

At the end Royle might justifiably have turned his ire on his captain Richard Edghill, whose error culminated in Bradbury's equaliser with seven minutes to go. Instead he chose to berate the referee. Behind closed doors one suspects his reaction might have been different.

"We didn't shoot ourselves in the foot," Royle insisted. "We didn't have the gun." The executioner in his eyes was Paul Alcock, whose penalty award in first-half injury-time let Portsmouth back into a game City had dominated.

When Justin Edinburgh's cross struck Robert Taylor's arm it looked a case of ball to hand. Royle doubted, too, whether Taylor was inside the area. "I thought it was outside from my view and the ball was smacked at him but the referee couldn't wait to give it," he said.

"We handled the 11 in blue magnificently. It was the fella in the other colour we struggled with. That decision changed the game. I tried to talk to him at half-time but he got a bit precious."

Before Bradbury slotted in the spot-kick City looked to be cruising, cushioned by goals from Spencer Prior and Taylor, and there seemed only one likely outcome.

After Prior had glanced a header beyond the reach of Russell Hoult, Mark Kennedy's centre was nodded in at the near post by Taylor. Early in the second half Taylor hit the post but gradually City lost the initiative.

There was still little to suggest that Portsmouth would draw level until the final 10 minutes as City dealt comfortably with all they could muster. Even then Nicky Weaver saved well from Kevin Harper and Darren Moore before Edghill managed to give the points away.

His failure to clear allowed Ceri Hughes to gallop down the left flank and cross for Bradbury to head in. But for a block by Richard Jobson, Bradbury might even have won the game in injury-time.

The point secured Pompey's First Division status and was revenge of sorts for their manager Tony Pulis, whose Gillingham side went 2-0 up against City in last season's Second Division play-off final only to lose on penalties.

"It was always going to be a nervous end," Royle said. "We'd settle for being four points clear with two games to go." Hold tight because at Maine Road it is best to expect the unexpected.

fields.headline: Charlton look beyond their title
fields.trailText: An anti-climax? Not a bit of it. Charlton Athletic may have staggered over the finishing line with all the conviction of a pantomime horse, but they certainly enjoyed their afternoon as they finally clinched the First Division championship.
fields.body:
An anti-climax? Not a bit of it. Charlton Athletic may have staggered over the finishing line with all the conviction of a pantomime horse, but they certainly enjoyed their afternoon as they finally clinched the First Division championship.

The Premiership starts here for Charlton and their manager Alan Curbishley, although a run of five games without a win suggests they have been looking forward to next season for weeks anyway.

"We were always confident we would win it," said Curbishley. "It was just a question of when, not if. We would have liked to have done it by winning in front of our own supporters last week but it wasn't to be.

"We're going back to the Premiership stronger as a club, with a stronger squad and with a little bit of money to spend."

The striker Mathias Svensson gave Charlton the lead midway through the first half and was culpable on 62 minutes when his lunge on David Dunn allowed the Blackburn captain Lee Carsley to equalise from the penalty spot.

webTitle: Birmingham almost there as Furlong unseats Saddlers

fields.headline: Birmingham almost there as Furlong unseats Saddlers
fields.trailText: Birmingham City took another step towards the play-offs with a victory that leaves Walsall in dire danger, defeat pushing them back into the bottom three. With Walsall's last game at promotion-chasing Ipswich, their prognosis for survival is not bright.
fields.body:
Birmingham City took another step towards the play-offs with a victory that leaves Walsall in dire danger, defeat pushing them back into the bottom three. With Walsall's last game at promotion-chasing Ipswich, their prognosis for survival is not bright.

In contrast, City need two points from two remaining games to be sure of a second successive tilt at the play-offs and, while not celebrating yet, their manager Trevor Francis seems confident.

"We'll be bitterly disappointed if we don't make it now," he said. "This victory puts us eight points clear of Wolves and means they will have to win each of their last three games to overtake us."

If City do get there, they may be without Martin Grainger. The midfielder was carried off midway through the second half and, although his knee injury has not been diagnosed, Francis confirmed it looked bad. Until his exit Grainger had been City's most effective player and, perversely, his side finally broke the deadlock within five minutes of his departure.

Francis brought on Paul Furlong and Andrew Johnson 11 minutes into the second half and by the 70th the change proved effective when Gary Rowett headed on a Stan Lazaridis corner for Furlong to scramble home.

Dean Keates and Michalis Vlachos responded to give Thomas Myhre some overdue action before Furlong sealed it from the spot after Andrew Johnson had been fouled by Tony Barras, who was sent off for his trouble.

webTitle: Bassett survives edgy finale to steer Barnsley into play-offs

fields.headline: Bassett survives edgy finale to steer Barnsley into play-offs
fields.trailText: Dave Bassett took a step nearer the eighth promotion of his career as Barnsley secured their place in the play-offs and kept alive their automatic hopes.
fields.body:
Dave Bassett took a step nearer the eighth promotion of his career as Barnsley secured their place in the play-offs and kept alive their automatic hopes.

But even Bassett looked slightly nervous as he left a seat in the stand for the touchline in the last 15 minutes when Norwich were threatening to ruin the celebrations.

The Oakwell crowd were in party mood as Steve Chettle and Neil Shipperley put them two ahead shortly before half-time, and victory seemed a formality. But it did not quite work out that way as the substitute Craig Bellamy pulled one back for Norwich in the 67th minute.

"I wasn't desperately panicking," said Bassett with a smile. "I wasn't confident, either, but not panicking."

Norwich buckled in a 15-minute spell before the break when they were bombarded with corners and free-kicks.

Chettle stepped up, when Bruce Dyer was brought down by Malcolm Mackay, and smashed a 23-yard free-kick through the wall, giving the keeper Andy Marshall no chance. Then, from a Hignett corner, Shipperley climbed to head home with Marshall in no man's land.

Bellamy struck from a Des Hamilton ball to set the alarm bells ringing but Bassett was happy as he reviewed his first season at Oakwell: "I'm delighted for the players but we've run out of games and we've got to depend on others.

"It's just a pity we lost three of the first five matches when I was sorting things out here but that's the game."

webTitle: Chester see a late route to survival

fields.headline: Chester see a late route to survival
fields.trailText: While Northampton's leap into third place may have given Darlington and Peterborough pause for thought, the most significant move was by Chester, whose attempt to avoid relegation from the Football League was galvanised by a 2-0 victory over York.
fields.body:
While Northampton's leap into third place may have given Darlington and Peterborough pause for thought, the most significant move was by Chester, whose attempt to avoid relegation from the Football League was galvanised by a 2-0 victory over York.

Only their fifth home win of the season came courtesy of a Mark Bower own-goal followed three minutes later by Luke Beckett's 19th goal of the season. The win lifted Chester above Shrewsbury and Carlisle.

Shrewsbury returned to the bottom in cruel fashion at Halifax, where they lost to a last-minute winner by their former striker Steve Kerrigan after Lee Steele had equalised Andrew Tretton's own-goal seconds earlier. Carlisle went down at Southend to late goals by Martin Carruthers and Nigel Pepper.

Exeter eased their own relegation fears with a 3-0 win at home to Plymouth, who had their play-off hopes dented and Craig Taylor sent off.

Swansea continue to hold a one-point lead over Rotherham at the top: Neil Cusack was on target for Swansea at Mansfield and Darren Garner and Jason White scored for Rotherham against Cheltenham at Millmoor. Darlington lost ground in a 1-1 draw at Hartlepool and Northampton took advantage with goals by Steven Howard, after 69 seconds, James Hunt and Carlo Corazzin at Rochdale.

fields.headline: David Thorne
fields.standfirst: The general who served in Northern Ireland and the Falklands, and defended the regimental structure of the British army
fields.trailText: When David Thorne, who has died aged 66 from prostate cancer, took over military command of the Falklands after the 1982 conflict, they called him "the man with the spring-loaded salute". He had a springy left jab too, as many in his 5,000-strong garrison soon found out.
fields.body:
When David Thorne, who has died aged 66 from prostate cancer, took over military command of the Falklands after the 1982 conflict, they called him "the man with the spring-loaded salute". He had a springy left jab too, as many in his 5,000-strong garrison soon found out.

All over the islands, in the harsh weather and work of that pioneering year, men of all ranks walked around with bruised shoulders as badges of honour. If General David gave you his quick one-two, it meant he had noticed you were doing an especially hard job well.

Everything about him was spring-loaded: his physical vigour, his intellectual relish at getting to grips with the detail of a problem and his joy when his team began to get on top of it.

When he spoke to troops, he struck those of us who saw him in the field as having more than a touch of Henry V before Agincourt. He was apt to turn up, cheerful as a terrier, anywhere at any time where the going was hardest and most urgent. He was one of the most remarkable coordinators, enthusers and inspirers the British armed forces have produced since the second world war.

He came to the Falklands with an outstanding record of being in the thick of things. In Northern Ireland in 1979, he was the first officer to brief Mrs Thatcher, as the new prime minister, among the debris of the Warrenpoint bombing, which killed 18 soldiers.

As the army's youngest major-general, he was appointed vice-quartermaster general to the south Atlantic task force, another densely detailed job. When he left the islands, full of golden opinions from contemporaries, he was knighted.

His chief of defence staff, field marshal Lord Bramall, wrote to him, "I would say, with a bit of luck - which we all need - the sky could be the limit."

Luck, however, did not quite work out in that way. Thorne went on to head the 1st armoured division of the British Army of the Rhine (BAOR), the prime job for his rank. But he never became chief of general staff, or of defence staff. Five years later, he retired from the army, sidelined, as he saw it, by his temperamental distaste for joining coteries on the way to the top.

But he also made his own luck. When he finished his final posting, as the army's director of infantry, he had - against heavy odds - won an unpublicised, but convulsive, internal battle to save the infantry's precious regimental and battalion roots.

On his retirement, presenting a silver salver from all infantry regiments, the ex-Rhine army general Sir Jeremy Reilly said, "I would rate General David as being the outstanding director of infantry since the war, without question, and probably of all time."

It was a gesture of rare affection. As a civilian, Thorne went on to head the Royal Commonwealth Society, raise £10m and save it from bankruptcy, a longer struggle with fewer big guns at his disposal than in any military posting; but, after nine dogged years, it was done.

At home in Suffolk, in a memoir about his working life, Thorne wrote, "I have seen enough of leaders under pressure and in crisis to know that many - even with fine reputations - bend with the wind. One always has to guard against giving away any of one's integrity for short term ease or advantage."

Born in Hertfordshire, David Thorne was educated at St Edward's School, Oxford, and at Sandhurst, from which he was commissioned into the Royal Norfolk (later Royal Anglian) Regiment. He spent his early career on the defence intelligence staff and as an RAF staff college instructor.

In 1972, when he was 38, he rose to command the Royal Anglian regiment and, five years later, the 3rd infantry brigade in Northern Ireland. James Callaghan's government then believed IRA support was waning and was keen to hand control of troublespots - including south Armagh - to the Royal Ulster Constabulary and South Armagh defence regiment.

The new brigadier's "not too fashionable" early assessment of IRA trends was less rosy. It led him to argue against the handover, for improved intelligence and for better army/RUC coordination. Shootings and bombings did escalate. After three Grenadier guardsmen were shot dead in December 1978, he managed to get a joint operations room set up.

Nine months later, came the assassination of Lord Mountbatten and - the same day - the two Warrenpoint explosions. Thorne landed by helicopter in the carnage. A young paratroop commander, restraining tears, told him: "You should have this", handing him an epaulette. It was all that remained of David Blair, commanding officer of 1st battalion the Queen's Own Highlanders.

Briefing Mrs Thatcher 36 hours later, he "laid David Blair's cloth epaulette gently on the table beside her". At the end of his briefing, which stressed intelligence and coordination, he said, "I would now like briefly to come back to the human factor. David Blair has a son [then aged eight]. I have a son..."

He was unable to finish the sentence but thought she had understood, his memoir says. His Ulster commander called the briefing "a highly personal tour de force". Five weeks later, the Cabinet decided to appoint a coordinator of army/RUC operations. But, Thorne wrote in a cautionary memo to himself, "God preserve us from officers who claim, after two years, to have cracked the problem."

In 1981, in the first of the army's new fast-stream promotions, he was made three-star general. That led to the Falklands, where his achievement was to get long-term defences up and the garrison under shelter, before winter arrived. He also saw off, by argument, an MoD cost-cutting proposal to halve garrison numbers.

In his last weeks on the island, he led the topping-out of Mount Kent radar station, one of three built despite 100mph winds and almost intolerable logistics. The plaque he unveiled read: "Zeus - a routine project for 34 field squadron."

In a speech which epitomised his qualities of rapport as a soldier, he said, "You know, and I know, that it was not a routine task. It was a unique task. We are a particular brotherhood and you have scored yet again."

Back in England, in his prime, his bright prospects suddenly unravelled. On his first day with BAOR, his commander General Sir Nigel Bagnall, soon to be chief of general staff, told Thorne he had not wanted him as a subordinate. Thorne had fallen foul of career rivalries between the UK-based army, which was his own background, and the Rhine army. The latter - with Bagnall in the ascendant - controlled promotions at the very top.

That set a frustrating pattern till he retired. But he got stuck into tightening aspects of BAOR and, in his last role as director of infantry, found decisive influence. He was up against a plan, spearheaded by Bagnall, to "trickle-post" individual officers and soldiers between battalions on UK and overseas assignments, rather than transfer them as complete battalion units.

This, though arguably more efficient, was seen by Thorne and many others as undermining a regimental system which was at the core of the army's cohesiveness and mutual loyalties on active service. At first, in 1986, he felt virtually isolated on the general staff. "No senior officers came to my aid," his memoir says. "Most were in their tents, polishing their helmets - and looking in the mirror."

He argued his case, partly through two daring unsigned articles in the British Army Review, winning service-wide backing. In early 1988, the reorganisation was dropped. He was deluged with letters of gratitude. The victory was decisive: the issue has not subsequently been re-opened.

As director general of the Royal Commonwealth Society until 1997, he wove another of his "particular brotherhoods", which stretched from Prince Charles to the commonwealth secretary general Chief Anyaoku to the chairman of BAT industries Sir Patrick Sheehy, and gradually won the day. Working with, and promoting the cause of, young people of many races brought him some of the deepest satisfaction of his working life.

At home in Framlingham, Suffolk, finally though all too briefly, with his wife Anne and her variable second family of cats, dogs, sheep, Shetland ponies and muscovy ducks which had gone with them on most of their postings, he reflected, "The lesson I have re-learned is that the best and happiest moments in life come when one is under pressure in a good cause - with just sufficient people to give at least an outside chance of success."

He achieved one last target, through willpower and the care of his family: to live until Easter Sunday morning, the date fixed for a get-together of friends at his home to raise funds for Macmillan cancer nurses and Framlingham church.

He leaves Anne, their daughters Georgina and Laura, and their son Edward.

 Major-General Sir David Calthrop Thorne, soldier and administrator: born December 13 1933; died April 23 2000

He was one of the most remarkable coordinators, enthusers and inspirers the British armed forces have produced since the second world war. He came to the Falklands with an outstanding record of being in the thick of things. In Northern Ireland in 1979, he was the first officer to brief Mrs Thatcher, as the new prime minister, among the debris of the Warrenpoint bombing, which killed 18 soldiers. As the army's youngest major-general, he was appointed vice-quartermaster general to the south Atlantic task force, another densely detailed job. When he left the islands, full of golden opinions from contemporaries, he was knighted. His chief of defence staff, field marshal Lord Bramall, wrote to him, "I would say, with a bit of luck - which we all need - the sky could be the limit." Luck, however, did not quite work out in that way. Thorne went on to head the 1st armoured division of the British Army of the Rhine (BAOR), the prime job for his rank. But he never became chief of general staff, or of defence staff. Five years later, he retired from the army, sidelined, as he saw it, by his temperamental distaste for joining coteries on the way to the top. But he also made his own luck. When he finished his final posting, as the army's director of infantry, he had - against heavy odds - won an unpublicised, but convulsive, internal battle to save the infantry's precious regimental and battalion roots. On his retirement, presenting a silver salver from all infantry regiments, the ex-Rhine army general Sir Jeremy Reilly said, "I would rate General David as being the outstanding director of infantry since the war, without question, and probably of all time." It was a gesture of rare affection. As a civilian, Thorne went on to head the Royal Commonwealth Society, raise £10m and save it from bankruptcy, a longer struggle with fewer big guns at his disposal than in any military posting; but, after nine dogged years, it was done. At home in Suffolk, in a memoir about his working life, Thorne wrote, "I have seen enough of leaders under pressure and in crisis to know that many - even with fine reputations - bend with the wind. One always has to guard against giving away any of one's integrity for short term ease or advantage." Born in Hertfordshire, David Thorne was educated at St Edward's School, Oxford, and at Sandhurst, from which he was commissioned into the Royal Norfolk (later Royal Anglian) Regiment. He spent his early career on the defence intelligence staff and as an RAF staff college instructor. In 1972, when he was 38, he rose to command the Royal Anglian regiment and, five years later, the 3rd infantry brigade in Northern Ireland. James Callaghan's government then believed IRA support was waning and was keen to hand control of troublespots - including south Armagh - to the Royal Ulster Constabulary and South Armagh defence regiment. The new brigadier's "not too fashionable" early assessment of IRA trends was less rosy. It led him to argue against the handover, for improved intelligence and for better army/RUC coordination. Shootings and bombings did escalate. After three Grenadier guardsmen were shot dead in December 1978, he managed to get a joint operations room set up. Nine months later, came the assassination of Lord Mountbatten and - the same day - the two Warrenpoint explosions. Thorne landed by helicopter in the carnage. A young paratroop commander, restraining tears, told him: "You should have this", handing him an epaulette. It was all that remained of David Blair, commanding officer of 1st battalion the Queen's Own Highlanders. Briefing Mrs Thatcher 36 hours later, he "laid David Blair's cloth epaulette gently on the table beside her". At the end of his briefing, which stressed intelligence and coordination, he said, "I would now like briefly to come back to the human factor. David Blair has a son [then aged eight]. I have a son..." He was unable to finish the sentence but thought she had understood, his memoir says. His Ulster commander called the briefing "a highly personal tour de force". Five weeks later, the Cabinet decided to appoint a coordinator of army/RUC operations. But, Thorne wrote in a cautionary memo to himself, "God preserve us from officers who claim, after two years, to have cracked the problem." In 1981, in the first of the army's new fast-stream promotions, he was made three-star general. That led to the Falklands, where his achievement was to get long-term defences up and the garrison under shelter, before winter arrived. He also saw off, by argument, an MoD cost-cutting proposal to halve garrison numbers. In his last weeks on the island, he led the topping-out of Mount Kent radar station, one of three built despite 100mph winds and almost intolerable logistics. The plaque he unveiled read: "Zeus - a routine project for 34 field squadron." In a speech which epitomised his qualities of rapport as a soldier, he said, "You know, and I know, that it was not a routine task. It was a unique task. We are a particular brotherhood and you have scored yet again." Back in England, in his prime, his bright prospects suddenly unravelled. On his first day with BAOR, his commander General Sir Nigel Bagnall, soon to be chief of general staff, told Thorne he had not wanted him as a subordinate. Thorne had fallen foul of career rivalries between the UK-based army, which was his own background, and the Rhine army. The latter - with Bagnall in the ascendant - controlled promotions at the very top. That set a frustrating pattern till he retired. But he got stuck into tightening aspects of BAOR and, in his last role as director of infantry, found decisive influence. He was up against a plan, spearheaded by Bagnall, to "trickle-post" individual officers and soldiers between battalions on UK and overseas assignments, rather than transfer them as complete battalion units. This, though arguably more efficient, was seen by Thorne and many others as undermining a regimental system which was at the core of the army's cohesiveness and mutual loyalties on active service. At first, in 1986, he felt virtually isolated on the general staff. "No senior officers came to my aid," his memoir says. "Most were in their tents, polishing their helmets - and looking in the mirror." He argued his case, partly through two daring unsigned articles in the British Army Review, winning service-wide backing. In early 1988, the reorganisation was dropped. He was deluged with letters of gratitude. The victory was decisive: the issue has not subsequently been re-opened. As director general of the Royal Commonwealth Society until 1997, he wove another of his "particular brotherhoods", which stretched from Prince Charles to the commonwealth secretary general Chief Anyaoku to the chairman of BAT industries Sir Patrick Sheehy, and gradually won the day. Working with, and promoting the cause of, young people of many races brought him some of the deepest satisfaction of his working life. At home in Framlingham, Suffolk, finally though all too briefly, with his wife Anne and her variable second family of cats, dogs, sheep, Shetland ponies and muscovy ducks which had gone with them on most of their postings, he reflected, "The lesson I have re-learned is that the best and happiest moments in life come when one is under pressure in a good cause - with just sufficient people to give at least an outside chance of success." He achieved one last target, through willpower and the care of his family: to live until Easter Sunday morning, the date fixed for a get-together of friends at his home to raise funds for Macmillan cancer nurses and Framlingham church. He leaves Anne, their daughters Georgina and Laura, and their son Edward.  Major-General Sir David Calthrop Thorne, soldier and administrator: born December 13 1933; died April 23 2000

fields.headline: Preston crowned despite defeat
fields.trailText: Preston secured promotion - and the title - yesterday but hardly in the style the leaders wanted. David Moyes' men lost 2-0 at lowly Cambridge and had Michael Jackson sent off in the last minute for violent conduct.
fields.body:
Preston secured promotion - and the title - yesterday but hardly in the style the leaders wanted. David Moyes' men lost 2-0 at lowly Cambridge and had Michael Jackson sent off in the last minute for violent conduct.

But, after hearing Wigan had been held to a 1-1 draw at Luton, the Preston party began at the Abbey stadium.

Until then it had been a day to forget for Preston as first-half goals from Johnny Hansen and Trevor Benjamin consigned them to only their third away defeat as Cambridge strengthened their survival chances.

Wigan, for whom Neil Redfearn's penalty secured a point, stay second only on goal difference from Burnley, who came from behind to win 3-2 at Brentford. The arrival of Ian Wright on the hour turned the game.

John Mullin levelled after good work by Wright before the substitute scored himself two minutes later. Mullin's second goal effectively settled the game.

Millwall and Gillingham played out an incident-packed 2-2 draw with the Lions going 2-0 up in eight minutes, only for Ty Gooden and Andy Hessenthaler to reply before half-time.

Bristol Rovers slipped from third to sixth after a 2-1 defeat at Blackpool, who resurrected their survival hopes. Oxford United, drawing 2-2 at Bristol City, escaped from the relegation zone, trading places with Cardiff, beaten 2-0 at home by Bury.

webTitle: Ticket sale sparks Arsenal final fears

fields.headline: Ticket sale sparks Arsenal final fears
fields.trailText: Fears over Arsenal fans' security at the Uefa Cup final heightened yesterday when it emerged that 9,000 tickets for the match against Galatasaray in Copenhagen had gone on general sale in Denmark.
fields.body:
Fears over Arsenal fans' security at the Uefa Cup final heightened yesterday when it emerged that 9,000 tickets for the match against Galatasaray in Copenhagen had gone on general sale in Denmark.

Both sides have received an allocation of 12,000 tickets for the final on May 17 in the 40,000-capacity Parken Stadium, raising fears that surplus tickets could fall into the hands of those wishing for a repeat of the violence which blighted Galatasaray's semi-final against Leeds United.

Uefa has kept 3,000 tickets for its own officials and VIPs, but in addition to the 9,000 tickets that have already gone on sale - nominally to Danish fans - a further 3,000 will be available on "the international market".

Arsenal's French midfielder Patrick Vieira will not be punished further for his alleged head-butt on the Watford striker Heidar Helguson during the Gunners' 3-2 win at Vicarage Road on Sunday. Vieira was booked by the referee Rob Harris.

webTitle: Barca out of cup after refusing to play

fields.headline: Barca out of cup after refusing to play
fields.trailText: Six days after their epic triumph over Chelsea, Barcelona have been eliminated from the Spanish cup - for refusing to play.
fields.body:
Six days after their epic triumph over Chelsea, Barcelona have been eliminated from the Spanish cup - for refusing to play.

The Catalan side alleged that they did not have enough players to take on Atletico Madrid a second time, owing to international call-ups, including six Dutch players due to face Scotland. Barca said they had just 11 players, two of them goalkeepers, available out of a squad of 25. Barcelona lost the first leg 3-0.

The Barcelona players appeared on the side of the pitch but refused to play, while some 200 fans booed and jeered. After a short wait, the referee informed the Atletico players they had "won" the game.

Barcelona face automatic elimination from the cup, a fine and a probable ban from next year's competition.

Gary Holt, the 27-year-old Kilmarnock midfielder, has been called up for Scotland's friendly against Holland in Arnhem tomorrow night.

fields.headline: Derby cruise to comfort zone
fields.trailText: To the immense relief of everyone connected with Derby County, not least their bank manager, the threat of Nationwide League football all but disappeared along with the tepid challenge of Southampton here yesterday.
fields.body:
To the immense relief of everyone connected with Derby County, not least their bank manager, the threat of Nationwide League football all but disappeared along with the tepid challenge of Southampton here yesterday.

Although their survival is still not mathematically certain an ultimately comfortable victory over demob-happy opponents means there is scant danger of Jim Smith's team getting their sums wrong now.

The win that leaves them tantalisingly close to safety was accomplished through first-half goals from Darryl Powell and Malcolm Christie and all that was missing as Smith emerged shortly after the final whistle was his customary cigar.

Certainly he could have been excused for puffing out a few celebratory smoke circles. "It would need Bradford or Sheffield Wednesday to win all their games now which is asking one hell of a lot," he said. "This game has a nasty habit of kicking you in the teeth, so I'm not going to say we're safe while it's still not certain. But we're certainly thinking that way and it would be some shock to the system if we were proved wrong now."

Half of the domestic game's top tier have already taken maximum points here this season, not to mention the rich pickings offered by Pride Park's obliging hosts to Burnley and Bolton in the two cup competitions.

Yet, for reasons best known to Glenn Hoddle, Southampton deployed the sort of defensive tactics that most teams usually reserve for visits to Old Trafford.

For much of a thoroughly lukewarm 90 minutes Hoddle's players exuded a palpable air of apathy. The outcome was always going to carry far greater weight for their hosts and Derby reaped the rewards for outshining their guests in both industry and adventure.

They could have been ahead within the opening 10 seconds after the type of abject misunderstanding that was to sum up the visitors' performance all afternoon.

Dean Richards and his goalkeeper Neil Moss left an innocuous through-ball to one another and Christie nipped in between them only to hook an angled shot on to the roof of the net. The inquest was still going on in the Southampton defence when Derby broke forward to score.

Craig Burley manoeuvred space for himself on the left and dragged a low ball across a congested penalty area where Powell reacted first to squeeze a first-time shot inside the near post.

The remainder of the opening period was the Georgi Kinkladze show, Derby's Georgian recruit playing with a carefree abandon and supplying the through-ball for Christie to emphasise the hosts' superiority.

Christie had instigated the move deep inside his own half and the right-foot finish that squeezed beneath Moss took his tally to six goals in seven Premiership starts. "I'm sure he will be recognised by the England Under-21s soon," said Smith.

As for Hoddle, he was left muttering dark threats about offloading players, although on the evidence of yesterday there might not be an abundance of Premiership clubs jostling each other to snap them up.

Derby County (3-4-1-2): Poom; Schnoor, Laursen, Dorigo (Boertien, h-t); Delap, Burley, Powell, Johnson; Kinkladze (Murray, 89min); Strupar, Christie.

Southampton (4-5-1): Moss; Dodd, Richards, El Khalej, Bridge; Ripley, Soltvedt, Marsden (Davies, h-t), Oakley, Kachloul (Tessem, 81); Beattie (Le Tissier, 69).

Referee: P Jones (Loughborough).

webTitle: Dreyer gives Bradford a lifeline and condemns Watford

fields.headline: Dreyer gives Bradford a lifeline and condemns Watford
fields.trailText: Bradford City have known for some time that, if salvation was to be achieved, they would have to find another victory away from West Yorkshire. Yesterday they found it.
fields.byline: Ian Ross at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Bradford City have known for some time that, if salvation was to be achieved, they would have to find another victory away from West Yorkshire. Yesterday they found it.

While fortunate to travel to Wearside on a day when Sunderland - with little left to play for, having not applied for the InterToto Cup - were in wretched form, Bradford deserved to edge this untidy affair. Their victory, coming after a run of one point from their previous 12 away games, sets everything up nicely because they now stand two points behind fourth-bottom Wimbledon, whom they face on Sunday at Valley Parade.

Bradford's manager Paul Jewell said: "This is a great boost in our fight for survival. We simply have to win a game - any game. Our meeting with Wimbledon is now a massive fixture. By winning here today, when nobody fancied us, we have given ourselves a real chance, a realistic chance, of staying in the Premiership."

From a managerial perspective the only problem with leading an unfashionable club to unlikely success is that it does precious little for long-term job prospects.

Jewell is a classic case in point. A more amiable and dedicated man one will not find and yet what was always going to be a difficult season in the Premiership has led some to demand his removal. Presumably humble pie was being served in many Bradford households last night.

Jewell's ploy of shoehorning into his side as many experienced, long-in-the-tooth players as he could lay his hands on may well have been a gamble worth taking.

Bradford were never fluent yesterday but they offered stubborn resistance.

In a first half which never threatened to raise itself above the ordinary Sunderland were uncommonly lazy, going through the motions rather than up the through the gears. It did not occur to them that by reducing the tempo - at times to a standstill - they were playing directly into enemy hands.

It was dismal fare, though, and the interval was reached without the game yielding a single good chance for either side. The Bradford defender David Wetherall went closest to lifting the afternoon out of the gutter but his firm early header from a Peter Beagrie corner was comfortably smothered by the Sunderland goalkeeper Thomas Sorensen.

The game had lurched, almost without incident, to its 57th minute before the tedium was genuinely threatened.

Surprisingly, the first sweeping move was thrown together by Bradford, Dean Saunders sprinting clear before laying the ball into the path of Robbie Blake who hit the face of the crossbar with a vicious shot.

Then, astonishingly, on the hour there was a goal.

Beagrie's first cross from the left was headed back to him but his second, to the far post, landed directly in front of John Dreyer who claimed his first goal in three seasons with the cleanest of headers.

Thereafter Sunderland rallied but Bradford defended magnificently.

The battle was won but even now the war wages on.

Watford's relegation from the Premiership was confirmed yesterday with Bradford's win, sending Graham Taylor's side back to the First Division after one season.

webTitle: Nasa fuels shuttle for afternoon launch despite dismal forecast

fields.headline: Nasa fuels shuttle for afternoon launch despite dismal forecast
fields.standfirst:
Nasa Human Spaceflight
Kennedy Space Centre: Shuttle countdown online
fields.trailText: Nasa fuelled space shuttle Atlantis for lift-off Tuesday afternoon on a mission to repair the international space station, even though high wind threatened to delay the launch again.
fields.body:
Nasa fuelled space shuttle Atlantis for lift-off Tuesday afternoon on a mission to repair the international space station, even though high wind threatened to delay the launch again.

Forecasters put the odds of acceptable launch weather at a mere 20 percent.

Launch managers decided this morning to aim for a 3:52 p.m. (19:52 GMT) lift-off. They considered waiting for significantly better weather on Wednesday, but were loath to pass up Tuesday's opportunity.

"We've launched with weather predictions as bad or worse in the past," said Nasa spokesman Joel Wells. "You take every opportunity to launch."

Nasa has only five minutes each day to send Atlantis and seven astronauts to the station. The brief launch window allows the shuttle to use a minimal amount of fuel to reach it.

Monday's launch attempt was called off at the nine-minute mark of the countdown after wind gusts exceeded the safety limit. Nasa flight rules say crosswind can be no higher than 17mph, in case the shuttle has to make an emergency return to the launch site.

"We'll get 'em next time," shuttle commander James Halsell Jr. said.

Atlantis is loaded with fresh batteries, smoke detectors, fire extinguishers and fans for the 1 1/2-year-old space station. Since astronauts last visited the station last spring, two of its six main batteries have failed and another two are showing signs of deterioration.

In addition, an antenna is broken, a crane is loose and the space station's orbit is dropping nearly two miles closer to the Earth each week because of increased solar activity.

Nasa wants Atlantis and its crew up there as soon as possible to fix all the problems.

Atlantis was not supposed to fly until the Russians had launched a critical service module with guidance and life-support systems. But with the service module more than two years behind schedule and due to fly no earlier than July, Nasa moved up Atlantis' repair mission.

The Russian delays - and the Florida weather - aren't the only things that have kept Atlantis grounded. Halsell twisted an ankle during training last month, and that forced a one-week postponement.

fields.headline: Reasons to be cheerful... 1, 2, 3 (and 4)
fields.trailText: Depressed about Manchester United's procession to the title? Don't be.
fields.body:
There was something infinitely depressing, and not just for Chelsea fans, about watching Manchester United¹s coronation as champions on Easter Monday.

The embarrassing ease with which they dealt with a team supposedly among their most eager challengers was an eloquent comment on the procession that the Premiership has become.

So for those losing faith in a game where differentials in income are expressing themselves more and more shamelessly in the league table, here are four non-Premiership reasons to be cheerful at the end of the season.

1. Fulham
Spend packets of cash, sack a relatively dour manager in preference for any foreigner on hand (one who doesn¹t even want to be a manager, one who doesn't speak English) and see how far you get. Not as far as the play-offs anyway.

2. Borussia Dortmund

fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy deal delayed
fields.trailText: Ruud van Nistelrooy's proposed £19m transfer from PSV Eindhoven to Manchester United has been held up by his cruciate knee injury.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy's proposed £19m transfer from PSV Eindhoven to Manchester United has been held up by his cruciate knee injury.

United want to carry out further tests on the Dutch striker's knee before completing the deal which would break the British transfer record.

Van Nistelrooy underwent a medical today but United financial director David Gill, said in a brief statement: "We have been unable to complete all necessary tests to our satisfaction today."

Van Nistelrooy had been expected at a news conference at Old Trafford this afternoon alongside Sir Alex Ferguson's assistant Steve McClaren.

But United financial director David Gill and United solicitor and director Maurice Watkin appeared instead. Gill told the press: "As you will be aware Ruud van Nistelrooy has had a knee injury and has not played for the last six to eight weeks.

"The key focus of our tests today has been on the injured knee and we have been unable to complete all the necessary tests to our satisfaction today.

"We will continue to conduct the tests over the course of the next few days in co-operation with PSV Eindhoven and will communicate the position as soon as possible. I am pleased to inform you that we have concluded negotiations with both PSV and Ruud and we will complete the transfer as soon as the tests have been satisfactorily concluded."

The 23-year-old striker is the hottest property in Holland, having scored 30 goals in the Dutch league last season and 29 this before injuring his knee in a friendly on March 6 against Danish side Silkeborg.

fields.headline: Prosecutors seek Lockerbie trial delay
fields.trailText: The Lockerbie trial could be postponed for several weeks if an application by Scotland's senior law officer for a delay is successful, it emerged tonight.
fields.body:
The Lockerbie trial could be postponed for several weeks if an application by Scotland's senior law officer for a delay is successful, it emerged tonight.

Lord advocate Colin Boyd will make the application to the high court after notice from the defence last week that there will be 119 defence witnesses, the crown office said.

The trial of the two Libyans accused of causing the PanAm jet disaster, Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, was due to start at Camp Zeist in the Netherlands on May 3. The plane exploded over the Scottish town of Lockerbie in December 1988 killing 270 people, including 11 on the ground.

Mr Boyd will make his application for a postponement at a hearing before Lord Sutherland at Camp Zeist on Thursday.

The application is being made on the grounds that the prosecution has not been provided with any advance notice of any defence witnesses despite repeated requests and has not yet seen any defence documents.

It will be argued that given the number of witnesses and the fact that many live abroad, the prosecution team does not consider that the case can go to trial next week.

The defence witnesses are based in a number of countries including Malta, Sweden, Germany and the United States, but the largest number are from Libya.

Mr Boyd is likely to ask for a postponement of several weeks.

The trial, scheduled to last for a year, will be conducted under Scottish law.

The suspects were extradited only after Britain, the US and Libya agreed to hold the trial in a neutral country.

Jim Swire, spokesman for relatives of the British victims of the disaster, said he planned to be present at Camp Zeist for Thursday's hearing.

"I understand the reason is the crown have only recently received a full list of defence witnesses, and they feel they need time," he said.

"Any further postponement would be unwelcome, but we are after truth and justice. If a postponement would improve the quality of the defence or prosecution, we would go along with the decision of the judges if they feel it's important for the fairness and objectivity of the trial."

The trial has already been postponed once - it had been due to start in February, but late last year was put back at the request of the defence.

fields.headline: Just say no
fields.standfirst: A guide to the perfect Research Avoidance Exercise by  Robert French and  Charles Booth :  Write on
fields.trailText: A guide to the perfect Research Avoidance Exercise by Robert French and Charles Booth : Write on
fields.body:
As the pressure cooker of the official Research Assessment Exercise (RAE1) reaches maximum steam, we have recognised a parallel phenomenon, an alternative or shadow RAE - RAE2. It is, of course, the Research Avoidance Exercise.

In the New Order, where quantity is all, "research" simply means "publication". Everything else - teaching, talking, conviviality, even real research - is more or less an irritation, distracting from the quest for the pot of gold at the end of the RAE1 rainbow. The idea that the purpose of research is to uncover something that might be of use to humanity sinks deeper into the mud. Forget chapters or monographs, it's journal articles that count! Must be a 5-rated journal! And preferably single-authored.

For the Research Avoidance Exercise, however, distractions and irritations are the whole point: good things come to those who avoid.

Here are some handy hints we hope will help all those who find it's all become too much. We have attempted to grade and categorise them for ease of use - but please read footnote 1 before reading any further.

Everyday avoidance techniques that anyone can use
Become (or just remain) obsessed with bodily needs - food, drink, etc. Relax - TV, a walk, daily papers. Remember - mens sana in corpore sano . And either go to the gym or to the pub, depending on your inclination and your mental and corporeal states. Make - then amend, update, refine - "to do" lists. Do "things-to-get-out-of-the-way-so-your-mind-is-clear" - phone calls, letters, gardening, mending. Do "things-to-tidy-so-your-physical-space-is-clear" - desk, cupboards, shelves, floor, bedroom, kitchen, garage.

Although clearly not in the "everyday" category, sex is also extremely useful as an avoidance technique, partly because it can itself be interpreted - "in the here-and-now" - as a form of research, partly because it actually is a form of avoidance of reality. (See the standard edition of the complete psychological works of Sigmund Freud, especially volumes 1-24.)

Avoidance techniques specific to academic roles
Marking, planning courses, writing up minutes, reading minutes, ordering books (even), doing lists, attending exam boards. Preparing RAE1 submissions. Teaching.

Techniques so plausible and laudable they will not be spotted as avoidance
Going to the library, commenting on a colleague's chapter, agreeing to be an external examiner, taking on a PhD student, talking about something interesting over coffee, attending a time-management or speed-reading course. All electronic avoidance techniques fall into this category. To give only two examples:

(i) After two days out of the office, one of the authors was disappointed to find only 76 emails in his inbox. But skilful use of the frame of mind we are grappling to describe here meant that he could devote his first day back exclusively to dealing with these messages - and still have several left for avoiding all research-related work for the next few days.

(ii) Anything to do with the internet and websites. Best of all, set up a site yourself!

Second order avoidance
Setting out to clear your room, but putting that off to return a book to the library.

Third-order avoidance
While you are in the library, staying on to look up some articles/references (or just read the newspaper).

Fourth-order avoidance
This is the ideal; an ideal towards which we can all strive. In this beatific state, you have to go so far back along the sequence of avoidance to find what it was you set out to avoid that any insight into your condition is impossible. For example, coming to work is clearly an avoidance of having to be with the family. Thus, all work contributes to the radical "project" of avoiding one's broader life responsibilities. In that context, techniques which appear to be aimed at avoiding research offer a double "screen" which blocks out insight into the more profound avoidance strategies one has evolved for genuine life issues.

If all else fails, write a newspaper article on RAE2 - or even the "real" RAE. (You will already have noted that "real" is an anagram, combining "RAE" with "what the L?")

Basic reading
Prigogyne, A and Rozov, N (1973), "Traffic flows as chaotic systems: a response to our critics", proceedings of the Belorussian Mathematical Society, 12(3): 99-109.

Footnotes
Always read every footnote you see. Always follow up and check out all references. The writing and the reading of footnotes are essential techniques. (For a stunning use of the creative use of footnotes, see Illich, 1983, 1993; also Poerksen, 1995. The Poerksen reference is a translation into English of Poerksen, 1988. As an example of the frame of mind we are describing here, the Top Achievement Award for Avoidance would go to anyone who learnt German in order to read this text in the original form.)

Do you get an empty, almost panicky, feeling if you cannot log into your email in the mornings or are separated from it for more than 24 hours? This is an excellent sign! It means your dependency on email to avoid all research-related activity is so automatic you think it normal.

It may even be an encouraging indication of fourth-order avoidance (see 7 above). If you think there is any connection whatever between your research and the use of email, you have definitely reached the fourth order.

To give these ideas on RAE2 an experiential edge, you might like to test them out right now, by doing one of the following exercises:

(i) Re-grade all our suggestions in a way which suits your own tastes and inclinations, writing a commentary on each.

(ii) Start an email correspondence with the authors - to explore advanced techniques or to get hold of references we have failed to supply. Our email addresses will be supplied in return for a guarantee that you will cite one of our publications in your next article.

 Robert French and Charles Booth are from Bristol Business School, University of Western England.

fields.headline: Quality street
fields.standfirst: John Randall announces a new system of assessment aimed at cutting pointless paperwork
fields.trailText: John Randall announces a new system of assessment aimed at cutting pointless paperwork
fields.body:
In Bogota, I listened politely as the university rector spelt out the unique problems faced by higher education in Colombia. What would these be, I wondered. Murder? Kidnapping? Drug running? Far from it. The problems of Colombia had a familiar feel. They were the pressure to expand higher education rapidly to meet the needs of the knowledge economy, the fact that the money available for this was limited, and the public demand that standards should be seen to be maintained.

Throughout the world, higher education is in transition from elite systems to mass participation. One consequence is the development of a more formal approach to quality assurance. In the past decade, quality assurance agencies have been established in some 50 countries.

There are two reasons for this. The first is obvious. The amounts governments spend on higher education are significant. Multi-million pound sums, sufficient to fund several ministerial pet projects, are but the small change of the multi-billion pound UK higher education budget. Little wonder there is public and political concern that value for money should be demonstrated.

The second reason is less obvious, but of equal importance. As the student population has become larger, has grown to include more mature students and has become more representative of society at large, the relationship between students and their teachers has altered.

With all other professionals, university teachers are learning that deference to title or position has been replaced with respect for ability and quality of service. Most people make the choice of a degree course only once, and a mistake may be both difficult and expensive to put right. Many potential students, especially mature ones, may not be as mobile as the young school leaver. Such people need reliable information about what may be the only university to which they can apply.

Academic standards are not a private matter. Explaining what they mean, and confirming that they are achieved, does no more than meet modern democracies' proper expectations of transparency and accountability in those who provide professional services. The public assurance of quality allows students and employers to make informed choices between institutions, and enables academics to earn the respect on which professional standing now rests.

It would be naive to expect that external scrutiny of academic activities would be welcomed universally by those subject to it. But there is general acceptance of the principle of scrutiny as a means of providing accountability, generating public information and disseminating good practice.

Yet when it comes to the reality of conducting a scrutiny there are complaints, sometimes well-founded, of intrusiveness and bureaucracy. The cartoons that adorn my office wall relate to the perception of quality assurance as a bureaucratic nightmare, and show harassed dons buried beneath mountains of paper.

This week the Quality Assurance Agency will launch a new approach to the scrutiny of academic affairs. No longer will it be possible for vice-chancellors to pose for photographs in a room full of box files containing the evidence needed to demonstrate the quality of their teaching.

The old approach involves a snapshot of activity from a short visit. Information had to be assembled artificially and for no other purpose, and kept at hand in case it was required. Much of it was not needed, giving rise to complaints of wasted effort. In future, we will work with the grain of academic activity. The time of reviewers will not be compressed into one visit but will be spread, to enable them to deal with naturally arising rather than artificially assembled evidence.

Visits will coincide with internal events for which the institution has had to assemble evidence for its own purposes - such as the periodic reapproval of a course. At the heart of the process will be the institution's evaluation of its own provision, which reviewers will seek to test and verify. Gone, too, will be the uncertainty that leads to time being wasted in preparing for every eventuality. There will be a new transparency to the process, with a published code setting out straightforward precepts of good practice.

The new approach abandons the complex system of numerical scoring which has proved open to misinterpretation. Instead, if provision is failing we will say so. If there are exemplary features we will single them out. At the heart of the new approach is a concern with standards which was identified in the Dearing report. We will look at the systems that universities use to approve new courses and to ensure that they meet standards. Subject by subject, we will assess the standards set, the effectiveness of the curriculum in enabling these to be achieved, and the appropriateness of the assessment methods chosen to measure success. Lastly, we will take a look at the quality of the learning opportunities provided through teaching, tutorial support and library and other resources.

The challenge faced by any quality assurance system is to ensure that it meets the requirements of accountability, provision of public information and supporting continuous improvement, whilst avoiding the dangers of bureaucracy and unproductive effort.

The agency's new system is the product of extensive consultation and trialling involving thousands of academics and the canvassing of employers and other stakeholders. I believe that we now have a system to command the confidence both of the academic community and of the wider society that it serves.

 John Randall is chief executive of the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education.

webTitle: NUT using pupils as pawns says Woodhead

fields.headline: NUT using pupils as pawns says Woodhead
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, yesterday attacked the largest teaching union for using children "as pawns in a game" to fight the government's plans for performance-related pay.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, yesterday attacked the largest teaching union for using children "as pawns in a game" to fight the government's plans for performance-related pay.

As delegates at the National Union of Teachers' annual conference in Harrogate warned of stress on pupils caused by pressure on staff to improve test scores, Mr Woodhead said the argument amounted to a breach of professionalism.

"A seven-year-old who feels any pressure when they are doing the test, only feels that pressure if the teacher communicates it," he said on BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"Their pay doesn't depend exclusively on results. Part of it does and part of it should because the teacher's job in a primary school is to ensure that children learn to read and write and master rules of basic numbers. I don't think teachers are so unprofessional that they are going to communicate unacceptable levels of stress on their children. They are using children as pawns in a game, the game being that the union is opposed to performance-related pay, just as it is opposed to inspection," the Ofsted chief said.

Doug McAvoy, the union's general secretary, said teachers being measured by results were bound to suffer anxiety and pass it on to children.

There was also a danger that staff would concentrate their efforts on particular children whose results would affect delivery of performance targets, at the expense of others in the class. "I can't imagine that is what parents want, but that is a consequence of performance-related pay," he said. The union's campaign against the government's pay scheme got strong support from Phil Willis, the Liberal Democrats' education spokesman.

In an address to the conference he appeared to congratulate delegates who heckled Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, on Saturday. "It's about time teachers displayed their anger at the way they are being treated," he said.

The government should stop telling teachers how to teach and abandon "the bureaucratic farce called performance-related promotion".

It was being introduced absurdly quickly, with inadequate training of headteachers and external assessors who would decide which teachers deserved a £2,000 performance bonus. It was not possible to identify which teacher made the difference to a pupil's performance, he said.

The conference edged nearer a programme of industrial action against performance pay, but it was still unclear last night whether the union would be able to agree a clear policy before it closed today.

Ron Haycock, a teacher from Waltham Forest, east London, said: "Ministers want good performance. Teachers have been performing miracles for years. So pay all of us."

The union should resist the government's scheme with a one-day strike. "We owe it to every child we teach to go on national strike," he said.

But Jerry Glazier, for the union's executive, said that a one-day strike would split the union and hand a propaganda weapon for the government to turn on teachers.

The conference agreed a campaign against privatisation of state education, including local strike action when teachers' jobs were threatened by contracting out to private firms.

The conference also approved resolutions to cut class sizes and protect teachers from undue stress.

Delegates reported surveys showing that a quarter of teachers suffered from "workplace bullying" by over-zealous superiors and 56% suffered from stress serious enough to require medical attention.

fields.headline: Proposals to facilitate adoption welcomed
fields.trailText: Adoption agencies today welcomed new legal proposals to make adoption easier and were "hopeful" of extra cash for post-adoptive support, following a summit on the issue at Downing Street.
fields.body:
Adoption agencies today welcomed new legal proposals to make adoption easier and were "hopeful" of extra cash for post-adoptive support, following a summit on the issue at Downing Street.

Experts say that around 5,000 children suitable for adoption are currently trapped in the care system because they cannot be matched with couples who want to adopt them, while hundreds of hopeful parents find themselves frustrated by the complex adoption procedures.

Health minister John Hutton, who chaired the meeting of social services professionals, adoption agencies and children's charities, said that the key issues identified were the need for national standards on adoption and clarity on what was required of prospective parents.

Mr Hutton estimates that up to 1,000 extra adoptions could happen each year as a result of the reform of the system planned by the government.

It is hoped that creating national standards will sweep away the situation where different councils apply different criteria when deciding who may adopt - some of them rejecting parents because of their age, because they have a different racial background to the child or even because they smoke or are overweight.

No details of what criteria adoptive parents will be required to meet in future have yet been finalised, but Mr Hutton hinted that it was likely that restrictions on older couples adopting would be relaxed.

One proposal which seems certain to become policy is the creation of a new national register of children seeking adoption and hopeful couples, to end the situation where couples approved for adoption are forced to apply to many different local authorities.

Today's meeting was part of a review of the adoption system which will result in a report to the prime minister next month.

webTitle: Big money, Little job and Tiny excuse

fields.headline: Big money, Little job and Tiny excuse
fields.trailText: SPEND, SPEND, SPEND
fields.body:
SPEND, SPEND, SPEND

Manchester United have just won the league for the sixth time in eight seasons. The bookies reckon they're going to win it again for the next 50 years or so. And they've just completed the £19m transfer of talented young Dutch striker Greg van Rusedski. But the twitching corpse of English football isn't quite dead yet - because it looks as though there's another massive barney developing between tightwad chairman Money Mart Edwards and the Viv Nicholson of football management, Alex Ferguson. Scrap! Scrap! Scrap!

The new friction began to crackle this morning, when Edwards popped up on a BBC newsreel to order Fergie to sell one of his strikers. "The manager now has to decide which of his other strikers he feels he can get by without," he dictated. "I don't think that sensibly you can keep five strikers happy."

Of course, it's not just about Andy and Teddy's feelings. Caring, sharing Mart is naturally a bit worried about his bottom line as well. "Manchester United earns roughly £30m a year profit," Edwards explained, testily tapping on a calculator. "You then have tax, which makes it about £20m a year," he continued, slamming beads angrily around an abacus. "Then you have to pay £5m for a dividend, so you've got £15m to spend," he screamed, wildly ripping balance sheets out of a box file like an accounta-nutter.

"That's not just on players - that's on ground improvements and everything else," he went on, bunging a flip-chart-on-a-stand through a nearby window. "So clearly to go and spend all that on one player - more than you actually earn - doesn't actually make sense." The Fiver sees his point. Although whether it makes much sense to rub your short-tempered but very successful manager up the wrong way is another thing.

LITTLE SUCCESS

Brian Little has got himself a new job. It seems as though it happens every other day, but it doesn't, really it doesn't. He's the new manager of Hull, and if there's ever going to be an acceptable time to trot out the usual tiresome bilge about 'potential' it's now - the city is huge and the football team have always been hugely inept. "I am looking forward to the opportunity to join a big club which has the desire and potential to play at the highest level," said a totally justified Brian.

Although the ex-Darlo boss is naturally excited to take over at the club whose floodlights are serviced by Nick Barmby's old man - "I will have the opportunity to assess the playing staff in the week before the final home game and to spend the summer looking to strengthen!" - his new job continues something of a downward trend in his career since the heady days of Leicester and Aston Villa.

Why Little has been forced down the divisions we don't know - he hasn't presided over any full-scale disasters as of yet. So the Fiver thinks the appointment is a good one for Hull - but we're very, very sorry to everyone on Humberside if we've tempted fate.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"You'll not find any quotes from me in which I've been critical or condescending towards Rangers" - Celtic director of golf Kenny Dalglish further endears himself to the Parkhead faithful.

MY NAME IS ROBERT PAGE

Wouldn't it be nice if, just for once, managers of relegated sides were just a tiny bit more truthful. Instead of blaming their 15-point gap from the rest of civilisation on a crippling injury list, a tight-fisted chairman or a spate of gonorrhoea, why not give it to us straight? "We're **** and we know we are," or "Even Lord Ferg couldn't keep us up". That sort of thing.

Thank God for honest Graham Taylor. "You need to stay in the Premiership for the Premiership referees to get to know you, so they can call you by your first name," says Taylor, somewhat unusually. "Referees come out and think 'Who is Robert Page? Who is that Watford player?' They know the likes of Patrick Vieira or Tony Adams, and that gives you that feeling."

According to Taylor, this sort of chummy banter has been costing Watford points, none more so than on Sunday when Rob Harris didn't send off Pat Vieira for throwing his head about as though he was in a shampoo advert. "For me, there's no place on a football pitch for head movement - whether he catches him or not," said Taylor, amazingly steering clear of double-negatives. "Is he attempting to butt another player? If the answer is yes, then there's only one place for him." And, the Fiver sadly suggests, there's only one place for Taylor: the First Division.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Les Ferdinand could make a return to Turkish club Besiktas at the end of the season.

Chelsea, Aston Villa and Spurs are lining up bids for Andy Cole.

Spurs have denied reports suggesting that Southampton boss Glenn Hoddle will replace George Graham as manager at White Hart Lane.

Everton are interested in Sheffield Wednesday captain Peter Atherton. The 30-year-old defender is available on a Bosman free in the summer.

Middlesbrough have offered Manchester United £1.5m for John Curtis.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Liverpool may quit Anfield in order to keep up with Manchester United. Chief executive Rick Parry and stakeholders Granada want to match United's 60,000-plus capacity, but any serious expansion plans of the current stadium would certainly be blocked by local residents. Chairman David Moores is expected to fight the plan.

Danny Wilson has been interviewed for the vacant manager's job at Chesterfield.

Tottenham have completed the £1m signing of Luton striker Gary Doherty.

Matt Elliott has joined Scotland's list of injured players after being forced out of training ahead of tomorrow night's friendly with Holland in Arnhem.

The Spanish Football Federation will tonight decide the fate of Barcelona in the Copa del Rey following the club's refusal to play the second leg of their semi-final against Atletico Madrid at the Nou Camp. Barca face being thrown out of next season's Copa and may be fined £7,000.

Newcastle defender Alessandro Pistone will return to action for the reserve team against Blackburn tonight barely 11 weeks after breaking his leg.

Derby captain Darryl Powell will undergo a hernia operation next week - provided the club have secured their Premiership status. Powell has been playing with the injury for the past three months.

Charlton will receive the Nationwide League championship trophy after their final home game of the season against Ipswich on Saturday.

Wolves have extended the loan of Danish international midfielder Allan Nielsen.

Barry Venison has set up an on-line auction site for autographed sports memorabilia called Bid4sport.com to raise money for children's charity Peggy and Friends. Items from the likes of David Beckham, Michael Owen, Alan Shearer and Lennox Lewis will be under auction.

Bonus ball.

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.20am)
The best league in Europe that isn't Spain.
