fields.headline: Bitter harvest
fields.standfirst:
Two decades ago it was the toast of the liberal world. Even three years ago it was considered an economic success. So what went wrong in Zimbabwe? Gary Younge on how Mugabe's failure to tackle the land issue brought the country to the brink of anarchy
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText:
Two decades ago it was the toast of the liberal
world. Even three years ago it was considered
an economic success. So what went wrong in
Zimbabwe? Gary Younge on how Mugabe's
failure to tackle the land issue brought the
country to the brink of anarchy
fields.body:
The World Cup qualifying match between Zimbabwe and the Central African Republic was a peculiarly symbolic affair. Zimbabwe went two-nil up against the run of play when a reckless tackle in the 37th minute earned CAR midfielder Potasse Taraine a red card. Scarcely had the referee reached for his top pocket when the CAR captain, Azo Alain, was upon him, felling him with a running punch and chasing him around the pitch.

A full-scale punch-up ensued which brought not only officials but riot police on to the pitch, complete with batons, dogs, and canisters of tear gas. It took 15 minutes to restore order. In politics as in football it is almost impossible to predict what will happen next in Zimbabwe. The situation is volatile, tempers are short, those who are supposed to provide leadership are acting irresponsibly and those who are supposed to maintain order are either unable or unwilling to do so.

One moment the country's president, Robert Mugabe, is declaring a truce between "war veterans" and farmers and the supreme court has convicted the veterans' leader, Chenjari "Hitler" Hunzvi, of contempt. The next, white farmers have fled their homesteads, two women have been raped and the political opposition have been branded as lackeys of foreign interests.

The situation does not so much vary from day to day as spin off in myriad contradictory directions within the same day. Take last Tuesday. The morning started with reports that a white farmer near Bulawayo had been injured. A couple of hours later, after the farmer had been confirmed dead, Mugabe was on television delivering his independence day speech. He spoke of reconciliation and described white deaths as "regrettable". Soon after, he had branded white Zimbabweans as "enemies of the state" and blamed them for bringing the attacks on themselves.

One step forward, two steps back; political progress followed by pernicious pogroms. Inflation, unemployment are up; foreign reserves, fuel supplies and political trust are down; and, in the words of Gil Scott-Heron, common sense is at an all-time low.

Zimbabwe wasn't always like this. When Mugabe took over in 1980 he was the toast of the liberal world. He did not have the stature of Nelson Mandela - who does? - but he did have democratic legitimacy and vowed to work towards reconciliation in the interests of the many rather than the few, which was more than can be said for his predecessor, Ian Smith. As recently as three years ago the country was regarded as one of Africa's success stories. Economic growth, at 8%, was strong, and investment was pouring in.

"Our economic outlook is the brightest and strongest it has been for 15 years, even 20 years," said Isaac Takawira, the managing director of Barclays Bank of Zimbabwe in early 1997. "Our clients are dusting off projects that have been on the shelf for years. Businesses are making expansion plans. With good cooperation between government and the private sector we should enjoy a stable macroeconomic situation and sustainable growth."

Although Amnesty International had severe criticisms of the country's proposed constitutional reform - which was rejected by the voters last month - it nonetheless concluded that "the draft constitution represents major human rights improvements compared to the present constitution".

But even as the world has praised Mugabe it has expressed concern over the cronyism and despotism that has become endemic through his 20 years in power.

During the 80s he cemented his rule through a murderous campaign against the Ndebele in general and his former liberation allies, the Zimbabwe African Peoples Union (Zapu), in particular. He only abandoned his commitment to one-party rule, under considerable duress, about five years ago. His portrait still hangs everywhere, from the Kentucky Fried Chicken to the car hire offices. Desmond Tutu, the former archbishop of Cape Town, once described Mugabe as "almost a caricature of all the things people think black African leaders do".

The financial world has been disdainful of his economic performance partly because it has concentrated on the interests of the poor. Much of spending has gone to education - at 92% Zimbabwe has one of the highest rates of literacy in Africa - health and infrastructure. But his claims that the democratically decided priorities of his government were being overruled by economic imperialism have been undermined by his tendency to line the pockets of the political elite and to use inflationary pay rises to buy off discontent among civil servants. If that were not enough, his senseless and unpopular war in the Congo is costing money that his country simply does not have.

If Mugabe had left government in 1995, says Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of opposition party the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), he would have gone with his reputation intact, but "the past five years have been a disaster".

Ironically, the one area in which he gains most sympathy in this part of the world is land reform. The first law passed by South Africa's African National Congress in 1994 was to permit those who had been evicted from their land during apartheid to reclaim their property, and a recent survey showed that a slim majority of South Africans believe Zimbabwe's squatters were right to seize land. Ever since Zimbabwe was liberated from white minority rule the thorny question of the redistribution of land has been simmering.

This has always been an essentially political issue, although race has never been far away. In a country where history has both racialised politics and politicised race it is difficult to see how it could be otherwise. Those who own the best land are white; those who want it are black. Whites stole the land from blacks for several decades at gunpoint; now blacks want some of it back and they are prepared to get it in the same way they lost it if they have to.

Contrary to what many white farmers here would have you believe, Zimbabwe was not an oasis of racial harmony before Mugabe started to stoke up tensions. The white-owned estates are collectively the country's largest employer and pay the lowest wages. Maids earn more than farm labourers and many white farmers treat their staff with racist contempt resonant of the bad old days of Rhodesia. "The farmer here is not a good man," said Gladman T, who works as a labourer near Ventersburg. "When he gets angry he throws things at us or lets the dogs on us. He got angry one day when the machinery broke and cut the electricity off to all our houses.

"He is like many whites. They only want to deal with blacks as workers. His attitude creates a bitterness among us. If there were to be trouble here with the war veterans I don't think any of his workers would help him." But nor has it merely been a tale of bitter racial conflict. In the cities a black middle class is both thriving and growing. In the countryside some white farmers have been slowly coming around to the idea that their black workers are staff rather than hired chattels, although an insipid strand of paternalism remains firmly lodged in their psyche. Black Zimbabweans want land reform not to spite whites but because they feel it is just and because that is what they fought for 20 years ago. Tales of them defending the farms where they work against squatters tell us more about their fear that the squatters will take the land for themselves and leave them with nothing than any great love for their bosses.

While Mugabe has painted him self as the champion of the landless in recent months, it has been the landless who have been forcing him to act over the past few years.

Almost two years ago squatters occupied white farms, pointing to family grave sites and grinding stones used by their mothers to illustrate how their land was seized by British colonialists without a penny of compensation. Their immediate actions were directed at white farmers, but they were motivated by frustration after years of waiting for the government to tackle the issue. At the time, Mugabe imposed a two-week ban on public demonstrations and strikes after a veterans' demonstration which took place while African-American businessmen were here for an investment conference.

Nor is the death of white farmers anything new. As far back as 18 months ago one elderly farmer was killed and another white couple assaulted. At the time white farmers barricaded themselves into their houses, armed themselves, and vowed they would never leave their land. "Our hard-won peace and sta bility is threatened by our people's urgent need for fertile land," said the then minister of state, Joseph Msika. "I shudder to think what the future holds for us if we do not achieve an equitable distribution of our land." Welcome to the future. Msika has been promoted to vice president, equitable distribution has not been achieved and the entire nation is shuddering with the consequences.

At the Old Vic pub in Bulawayo the great and good of the ruling Zanu-PF party are knocking back the Mikuyu Pinot Noir, a popular Zimbabwean red wine. They are in town in Msika's honour. Those who checked into the adjacent Rainbow hotel paid in cash - huge wads of Zimbabwean dollars which bear testament to the 50% inflation for which their government is responsible. If there was ever an illustration of an effete ruling elite, it is this.

A few miles away, in the plush suburb of Hillside, big men are weeping at the funeral of the white farmer Martin Olds, who was murdered by squatters last Tuesday. Like the corpse, they are dressed in khaki. Black ties and jackets were left behind when they left their homes in haste following the killing. Following Olds' death we learned that "he had the gentlest eyes you have ever seen". What we did not hear was that his objectionable manner made him deeply unpopular with black people in the district of Nyamandlovhu where he lived. During the liberation war he served in the Grey Scouts, a mountain reconnaissance team that fought determinedly to preserve minority rule. He had been in trouble with the police in the past for shooting at poachers; he had promised that squatters would receive the same treatment.

From the pulpit Reverend Paul Andrianatos pulls no punches. Voting for Zanu-PF "would be a vote for the devil", he says, before going on to compare Mugabe with Hitler. If ever there was an illustration of a besieged, privileged and panicked minority, it is this.

Mugabe is not the devil any more than Olds was an angel. That doesn't mean the former deserved to rule any more than the latter deserved to die. What is going on in Zimbabwe is not a black and white issue. It is about politics, fuelled by history and propelled by self-interest.

The reason the Zimbabwean president wavers between reconciliation and revenge is that there is disquiet among many in Zanu-PF - including Msika, who ordered the occupations to stop less than a fortnight ago - that he is going about land reform in the wrong way. But their concern is electoral rather than moral.

An election is scheduled for May - although it is not likely to take place until July, and the party's defeat in the referendum has taught it that it is no longer invincible. It has come to consider itself not only as the natural party of government but the only party of government. In the past, opposition has either been hopelessly divided or crippled by ethnic associations that were unable to reconcile disparate forces. Now the MDC has emerged, bringing together everyone from the trade union movement to the white farmers, who want a change of government. Zanu-PF has not delivered and is running out of wriggle room. It has no money left to buy off dissenters and there are few minorities left to persecute. Now it is desperate.

webTitle: In brief, and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief, and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: • There have been reports from Coming Attractions on the Blair Witch sequel/prequel. Apparently a trailer - very much a work in progress - has been made. "It's the same length as the original teaser, but this time simply features ooky chanting accompanying reddish-orange illuminated iconography," reports the spy. "[Production company] Artisan plans to - predictably- go all out with promotions for the film, including installing internet kiosks at major theatres that will allow patrons to visit the BWP2 website."
fields.body:
 There have been reports from Coming Attractions on the Blair Witch sequel/prequel. Apparently a trailer - very much a work in progress - has been made. "It's the same length as the original teaser, but this time simply features ooky chanting accompanying reddish-orange illuminated iconography," reports the spy. "[Production company] Artisan plans to - predictably- go all out with promotions for the film, including installing internet kiosks at major theatres that will allow patrons to visit the BWP2 website."

 Britain's world heavyweight boxing champion Lennox Lewis was quoted today as saying that he fancies being a film actor when he quits the ring. The Sun reports that 34-year-old Lewis got a taste for the movies while helping Denzel Washington prepare for his Oscar-nominated role as a prize fighter wrongly accused of murder in The Hurricane. "I would definitely like to get involved in movies. I have a strong interest in the film business, both in front of and behind the scenes,'' said Lewis.

 Gwyneth Paltrow is being sued by a couple who claim she caused them "permanent and serious'' back and neck injuries when her car collided with their vehicle a year ago. "They were stopped and she rear-ended them,'' said James Earle, representing the plaintiffs. "They suffered $4,000 in damages to the car and $8,000 in medical damages.''

Casting couch

 Oscar-nominated Denzel Washington has committed to the drama John Q for New Line Cinema, with Nick Cassavetes attached to direct. The film centres on a family without health insurance, whose father, so furious that he can't get medical help for his son, takes the entire emergency room hostage.

 Willem Dafoe and Haley Joel Osment are set to star in Edges of the Lord, yet another second world war drama set in Poland. Osment plays a 12-year-old Jewish boy who hides with a family of Catholic peasant farmers to escape the Nazis. Dafoe, meanwhile, takes the role of a priest who protects and guides the community's children. Yurek Bogayevicz will direct from his own script, which draws on some of his own experiences growing up in Poland. The $7.5m independent production begins filming in Poland in May.

 John Travolta has signed on to star in Domestic Disturbance, his fifth film for Paramount since 1997. Disturbance tells the story of a divorced dad, played by Travolta, who finds that his 11-year-old son's new stepfather is a bit creepier than earlier imagined. Travolta's character then must bail his son out of a dangerous home life.

 Ray Liotta is on the verge of signing on to the cast of Ridley Scott's Hannibal project. Variety reports he is set to take on the role of FBI investigator Thomas Krendler. Shooting is scheduled to begin next month.

fields.headline: New baby
fields.trailText: The arrival of a new baby in the family is a thrilling, yet sometimes daunting prospect for older siblings. Sarah Harrington at Book Trust has selected a range of titles which treat this subject with humour, warmth and understanding
fields.body:
The arrival of a new baby in the family is a thrilling, yet sometimes daunting prospect for older siblings. Below are a selection of titles compiled by Sarah Harrington at Book Trust, which treat this subject with humour, warmth and understanding, aiming to reassure both children and parents at a time of excitement and uncertainty.

The invaluable non-fiction title, How Do I Feel About Our New Baby by Jen Green (Franklin Watts, £5.99) uses photographs of four children, interspersed with colourful line drawings, to explore common responses and emotions of older siblings when a new baby is born. It is packed full of examples, advice and discussion points, providing an informative and reassuring resource to share with children aged five and over.

Told from the point of view of a toddler, Za-za's Baby Brother by Lucy Cousins (Walker Books, £5.99) is a colourful, bold picture book with simple text aimed at two- to six-year-olds. Za-za (a zebra) feels excluded when the new baby receives all the attention, and her parents are either too busy or tired to play with her. But in time she adjusts, and enjoys caring for and playing with her new brother. She even gets her own cuddle in the end, although she has to wait for it a bit longer than she would have liked!

Bob Graham's Brand New Baby (Walker Books, £4.99) explores the emotions and reactions of two young children throughout the pregnancy and after the birth of their new brother. Although Wendy and Edward are excited when Walter comes home from the hospital, they soon realise they will have to change their lifestyle to adapt to the new arrival. This book for children aged two and over is humorously written and illustrated and will be a big hit with older siblings and parents everywhere.

Little Monster Did It! by Helen Cooper (Picture Corgi, £4.99) is a stunning picture book, told from a child's point of view and would appeal to children aged three to seven. When Mum returns from the hospital with a new baby, Amy's toy, Little Monster, takes an instant dislike to him. Together, the two friends cause havoc, stomping about, flooding the sink and banging drums, but Amy never takes the blame, always claiming "Little Monster did it!" A delight to read.

This comically illustrated tale for three- to seven-year-olds, I Want a Sister by Tony Ross (Picture Lions, £4.99) introduces the concept of a new sibling for the Little Princess. When she realises the new baby may be a boy, the Little Princess has her reservations. She doesn't want a smelly, rough brother who plays with the wrong sorts of toys. But when the baby arrives, she decides not to put him in the dustbin as she had planned. The family already has a Little Princess, maybe a Little Prince won't be so bad!

Twin Trouble by Jacqueline Wilson (Mammoth, £3.99) is an amusing and comforting story for confident readers aged six and over. Eight-year-old Connie is very happy being an only child, as she has her parent's undivided love and attention. So she is more than a little alarmed by the news that her mother is expecting twins. When the new babies arrive, things go from bad to worse, but events take an unexpected, magical turn when Nurse Meade arrives to help!

fields.headline: Farmer's funeral as Zimbabwe simmers
fields.trailText:
The funeral of white farmer David Stevens took place on
Tuesday as a British-born man forced to flee Zimbabwe called
on Tony Blair to intervene in the crisis.
fields.body:
The funeral of white farmer David Stevens took place on Tuesday as a British-born man forced to flee Zimbabwe called on Tony Blair to intervene in the crisis.

Mr Stevens was abducted and shot when squatters invaded his farm on 15 April.

He was the first white farmer to die in the violence in the country where up to 1,000 farms have been occupied by veterans of the independence war since February in a political row over land redistribution.

Some of the families who fled the Macheke district near Marondera in the wake of Mr Stevens' murder have returned to their homes.

About 45 farmers and their families, out of about 80 who fled, were given a police escort back to their land yesterday.

But mobs have continued to attack farms, stepping up attacks on black farm workers and torching a tobacco barn in the east of the country.

An unspecified number of workers were being treated at a hospital in the provincial centre of Marondera, 45 miles east of the capital Harare, the Commercial Farmers Union said. The extent of their injuries was unclear.

Stephen Murray, who arrived back in Britain after being forced to flee for his life, told how he and his wife feared for their lives after they were tied up and robbed by squatters in their home.

He warned the situation could be worsening in the African country where he had left his daughter and son-in-law trapped on their remote farm surrounded by 200 squatters.

Mr Murray, 64, originally from Liverpool, has lived in Zimbabwe for 35 years. He said: "Any reports of tension lifting in the country are rubbish.

"Mugabe is laughing at the British Government because he knows they won't do anything."

Talks aimed at resolving the crisis are due to be held in London on Thursday by the British Government and an official delegation from Zimbabwe.

There have been some signs of an easing in tension.

Armed farm occupiers withdrew from a homestead near Mvurwi, 75 miles north of Harare, freeing farm manager Duncan Hamilton and two women who were trapped in the house overnight, it was reported.

A spokesman for United Nation Secretary-General Kofi Annan said he was in regular contact with Mr Mugabe, but was not planning any further intervention in what he regarded as "a domestic matter" for Zimbabwe.

"The Secretary-General met with President Mugabe in Havana. They have been in contact several times since then and President Mugabe has briefed the Secretary-General about what is happening there," spokesman Patrick Heyford told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

"The Secretary-General has encouraged him to find a peaceful solution to the problem in that country.

"This situation is essentially a domestic matter for Zimbabwe."

fields.headline: Fresh vision
fields.standfirst: Joanna Carey talks to Michael Foreman, whose career as an illustrator spans 40 years
fields.trailText: Joanna Carey talks to Michael Foreman, whose career as an illustrator spans 40 years
fields.body:
Combining a fluid watercolour technique with the dry textures of pastel and crayon and even oil paint - "I use a bit of everything" - Foreman's illustrations have a luminosity that can rise from the page like a morning mist, creating atmospheric shifts of mood and colour. But the key to his work is draughtsmanship. He makes few concessions to the very young: "I don't think about 'age groups'." But his drawing is easy to read, and his line - usually soft pencil - has a subtle authority that delivers truckloads of information with eloquent economy.

He's one of a handful of contemporary children's illustrators whose work, beyond the wit and warmth you'd expect, has real breadth and integrity.

Meeting him, it's hard to believe that his career now spans 40 years. But he had an early start, he tells me. He grew up in rural Suffolk, where his mother ran a village shop. As the only one of her paper-boys unable to ride a bike, he did his round on foot, and that was how he got to know one of the customers who was an art teacher.

Michael, who was obsessed by drawing but "never dreamed it could be 'a job'," was invited to join a free Saturday class at Lowestoft Art School. Then, at 15, he left school to study painting full-time. "So, if I'd been able to ride a bike, I'd never have heard of art school, let alone gone to one." He later came to London, to St Martin's and the Royal College of Art, where he studied graphics - "illustration, as such, wasn't taught in those days" - and where his teachers included Edward Ardizzone. He agrees he was lucky to have started art school so young, "and luckier still," he says with some vehemence, "that art schools in those pre-formaldehyde days actually taught ART - it was a rigorous training - not just painting and drawing from life, but hours of anatomy and perspective - boring at the time, but it really taught you to understand what you were looking at. But art schools have changed now. I've done a bit of teaching, but I gave it up - I felt uneasy teaching illustration to people who hadn't yet learned to draw."

With an astonishing 158 books to his name, he's illustrated everything from Grimm, Andersen and Mother Goose to new fiction - including a series of books with Michael Morpurgo that range from retellings of Robin Hood and King Arthur to the forthcoming Billy the Kid, an epic story about a footballer. He's also illustrated his own texts - notably War Boy, an evocative memoir of his war-time childhood, and War Game, a profoundly moving story about the Great War - and these stunning books show to perfection the impact non-fiction for children can have.

As a student, he did lots of freelance work, learning "to respond instantly to text" by drawing for newspapers, and also assisting the police in their inquiries, drawing female suspects "in the days when Identikit only did men". And he was still a student when his first book - The General, a pacifist tale - was published in 1960.

"In the US, it was labelled "a Communist tract for the nursery," he laughs, "but here it got terrific reviews and I really thought I'd cracked it." But it was years before he got another book accepted and, in the meantime, with a travel scholarship he worked as a "commercial artist", on commissions that took him, literally, all round the world.

"A fantastic education in itself," he says as he shows me sketchbooks he kept on those travels, bursting with exquisite drawings: figures, landscapes, architectural details, wildlife studies. He still travels a lot with authors to research locations. "It's part of the deal criss-crossing the globe with the likes of Madhur Jaffrey, Edna O'Brien, Kiri te Kanawa and Terry Jones," he laughs. "We're doing the story of the Crusades - but we've finished the first volume, and we still haven't got beyond Calais."

We talk in Foreman's west London studio, in the garden of his elegant 18th-century house. In one corner his youngest son, Jack, is immersed in homework, surrounded by books. There's a strong resemblance between father and son, and, as Foreman talks about his childhood, 13-year-old Jack provides a sort of visual flashback . . . apart from the spacious surroundings and the books, that is.

"I grew up completely without books, apart from the family Bible. I never read any fairy tales or classics until I was an adult, all we ever had was comics . . . No television either," he adds for good measure. "If we wanted entertainment, we hung around the fish shop," he says, warming to his theme. "It was the only place that was lit up at night."

Coming late to literature meant that, as an illustrator, he could approach fairy tales and classics with a fresh eye, with none of the visual baggage that most of us carry from childhood. So what were his influences? Other artists? "No, not really . . . as a painting student I'd tended towards abstract expressionism . . ."

He listens patiently while I suggest there might be an echo of Rackham in his early work, or Dulac, perhaps, in his sumptuous, romantic illustrations for The Arabian Nights? He admires them, but sees Rackham as more of "a line merchant," while Dulac is "more painterly . . . allowing the paint to make its own edges," and, yes, he concedes, "that's something I try to do".

But the influence he readily acknowledges is that of Brueghel and Bosch. "It's the period detail - the difference between cheap and expensive clothing . . . in a crowd, that lets you see things from both sides. In big battle scenes, like King Arthur, you see the knights in all their fine armour, but they're not in the thick of it: follow the perspective, and you'll find some poor little sod, who didn't want to be there, anyway, with his head split."

And does the work get easier? "No. In many ways I keep making it more difficult for myself, trying to make things more real - not in a literal, photographic sense, but in an emotional sense . . . telling a story by capturing the essence of the situation, giving it some meaning. Ardizzone did it, not just in books, but also as a war artist. It's a question of creating another world, believable in its own right. Quentin Blake does it too - it's all in the drawing."

The Foremans have a second home in St Ives. Cornwall is a "rich source of inspiration," and his recent illustrations for The Merrymaid of Zennor, by Cornish poet Charles Causley, vigorously reflect both the harsh realities and the haunting magic of the place.

Interestingly, he's about to start work on The Wind In The Willows - another classic he missed out on as a young child. Boldly uprooting it from the home counties, he's setting that, too, in the Cornish landscape, which, he says, Grahame also knew and loved.

Soft-spoken, easygoing and straightforward, the only mystery about Foreman is how does he find the time for such a colossal output, with so many other commitments? He's currently involved with the film version of The Rainbow Bear - "I'm having to draw to music now!" he says, explaining the vast musical score on his desk - and he runs Ambit, the arts magazine. "No mystery," says his wife, Louise. "It's a struggle to stop him working - even on Christmas Day."

 Michael Foreman will be giving a talk and slide show at Random House in London, SW1 on Thursday May 18 at 6.30pm. A limited number of free tickets are available for readers. webTitle: The landfill tax facts: our investigation in full

fields.headline: The landfill tax facts: our investigation in full
fields.standfirst: Download the Guardian's full report here
fields.trailText: Today the Guardian publishes all the material it has gathered from a year-long investigation into the workings of Britain's first £1bn green tax which we believe has encouraged widespread illegal dumping in the countryside and has failed to provide the much needed boost to new environmental projects.
fields.body:
Today the Guardian publishes all the material it has gathered from a year-long investigation into the workings of Britain's first £1bn green tax which we believe has encouraged widespread illegal dumping in the countryside and has failed to provide the much needed boost to new environmental projects.

The report - in the form of a 30,000 word submission requested from Michael Meacher, the minister of state for the environment - calls on the authorities and parliament to mount a series of investigations into shortcomings and flaws in the law to stop the illegal dumping of waste and reform a regulatory system (called the landfill tax credit scheme) which should have delivered £250 million for new community projects.

The investigation into the workings of the new landfill tax introduced by the last government was published in the Guardian between April 5-7 and shown on Channel Four's Dispatches program, Dirty Money, on April 6. It was based on a wealth of material taken from all over Britain. This material is published today for the first time on Guardian Unlimited.

The new tax was meant to make the polluter pay and give millions of pounds to save the environment. Britain has the worst record in western Europe for dumping rubbish in the ground - and is the biggest laggard in recycling. This report provides a snapshot into what is happening in Britain now.

Michael Meacher, talking about the Guardian's investigation at a House of Lords reception held by Onyx Environmental Trust on April 11, said: "I want to assure you that the government takes very seriously any illegal dumping or abuse of the licensing exemptions. They are criminal offences with severe penalties including imprisonment. Likewise, I take very seriously any allegations of fraud concerning the credit scheme. I asked the journalists involved to supply me with any evidence they have uncovered, and I have assured them that any new allegations will be fully investigated."

fields.headline: Testimone
fields.standfirst: Mgr Luigi Bettazzi was in El Salvador to remember Archbishop Oscar Romero
fields.trailText: Mgr Luigi Bettazzi was in El Salvador to remember Archbishop Oscar Romero
fields.body:
Ho trovato la situazione meno tesa: la sinistra ha ottenuto il sindaco della città, anche se il governo rimane quello di destra e un antico Presidente ha in mano tutto, dalla stampa alle industrie.

La gente sente Romero come qualcosa di proprio, lo considera un santo e vorrebbe che fosse proclamato martire. Dice: grazie a Romero il Salvador è conosciuto nel mondo. Il 24 marzo sono state dette tre Messe: alla mattina, all'Hospitalito dove Romero è stato ucciso, quella più "popolare"; a mezzogiorno quella "ufficiale" in cattedrale, presieduta dall'arcivescovo che ha auspicato la beatificazione di Romero per il motivo della sua santità personale; alla sera, dopo la Messa presieduta dal cardinale Mahony, arcivescovo di Los Angeles, tra le 80 e le 100 mila persone sono confluite sulla piazza della cattedrale dove c'è stata la grande liturgia ecumenica.

C'è stata anche una grossa manifestazione civile, che ha riconosciuto la presenza di tanta gente venuta da lontano, dall'Europa all'Australia.

Siamo poi andati in altri due villaggi, passando per la strada dove fu ucciso un gesuita, Rutilio Grande, la cui morte spronò Romero alla difesa degli oppressi.

webTitle: Kensit pulls out of latest film project

fields.headline: Kensit pulls out of latest film project
fields.trailText: Patsy Kensit has been forced to pull out of The Enemy, a new film starring Roger Moore and Tom Conti, after being struck down by a stomach bug. She was to have played a CIA agent, but had not yet shot any scenes.
fields.body:
Patsy Kensit has been forced to pull out of The Enemy, a new film starring Roger Moore and Tom Conti, after being struck down by a stomach bug. She was to have played a CIA agent, but had not yet shot any scenes.

Said Kensit's spokesman: "Doctors have advised her to rest for a week and this has made it impossible to take part in the filming as shooting schedules could not be moved. She is so disappointed because it was to be her first movie since having her baby."

Kensit, who is married to Oasis frontman Liam Gallagher, gave birth to Lennon Francis in September 1999.

But fans of the actress need not be starved of her screen presence over the next few months. In May, she will be seen in Janice Beard: 45 Words Per Minute, in which she plays the head of a typing pool, and she will also be portraying Angie Best in a forthcoming biopic of the 60s footballer George Best.

fields.headline: Scream mask worn in stabbing
fields.trailText: A teenager wearing the ghoulish mask used in the Scream horror films stabbed his father and stepmother the day after the third movie in the series opened in France, it was reported yesterday.
fields.body:
A teenager wearing the ghoulish mask used in the Scream horror films stabbed his father and stepmother the day after the third movie in the series opened in France, it was reported yesterday.

The 16-year-old's two victims, from a town near Paris, are recovering today in hospital, and magistrates placed the youth, who was reported to have seen the film Scream 3 the day before the attack, under official investigation for attempted murder.

French television reported that another teenager had been arrested after being found near a suburban train station on the early hours of Sunday carrying a kitchen knife and dressed as the Scream assailant.

He told police he wanted "to frighten'' a man who had just attacked him. The 19-year-old will shortly be appearing before a magistrates court.

 Scream 3 opens in the UK on Friday.

webTitle: Now that's what I call scary

fields.headline: Now that's what I call scary
fields.standfirst: Neve Campbell made her name fleeing knife-wielding maniacs in the Scream movies but, she tells  Emma Brockes, ballet school was much tougher
fields.trailText: Neve Campbell made her name fleeing knife-wielding maniacs in the Scream movies but, she tells Emma Brockes, ballet school was much tougher
fields.body:
Neve Campbell is curled up, shoeless, in an armchair in London's Dorchester hotel, and she is smoking. "Smoking!" A whisper goes up in the press suite next door, until someone remembers she is Canadian, not American, and it can't be read as an act of protest.

Campbell is small and sensible; the PR machine around her is big and absurd and whirring because Scream 3, the conclusion to Wes Craven's horror trilogy in which Campbell survives successive stabbing attempts while sending up the genre, premiered in London the night before. Since then she has been confined to a hotel suite, padding about in stretch fabrics while the studio people flash through the corridors, marshalling journalists.

"I don't enjoy all this, the circus," says Campbell, hugging herself further into the chair. "I was never going to be an actor. I was going to be a classical ballerina. This all just happened." Her third outing as Sidney Prescott sees her back on form as the terrorised victim whose friends keep dying, or trying to kill her. The denouements have become weaker, but Scream 3 is as funny and as scary as its predecessors. Campbell was 23 when she was first cast in the role. With each instalment her haircuts have got sharper, her action sequences longer and more demanding: in Scream 3 she has a fight scene that borrows heavily from Buffy the Vampire Slayer. There are other changes too. Campbell is now on an equal footing with Courtney Cox, who was the only name in the cast of the first Scream in 1996.

"We shot the first film outside San Francisco in the summer. We were all staying in the same hotel, shooting really weird hours, so we were hanging out all the time and we had a blast. We all just really hit it off and that's part of why that movie was so successful, because the energy between us was really good. Doing this film felt like returning to summer camp."

Without make-up, Campbell is freckled and studenty, pretty in an unobtrusive way and prone to an earnest frown that comes from a determination to see things positively.

While in Britain she plans to visit her father's native Glasgow for the first time and meet the aunts and uncles living there. Gerry Campbell emigrated to Canada as a child and after becoming a high school drama teacher, married Marnie Neve, a Dutch psychologist. They divorced when Neve was a baby and she and her older brother grew up with their father in Toronto. "I was brought up in a very Scottish and Dutch atmosphere. I was surrounded by a European culture. Then suddenly I find myself in somewhere like LA, where blacks and whites don't mix and there's racism like I've never seen before."

She arrived in LA two weeks after the earthquake in 1994 and started hawking her portfolio around agents' offices. She was 20 and fresh from a role in Web of Deceit, a movie filmed in Canada for an American network. While doors all over town slammed in her face, a woman who shared a production office with the Deceit team offered to put her up for some auditions. One of them was Party of Five, the TV teen soap about a family of orphans in which Campbell would be cast as Julia Salinger, the sensible one. "The fan mail started pouring in after a year, but it was after Scream that it got huge."

After six years, she has just shot her last scenes for Party of Five and now, at the age of 26, is going through the difficult screen transition from teenager to adult. "It is a little intimidating," she says. "But I am at a place where people know I can do comedy, they know I can do drama, they know I can do a bunch of different kinds of characters, so I'm getting good offers from cool independent directors who want to experiment - and I'm willing to do that because financially I'm in a good place so I don't need to worry about getting a studio picture."

She has another two films coming up: Drowning Mona, "a highbrow comedy" with Bette Midler and Casey Affleck (Ben's brother), and Three to Tango, a comedy with Matthew Perry. These are the kind of roles that could promote her to the solid gold status of an American sweetheart like Sandra Bullock. She is not entirely sure she wants this yet, and has demonstrated it by taking some quirky interim roles. She played Ginny Otis in The Canterville Ghost, a TV film shot in Stevenage with Patrick Stewart and Donald Sinden. She was Suzie Toller, a bi-sexual con-woman alongside Matt Dillon in Wild Things (1998), and in a week's time she goes to Berlin to start filming Investigating Sex, a "no- budget, absolutely independent, fun, experimental film and I don't know if anyone will see it but I don't care."

It is an unexpected sentiment from someone whose stock is riding as high as Campbell's. Scream 3 took £23m in its opening weekend in the US, but she says her tastes have always been elsewhere. "I grew up on foreign films. My father used to bring me the reviews every Wednesday. I hadn't even seen the Godfather until last year."

This resistance to Hollywood is partly due to her late introduction to it. When she was nine she joined the National Ballet School of Canada, where children learned discipline and endurance. She was on a full scholarship while most of her class were from "well-to-do" backgrounds. She did not have friends and related to older people better, acting in her father's theatre group outside of school.

By the time she was 14 and a boarder at the school, she snapped: "I just got to a place where I didn't like dancing any more because of the competitive mentality." Hollywood is a breeze by comparison, she says. You don't have to face your competition in class everyday, and there is no end- of-year exam threatening to throw you out. She is still competitive, "but it's not against other people. I don't get jealous if I don't get a part. I really believe in fate and that if I lose a role, it wasn't meant to be. I had a ballet teacher say to me once, be 10% better than yourself, as opposed to anyone else, because then you're not spending your energy fretting about other people."

The other thing she learned at ballet school was to brace herself for burnout. A ballerina's career ends at 35; a Hollywood actress is in peril from about the same age. "I'm trying to educate myself in other facets of the business, because as a female especially, this career isn't going to last forever. So I'm getting interested in writing and directing."

She still finds LA a nightmare, but with habitual pragmatism has counselled herself into standing it. "I got to a place where I was bored of hearing myself complain about it. I realised that I have to be here, so I better choose to like it."

webTitle: Show time for Figgis's Time Code 2000

fields.headline: Show time for Figgis's Time Code 2000
fields.trailText: Mike Figgis's Time Code 2000 opens this Friday in the US. The film, the first of its kind to have been shot without a script and entirely on digital cameras, has attracted considerable interest, particularly as the actors (who include Salma Hayek, Jeanne Tripplehorn and Holly Hunter) improvised their scenes, and the entire 90-minute movie was shot in one uninterrupted take.
fields.body:
Mike Figgis's Time Code 2000 opens this Friday in the US. The film, the first of its kind to have been shot without a script and entirely on digital cameras, has attracted considerable interest, particularly as the actors (who include Salma Hayek, Jeanne Tripplehorn and Holly Hunter) improvised their scenes, and the entire 90-minute movie was shot in one uninterrupted take.

It seems that what looks like a risky venture for the British director has come off. A member of a preview screening audience writes on internet spy site Coming Attractions that it is a "great film" that "works beautifully".

"There are four boxes on the screen, each showing a different camera's view. In addition, each camera does not cut so that you see what that camera sees for 90 minutes," writes the anonymous reviewer.

"What keeps the film going and makes it work so well is Figgis's mixing of the soundtracks for each camera block. As you watch the four blocks, your attention goes to the block whose soundtrack is at full volume. Sometimes, Figgis will mix tracks so that several of the blocks have sound going at the same time. It sounds like it could be a mess, but it works beautifully." Sure sounds intriguing...

fields.headline: Touch of real drama
fields.standfirst: For too long, medical students have not had time in their studies to learn about the reality of living with cancer. They have now, reports Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: For too long, medical students have not had time in their studies to learn about the reality of living with cancer. They have now, reports Simon Midgley
fields.body:
A ground-breaking humanities course in a leading British medical school is helping trainee doctors understand how people feel when they are living with or dying from cancer.

The full-time, two-week special studies module, Living and dying from cancer, is an arts-based course in which medical students use literature, film, drama and fine art to explore the experience of people suffering from cancer and that of the relatives, nurses and doctors caring for them.

Dr Richard Meakin, director of the Medical Humanities Unit at the Royal Free and University College Medical School, says that medical undergraduates do not have time during their studies to find out much about what it is like to have cancer. They come across it on a number of occasions but do not have space within the course to talk to sufferers or carers about the experience beyond discussing what drug to administer when.

"It is not just a matter of understanding how people feel but how they view things - what it is actually like to live with the sword of Damocles hanging over you or to care for somebody - your nearest and dearest - who is dying, or to have to tell somebody they have a terminal illness."

For many years, Dr Meakin said, there have been fears that as medicine has become more and more science-based that there has been a danger of losing the art of medicine. In the 1970s in the US a number of people started saying, "Hang on, can we learn something from the arts and humanities about illness and suffering and relate what we learn to the practice of medicine?"

Traditionally, medicine was always regarded as an art in the sense that it was based on practice, he said. Preparing to be a doctor required an apprenticeship-type of training that involved acquiring knowledge - about genes, molecules and biochemistry - but also questions of interpretation, intuition and a broader understanding of the human condition.

As early as the 1920s one commentator, Francis Peabody, observed: "Young graduates have been taught a great deal about the mechanism of disease but very little about the practice of medicine or, to put it more bluntly, they are too scientific and do not know how to take care of patients."

And Richard Horton, editor of The Lancet, recently suggested that medical schools ought to be considering introducing literature into undergraduate medical education to learn about the experience of being human.

Some 18 months ago Dr Meakin established the Medical Humanities Unit at the hospital to do just this - to use the arts and the humanities to enrich what science brings to medicine. He won a £20,000 prize from the Cancer Research Campaign to develop and evaluate the living with cancer module.

He was able to set up the new module because the General Medical Council's review of medical education, Tomorrow's Doctors, for the first time allowed students of medicine to opt to do courses in areas that were non-medical but related to medicine.

The course, which consists of interactive small group sessions, is taught by doctors, a professional artist who has recovered from cancer, a drama teacher, a psychotherapist, and the widow of Martyn Harris, a national newspaper journalist who died from leukaemia.

It involves students studying pieces of writing about the experience of living with and dying from cancer. It also requires them to critically examine paintings depicting the experience of having cancer and evaluate the film Shadowlands, which chronicles the death from cancer of CS Lewis's wife. Caroline Heler, Martyn Harris's widow, leads a seminar on why people write about having cancer and how it helps them face up to their illness.

"Caroline is a remarkable woman," said Dr Meakin. "She is very brave and extremely open with the students, so much so that on one of the first courses the students were completely nonplussed by it. They said very little because they were so overwhelmed by how open she was about her relationship with Martyn and the meaning of his writing."

Students also have to explore the experience of having cancer by painting, taking part in a play and in producing a piece of creative writing.

"Though cancer is a common problem, it raises huge issues for patients, relatives and carers both lay and professional because it raises all the issues to do with uncertainty and terminal illness," said Dr Meakin.

To date there have been three courses and 26 students have taken part. "It's terrifying to some students," Dr Meakin said. "Most medical students would not have done anything in the arts since they were 16.

"All the students have come up trumps - no one has failed to present either their creative writing or to participate in the drama, and the overall standard has been extremely high."

After completing the course one student remarked: "It was the first time in my training when what I thought, as opposed to what I knew, was acknowledged as important."

Another said: "It took me off the treadmill of clinical attachments and provided me with a valuable understanding of human needs, including my own,0" while another, who had been allocated to the course rather than having chosen it, said: "It is the people who don't want to do the course who need it the most."

Since its inception, two other humanities modules have been developed: The Human Impact of the Genetic Revolution, exploring the impact of genetic disorders on people's lives, and a course that looks at how doctors are portrayed in the media, including a seminar by a scriptwriter for Casualty.

As far as using the humanities to deepen the understanding of doctors goes, Dr Meakin quotes from a letter from the playwright Anton Chekov. In the 1880s Chekhov said: "The sensitivity of the artist may equal the knowledge of the scientist. Both have the same object, nature, and perhaps in time it will be possible for them to link together in a great and marvellous force which is at present hard to imagine."

We shall see.

After completing the course one student remarked: "It was the first time in my training when what I thought, as opposed to what I knew, was acknowledged as important." Another said: "It took me off the treadmill of clinical attachments and provided me with a valuable understanding of human needs, including my own,0" while another, who had been allocated to the course rather than having chosen it, said: "It is the people who don't want to do the course who need it the most." Since its inception, two other humanities modules have been developed: The Human Impact of the Genetic Revolution, exploring the impact of genetic disorders on people's lives, and a course that looks at how doctors are portrayed in the media, including a seminar by a scriptwriter for Casualty. As far as using the humanities to deepen the understanding of doctors goes, Dr Meakin quotes from a letter from the playwright Anton Chekov. In the 1880s Chekhov said: "The sensitivity of the artist may equal the knowledge of the scientist. Both have the same object, nature, and perhaps in time it will be possible for them to link together in a great and marvellous force which is at present hard to imagine." We shall see.

fields.headline: Inquiry starts into 'nobbled' jury
fields.trailText: An investigation into allegations that the jury in the murder trial of Tony Martin was "nobbled" is to be launched today by the lord chancellor's department.
fields.body:
An investigation into allegations that the jury in the murder trial of Tony Martin was "nobbled" is to be launched today by the lord chancellor's department.

Officials will meet at Norwich crown court to discuss suggestions that members of the jury felt intimidated into convicting the Norfolk farmer of murder at the end of his trial last week.

The sentencing to life imprisonment of the man who shot two burglars at his isolated farmhouse has sparked a nationwide debate about the rights of householders to defend their property and the level of policing in rural areas.

A group of Conservative MPs warned yesterday that a breakdown of law and order in the countryside was a "real possibility" as people had lost faith in the ability of the police to protect them against criminals.

Their comments came after the Guardian revealed the government's decision to increase police funding to rural areas following a Home Office commissioned report that found that spending policy had failed to take account of the special costs of policing sparsely populated areas.

The four Norfolk MPs - the former cabinet ministers, Gillian Shephard (Martin's MP), and John MacGregor, as well as David Prior and Keith Simpson - have urged the government to "look seriously" at the consequences of the Martin case and act fast. "People no longer have confidence in the ability of the police to defend them and their property," their statement said. "They are, as a consequence, likely to be tempted to take the law into their own hands, as the Martin case, and its aftermath, have demonstrated. Many are saying that, like Tony Martin, they too would have defended themselves if the police were unable to help them."

The MPs added: "Ministers must put right their neglect of rural policing, and fast ... action is needed now."

Jim Wilson, chairman of the Norfolk police authority, called for greater clarity in the law on self defence. In a letter to the Norwich-based Eastern Daily Press he said: "The minds of householders would be set at rest if our legislators could define with greater clarity the law which governs a citizen's right to defend his home and property."

Martin, 55, was found guilty by a majority verdict of murdering 16-year-old Fred Barras and of attempting to murder Brendon Fearon, another burglar, with intent to cause grievous bodily harm. The farmer was cleared of attempting to murder Mr Fearon and of possessing a pump-action shotgun with intent to endanger life. Martin claimed he acted in self defence after he found the burglars inside his home.

Last night, the farmer's lawyers said they would launch an appeal at the high court on Friday. They are conducting their own investigation into the allegations of jury intimidation following a call to a local radio station by a woman claiming to have been on the jury.

The radio station, Broadland 102 FM, insisted that the woman caller had not spoken of being "intimidated, pressured or nobbled". A spokeswoman said the caller claimed the trial had "changed her life" and that now she felt "frightened to leave her house" because of what she had heard during the trial.

Michael Ballinger, one of Martin's legal team, said it was important to "get to the bottom" of the allegations. "We shall be talking to the court," he said. "Our first aim is to get to the bottom of this. We feel we have got plenty of other grounds for appeal but if there proves to be anything in these allegations of intimidation then that would no doubt play a part in any appeal."

A spokesman for the lord chancellor's department confirmed that investigations will take place today. "Basically, this will be an informal meeting to discuss what has happened and what has been reported since the end of the trial. The court manager at Norwich, the general manager and the circuit administrator, will be involved. The first stage will be to look at whether there is any need for an investigation."

webTitle: Edwards tells Ferguson to sell a striker

fields.headline: Edwards tells Ferguson to sell a striker
fields.trailText: Martin Edwards has told Sir Alex Ferguson the £19m signing of Ruud van Nistelrooy has wiped out his transfer kitty and that he will now have to sell a striker. The United chairman even went as far as to say that spending so much money on just one player "doesn't actually make sense".
fields.body:
Martin Edwards has told Sir Alex Ferguson the £19m signing of Ruud van Nistelrooy has wiped out his transfer kitty and that he will now have to sell a striker. The United chairman even went as far as to say that spending so much money on just one player "doesn't actually make sense".

"The manager obviously was keen to buy van Nistelrooy and he now has to decide which of his other strikers he feels he can get by without," said Edwards. "I don't think that sensibly you can keep five strikers happy, so I think there will be some movement out. But that's down to the manager."

Teddy Sheringham is likely to make Ferguson's decision for him and the 34-year-old is widely expected to leave on a free transfer this summer. United would not recoup a penny from Sheringham's departure, and Edwards claims Ferguson has already overspent for the year with the signing of van Nistelrooy.

Edwards poured cold water on talk that United could make another big-money signing this summer - possibly Sol Campbell from Tottenham.

He also pointed out that Ferguson had already made a substantial hole in his transfer fund by spending £10m on Mickael Silvestre, Massimo Taibi and Quinton Fortune during the season.

"Manchester United earns roughly £30m a year profit," Edwards said on BBC TV News. "You then have tax, which makes it about £20m a year. Then you have to pay £5m for a dividend, so you've got £15m to spend. That's not just on players - that's on ground improvements and everything else.

"So clearly to go and spend all that on one player - more than you actually earn - doesn't actually make sense. And don't forget this year we have already bought players. We've brought Taibi in, we've brought Silvestre in and we've brought Fortune in.

"So we've already spent how many millions this year, so it makes economic sense to balance the books. It seems strange to be talking about spending more when we've just spent £18m on a centre-forward.

"As I've said before the economics of the thing are if you are buying, sooner or later you will have to balance the books, look at the size of the squad and say do you need so many players in the squad?

"What do you need sensibly to challenge for the top honours domestically and in European football? We have a huge squad and we actually have about 67 professional players on our books, and I think we probably have 20 professional players more than any other club. So you need to look at all these things."

Edwards' words are unlikely to go down well with Ferguson and they could re-open the simmering feud between the two. United boss Ferguson has also said several times over the last couple of days that he does not want to sell anyone.

Ferguson wrote in his autobiography 'Managing My Life' that money has always been a source of friction between the pair. Ferguson has always been unhappy with the size of his salary and the club's reluctance, in his eyes, to buy big.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the craic in one click
fields.trailText: All the craic in one click.
fields.body:
Daily Mail

Liverpool may quit Anfield in order to keep up with bitter rivals Manchester United. Chief executive Rick Parry and stakeholders Granada want to match United's 60,000-plus capacity, but any serious expansion plans of the current stadium would certainly be blocked by local residents. Chairman David Moores is expected to fight the plan.

Teamtalk

Chelsea, Aston Villa and Spurs are lining up bids for Andy Cole in the wake of Manchester United's signing of Ruud van Nistelrooy.

Spurs have denied reports suggesting that Southampton boss Glenn Hoddle will replace George Graham as manager at White Hart Lane.

Planet Football

Everton will attempt to capture Sheffield Wednesday captain Peter Atherton on a Bosman free in the summer. Wigan have already been linked with the 30-year-old defender but Premiership football would be an obvious trump card for the Toffees in any transfer struggle.

Middlesbrough have offered Manchester United £1.5m for John Curtis. The England Under-21 defender is currently on loan at Barnsley, who are desperate to sign him on a permanent basis. Meanwhile, Fiorentina's Paul Okon is close to signing for Boro on a Bosman free.

18-year-old Brann Bergen striker Azar Karadas is the subject of interest from Leeds, Arsenal and Tottenham. Karadas, along with team-mate Thorstein Helstad, is also being tracked by Besiktas and Trabzonspor.

webTitle: Fellow actor dismisses Caine as 'a whinger'

fields.headline: Fellow actor dismisses Caine as 'a whinger'
fields.trailText: Michael Caine has rarely been far from the front pages this year, and today, veteran British actor Richard Harris gets a piece of the action too.
fields.body:
Michael Caine has rarely been far from the front pages this year, and today, veteran British actor Richard Harris gets a piece of the action too.

In an interview with the Daily Telegraph, Harris, who will shortly be seen in Ridley Scott's epic Gladiator, dismissed his one-time friend Caine, as "a light comedian" whose attempts at playing tough guys was "a joke".

Referring to Caine's now famous outburst at this year's Bafta ceremony, Harris suggested that the double Oscar-winning actor would be advised to stop complaining that snobbery means he feels an outcast in Britain's film industry, given that it was Caine himself who left Britain years ago to pursue a career in the US.

"He takes himself too seriously," said Harris, "I've made 63 movies and I've never been nominated by Bafta for anything. Do I care? Not in the slightest."

Harris's attack is the latest spat in a public argument that began in 1995 when Caine dismissed Harris, Peter O'Toole and the late Richard Burton as "drunks".

Michael Caine has yet to comment on Harris's latest remarks.

webTitle: Miami strikes: Cuban residents in protest at Elian seizure

fields.headline: Miami strikes: Cuban residents in protest at Elian seizure
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Miami residents have threatened to turn the city into a ghost town for the day in protest at the seizure of Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy in a custody dispute between his Miami relatives and his father.
fields.body:
Miami residents have threatened to turn the city into a ghost town for the day in protest at the seizure of Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy in a custody dispute between his Miami relatives and his father.

Dozens of businesses pledged to shut their doors, many workers said they would stay home and the protest organisers urged parents to keep children home from school. But city officials said Miami airport, the port of Miami, police and schools would operate as normal. Many non-Cuban businesses also said they expected to open as usual.

Four Florida Marlins baseball players and several coaches - all of Cuban descent - said they plan to miss tonight's game in San Francisco to honour the protest. Their manager said they would be excused with pay for the day. While many non-Cuban businesses said they expected no interruptions in service, several workers in Little Havana and demonstrators outside the house, where Elian stayed, said that much of the city would not be spared from the effects of the protest.

"It's going to look like a ghost town," said Antonio Pazos, 45, a warehouse clerk who said he would go to work. The owner of the El Paisa Cafeteria, a few blocks from the Gonzalez home, said he felt pressured to go along with the strike but would stay open. "I am Hispanic, but that doesn't mean I have to agree," said the Nicaraguan owner. "I have to pay my rent, I have to pay my bills."

Attorney general Janet Reno has expressed "no regrets whatsoever" for the raid that returned Elian to his Cuban father, in advance of an expected grilling today from Republicans on Capitol Hill. The attorney general was to meet a bipartisan group of 11 senators selected by senate majority leader Trent Lott, a Mississippi Republican.

The session coincides with the start of preliminary inquiries in the Senate and the House of Representatives into Saturday's pre-dawn raid. Jesse Helms, the Republican chairman of the Senate foreign relations committee, decried "the grotesque image" of the seizure at gunpoint. The administration in turn accused Republicans of playing politics, with White House spokesman Joe Lockhart denouncing "wild statements" by senior Republicans.

"Everyone's got to take a deep breath," Mr Lockhart said. Ms Reno yesterday defended her actions in several television interviews. "It was time he was returned to his daddy," Ms Reno said of the 6-year-old shipwreck survivor. She said she struggled with different options before giving the go-ahead for the seizure - including "going up there myself" to claim the boy.

Elian was removed from his great uncle's home in Miami on Saturday, where he has been staying since his rescue from the Atlantic last November. He is currently in seclusion with his father at Andrews Air Force base. Despite the outrage voiced by Elian's Miami relatives, most Americans said they supported the government's decision to return the boy to his father. But Elian has to stay in the US until at least a May 11 hearing on an application for asylum he filed, when he was staying with his Miami relatives.

webTitle: Dead Tuesday:  Protest to halt Miami as Elian and father share time

fields.headline: Dead Tuesday:  Protest to halt Miami as Elian and father share time
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Cuban exile leaders have threatened to bring Miami to a halt today with a general strike in protest at the government's seizure of Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy at the centre of an international custody dispute.
fields.body:
Cuban exile leaders have threatened to bring Miami to a halt today with a general strike in protest at the government's seizure of Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy at the centre of an international custody dispute.

The city authorities appealed for calm in Little Havana, home of Elian's Miami relatives and the centre of the protest movement which has developed in the past five months around the demand for him to stay in the US.

More than 800,000 of the city's 2.1m people are Cuban-Americans, and they make up about half the workforce. The city government said it would accept the stoppage, dubbed "Dead Tuesday", but would not pay employees who failed to turn up for work.

The mayor of Miami-Dade county said the strikers had been asked not to repeat their earlier tactics of blocking roads, the seaport and the airport.

The White House defended Saturday's raid, in which heavily armed federal agents stormed the Miami house to snatch Elian and reunite him with his father.

Its spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said: "This happened because the family did not respect the legal process that dictated the father should be reunited with the young boy."

fields.headline: Hyphenated Americans
fields.standfirst:
As Elian's ugly case shows, ethnic lobbies are the curse of the US

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: A lthough the old saying that hard cases make bad law might seem to apply to the case of Elian Gonzalez, it wasn't really so hard. The law held that he should be reunited with his father, that is what most Americans thought should be done and that is what has now happened. But the case leaves ugly scars, and it raises once again the question of what should be the rights - and responsibilities - of "hyphenated Americans". The boy would have joined his father in Cuba weeks ago if he hadn't become an emblem, or a pawn, for one of the most noisiest and most feared of such groups, the Cuban Americans.
fields.body:
A lthough the old saying that hard cases make bad law might seem to apply to the case of Elian Gonzalez, it wasn't really so hard. The law held that he should be reunited with his father, that is what most Americans thought should be done and that is what has now happened. But the case leaves ugly scars, and it raises once again the question of what should be the rights - and responsibilities - of "hyphenated Americans". The boy would have joined his father in Cuba weeks ago if he hadn't become an emblem, or a pawn, for one of the most noisiest and most feared of such groups, the Cuban Americans.

The United States is a land of immigrants, with complicated feelings towards their ancestral lands. It is also a free country where interest-group politics have always flourished, which does not mean that the effects of these groups or lobbies have been benign. To the contrary, the pressure exerted by the "hyphenates" has been almost unfailingly malign, for the American republic and for American people as a whole.

It is made worse by the cravenness of American politicians. In Of Thee I Sing, the Gershwin brothers' very funny 1931 musical satire on American politics, the campaign song goes, "He's the man the people choose,/Loves the Irish, loves the Jews." Real-life American polls have all too often taken this jest as a true word.

The US's emergence as a great power dates from the the first world war, which the country entered belatedly, and despite the wishes of many Americans. Tens of millions of German Americans obviously didn't want to fight against their fathers' fatherland. Millions of Irish Americans were scarcely keener to fight for the king of England, or millions of Jewish Americans for the tsar of all the Russias whose oppression most of them had fled. And indeed the US did not enter the war until after the 1917 February revolution and the fall of tsardom.

Then the fun began. Irish-American pressure led towards the creation of an Irish Free State. Whatever else may be said of this, it was by no means in the American national interest. During the second world war, the most important war the Americans ever fought, once they, again belatedly, entered it, that Irish state was sullenly neutral.

There has recently been much bitter criticism in America of Swiss neutrality during the war. Apart from the fact that Switzerland was surrounded by the Axis and had no choice between neutrality and annihilation, Swiss neutrality did no military harm to the Allied cause. By contrast, Irish neutrality delayed victory in the battle of the Atlantic and thus the defeat of Hitler, with all that implies.

After the Irish came the Czech Americans' turn. Largely thanks to them President Woodrow Wilson's 14 points included the 10th point: "The peoples of Austria-Hungary ... should be accorded the freest opportunity of autonomous development." From this light-hearted undertaking came the destruction of the Habsburg monarchy.

The rights and wrongs of that aren't simple, but it is worth noting that the allegedly national "successor state" of Czechoslovakia thereby called into being no longer exists. Nor does Yugoslavia, the other state invented after the great war.

No other hyphenated group has been as politically powerful as the Jewish-American lobby. Although Washington politicians may tremble at the phrase "the 40m Irish Americans", they tremble more before the numerically fewer Jewish Americans. The American-Israeli Public Affairs Committee has won a reputation as the most formidable, and often the most ruthless, of all such pressure groups. Having spent some little time looking into this subject, I would merely say that the activities of that lobby will one day come to be seen as not having served the true interests of the United States, of Jewish America, or even, in the end, of Israel.

The behaviour of Cuban America over Elian speaks for itself, and the lobby has anyway prevented a necessary rapprochement between the US and Cuba. What has been more shocking than the hysteria of Little Havana in Miami has been the fawning on the Cuban Americans by politicians, including both presidential candidates.

y et even that is trivial compared with what may prove to be the true "legacy" (in the president's favourite word) of the Clinton administration. The eastward expansion of Nato must rank, in a hotly contested field, as the craziest single piece of American statecraft since the invasion of Cambodia 30 years ago this week. After the end of the cold war, it has no good strategic or political justification but can only justifiably inflame Russian suspicions and means, strictly speaking, that we must go to war on behalf of Hungary in a border dispute with Slovakia.

Why has it happened? It was inspired partly by the president's desire to enrich what his wiser predecessor Eisenhower called the military-industrial complex, but more importantly by his ingratiating himself with ethnic lobbies. Historians will date Nato expansion to Clinton's grovelling to a Polish-American audience in Chicago.

Even if the politics of hyphenated- America didn't produce such sorry practical consequences, it would be an affront to the "American idea". In direct contrast to European nationalism, the concept of "the American nation" is not based on ethnicity. Unlike European nation states, the American republic is founded not on a people, but on a proposition. This ideal has often been neglected, to put it mildly, and it may not say much to many black Americans, but it is noble in inspiration. If only American politicians remembered that more often.

In between sucking up to Cuban Americans and claiming to have invented the internet, Vice-President Gore not long ago produced an exquisite howler. The country's motto is E pluribus unum, which means, he told his audience, "out of one, many". It was a true Freudian slip. He made a mistake, but in his ludicrous way he expressed a truth, about the fragmentation of America into all too many fractious and competitive components.

What the 18th-century creators of the American republic believed in was "out of many, one". One people would emerge from many different origins, sharing common creeds (that all men are created equal, entitled to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness), rather than common gene pools. What the 20th century has seen is a regression to the primitive atavistic group loyalties which the new country was meant to avoid.

More than a hundred years ago, a federal judge told an Irish-American agitator that any American was entitled to sentimental sympathies for another country, but that every American's first political duty must be to the United States. Someone should tell that to the mayor of Miami and to Al Gore.

fields.headline: Asylum backlog starts to clear
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The number of asylum seekers waiting for their cases to be processed has fallen by the largest amount since Labour came to power, figures today will reveal.
fields.body:
The number of asylum seekers waiting for their cases to be processed has fallen by the largest amount since Labour came to power, figures today will reveal.

After a record month of activity by Home Office immigration officials in March the number of outstanding asylum cases is likely to fall below 100,000, representing a decrease of about 3,000 cases.

Although 7,000 new cases were lodged last month, 10,000 cases were processed.

When Labour was elected in 1997 it inherited a backlog of about 50,000 cases, which had more than doubled to 104,890 by the beginning of this year.

A year ago the Home Office was clearing fewer than 2,000 cases a month as new asylum seekers were added to the list. This increased to 4,000 in January and 8,000 in February when new staff were appointed.

The fall will be a boost for Labour, after criticism from the Conservatives over alleged inaction on the asylum issue. The government will hope to use these figures to prove that they have the situation under control.

The Tories, sensing that public opinion has turned sharply against refugees have made the issue a major campaigning point in the next month's local election race. Tony Blair has attacked William Hague's willingness to use what many anti-racism campaigners consider to be dangerous language.

The Conservative leader caused outrage earlier this month when he said that under the Tories all asylum seekers in Britain would be locked in detention centres while their cases were processed.
