webTitle: Six children hurt in teenage shoot-out at Washington zoo

fields.headline: Six children hurt in teenage shoot-out at Washington zoo
fields.trailText:
Six children were wounded by gunfire at the national
zoo in Washington yesterday as a violent feud between
groups of teenagers turned one of America's most
visited landmarks into the scene of the country's latest
shooting outrage.
fields.body:
Six children were wounded by gunfire at the national zoo in Washington yesterday as a violent feud between groups of teenagers turned one of America's most visited landmarks into the scene of the country's latest shooting outrage.

A hospital spokesman at Washington children's hospital said that three of the victims involved were in critical condition.

A teenage boy was reported to have been shot in the head, said Brian Lee, a spokesman for the district of Columbia fire and emergency services. One girl was in a serious condition with a gunshot wound to the chest. A seventh victim, a pregnant woman, was taken to hospital after going into labour after the shooting broke out.

The zoo, which is part of the Smithsonian Institution group of national museums, was holding an African-American family celebration day at the time. The ethnic origin of the victims and the shooters was not clear from early reports.

As reports of the shooting broke, the street outside the zoo was rapidly filled with anxious parents and many small children who had been visiting the zoo.

Sandra Edwards, who was visiting the zoo with her grandchildren when she heard the shots and saw youths fighting, said: "I am not bringing them back. These are my grandkids. It is not safe."

Nakisha Johnson, 17, said she saw one young man open fire after a feud between youths became violent. She said the children who were wounded were caught in the middle of the two groups of young people. "He was just shooting at the people he was fighting," she said. But the bullets hit the children.

Other witnesses said the shooting occurred when a bottle was thrown from one group of youths to others. A piece of glass struck a young woman in the face, and then shots rang out, the witnesses said.

The city's mayor, Anthony Williams, went to the scene shortly after the incident and visited local hospitals expecting to take in casualties.

The annual African-American families day at Washington zoo has been a regular Easter event for the city's black community for more than a century.

The shootings come less than a week after the first anniversary of the Columbine high school shootings in Littleton, Colorado, in which two teenage boys shot 12 other students and a teacher dead before killing themselves, the worst teenage shooting incident in modern America.

Vice-President Al Gore announced the shootings at a Democratic party fundraising meeting in New York, bringing gasps from members of an audience that included the actress Lauren Bacall.

Mr Gore took the opportunity to press for tighter gun control laws of the kind at present being pushed by the Clinton administration but opposed by Republican leaders in Congress.

"We really have to have mandatory child safety trigger locks and photo licence IDs for the purchase of new handguns," Mr Gore told the crowd.

fields.headline: Switchboards face new numbers test
fields.trailText: Britain's telephone exchanges face their biggest test since the weekend's local phone number changes as millions of people return to work after the Easter break today.
fields.body:
Britain's telephone exchanges face their biggest test since the weekend's local phone number changes as millions of people return to work after the Easter break today.

Some estimates said as many as 60% of switchboards would be unable to recognise the codes introduced on Saturday.

Many businesses may not realise that their systems are not working because of the long bank holiday. Telecom companies are bracing themselves for potential chaos as people try to use the new numbers only to be told that they have dialled incorrectly.

A problem can strike companies using alternative network routing (ANR), which allows switchboards to choose between different telecom firms for local, national and international calls.

If the switchboard has not been reprogrammed to handle the new numbers, customers using the new numbers without the correct area code will not be able to get through.

Ed Townsend from The Big Number, the firm set up to handle the number change and co-ordinate the 40 telecom companies involved said: "This is not a network issue. It is an equipment issue which the phone companies cannot control. We have been alerting businesses to this and other equipment issues for 18 months. We know that many have taken action but fear that some have not."

Michael Dixon, chairman of the Telecoms Managers Association's numbering group, said: "Switched-on businesses, especially those with telecoms managers, should have eliminated the switchboard bug before or during Easter."

Numbers were changed in London, Cardiff, Coventry, Portsmouth, Southampton and Northern Ireland.

webTitle: Collie's stick puts owner in doghouse

fields.headline: Collie's stick puts owner in doghouse
fields.trailText: Teaching your dog to fetch a stick can be frustrating, but for one unlucky owner it led to a brush with the law.
fields.body:
Teaching your dog to fetch a stick can be frustrating, but for one unlucky owner it led to a brush with the law.

With tales of rural crime on the increase, the story of Bramble and the stolen stick is a cautionary tale for country dwellers.

Laura Bunday, 40, was out for a stroll with her collie in Stover country park, near Newton Abbot, Devon. When Bramble took a liking to a large stick, she thought nothing of loading it into the boot of her car and taking it home. But a park warden cried foul and called the police.

Officers traced her through her car registration, and she was warned that she had committed a criminal offence. She immediately returned the stick to the spot where she had found it, much to Bramble's disappointment.

Mrs Bunday, a sales assistant from Newton Abbot, said: "Bramble loved the stick so much I just put it in the boot without thinking. I never thought it would come to this."

Her furious husband Nick, 47, said the police action was farcical. "What a fuss over a 2ft piece of wood in a forest full of them. With all the fuss about rural police being undermanned, you would think that they would have better things to do."

A spokesman for Devon and Cornwall police said: "There is not a specific law against the theft of wood. But if it is on private property, and you take something without the landowner's permission, then it is theft."

webTitle: How ministers plan to make money out of jam tomorrow

fields.headline: How ministers plan to make money out of jam tomorrow
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Irate motorists caught in interminable traffic jams will take little comfort from knowing that the government may soon make money out of their misery.
fields.body:
Irate motorists caught in interminable traffic jams will take little comfort from knowing that the government may soon make money out of their misery.

The Department of the Environment is considering offering drivers its own version of the third way - out of the logjam and on to less clogged roads - at a price. Ministers are considering establishing a computerised traffic system to sell in-car information on traffic jams to motorists. A feasibility study has already been ordered.

The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, has acted after government concerns about private firms snatching the initiative and reaping the benefit of technological advances.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, recently saw, in Miami, a computerised in-car traffic jam "buster". He is said to have been enthusiastic about its robotic voices telling him to turn left or right to avoid the city's traffic mire.

But not all of Mr Prescott's ministerial colleagues are sold on the idea. Some fear the system may be addictive causing drivers to spend time pressing buttons, twiddling knobs and studying in-car displays to find the fastest routes, meanwhile neglecting road safety.

"We can hardly run a campaign to encourage people not to use handheld mobile phones when driving, if at the same time we are introducing complex and distracting gadgets in to cars," a source said.

Ministers are initially examining a radio data system to broadcast up-to-the-minute traffic information on specific roads, directly to cars. In-car information could also be provided via roadside sensors.

The government believes it is in a perfect position to provide the system, since the highways agency controls much of the traffic information via control centres across the country. The plan appears as an obscure reference in the Department of the Environment's annual report: "Clear accurate, timely and relevant information to drivers before and during a journey helps them to make the best use of the road networks.

"We are assessing systems to provide information 'in-vehicle' through communications between vehicles and roadside microwave beacons. We are looking at the business case for online in-vehicle information services and identifying the safety needs."

Ministers see political advantage in highlighting the study, since it can be sold as proof that the government is not anti-motorist or intent on driving cars off the road by leaving them stuck in their traffic jams.

They hope the scheme could compete with Trafficmaster, the highly profitable traffic information service that already offers a website enabling drivers to check for congestion on any main road, free of charge.

Those willing to pay Trafficmaster's monthly fee, starting from £2, can get automatic warnings about hold-ups on specified routes. The system also sends emails and relays text or voice messages to the mobiles of paying customers alerting them to problems occurring on their normal routes.

webTitle: Mobs turn fury on black farm workers

fields.headline: Mobs turn fury on black farm workers
fields.standfirst:
'They said we must die. They said this is Mugabe's country'

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Supporters of Zimbabwe's ruling party stepped up their terror campaign against the political opposition yesterday as they switched the target of their intimidation from white farmers to black farm labourers.
fields.body:
Supporters of Zimbabwe's ruling party stepped up their terror campaign against the political opposition yesterday as they switched the target of their intimidation from white farmers to black farm labourers.

Gangs of Zanu-PF supporters roamed the countryside burning houses, abducting workers and beating and burning anyone suspected of supporting the opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change.

Hopes that the return of white farmers to their properties and the intervention of police in land occupations at the weekend signalled a gradual return to normality were dashed as violence flared in rural areas, sparking an exodus of hundreds of farm workers.

Most bore physical evidence of having been brutally beaten by squatters. Several were in hospital in the provincial centre of Marondera, near where the first murder of a white farmer took place 10 days ago.

One farmer was seen taking about 10 workers, with bruises on their hands, legs and backs, to hospital in his pickup truck. "The trouble is that we are not in a position to help our workers," he said.

Ishmael Mutengiwa, a labourer from a farm 75 miles east of the capital, and his wife, Farirai, were both badly burned after a gang of self-styled war veterans burned down their home. Mr Mutengiwa suffered suffered severe burns to his hands while he struggled to open the front door, which was locked from the outside, and his wife's face was burned.

"We were sleeping... [they] put grass in the house and poured petrol and lit the fire," Mr Mutengiwa said. "They said we must die because we are MDC. They said this is Mugabe's country."

Another farm worker said he had been picked up by a gang of squatters on Sunday night and forced to join them: "They beat us and told us to follow them to the next farm. We were forced to beat our own friends."

A black foreman who was taken away in handcuffs on Sunday was still missing yesterday.

Though in some areas police followed the squatters without intervening, 60 miles north of the capital a farm manager, his girlfriend and another woman were freed after officers ordered 700 veterans to end a one-day siege of their farm.

Officers also escorted 45 farmers and their families back to to the Macheke district near Marondera yesterday morning. "They are taking an active role. "There has been a definite change in the last 48 hours," said Tim Henwood of the Commercial Farmers' Union.

Mike Moon, a farmer, said: "Pressure has eased off us and been transferred onto labour. There is constant beating of labourers every night. We are powerless to do anything."

The switch in tactics pointed to the growing desperation of President Mugabe and his party in the run-up to elections, which were due to be held some time next month but are now likely to be delayed. The targeting of black farm workers, who are among the most poorly paid in the country, means there is no longer any pretence that the wave of violence across Zimbabwe has been prompted by a desire for land or racial hatred.

Mr Mugabe has endorsed the land occupations, which have left five MDC activists, two white farmers and a policeman dead. Last week he branded white farmers "enemies of the state" for backing the MDC.

[they] put grass in the house and poured petrol and lit the fire," Mr Mutengiwa said. "They said we must die because we are MDC. They said this is Mugabe's country." Another farm worker said he had been picked up by a gang of squatters on Sunday night and forced to join them: "They beat us and told us to follow them to the next farm. We were forced to beat our own friends." A black foreman who was taken away in handcuffs on Sunday was still missing yesterday. Though in some areas police followed the squatters without intervening, 60 miles north of the capital a farm manager, his girlfriend and another woman were freed after officers ordered 700 veterans to end a one-day siege of their farm. Officers also escorted 45 farmers and their families back to to the Macheke district near Marondera yesterday morning. "They are taking an active role. "There has been a definite change in the last 48 hours," said Tim Henwood of the Commercial Farmers' Union. Mike Moon, a farmer, said: "Pressure has eased off us and been transferred onto labour. There is constant beating of labourers every night. We are powerless to do anything." The switch in tactics pointed to the growing desperation of President Mugabe and his party in the run-up to elections, which were due to be held some time next month but are now likely to be delayed. The targeting of black farm workers, who are among the most poorly paid in the country, means there is no longer any pretence that the wave of violence across Zimbabwe has been prompted by a desire for land or racial hatred. Mr Mugabe has endorsed the land occupations, which have left five MDC activists, two white farmers and a policeman dead. Last week he branded white farmers "enemies of the state" for backing the MDC.

webTitle: MPs investigate mounting crisis in car industry

fields.headline: MPs investigate mounting crisis in car industry
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The mounting crisis in Britain's car industry has prompted the Labour-controlled industry select committee to mount an emergency inquiry. Senior motor executives, including representatives from Ford, Honda and BMW, will be asked to give reassurances about their commitment to British-based car production.
fields.body:
The mounting crisis in Britain's car industry has prompted the Labour-controlled industry select committee to mount an emergency inquiry. Senior motor executives, including representatives from Ford, Honda and BMW, will be asked to give reassurances about their commitment to British-based car production.

The inquiry is expected to include a stiff cross examination of the Treasury over its refusal to ease the level of sterling down, a policy cited by the car manufacturers as one of the chief causes of the current over-capacity and job losses.

The inquiry is a further sign that Labour politicians are alarmed that the crisis heralds a wider downturn in British manufacturing.

Tony Blair has already intervened by meeting senior Ford executives over the company's threatened plan to end car production at Dagenham.

This week the industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will publish an interim report on the likely regional impact of BMW's plans to end mass car production at Longbridge.

Union leaders hope that ministers will use the report as a lever to persuade BMW's supervisory board to intervene on behalf of the Phoenix consortium led by the ex-Rover executive John Towers.

The Labour chairman of the industry select committee, Martin O'Neill, said the Longbridge crisis was "more than simply a German firm walking away from an old British asset. The fact is that 20m cars are being produced in a market that is only accepting 16m," he said. "We need urgently to find the reasons for the current problems, and the extent to which issues of sterling or productivity are to blame."

The committee will be asking Ford executives to give reasons for their rumoured plan to end car production at Dagenham, pointing out that the unions had made productivity concessions on the basis that the plants at Halewood and Dagenham would be safe.

Mr O'Neill said Labour MPs had been lobbying the chancellor, Gordon Brown, over the high value of sterling with no success.

The monetary policy committee, he insisted, should look at a wider range of targets than simply inflation.

In the short term the unions are concentrating on pressing BMW to give more time to the consortium led by Mr Towers.

Roger Lyons, the general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union, said nine of BMW's 20 supervisory board members were trade unionists.

"They have assured our representatives they will do everything within their power to ensure Mr Towers' bid is given every opportunity," he said.

The unions have complained that BMW is not providing the Phoenix consortium with the same time and information needed to make a formal bid against Alchemy, the venture capital company.

The risk for BMW is that Alchemy could abandon the Rover deal if it is forced to wait.

fields.headline: Scrap metal dealers on 'nuclear alert'
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: Scrap-metal dealers were warned to be vigilant last night after it emerged that two pieces of nuclear waste have been found in scrapyards in recent weeks.
fields.body:
Scrap-metal dealers were warned to be vigilant last night after it emerged that two pieces of nuclear waste have been found in scrapyards in recent weeks.

In one case a dealer discovered he had driven around for months with a block of radioactive uranium in his van.

Nicholas Rembrance stored the 20lb metal block in his vehicle after recovering it from a recycling skip at his yard in Lowestoft, Suffolk.

He said: "It was completely different from any metal I had seen before - it was incredibly heavy for such a small lump and it gave off sparks when I dropped it. I just chucked it in the back of my van and forgot all about it."

Mr Rembrance discovered what it was when he delivered a consignment of metal to a local scrapyard and a geiger counter on the weighbridge went berserk.

A chemical unit from Suffolk fire brigade sealed off the area and called in experts from nearby Sizewell nuclear power station. The metal has been identified as depleted uranium. Robin Thornton, a spokesman for Sizewell, said the 9kg block had probably been used as ballast.

In Tamworth, Staffordshire, over the weekend a uranium fuel rod was found in a scrapyard. It is believed it could have been there for more than a year.

A spokesman for the environment agency said: "When we find out who dumped this uranium they will be made responsible for its proper disposal and the agency will consider legal action."

webTitle: Meacher orders inquiry into illegal dumping

fields.headline: Meacher orders inquiry into illegal dumping
fields.standfirst: Landfill tax scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Meacher, the environment minister, has ordered an internal inquiry into the illegal dumping of millions of tonnes of waste in the countryside following the revelations by the Guardian and Channel 4 Dispatches programme earlier this month.
fields.body:
Michael Meacher, the environment minister, has ordered an internal inquiry into the illegal dumping of millions of tonnes of waste in the countryside following the revelations by the Guardian and Channel 4 Dispatches programme earlier this month.

The decision comes as the Guardian delivered a 30,000 word dossier to the minister revealing the background to the year-long investigation into the running of Britain's £1bn "green tax".

It calls on the authorities and parliament to investigate shortcomings and flaws in the law to stop the illegal dumping of waste and reform the landfill tax credit scheme which should have delivered £250m for community projects.

It says that widespread reform is needed to safeguard the health of the public from illegal dumping and make dramatic progress towards the recycling rather than dumping of rubbish.

The dossier, published today on the Guardian's website, reveals a disturbing picture of the operation of the tax and names local councils, trade associations and environmental bodies which should be investigated by the authorities for their stewardship of the tax.

It also gives the full background to the six investigations undertaken by Channel 4 and the Guardian into the illegal dumping of waste and the manipulation by waste companies of the tax credit schemes which were aimed to improve the local environment.

The report names golf courses and sporting facilities which have been used for dumping.

Other investigations revealed for the first time on the website include an examination of the handling of landfill tax money by Devon county council and an investigation into the refuse collection service in the south London borough of Wandsworth.

The website report poses a series of questions about the competence of Entrust, a private regulatory company, responsible for supervising the £250m given to environmental bodies.

It poses questions about a big serious fraud squad innvestigation into one of the environmental bodies, the Global Wildlife Trust.

The new tax was meant to make the polluter pay and give millions of pounds to save the environment.

Britain has the worst record in Western Europe for dumping rubbish in the ground and is the biggest laggard in recycling.

This report provides a snapshot into what is happening in Britain now.

Speaking at a House of Lords reception held by Onyx Environmental Trust, Mr Meacher said: "I want to assure you that the government takes very seriously any illegal dumping or abuse of the licensing exemptions.

"They are criminal offences with severe penalties including imprisonment.

"Likewise, I take very seriously any allegations of fraud concerning the credit scheme. I asked the journalists involved to supply me with any evidence they have uncovered, and I have assured them that any new allegations will be fully investigated."

Other copies of the report have gone to customs and excise, the audit commission, the national audit office and to the regulatory body, Entrust.

fields.headline: How suspects came to court
fields.standfirst: Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: Timeline
fields.body:
December 21 1988: Bomb on Pan Am Flight 103 from Heathrow to JFK, New York, explodes at 31,000ft, killing all 259 people on board and 11 on the ground as it crashes on Lockerbie

February 1991: After a 55-day inquiry, Sheriff Principal John Mowat QC finds that the tragedy was caused by a plastic explosive hidden in a radio-cassette player in a suitcase carried by Pan Am from Frankfurt to Heathrow before being transferred to Flight 103

November 14 1991: Warrants issued for the arrest of Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah

January 22 1992: UN resolution urges Libyan leader Colonel Gadafy to comply with suspects' extradition

April 15 1992: UN imposes embargo on air travel and arms sales after Libya refuses

January 1994: Robert Black, professor of law at Edinburgh University, and Ibrahim Legwell, then head of the Libyan defence team, propose a trial in the Hague by international judges. Rejected by British government

October 25 1997: Nelson Mandela asks Britain and US to accept trial in neutral state after meeting Jim Swire, father of one of the victims

August 24 1998: Britain and US agree trial can be held in neutral country. Col Gadafy agrees in principle

April 5 1999: Suspects are handed over in Tripoli and arrive in the Netherlands

fields.headline: Microsoft plunges $70bn
fields.standfirst: Rumours of break-up send share price tumblingThe future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft yesterday was on the brink of being stripped of its mantle as the world's most powerful computer software company, as rumours emerged that it could be split into three separate groups.
fields.body:
Microsoft yesterday was on the brink of being stripped of its mantle as the world's most powerful computer software company, as rumours emerged that it could be split into three separate groups.

American newspapers, including the Washington Post and Wall Street Journal, agreed that US regulators wanted Microsoft to be broken up to curb the software giant's monopoly of PC software and access to the internet. The papers quoted sources close to the US justice department saying the company should be broken into two or three parts.

The growing likelihood of a breakup alarmed Microsoft shareholders, who sent the company's shares plunging in early trading yesterday. They fell $13.38 to $65.56 (£41.52), wiping $70bn off the company's market value within minutes. Bill Gates, chairman of Microsoft and 15% shareholder, saw his fortune slide $10.4bn to $51.5bn.

It would be the first time since 1974 that the American justice department has forced a company to sell parts of its business because its size has made it anti-competitive. In 1974 telephone giant AT&T was forced to demerge divisions of its company.

The reports said the plan was to break up Microsoft along its product lines, which would see it forced to spin off the hugely successful Windows operating system. But the software functions that al low users to browse the internet could possibly be kept with the Windows company.

Microsoft's decision to integrate its internet browser software, Explorer, with Windows 95 sparked the first accusations that the company was abusing its effective monopoly of the PC operating system market. Microsoft has vowed to appeal against a federal court ruling earlier this month which supported claims that it had violated competition laws.

The court also found that Microsoft had used its dominance of the software applications market, such as word proces sors and other programmes, to protect its monopoly in the operating system market.

Microsoft's software applications arm may become a stand-alone company as well as a separate Microsoft internet group that would include Microsoft Network, the company's internet service provider and web portal.

The case against Microsoft has been in the courts for the past two years. The company argued that a breakup is not in the interest of the industry or its customers. Yesterday, a Microsoft spokesman said: "The department of justice has un til April 28 to submit its remedies to the court and Microsoft has until May 10 to respond. We are confident the judicial system will rule that Microsoft's innovation is good for consumers and good for the computer industry."

Steve Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, has said the company is still open to a possible settlement.

The decline in Microsoft shares was also driven by the release last Thursday of the company's third-quarter results, which disclosed revenue that was below analysts' expectations. The revenues were up 23% to £5.66bn, but analysts had been looking for £5.9bn. Failure to meet the expectations was blamed on slower sales in PCs to the corporate market.

George Gilbert, an analyst with the Northern Trust technology fund in Chicago, said yesterday: "The combination of the earnings figures and the anti-trust news I suspect is keeping buyers of Microsoft at bay. The earnings conference call on Thursday night was about as sombre as any [it] has held. This is the third time in the last four years they have tried to tone down estimates for the final-quarter."

webTitle: RAF 'nearly ran out of bombs' in Kosovo

fields.headline: RAF 'nearly ran out of bombs' in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The beleaguered Ministry of Defence came under renewed fire yesterday after a leaked report from an independent Commons watchdog revealed that the RAF came close to running out of bombs during the Kosovo war and British soldiers were provided with a key drug which was past its sell-by date.
fields.body:
The beleaguered Ministry of Defence came under renewed fire yesterday after a leaked report from an independent Commons watchdog revealed that the RAF came close to running out of bombs during the Kosovo war and British soldiers were provided with a key drug which was past its sell-by date.

RAF bombers faced the prospect of "a critical" shortage of weapons and suffered from an acute lack of spare parts, according to a draft report from the national audit office on problems facing the armed forces ranging from ammunition to toilets.

The report, leaked to BBC Radio 4's Today programme, echoes criticism about inadequate equipment made earlier this year by senior British commanders engaged in the Kosovo operation.

"The rate of consumption of munitions was such that munition stocks were only just adequate," said the report. "Had the air campaign continued it would quickly have exhausted munitions stocks in a number of areas."

The report also detailed problems with fuselage-mounted missiles on Royal Navy Harriers that suffered from proximity to heat and vibration during take-off and were so troublesome that within two months of the 78-day bombing campaign over half the missile stocks were unserviceable.

British aircraft dropped over 1,000 weapons during Nato's air assault on Serbia, including 531 cluster bombs.

The report said the MoD failed to learn lessons from Bosnia over the need for secure communications. At times, the only functioning communications available were civilian mobile phones and satphones with the result that the 4th armoured brigade had to compete with others, including the media, to get "on air".

The report pointed to some improvements. It said food for British troops was "of high quality and good variety".

But it said there were insufficient chefs, a shortage of portable toilets, and that legs of 10,000 new camp beds bought by the MoD were prone to collapse.

There was a shortage of signals personnel, logistics experts, and medical staff, leading to what the NAO describes as "an adverse implication for morale and retention".

It said that while there were "vast surpluses" of some medical stores - for example, 47 years' supply of ampicillin injectors - the MoD sent 6,000 "morphine autojets" to the Balkans in March 1999 with a shelf life lasting until April 1999.

The report revealed that the MoD estimates the Kosovo operation will have cost it £810m by the year 2003, though this excludes the cost of replacing some categories of weapons.

Despite their problems, the success of British peacekeeping troops in Kosovo was a "testament to [their] professionalism and commitment", the report said.

However, it raises further questions about the ability of Britain's armed forces to conduct the kind of expeditionary operations emphasised in the 1998 strategic defence review.

Menzies Campbell, Liberal Democrat foreign affairs and defence spokesman said yesterday that the report, if published in the same form, would be "extremely disturbing".

Shadow defence secretary Iain Duncan Smith said soldiers had complained of a "just in time" supply system.

He said: "You either have to say we can do fewer things and we want to do those things we do well, or you have to say we need to spend more money."

An MoD spokesman said: "Kosovo remains a very successful campaign which met all its objectives without a single combat casualty.

"Overall the report is very positive about the British performance and about how the lessons of previous campaigns have been learned."

Under fire: Front line failures

Bureaucratic incompetence, budget constraints and procurement failings lie behind the shortcomings suffered by the armed forces during the Kosovo war identified in the leaked national audit office report.

Weapons systems

"Having deployed 16 Tornado GRI aircraft and 12 Harrier GR7 aircraft, the UK faced the prospect of a critical munitions shortage.

"RN [navy] Harrier aircraft flew with fuselage-mounted missiles which suffered from proximity to heat and vibration during take-off and recovery. Within two months over half the missile stocks were unserviceable ... there were shortages of spares for some aircraft."

Communications

"HQ3 Division commented that the Department [Ministry of Defence] had not learned lessons from Bosnia.

"Armoured Brigade: at times, the only functioning communication systems were civilian mobile phones and satphones and the brigade had to compete with others for their use. At the tactical level, communications using the ageing Clansman system were insecure and the Serbs, KLA and the media regularly monitored local communications."

Accommodation

"There was a serious shortage of portable toilets - the ratio of personnel to toilets exceeded 50 and compared poorly with other nations' forces.

"The MoD bought 10,000 new camp beds at a cost of £24 each ... we found that the legs of many of the beds had collapsed. At one unit we visited 24% of the beds had broken within one month of the unit arriving in theatre."

Good points

The standard of field accommodation had been "substantially improved", food was "of high quality and good variety" and soldiers "were pleased with the quality of their new combat uniform".

The report concludes the campaign had been a success and praised "the professionalism and commitment of our armed forces".

Accommodation "There was a serious shortage of portable toilets - the ratio of personnel to toilets exceeded 50 and compared poorly with other nations' forces. "The MoD bought 10,000 new camp beds at a cost of £24 each ... we found that the legs of many of the beds had collapsed. At one unit we visited 24% of the beds had broken within one month of the unit arriving in theatre." Good points The standard of field accommodation had been "substantially improved", food was "of high quality and good variety" and soldiers "were pleased with the quality of their new combat uniform". The report concludes the campaign had been a success and praised "the professionalism and commitment of our armed forces".

webTitle: World's gaze turns to Camp Zeist

fields.headline: World's gaze turns to Camp Zeist
fields.standfirst:
A sleepy Dutch town is the setting for the biggest mass murder trial in Scottish history
Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: On the high street of the Dutch town there is barely a hint of what is going on a few miles away. The only reference to Scotland comes in the form of shop window displays advertising McGregor's clothing. Yet just outside Zeist a saltire flutters and, a week tomorrow, the biggest mass murder trial in Scottish legal history is to begin there.
fields.body:
On the high street of the Dutch town there is barely a hint of what is going on a few miles away. The only reference to Scotland comes in the form of shop window displays advertising McGregor's clothing. Yet just outside Zeist a saltire flutters and, a week tomorrow, the biggest mass murder trial in Scottish legal history is to begin there.

It has been a long time coming. Since Pan Am Flight 103 fell from the skies over the previously anonymous town of Lockerbie on December 21 1988, the families of the 270 people who died have been fighting for a trial. After years of international sanctions and diplomatic manoeuvring, the Libyan bombing suspects Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah will finally begin answering the case against them next Wednesday, May 3, in front of three Scottish judges.

The logistics of staging the world's highest security trial - scheduled to last at least a year - have been as intricate as the trial will be complex. In nine months a former US barracks at the Soesterberg military airport has been converted into a prison, courthouse and international media facility.

Since the suspects arrived at Camp Zeist last April, the town of Zeist, set in woodland 18 miles from Amsterdam, has grad ually become used to the Celtic cuckoo in its nest. The 100-acre site is to remain Scottish soil until the end of the trial.

"There was a lot of excitement when the Libyans were brought here," says Rene van Zanten, editor in chief of Utrechts Nieuwsblad, the region's main newspaper. "It really was the talk of the town for months and now, with the trial so close, interest is going up again. Zeist has a reputation for being a quiet place with lots of rich people: it is not used to so much attention."

But attention is coming en masse. The town's main hotel has been booked out for months, and with around 1,000 reporters, cameramen and photographers expected for the opening day of evidence, rooms even in the nearby city of Utrecht are almost impossible to come by.

For the victims' relatives who want to attend the trial, accommodation is posing a real problem. Although the US justice department has agreed to foot the bill for each of the American relative's flights and accommodation for two weeks, there is no support for families wanting to spend longer in Zeist.

In the wake of the bombing an international appeal raised $2m (£1.25m), but in 1991 the trust fund was wound up. Its remaining assets - around $250,000 - were signed over to another trust whose deeds state that the money can only be spent in Lockerbie, so the victims' families cannot get access to the money raised in the name of their dead relatives to travel to Camp Zeist.

Financial worries
For Jim Swire, the head of UK Families Flight 103 whose daughter died in the crash, this means he will receive no financial support to attend the trial, even though he plans to give up his job as a GP.

"A group of us have found a flat in Zeist and we have taken on the lease of that for a year," he says. "Kind Dutch friends are currently painting and decorating it.

"I don't wish to sound as if I am beg ging, but at the moment we are having to pay for it ourselves and it is very difficult."

On site, £12m has been spent constructing secure accommodation for the suspects and converting the air base. Since they were extradited from Tripoli in March last year the Libyans have been guarded by Scottish prison and police officers. The bomb- and tank-proof jail in which they will stay for the duration of the trial has just been completed.

It has 4ft thick walls and laser sensors, but the remand prisoners are also afforded a hint of custodial luxury: they have their own chef flown over from Libya and there is an accommodation wing where the suspects can receive relatives. For the 200 police officers and prison guards who are working at Zeist, there is a gymnasium, tennis court, football pitch, canteen, recreation room and satellite television to keep them entertained.

Security scrutiny
Yet under the cosy touches of home there can be no mistaking how seriously the international community is taking this trial. Everyone employed on the site - from cleaner through to court usher - has been cleared by British and Dutch intelligence services. When the Libyans walk through underground tunnels to sit in the specially constructed dock, they will be in one of the most secure, hi-tech and costly courthouses ever built.

The defendants will answer charges of murder, conspiracy to murder and contravening the 1982 Aviation Security Act from behind bulletproof glass. Banks of video screens sit on the benches and, throughout the trial, the Libyans will don headsets to receive simultaneous translation of the proceedings. When non-English speaking witnesses take the stand the judges and lawyers will also have to don headsets - and these have been designed to fit over their horse-hair wigs.

From the public gallery the proceedings will be watched by eight UN observers, up to 250 members of the public, and as many press as it is possible to fit in. Although anyone can, in theory, attend the trial, relatives will be given priority and everyone will be subject to airport-style security checks.

Despite protestations by the BBC and US television networks, there will be no live broadcast of the trial. But for those relatives who cannot make it to Camp Zeist the proceedings will be relayed to viewing centres in government buildings in New York, Washington, London and Dumfries. For the legion of reporters who will be unable to make it into the court, there is a media centre equipped with screens and headsets.

None of this comes cheap. The capital costs of the trial, which are being met by the Treasury, have reached £12.9m, and the running costs have hit £21.9m. It costs £2m a month to run Camp Zeist and this figure is expected to increase dramatically when the trial gets under way. The final bill will total at least £100m and, although the US has said it will help with any costs over and above those it would have taken to run the trial in Scotland, so far it has contributed only £4.77m. The bulk of the money - around 80% - will come from UK reserves, with the burden of the remaining 20% falling on the Scottish executive.

These figures are only estimates and the costs could rise further still. The trial could run for much longer than a year. The prosecution witness list is understood to run to more than 1,000 names, alongside 1,500 documents and 550 articles of evidence. The defence list may be similarly lengthy. And, in the event of a conviction, an appeal before five other Scottish judges in the Netherlands would push demands on time and money even higher.

But time and expense is, for the families of the 270 people who died - 259 on board the Pan Am flight and 11 Lockerbie residents - an irrelevance. May 3 is a date they thought they would never see.

Long wait
But beyond the years of diplomatic wrangling and the staggering logistics of staging the trial there is at last the opportunity to properly scrutinise the piles of evidence. The families will finally hear in detail the circumstances surrounding their loved ones' deaths. And there will be the opportunity, whatever the verdict, for the families to have their questions answered.

"In a sense, the verdict here is almost not the important thing," says Dr Swire.

"Whenever we have pushed for an inquiry or other such thing we were told we couldn't have it because criminal proceedings were pending. In perhaps a year the proceedings will be over, we will have a verdict and we will also be able to get to the truth about many other things - from the failure of airport security to the failure of British intelligence."

fields.headline: Minister denies NHS cash confusion
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The health minister, John Hutton, yesterday denied the government did not know how to spend the large injection of cash into the NHS as he defended plans for public consultation on the future of the health service.
fields.body:
The health minister, John Hutton, yesterday denied the government did not know how to spend the large injection of cash into the NHS as he defended plans for public consultation on the future of the health service.

Mr Hutton gave further details of the consultation announced by Tony Blair and health secretary Alan Milburn.

From next month, the government will launch an advertising campaign, an internet site and telephone lines seeking public views on the NHS. The consultation will end in July when the government's three-year comprehensive spending review is announced and a four year plan for the NHS is set out.

Opposition politicians doubted whether Mr Milburn had an open mind over his plans to reform the NHS, saying in reality most of the re forms would be initiated by civil servants and the six expert groups appointed by him.

British Medical Association sources fear Mr Milburn plans to use the consultation as a lever with which to put pressure on GPs to open their surgeries for longer.

A BMA spokesman said: "It is an excellent idea that the public are going to be asked about their views for changes to the NHS but it is important to recognise that the public's wishes for greater access to doctors around the clock would require considerable extra staffing."

Mike Stone, director of the Patients Association, said he was worried this was a government just looking for stories for the sake of stories.

Ministers are focusing on better training, an external inspectorate and greater use of technology such as smart cards, containing patients' medical records.

fields.headline: Marching orders:  Ulster 'apartheid' criticised
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Loyalist marchers in Northern Ireland, who were prevented from entering a Catholic area yesterday, criticised what they called attempts to negotiate apartheid in the province.
fields.body:
Loyalist marchers in Northern Ireland, who were prevented from entering a Catholic area yesterday, criticised what they called attempts to negotiate apartheid in the province.

A letter of protest was handed over to police in south Belfast as members of the Apprentice Boys order arrived at the Ormeau bridge leading to the nationalist Lower Ormeau Road.

A handful of police had placed barriers across the road, enforcing a ban imposed by the Parades Commission after opposition from a residents' group.

The main Apprentice Boys demonstration, at which 3,000 demonstrators were expected, was taking place in Tobermore, County Londonderry, but the feeder march, by the Belfast Walker Club, took place earlier.

Club spokesman Tommy Cheevers said: "We are prepared to enter into a further process but not to negotiate apartheid between these communities. A little bit of tolerance is all we are asking for."

The Easter Monday demonstration, which begins the marching season, has been kept away from the Lower Ormeau Road for several years.

Yesterday's ban was enforced as Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern gave a speech commemorating the 1916 Easter Rising in Dublin. He said: "The openness, transparency and accountability required by citizens in any modern society is not compatible with undercover armies not properly amenable to democratic control, who retain the power to hold up or frustrate political progress."

fields.headline: Prescott fights air traffic rebels
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott has decided to tackle backbench rebels head on over his plans to part privatise national air traffic control.
fields.body:
John Prescott has decided to tackle backbench rebels head on over his plans to part privatise national air traffic control.

He is sending all Labour MPs a letter showing that most air traffic in Britain is already handled by private firms.

The rebels claim that the £1bn part privatisation of the national air traffic service (Nats) will put passenger safety at risk.

Mr Prescott, deputy prime minister and secretary for the environment, transport and the regions, has been angered by a report from the Labour-controlled Commons transport select committee criticising his proposed public-private partnership as the worst possible option.

He is equally angry that Labour rebels have been claiming the support of as many as 100 backbenchers.

Figures he produced yesterday show that most aircraft movements are overseen by commercial contracts.

In 1998 1.9m movements, more than half the total for UK airports, occurred at airports where air traffic control is not provided by Nats. Many of these airports are run by municipal councils, with contracts given to private companies.

Mr Prescott said: "There has been a misapprehension that somehow Nats controls everything in this country. It does not. To claim that airports like Leeds or East Midlands or Southampton are dangerous because they are not run by Nats is a nonsense.

"It has been a central tenet of my critics' argument that if air traffic control is run commercially it must be less safe. That is not the case. In Britain 50% of the flights are controlled by somebody other than Nats.

"Nobody thinks the air above towns like Leeds has been sold off to the private sector."

He also claimed that the forthcoming EU open skies policy meant that the number of separate air traffic control systems in Europe was likely to fall from 49 at present to around five.

A part privatised Nats would be in an ideal position to bid for these contracts, he said.

He also claimed that it was fraudulent to suggest that he was facing a huge rebellion over the issue in a fortnight's time, when the transport bill covering the part privatisation returns to the Commons for its final stages.

He said the 100 or so "rebel" MPs, not all Labour, had only urged him to publish his response to the select committee report before the Commons debate, a pledge he had met.

Privately Labour whips expect the rebellion figures to be no higher than 40 Labour backbenchers.

Mr Prescott will meet all Labour MPs on May 3 to discuss the part privatisation.

webTitle: £120m stadium to be built next to incinerator

fields.headline: £120m stadium to be built next to incinerator
fields.trailText: Athletes coming to Britain to compete in the 2005 world championships will be in danger of damaging their health by breathing in noxious fumes from the country's largest incinerator, according to documents obtained by the Guardian.
fields.body:
Athletes coming to Britain to compete in the 2005 world championships will be in danger of damaging their health by breathing in noxious fumes from the country's largest incinerator, according to documents obtained by the Guardian.

They show that the rushed scheme to build a £120m athletics stadium at Pickett's Lock in Edmonton, north London, does not appear to have taken account of a controversial plan to expand Britain's biggest waste-burning incinerator nearby.

The expansion has been given the go-ahead by Nick Raynsford, the minister for London, and is now on the desk of Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, for final approval.

The proposal was given initial approval before UK Athletics and Sport England, with the backing of Chris Smith, the culture and sports secretary, put forward the plan for the new sports ground.

The stadium could also be the venue for the 2012 Olympics and a new stadium for Tottenham Hotspur Football Club.

An environmental impact study commissioned by London Waste, the company seeking to expand the incinerator, reveals that emissions from a new chimney will be concentrated on the very area where the stadium is to be built.

According to the report most prevailing winds in the area come from the south-west, blowing the plume from the bigger incinerator straight on to the stadium site in the Lee Valley country park.

"As the distance from the stack increases, the ground level concentration rises to a maximum and then falls away," the report says. "Depending on the wind speed, the point of maximum impact will lie some where between 500 metres and 2,000 metres from the stack."

It goes on: "The location of this point of maximum impact is approximately 1,200 metres to the north-east of the plant, or in the William Girling reservoir." This is alongside the stadium site.

Alan Watson, a scientist and environmental consultant from Public Interest Consultants in Swansea, told the Guardian: "The emissions known as NOx - or nitrate oxides similar to car exhausts - are the most likely to irritate the lungs or aggravate asthmatic conditions.

"If you are an athlete you are taking large lung fulls of air through your respiratory system. I find it absolutely incredible that anybody would think of putting an athletics stadium near a big incinerator.

"If I was an athlete I would have grave reservations about running there."

A spokeswoman for UK Athletics said: "What athletes do need is lots of fresh air. We hope this is not going to cause any controversy like the huge row over athletes running in Los Angeles because of the smog."

Nicky Gavron, Labour's leading candidate for the Greater London authority, last night called on Mr Byers to postpone any decision giving approval to expand the incinerator: "This should be a matter for the London mayor. The incinerator must not be expanded if it imperils the new stadium."

Chris Smith's office admitted it did not know about the plans for the incinerator and the department distanced itself from the scheme. It said it was the responsibility of Sport England, UK Athletics, and the government office for London.

Sport England said the matter was the responsibility for the Lee Valley country park. An official from Lee Valley country park said the park's management had sought assurances from London Waste about the effect of the new chimney but had not read the environmental impact study.

Only Enfield council, which backed the incinerator plan, said it was satisfied that the emissions should be safe - but added that this was as long as they were strictly monitored.

London Waste issued a statement through its public relations consultant, Spurgeon Walker. This said: "The proposed plant extension is being designed to meet stringent criteria and will therefore pose no threat to the environment or human health."

On emissions from the stack it said: "The results show that there will be insignificant change in the current levels of pollutants in London."

This said: "The proposed plant extension is being designed to meet stringent criteria and will therefore pose no threat to the environment or human health." On emissions from the stack it said: "The results show that there will be insignificant change in the current levels of pollutants in London."

fields.headline: Teachers' chief slates elitist Blair
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A teachers' leader yesterday launched a blistering personal attack on Tony Blair claiming he was systematically "dismantling' the comprehensive schools system by building on elitist education policies introduced by the Tories.
fields.body:
A teachers' leader yesterday launched a blistering personal attack on Tony Blair claiming he was systematically "dismantling' the comprehensive schools system by building on elitist education policies introduced by the Tories.

Martin Johnson, the incoming president of the National Association of Schoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers and a man considered a moderate, accused the prime minister of being completely out of touch with the needs of ordinary schools, and of strengthening academic selection beyond the surviving grammar school sector.

Attacking him as "bourgeois", he reignited the debate over Mr Blair's decision to send his two sons to a school outside his family's home borough, saying that local schools would have been just as good.

In his opening address to the union's annual conference in Llandudno, north Wales, Mr Johnson singled out Mr Blair, rather than his education secretary, David Blunkett, for creating a hierarchical structure whereby some schools, such as so-called specialist and beacon schools, receive more funding than others.

Specialist schools, for example, receive extra government cash to fund specialist teaching in a range of subjects, including arts, science, sports and media, and are allowed to select up to 10% of their pupils according to aptitude. This is helping to encourage academic selection by stealth, Mr Johnson told delegates.

"Grammar schools are not the only problem. The promotion of Tory innovations such as beacon schools and specialist schools... threatens to undermine the whole comprehensive secondary school system, a system... now being dismantled."

Mr Blunkett has famously pledged "no more selection" but was recently forced to clarify the government's policy on selection and the fate of grammar schools, which is being left up to parents to decide.

Making deliberate reference to Mr Blair's decision to send his two sons to a top-performing state school outside their original home borough of Islington, Mr Johnson said that the gap between good and poor state schools was being widened under Labour.

"The government causes a quite unequal distribution of available potential, and then lauds the schools which received great potential and converted it, and assaults with complete brutality the schools which received little potential and converted that.

"This might be the policy of a Tory prime minister; it is certainly the policy of a bourgeois prime minister. A prime minister with absolutely no understanding of how ordinary schools work... who unlike his secretary of state does not even realise that his own children's potential would have been fulfilled quite adequately in his local secondary schools."

Stating his union's policy of unequivocal opposition to academic selection, Mr Johnson said he regretted that under Labour it was systematically being strengthened.

"We are back to selection, a more subtle form of selection, a selection which brings in the marvels and mysteries of the middle class housing market, a selection which may be by the parents, is more likely to be by the school, and certainly is nothing to do with establishing an intake which reflects the whole community served by the school."

He said the union opposed "the expansion of a structure of differentiated secondary schools as inequitable and damaging to teachers and pupils alike".

The conference is the only one being addressed this Easter by Mr Blunkett, who in his speech tomorrow is expected to announce £500m of funding for "sin bins" for disruptive pupils.

Some delegates were surprised by the tone of the attack on Mr Blair. Mr Johnson has taught in some of London's most challenging schools and is the author of an acclaimed book, Failing School, Failing City. He recently appeared with the chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, at the launch of an Ofsted report on inner-city schools.

A spokesman for the Department for Education and Employment yesterday dismissed the claim that comprehensive education was being dismantled. "We want all schools to be centres of excellence", he said. "That is why we give beacon schools and specialist schools extra help so they can spread their expertise to other local schools."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Father charged with murder
A roofer, James Lawson, 51, appeared in court yesterday charged with murdering his 22-year-old daughter, Sarah, at their home in Worthing on Saturday, the day after she had been discharged from a psychiatric unit.
fields.body:
Father charged with murder
A roofer, James Lawson, 51, appeared in court yesterday charged with murdering his 22-year-old daughter, Sarah, at their home in Worthing on Saturday, the day after she had been discharged from a psychiatric unit.

Her boyfriend, Dave Ripley, 23, was bound over to keep the peace for a year by Worthing magistrates after a breach of the peace following news of her death.

Blair words for Irish symphony
Excerpts from peace speeches made by Tony Blair, Bertie Ahern, Bill Clinton and the former Northern Ireland secretary Mo Mowlam will be used in a symphony.

The words are intertwined with choral symphonic music in a work by the Irish composer Philip Carty called Path to Peace. It will be distributed to every school in the Irish Republic this week.

Climbers killed in fall named
Two climbers, who fell 400ft to their deaths on Sunday on the 3,352ft Buachaille Etive Mor, in Glencoe, were named yesterday as Andrew Pritchard, 28, a computer consultant, from Tamworth, Staffordshire, and Andrew MacKenzie, 34, a manager from London.

Plea to mother of 'hedge' baby
South Yorkshire police appealed yesterday to a mother to come forward after a 9lb 11oz boy was found crying and wrapped in a tea towel under a hedge in Rotherham, south Yorkshire, on Sunday, hours after being born.

The baby is being cared for at Rotherham district general hospital and is reported to be healthy.

fields.headline: Jobs toll 'eroding Labour support'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's campaign to win back Labour voters will be dealt a fresh blow today when a survey by the GMB union shows that 250,000 manufacturing jobs have been lost since the election in 1997.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's campaign to win back Labour voters will be dealt a fresh blow today when a survey by the GMB union shows that 250,000 manufacturing jobs have been lost since the election in 1997.

Amid warnings that the prime minister is presiding over the worst crisis in manufacturing since the "darkest days" of Margaret Thatcher, the survey found nearly 30,000 jobs have been lost this year. John Edmonds, the GMB leader, called on Mr Blair to "wake up and smell the coffee" or risk a revolt in Labour's heartlands.

"British industry is not facing an inflation crisis or a sterling crisis, it is facing a manufacturing crisis on a scale not seen since the darkest days of Thatcherism," said Mr Edmonds. "Unless action is taken to ease the pressure on manufacturers, the consequences for this government will be dire."

The GMB's "manufacturing watch" shows a dramatic fall in jobs: 221,428 lost since December 1997, with 55,480 in the last year and 28,222 so far this year. It also cast doubt on the prime minister's claim that talk of a north-south divide is overblown: just over a quarter of the job losses, 55,737, were in the south, while 79,239 were in the north of England.

The decline means that well below a fifth (16.5%) of the workforce is in manufacturing, down more than 2 percentage points since 1996. "Thousands of jobs are being lost every week in the very heartland areas that the Labour Party is supposed to be cultivating in the run up to the next election," Mr Edmonds said. "Jobs are being lost across the board from shipping, car manufacturing and textile industries," one GMB source said.

The union also wants ministers to step up preparations for British membership of the euro, because businesses are being devastated by the strength of the pound. It also wants members of the Bank of England committee which sets interest rates to include manufacturers, who would be wary of raising the cost of borrowing.

The survey will be an irritation to Downing Street, which is basking in the glow of record levels of employment. Figures last week showed unemployment had dropped to a 20-year low of 1.1m, allowing Gordon Brown to boast that he could be the first chancellor in decades to preside over full employment.

Last night the government dismissed the call for lower interest rates. One source said Mr Edmonds had not learnt the lessons of the early 1990s, when 1m manufacturing jobs were lost after the Tories followed such action, provoking a "boom and bust" cycle.

A spokesman for the Department of Trade and Industry said: "We appreciate that certain sectors of manufacturing are going through difficult times. However, an artificial devaluation of sterling will not be a lasting solution.

"It is also worth bearing in mind that sterling has remained at the same level as the dollar for the last five years. It is the relative weakness of the European currencies that is causing problems."

Peterlee struggles to cope with factory closures

Peterlee in Durham has one of the biggest job haemorrhages according to a survey by the GMB union.

When Dewhirst's Menswear was dropped from Marks and Spencer's suppliers' list this year, the company shut all three of its factories in the new town built in the 1960s to bring work to east Durham ahead of the retreat of coal.

The closures in March destroyed 850 jobs and kicked away a prop of the 15,000-strong community which had seemed unshakeable to seamstresses like Joyce Lake, 42, who had been with Dewhirst's for half her lifetime. "We all thought we had jobs for life," she said. "Peterlee's not a big place, and it's going to be very hard to recover from losing this many jobs in one go."

Worse was to follow, particularly for those of her colleagues who found similar work 25 minutes south of Peterlee at Bentwood's, another M&S supplier specialising in making fleeces. Three days before the women were due to start, Bentwood's announced it was closing too; the fleece contract had been lost, and a new one for M&S underwear was not "suited to the staff's skills".

The company admitted that much of its Y-front and boxer-short work would be sub-contracted overseas.

GMB regional officer Maxine Bartholomew said: "One of the worst things is that these were mostly women's jobs, and a lot of the women who held them were the breadwinners for their families. A lot of them provided the only money going into their homes."

Male unemployment in Peterlee for the over-40s has become a fact of life.

The biggest help to the town is a public sector affair, with work due to start shortly on new fire and police stations and a magistrates court. All three institutions have been kept busy by the youth crime that comes with unemployment. The town is getting the three new buildings free, as part of a £6.2m land swap that makes room for an Asda supermarket.

Peterlee is attracting a new sort of work - selling services over the phone. Orange has added 540 posts to its customer services centre there, and last week a telemarketing firm, Virtutel, announced 450 call centre jobs.

 Martin Wainwright

fields.headline: Pokemon cards 'exploit children'
fields.trailText: David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, yesterday accused the manufacturers of Pokemon cards of using sales tactics which trade on children's obsessions.
fields.body:
David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, yesterday accused the manufacturers of Pokemon cards of using sales tactics which trade on children's obsessions.

The craze of collecting the cards, which depict fantasy monsters, has swept Britain's playgrounds, generating sales of £140m in the past six months.

Some of the rarer cards have been changing hands in schoolyards for £25 each.

Many schools have banned the cards after instances of bullying among children trying to obtain the rarer cards.

Mr Hart accused the company of restricting the number of rare cards issued. Speaking on Radio 4's The World At One, he said: "What is happening is the people who are marketing them are holding certain cards so they become rarer and rarer.

"I gather 151 cards make up the set. Children appear to be willing to do all sorts of things in order to get hold of them.

"I actually think they are acting irresponsibly in terms of their marketing. I think manufacturers are trading on the children's obsessions."

In the past few weeks there have been a number of alarming cases where youngsters have been mugged for their Pokemon cards. In one incident in Hull at the weekend, two children aged 12 and eight were robbed at knifepoint by two older boys. A similar attack in Ramsgate, Kent, saw two teenagers attacked by a gang of six youths in a dispute over cards.

The attacks have led police to warn parents of the dangers of allowing their children to carry valuable cards around with them.

Mr Hart said teachers were having to cope with the more sinister consequences of this latest craze.

He suggested the price of the cards was also a factor in the recent spate of attacks. A starter pack of 60 cards retails at £7.25.

Mr Hart said: "They are just outside the sort of money that a child might get for pocket money and that is leading to children fighting each other for them and these extreme incidents such as knifing and stabbing of young children."

But a spokesperson for Wizards of Coast UK, the manufacturers, defended the craze as an aid to social interaction.

The company expressed "extreme concern" at the attacks and in response has set up a Pokemon trading card game league which it claims provides a "controlled, supervised environment for children to play, collect and swap cards".

The Pokemon phenomenon began life four years ago as a Japanese electronic game. Since then it has boomed into a multi-million pound empire boasting collectors' cards, computer games, soft toys and plastic figures.

fields.headline: Just look at that sound
fields.standfirst: David Toop on his fusion of art and noise at the Hayward Gallery
fields.trailText: David Toop on his fusion of art and noise at the Hayward Gallery
fields.body:
Something strange has been happening to music in recent years. Let's call it the sonic boom. In January I found myself in a compact gallery in Tokyo, squashed into the space left available by an audience of youthfully interesting haircuts and precipitous shoes. I had arrived some way into a musical performance, though from the look and sound of what was taking place, I might have stumbled upon a hi-tech seance transmitting Earth secrets to beings from other galaxies.

Three men - one Swedish, one German, one Japanese-American - sat bookishly hunched over laptop computers in the centre of the performance area. Perched on a bench within the audience was a Frenchman, also perusing a laptop display that apparently generated sound. Secreted elsewhere among the paying guests were two Japanese longhairs playing mixing desks. In other words, not a musical instrument in sight and even less animation than a typical Oasis gig. So what did it sound like? Something like eavesdropping on the circulating murmur of an android coffee morning, a pleasantly relaxing detox in the brave new digital steam room.

Sound is increasingly important in our bleeping, squawking turbosphere of talkative computers, MP3 downloads and mobile phones twiddling out their digital Mozart. Sixteen months ago I was approached by the Hayward Gallery, interested to hear my ideas about the art of sound. Tantalised as I was by the prospect of curating an exhibition called Sonic Boom, I harboured a few misgivings. Despite a visual art training, my background is in music. My personal memory archive of seeing Otis Redding, Jimi Hendrix and the Doors has left me less than enchanted by the dilettante end of sound dabbling. The question to answer, then and now, was why look at sound? Surely it's an ear thing.

Dangerous as it is to make predictions, electronic games, computers and the latest mobile phones all suggest that various unforeseen combinations of sound and image will come to dominate our work and leisure in the near future. As for the past, the marriage of music with the plastic arts has a history that goes back at least as far as the Italian Futurists at the beginning of the 20th century. I would trace it even further, to the inventors and pseudo-scientists who built speaking statues and violin playing mechanical monkeys for those dark days before radios, record players, television evangelists and virtual dogs.

The Futurists are a good place to start, however, because they undertook a mission to wipe out Wagner with new technology and the noises of the industrial revolution. A frail looking painter from Milan named Luigi Russolo was so enthused by the unprecedented racket of modern warfare and urban life that he built a collection of noise-making machines, christening them with names like Burster, Gurgler, Hisser and Whistler. His legacy has been kept on life support by Art of Noise, who appropriated the title he gave to his manifesto and formed a pop band.

Now Russolo's star is in the ascendant. Nearly 100 years ago, the Futurists predicted that electricity and machines would change the world beyond all recognition. The truth of that was evident in the performance I witnessed in Tokyo, a have-laptop-will-travel aesthetic unthinkable even a decade ago. It was also illustrated by Ryoji Ikeda's sold-out London performance in January, a concert directed by Ikeda from within the audience using a laptop computer and zip drive. Based in Tokyo but living in a state of permanent jet lag, Ikeda has been quietly building a global reputation for himself as one of the new gods of audio-visual minimalism. While the musical mainstream wanders into a dead end street of boy bands and Shania Twain, electronic nomads such as Ikeda, Pan Sonic and Scanner are working in outlets as diverse as clubs, radio, theatre performances, gallery exhibitions and huge annual events such as Barcelona's Sonar Festival. Ikeda even contributed to the Mind Zone in the Millennium Dome, though he might want to forget about that.

This dismantling of the wall between pop music and high art was begun by musicians such as Brian Eno in the late 60s, helped by the education system of the time. In between the life drawing you might see a Warhol exhibition in the morning, hear a piano recital of John Cage music in the afternoon, then spend the night at a Soft Machine concert. With this background, Eno can now float freely between the worlds of U2, Pavarotti, art galleries and lecture halls. A natural choice for Sonic Boom, Eno will be a neighbour in the Hayward Gallery to the likes of Ikeda, Mariko Mori, the Japanese artist who dresses herself up as a pop icon or sci-fi shamaness in her own videos, and John Oswald, the Canadian composer who makes complex music with thousands of tiny fragments sampled from the work of artists such as the Grateful Dead, Dolly Parton, Michael Jackson and Igor Stravinsky. In 1990, Oswald so affronted the notion of copyright ownership that representatives for Michael Jackson ordered him to physically crush all remaining copies of his Plunderphonic CD.

The common denominator for most of these artists is their frustration with traditional music performance. Sitting quietly in rows of chairs, listening to a group of musicians pluck, bang and scrape for a designated time is a fairly recent notion in the history of music. By the 60s, the Beatles were recording music that could not be duplicated live without hiring the London Philharmonic Orchestra, Karlheinz Stockhausen and the sound effects department of Elstree film studio. Then disco, followed by hip-hop, replaced musical instruments with record decks and lifted the audience off its collective backside and on to the dancefloor, so rushing the obsolescence of the gig towards its final conclusion.

Yet music is a uniquely social activity. Musicians tend to think about their audience, even if they don't want to bite the heads off bats at Wembley Arena. Sonic Boom gives sound artists the opportunity to show their work in settings that engage the eyes as well as the ears. For visitors to the exhibition, there is the chance to catch up on a cross-section of cutting edge musicians without having to wait up all night, endure lousy PA systems or sit through a parade of hopeless support acts. For artists you hate, you can stay five seconds; for those you love you can stay five hours. What could be more civilised?

 Sonic Boom is at the Hayward Gallery, London SE1 (020-7921 0600), from Thursday till June 18.
