The question to answer, then and now, was why look at sound? Surely it's an ear thing. Dangerous as it is to make predictions, electronic games, computers and the latest mobile phones all suggest that various unforeseen combinations of sound and image will come to dominate our work and leisure in the near future. As for the past, the marriage of music with the plastic arts has a history that goes back at least as far as the Italian Futurists at the beginning of the 20th century. I would trace it even further, to the inventors and pseudo-scientists who built speaking statues and violin playing mechanical monkeys for those dark days before radios, record players, television evangelists and virtual dogs. The Futurists are a good place to start, however, because they undertook a mission to wipe out Wagner with new technology and the noises of the industrial revolution. A frail looking painter from Milan named Luigi Russolo was so enthused by the unprecedented racket of modern warfare and urban life that he built a collection of noise-making machines, christening them with names like Burster, Gurgler, Hisser and Whistler. His legacy has been kept on life support by Art of Noise, who appropriated the title he gave to his manifesto and formed a pop band. Now Russolo's star is in the ascendant. Nearly 100 years ago, the Futurists predicted that electricity and machines would change the world beyond all recognition. The truth of that was evident in the performance I witnessed in Tokyo, a have-laptop-will-travel aesthetic unthinkable even a decade ago. It was also illustrated by Ryoji Ikeda's sold-out London performance in January, a concert directed by Ikeda from within the audience using a laptop computer and zip drive. Based in Tokyo but living in a state of permanent jet lag, Ikeda has been quietly building a global reputation for himself as one of the new gods of audio-visual minimalism. While the musical mainstream wanders into a dead end street of boy bands and Shania Twain, electronic nomads such as Ikeda, Pan Sonic and Scanner are working in outlets as diverse as clubs, radio, theatre performances, gallery exhibitions and huge annual events such as Barcelona's Sonar Festival. Ikeda even contributed to the Mind Zone in the Millennium Dome, though he might want to forget about that. This dismantling of the wall between pop music and high art was begun by musicians such as Brian Eno in the late 60s, helped by the education system of the time. In between the life drawing you might see a Warhol exhibition in the morning, hear a piano recital of John Cage music in the afternoon, then spend the night at a Soft Machine concert. With this background, Eno can now float freely between the worlds of U2, Pavarotti, art galleries and lecture halls. A natural choice for Sonic Boom, Eno will be a neighbour in the Hayward Gallery to the likes of Ikeda, Mariko Mori, the Japanese artist who dresses herself up as a pop icon or sci-fi shamaness in her own videos, and John Oswald, the Canadian composer who makes complex music with thousands of tiny fragments sampled from the work of artists such as the Grateful Dead, Dolly Parton, Michael Jackson and Igor Stravinsky. In 1990, Oswald so affronted the notion of copyright ownership that representatives for Michael Jackson ordered him to physically crush all remaining copies of his Plunderphonic CD. The common denominator for most of these artists is their frustration with traditional music performance. Sitting quietly in rows of chairs, listening to a group of musicians pluck, bang and scrape for a designated time is a fairly recent notion in the history of music. By the 60s, the Beatles were recording music that could not be duplicated live without hiring the London Philharmonic Orchestra, Karlheinz Stockhausen and the sound effects department of Elstree film studio. Then disco, followed by hip-hop, replaced musical instruments with record decks and lifted the audience off its collective backside and on to the dancefloor, so rushing the obsolescence of the gig towards its final conclusion. Yet music is a uniquely social activity. Musicians tend to think about their audience, even if they don't want to bite the heads off bats at Wembley Arena. Sonic Boom gives sound artists the opportunity to show their work in settings that engage the eyes as well as the ears. For visitors to the exhibition, there is the chance to catch up on a cross-section of cutting edge musicians without having to wait up all night, endure lousy PA systems or sit through a parade of hopeless support acts. For artists you hate, you can stay five seconds; for those you love you can stay five hours. What could be more civilised?  Sonic Boom is at the Hayward Gallery, London SE1 (020-7921 0600), from Thursday till June 18.

fields.headline: Anger as squatter sells up
fields.trailText: Ian Ames was fond of quoting the 19th century anarchist Proudhon's dictum, property is theft. It allowed the unemployed musician to live rent free for 15 years in a Victorian house, and to go to court successfully to argue its owner had forfeited the title because of his "squatter's rights".
fields.body:
Ian Ames was fond of quoting the 19th century anarchist Proudhon's dictum, property is theft. It allowed the unemployed musician to live rent free for 15 years in a Victorian house, and to go to court successfully to argue its owner had forfeited the title because of his "squatter's rights".

Now Mr Ames, 45, has espoused a way of thinking more typical of the 21st century: property is money. Showing an astute grasp of the property market, he has sold the house for £100,000.

Yesterday, as news filtered through Brixton in south London, neighbours were dismayed by the hypocrisy of a man they had supported against the house's former owner, Lambeth council.

"I can't believe it. He's sold out big time," said one neighbour who refused to be named. "Selling his house goes against his whole way of thinking. We were all under the impression he'd carry on living there and that was why he fought the case against the council. To me, it's just greed."

Another neighbour added: "It seems outrageous. All this time he lived rent free... and now he makes a fortune."

One man did admire Mr Ames's cheek. "I am a bit surprised after all he went through, but good luck to him," said Brian Delaney, 32, who lives opposite.

Mr Ames, who has written a book on the desirability of the alternative lifestyle, gained possession through a loophole in the 1980 Limitations Act, which bestows legal title to a property if someone lives in it unchallenged for 12 years.

When Mr Ames gained the deeds last July, he reflected: "It's nice when the law gives something back to the poor people." Last night, he was unavailable to comment on whether it was equally nice to pocket £100,000.

webTitle: Aid for Turkey dam may face court challenge

fields.headline: Aid for Turkey dam may face court challenge
fields.standfirst: Friends of the Earth threaten action to block £200m funding for British construction company
fields.trailText: The government has been warned it faces high court action for breaches of international law if it gives financial support to a giant dam project in Turkey.
fields.body:
The government has been warned it faces high court action for breaches of international law if it gives financial support to a giant dam project in Turkey.

Tony Blair has pushed reluctant cabinet colleagues into supporting a controversial £200m application from the construction company Balfour Beatty for export credits for the Ilisu Dam project.

Protests from environmental groups, the Kurdish people and Syria and Iraq have all been overruled by No 10 which wants Turkey to join the EU and seeks stronger trade links including new arms sales.

Three law professors have warned the government that it will be in breach of international law if it proceeds as planned. They say Turkey is obliged to consult countries downstream of the project before starting it - Syria and Iraq - something that Ankara has refused to do.

James Crawford, from Cambridge University, Philippe Sands, of London University, and Laurence Boiusson de Chazournes, of the University of Geneva, say that supporting Turkey would put Britain in breach of international law too.

The UN Charter, the International Court of Justice and the Convention on the Protection and Use of Transboundary Watercourses all required consultation and constructive negotiations before water rights of downstream neighbours were affected.

Richard Caborn, the trade minister, was sent a copy of the legal opinion last week by Friends of the Earth, which said that it could not believe that the government would want to ignore its obligations and thus risk facing high court proceedings. The letter said: "Parliament cannot be supposed to have intended the Export Credit Guarantee Act to be exercised so as to support an enterprise in breach of international law."

Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, announced in December that the UK was minded to support the dam, but expressed concerns about the fate of 36,000 Kurds who had not been consulted about the loss of their homes, farms and jobs.

He also wanted Turkey to reassure the government that Syria and Iraq accepted the plan to dam the Tigris. The government is still waiting for a response.

The dam is 40 miles from the border with Iraq and Syria and would take seven years to build at a cost of more than £1.3bn. It would drown 80 settlements including the ancient town of Hasankeyf, a centre of Kurdish culture where there are many historic buildings and cave dwellings, some still occupied.

The dam would cover 2,000 sq kilometres, the thin reservoir more than 120 metres deep snaking 135 miles to the north through the mountains.

Turkey broke off talks with its neighbours about its plans to build a series of dams on the Tigris and Euphrates nearly 10 years ago, and last year said it was not prepared to re-open them.

Syria, Iran and the League of Arab States have all complained to the Foreign Office about the British government's support for the project and warned that it could lead to conflict.

Tony Juniper, the FoE policy director, said: "Our legal advice is that Turkey has binding obligations to consult its downstream neighbours prior to going ahead with this dam. It has clearly not done that, and in our view will not do so.

"If Britain supports the Ilisu dam with an export credit, our government will be assisting Turkey in breaching its obligations. Assisting a breach of international law is illegal.

"We are committed to ensuring that the law is upheld and will take legal action against the British government if it is not.

"Ethical foreign policy should at least protect human rights, the environment and the security of nations' water supplies. Not only does this project undermine all of those considerations but if progressed on the basis of present plans will be illegal as well. If the Government wishes to retain some ethical credibility in the run up to the election it should decline support for Turkey's dreadful dam proposal."

A spokesman for the Department of Trade and Industry said that ministers were considering the legal opinion and would reply to Friends of the Earth in "due course".

Balfour Beatty is the head of a multinational consortium of construction companies, all of which are asking for export credit guarantees from their governments but are facing spreading international opposition to the project.

webTitle: 'I was poor. The only option was to make a scandal. It worked well. Too well'

fields.headline: 'I was poor. The only option was to make a scandal. It worked well. Too well'
fields.standfirst: Balthus, 92 years old and still painting, talks to  Nicholas Glass
fields.trailText: Balthus, 92 years old and still painting, talks to Nicholas Glass
fields.body:
Call it a compulsion to paint. On mornings when the light is good, "the north light, a cool light without reflections", the painter known as Balthus is eased into a wheelchair, wrapped up against the chill spring air, and pushed by his "Chinese slave" from his Swiss chalet across the road to his studio. At 92, purblind and hunched, sucking on his cigarettes, he sometimes paints till five in the afternoon, although he doesn't always remember that he has. His Japanese wife, Setsuko, some 30 years younger, says he always has painting on his mind.

The studio, an old stable, is kept at oven temperature. A huge window frames the mountain and, in the pool of light, we are shown two large canvases. The landscape is complete; the nude of a young girl awaits finishing touches. He has been working on A Midsummer Night's Dream for two years; it is the excuse for our visit. His sources are scattered among the paint pots: there's a reproduction of Poussin's Sleeping Nymphs Surprised by Satyrs, along with photos of his long-time model, a local doctor's daughter, now 17. The Balthus and the Poussin will hang side by side in the National Gallery in June in a show called Encounters - New Art from Old.

In his 1935 self-portrait, The King of the Cats, Balthus - or to use his real name, Comte Balthazar Klossowski de Rola - is aristocratic and dandyish, a sleek and handsome 6ft 2in, a cat nuzzling against his leg. "I've always loved cats. I was always surrounded by them," he says. It has been a mutual lifetime attraction; as a boy, he was followed by them. His first published work, at 13, was a series of illustrations for a story about cats. A cat observes our arrival from a high chalet window; a Burmese sidles through the living room while we talk.

There is no other 20th-century painter quite like Balthus. He resolutely ignored the art-isms of his time - "I was never interested in other modern painters because I had my painting, which preoccupied my mind more than anything else." From the 30s to the 50s he created an extraordinary series of realist paintings, often of adolescent girls, often charged with their own mysterious atmosphere, often erotic. "You can't explain why a painting is good or not," he says. "You have to look at it."

His work is where you'd expect it - in the Louvre, the Tate, the Metropolitan in New York, and in the hands of private collectors such as Billy Wilder, Mike Nichols, the Agnelli and Niarchos families. The most widely disseminated Balthus is Girl and Cat (1937), from 1989 till this month the cover of the Penguin paperback of Nabokov's Lolita. Martin Summers, his agent at London's Lefevre Gallery, advises against two things. Balthus does not like mention of paedophilia when talking about the work, and on meeting him, it somehow seems irrelevant. He is also "incensed" by biography of him by Nicholas Fox Weber, published last year, which dismisses his recent painting.

I bring Balthus a bottle of Drambuie and a box of shortbread biscuits. Born in Paris of Polish parents, he claims to be "a quarter Scottish". I am invited to take tea by Setsuko, who tells me to speak loudly and deliberately into his better left ear. I seem to be liked. There are a few long pauses, his delivery is slow. Yes, he remembers the Paris exhibition in 1934 that launched his career. By painting The Guitar Lesson, he'd deliberately courted controversy. The image is of a sexual awakening; the aroused girl lies across her music teacher, pudenda exposed, guitar discarded. "I remember I was very poor," he says. "The only way to get out of that state was to make a scandal. It worked well, too well."

Balthus belongs to another age, the Paris of the 30s. His parents were friends of Matisse and Bonnard. His dealer was Pierre Matisse, who chose the titles for all his paintings. He admired Bacon, counted him a friend; they agreed about painting. He was very close to Giacometti. But modern painters "have forgotten the metier. That's why the work is always so bad." Balthus once sat for Lucian Freud, but was never shown the result - "he probably wasn't pleased with it." The young Balthus would have painted a magical portrait of his declining self.

It is impossible to imagine Balthus without his wife. Herself a painter, Setsuko once modelled for him. She is his guardian, his memory and sometimes probably his eyes. She organises the chalet, its Asian staff, the Chinese doctor in almost constant attendance. When she is not in the room, he looks for her, calls out for her like a little lost boy. She tidies him up for the interview, finds a silk scarf to hide the T-shirt, stands behind me to help him with the questions. She's now preparing to establish a Balthus Foundation on land near the chalet. She has just organised an elaborate 92nd birthday party for him. Bono came and sang; Tony Curtis gave him "a bright painting". There have only been 23 birthdays; Balthus was born on February 29. He still remembers his first birthday, the four-year-old cajoling his "little comrades" into covering themselves in chocolate cake while he remained spotless.

The 92-year-old retains a sense of mischief. The first thing he asks me over tea and Easter cake - and teasingly he asks it three times - is "Do you like Matisse?". For the record, Balthus thinks Bonnard was infinitely the greater artist.

 Nicholas Glass is Channel 4 News arts correspondent. His interview with Balthus is broadcast tonight at 7pm.

webTitle: Rum do for NUS over drink deal

fields.headline: Rum do for NUS over drink deal
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Once they protested against the Vietnam war and Thatcher "the milk snatcher", and boycotted Barclays Bank over its trade links to apartheid South Africa. But the National Union of Students has decided not to include Bacardi, the world's largest rum producer, in its hall of infamy despite the company's anti-Castro links.
fields.byline: Michael Sean Gillard, Laura Milne  and  Laurie Flynn
fields.body:
Once they protested against the Vietnam war and Thatcher "the milk snatcher", and boycotted Barclays Bank over its trade links to apartheid South Africa. But the National Union of Students has decided not to include Bacardi, the world's largest rum producer, in its hall of infamy despite the company's anti-Castro links.

The commercial arm of the NUS has voted to accept a three-year "sole supply deal" worth £625,000 which will mean that student bars can now only stock Bacardi white rum and not Havana Club, its rival jointly owned by the Cuban government and French drinks giant Pernod Ricard.

Student leaders have called the NUS morally bankrupt and said it has opted "to make a quick buck", while Pernod Ricard is examining whether the deal contravenes new European Union competition legislation.

Bacardi already has 95% of the student white rum market and may be guilty of abusing its dominant market position.

Bacardi left Cuba soon after the 1959 revolution when its distilleries were nationalised. Since then the Bahamas-registered company has been a vocal critic of Fidel Castro.

Earlier this month the NUS refused to debate an emergency motion at its full delegate conference. But student union representatives from Oxford, Sheffield, London and Middlesex universities arrived at the NUS trade conference in Cardiff last week determined to oppose the Bacardi deal.

Their concerns had already prompted the NUS ethics committee to ask Bacardi a series of questions last year. The Guardian has seen Bacardi's confidential replies in which it admits supporting the US blockade of Cuba, which has been condemned by the United Nations.

Anneliese Dodds, president of the Oxford student union, said: "The NUS is now morally bankrupt. How can they speak out against other companies like Nestlé when they have accepted this deal?"

No one from Bacardi was willing to comment.

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
The Secret World Of Michael Fry
9pm, Channel 4
"Whenever I go anywhere else, there's always too much", says tart with a heart Donna (Rosie Marcel) as she tries to explain to confused town planner Michael Fry (Ewen Bremner) why she doesn't want to leave the depressed Welsh seaside town of Llangrych. Trouble is, local businessmen and councillors don't share her enthusiasm, and there's a whiff of corruption in the air as Michael's monstrous boss Hugh Wentworth Davies (Bob Pugh) makes secret plans to revitalise the area through tourism. Hardly new themes, but Paul Abbott's new two-parter also comes with a heavy pinch of Kafkaesque bleak humour that lifts this way above the average comedy-drama. Oh, and during Wentworth Davies' pompous video presentation, watch out for the slyest sheep-shagging joke ever.

Brits Abroad
10.50pm, BBC1
Trying to step out from his father's shadow, sculptor Matthew Spender (son of poet Stephen) left Blighty years ago to live in Tuscany, where he spends his spare time playing "idiotic music" in a town band. As the first in this series reveals, his emigration was by no means as unusual as you might imagine, and it's got to be at least worth pondering the fact that all those interviewed rave about their new lives in Europe. Time for language lessons?

Cutting Edge
10.20pm, Channel 4
In Rusholme, Manchester, 50 Indian restaurants vie for trade. Predictably, so much naan bread in such a small area draws post-pub punters in their droves, and this occasionally intriguing film looks at life in the area from the perspective of both customers and staff.

webTitle: Moscow shows scrap of Hitler's skull

fields.headline: Moscow shows scrap of Hitler's skull
fields.trailText: Plans to display a supposed fragment of Adolf Hitler's skull have prompted concern in Moscow that the exhibition may attract interest from resurgent neo-fascist groups.
fields.body:
Plans to display a supposed fragment of Adolf Hitler's skull have prompted concern in Moscow that the exhibition may attract interest from resurgent neo-fascist groups.

To some scepticism, the organisers of an exhibition to mark the 55th anniversary of the end of the second world war insisted yesterday that skull fragment, pierced with a bullet hole and blackened by smoke, was genuine. It will go on display tomorrow at the federal archives service in an exhibition entitled The Agony of the Third Reich: The Retribution.

Officials claimed that Hitler's jaw was also in the archives, but was too fragile to put on show.

Vladimir Kozlov, head of the archive service, declined to reveal how the fragments came to be in Moscow. The museum director, Aliya Borkovets, said "no doubts remained" about their authenticity, but did not elaborate.

When Russia first announced that it had the pieces of bone in 1993, Hitler experts disputed the claims and the biographer Werner Maser said the fragments were fakes.

The exhibition will include documents from Soviet investigations to identify the remains, which may help clarify their provenance, some of his belongings, and items from Hitler's bunker.

Soon after Hitler's suicide in his Berlin bunker on April 30 1945, his body is said to have been taken outside by staff, doused with petrol and set alight, alongside the body of his companion Eva Braun.

The facts about what happened next have never been established. Russian sources claim that Soviet troops dug up the fragments in 1945 and reburied them in Magdeburg, East Germany.

Other reports say that some skull fragments were found separately in Hitler's bunker by the KGB and may have been brought to Moscow.

webTitle: Philippine guerrillas grab 22 hostages from resort

fields.headline: Philippine guerrillas grab 22 hostages from resort
fields.trailText: Malaysia and the Philippines mounted an extensive naval search yesterday for 22 people, including 10 foreign tourists, who were kidnapped from a tropical island resort by heavily armed gunmen thought to be Filipinos.
fields.body:
Malaysia and the Philippines mounted an extensive naval search yesterday for 22 people, including 10 foreign tourists, who were kidnapped from a tropical island resort by heavily armed gunmen thought to be Filipinos.

Malaysian officials said they knew where the hostages were being held and believed they were safe. "We have found out the exact location," the defence minister, Najib Razak, said, without specifying it.

Six gunmen arrived in two boats on Sunday evening on the tiny Sipadan island, a world-renowned diving spot about 20 miles off the coast of the Malaysian state of Sabah, on Borneo island, and took the hostages out to sea.

The captives include nine Malaysians, three Germans, two French people, four South Africans, two Finns, one Lebanese and a Filipino. An American couple, James Murphy and his wife Mary, both 51, from Rochester, New York, escaped into the woods before the hostages were ordered into the boats.

There have been no reports of demands by the abductors.

The Philippines said a Muslim rebel group in the southern Philippines might be responsible. Its defence chief said the gunmen were believed to be heading for the Philippines and the navy had been ordered to intercept them.

"They are not yet here, although there is a strong reason to believe that they are going either to Sulu or Zamboanga, where there are many Tausugs," Orlando Mercado said in Manila.

Earlier Mr Mercado said that the kidnappers spoke Tausug, a dialect used in the Mindanao region of the southern Philippines.

But the Malaysian police chief, Norian Mai, said the kidnappers also spoke English.

"From the description we obtained, we conclude they are foreign elements, fluent in English but not in the local accent," he said.

Mr Mai said the captors stormed the police station and the local wildlife and forestry office on the island before heading for the resort.

"At the moment we still don't know what their motive is, but we are considering ransom, revenge and international politics as the possible motive," he said.

"Among these, we are most seriously considering international politics."

Sabah state is on the northeastern tip of the island of Borneo, which also includes Brunei and part of Indonesia. Sipadan is near the border between the Philippines and Indonesia, and a 45-minute boat ride from the southern Philippines.

Mr Mercado said he had received information from Malaysia that the kidnappers might belong to the Abu Sayyaf group, one of two rebel militias fighting for an Islamic state in the southern Philippines.

Twenty Abu Sayyaf rebels are believed to have been killed on Sunday when the armed forces mounted an assault to try to free dozens of hostages held by the guerrillas in their mountain lair on Basilan island in the southern Philippines.

The rebels have demanded the release of three Islamic militants held in US jails, including one believed to have been involved in the 1993 bomb attack on New York's World Trade Centre.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Loose cannons
fields.body:
Loose cannons

In the third recent accident involving former Soviet missiles, a Russian sea-to-sea missile hit a Ukrainian ship near Sevastopol yesterday, a spokesman said.

The Ukraine defence ministry admitted one of its tactical missiles had caused the blast at a block of flats last week which killed three people, and Kazakhstan said that a missile had spun out of control and exploded on Friday after its launch from a Russian site near the Caspian Sea.
Reuters, Moscow

Chechen attack
Chechen rebels said yesterday that they had swooped on a Russian armoured column near the village of Serzhen-Yurt south-east of Grozny, killing 80 soldiers and destroying 13 tanks and troop carriers.

According to the Russian military, 15 soldiers died and two vehicles were lost.
Reuters, Moscow

Mine blasts
Thirty people were killed and 17 injured when a two vehicles hit antitank mines in northern Angola, reports said yesterday. The mines were four miles apart and ringed by dynamite.

A new government offensive against Unita rebels, based on guerrilla tactics is under way, according to the independent weekly Agora.
AP, Luanda

webTitle: New US radar site threatens ABM treaty

fields.headline: New US radar site threatens ABM treaty
fields.trailText: The United States was thrown on to the defensive as the UN nuclear disarmament talks began yesterday by allegations that it had installed a new anti-missile radar in northern Norway, a few miles from the Russian border.
fields.body:
The United States was thrown on to the defensive as the UN nuclear disarmament talks began yesterday by allegations that it had installed a new anti-missile radar in northern Norway, a few miles from the Russian border.

Moscow has denounced the installation, believed to be the world's most advanced tracking and imaging radar, as a covert step towards the controversial US plan to develop a shield against incoming missiles, and therefore a potential breach of the 1972 anti-ballistic-missile (ABM) treaty.

"Everyone should be aware that the collapse of the ABM treaty would have a destructive domino effect for the existing system of disarmament agreements," the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, argued in yesterday's New York Times. "We would be back in an era of suspicion and confrontation."

The Norwegian government said the radar, in the border village of Vardo, was designed to keep an eye on potentially dangerous space debris, but that explanation was derided as implausible by several independent scientists.

The revelations emerged as talks began at the conference on the 1968 nuclear non-proliferation treaty (NPT) at the UN's New York headquarters, and US-Russian talks on a new disarmament treaty, Start III, entered their second week in Geneva.

The US and the Russia have both been under fire from disarmament watchdogs for negotiating in bad faith. Both have opted to stockpile and upgrade - rather than destroy - the warheads they have removed from missile silos.

The Vardo radar could have an even more damaging impact on the already precarious east-west nuclear balance. It was built in 1995 and moved to Norway in 1998, according to the latest issue of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, a US journal which monitors nuclear proliferation issues.

When a Norwegian journalist, Inge Sellevag, asked the Norwegian government the purpose of the new installation, he was told it was to be used by Nasa to monitor "space junk". But Nasa knew nothing about Vardo. John Pike, director of the Space Policy Project at the Federation of American Scientists, said yesterday: "One of the standard parts of creating a cover story for an intelligence operation is that the story is plausible and this cover story was not.

"This is a type of radar that was developed as part of the national missile defence [NMD] network, and I assume the reason they put it up there is to monitor Russian missile-testing."

The proposed NMD system is a successor to Ronald Reagan's Star Wars scheme. It is intended to create a nuclear umbrella over the US by coordinating an array of satellites, radars and missiles which would track and intercept any incoming missiles. Such a system is banned by the ABM treaty.

Tests on NMD technology are still under way and President Clinton has yet to give the system a green light, but the Vardo radar - along with the proposed upgrading of the early-warning radars at Fylingsdales in Yorkshire and Thule in Greenland - suggest that the Pentagon is already committed to the strategy.

Critics of the system believe the placing of the radars con firms that its main target is Russia, not rogue states like Iran, Iraq and North Korea as US officials have assured their counterparts in Moscow.

The Ministry of Defence's claim that the Fylingsdales radar was aimed at monitoring North Korea were dismissed by Mr Pike, who said: "Last time I checked England was on the other side of planet from North Korea. It might be a good place to hide from North Korea but not to watch it."

Meanwhile, US plans to upgrade its nuclear stockpile and develop "new nuclear options for emergent threats" were revealed in energy department documents made available to a court after a legal challenge by disarmament and environmental groups.

Greg Mello, director of one of the groups, the Los Alamos Study Group, said they revealed "a shocking disregard for US commitments, especially those enshrined in the NPT, to end the nuclear arms race."

"It's imperative that these plans be stopped. If we don't abide by the treaties we've signed, how can we get other countries to do so," he said.

fields.headline: HSBC named as Mexican bidder
fields.trailText: HSBC was named yesterday as one of the last two banks in the bidding for Serfin, the Mexican state-run bank.
fields.body:
HSBC was named yesterday as one of the last two banks in the bidding for Serfin, the Mexican state-run bank.

The decision by HSBC to remain in the running comes at a time when it has been blazing an acquisition trail - most recently buying the French group, CCF.

Serfin had a $12bn injection of state aid in 1995 to prevent its collapse. The other bank still interested is Banco Santander Central Hispano, the Spanish bank which also has expansionary plans.

The Mexican government said that Citicorp of the US and Groupo Financiero Banamex Accival, a local Mexican bank, had pulled out. Serfin is Mexico's third largest bank and suffered badly in the peso crisis of 1994, when the authorities had to pump $100bn into the banking system to prevent a collapse.

HSBC is no stranger to bidding for banks in emerging markets but has also run into difficulties - as it did in Indonesia last year.

 Sir John Bond, chairman of HSBC, was paid £750,000 last year, a rise of £95,000, and awarded £550,000 of performance related stock options.

According to the bank's annual report and accounts, Bill Dalton, the chief executive of HSBC UK, formerly Midland bank, saw his take home pay reach £441,000, a rise of £26,000. However, the bank said it paid an additional £120,000 into his pension fund "in return for prior waiver" of his 1999 discretionary bonus.

fields.headline: WorldCom joins Orange suitors
fields.trailText: MCI WorldCom is understood to have joined the array of potential suitors for Orange, Britain's third-ranked mobile phone operator, and to have recruited Salomon Smith Barney to advise it on a potential bid.
fields.body:
MCI WorldCom is understood to have joined the array of potential suitors for Orange, Britain's third-ranked mobile phone operator, and to have recruited Salomon Smith Barney to advise it on a potential bid.

MCI WorldCom - the US's second biggest long-distance phone compan - and Orange have already been in discussions. Hans Snook, the chief executive of Orange, confirmed he had spoken to his MCI WorldCom counter part, Bernie Ebbers, but would not reveal details of the talks.

Mr Ebbers is said to have told colleagues that the acquisition of Orange would help fill out the company's wireless portfolio in Europe.

A spokesman for Orange yesterday declined to comment.

France Telecom has also expressed interest in making a bid for Orange, as has Holland's KPN Telecom, with bid prices put at £25bn-£30bn.

MCI WorldCom and Orange were competing with each other in the UK government's auction of five licences for the universal mobile transmission system that will see mobile telephones offering video conferencing, fast internet access and performing simple computing tasks.

However, MCI WorldCom bowed out of the bidding, saying it had become too expensive. It might choose to regain a foothold in the market through buying Orange.

webTitle: Filmgroup seals £44m video on demand deal

fields.headline: Filmgroup seals £44m video on demand deal
fields.trailText: Filmgroup, the video-on-demand company heading for a £300m stock market flotation, yesterday announced its first content deals with the acquisition of rights to a string of forthcoming Hollywood film releases.
fields.body:
Filmgroup, the video-on-demand company heading for a £300m stock market flotation, yesterday announced its first content deals with the acquisition of rights to a string of forthcoming Hollywood film releases.

The firm claims to have spent around $70m (£44m) securing exclusive video-on-demand rights to 60 films, which include the remake of Get Carter, starring Sylvester Stallone, and The Pledge with Jack Nicholson.

The rights give the company a six-month window before screenings on cable or satellite television.

The company is also building a cinema film distribution business after poaching a team from PolyGram Filmed Entertainment. Filmgroup will have video-on-demand rights to the movies it distributes in cinemas; one of the first will be Ben Elton's Maybe Baby with Hugh Laurie and Joely Richardson (left).

"We have sewn up video-on-demand," said Filmgroup chief executive Simon Franks. "In the long term the technology of how you deliver these films becomes generic, and then it is all about content."

The company - backed by Cliff Stanford, who founded Demon Internet - will distribute movies over the web via set top boxes plugged into televisions. It aims to launch at the end of this year. Rivals Yes Television and Video Networks are also moving towards flotation.

fields.headline: Financial chief quits ailing Boeing
fields.trailText: Boeing's chief financial officer, Deborah Hopkins, added to the woes of the struggling aircraft maker yesterday when she abruptly quit after just over a year in the job.
fields.body:
Boeing's chief financial officer, Deborah Hopkins, added to the woes of the struggling aircraft maker yesterday when she abruptly quit after just over a year in the job.

Ms Hopkins is leaving the group to take up a similar post at Lucent Technologies, the world's largest telecoms equipment maker. Lucent, once part of AT&T, is regarded as one of the market's most innovative technology companies.

News of Ms Hopkins' departure surprised Wall Street, which immediately marked down shares in the Seattle-based aircraft maker. Ms Hopkins was credited with having introduced tough cost-cutting measures, including extensive job cuts, at Boeing.

Relations with the work force have soured over the same period, leading to a strike that hit production across its range of aircraft.

She was recruited by Boeing in 1998, when the company was experiencing serious operational problems which led to its first loss in 50 years. She had been chief financial officer at General Motors Europe.

Byron Callan, an aerospace analyst at Merrill Lynch, said: "This is a high visibility and unexpected departure for Boeing. However, we do not expect any fundamental break in strategy or performance as a result." Boeing said yesterday that it was still seeking a replacement for Ms Hopkins.

The group's treasurer and vice-president, Walter Skowrinski, is to take over her duties on an interim basis.

During her full year at Boe ing Ms Hopkins earned about $1.25m in basic pay, bonus and other compensation. Lucent refused to reveal how much they had agreed to pay her.

Ms Hopkins said: "I enjoy the passion and velocity of a hi-tech company and Lucent is at the centre of one of the fastest growing industries today. When I was offered the opportunity to join Lucent and Rich McGinn's senior team, I couldn't pass it up."

Ms Hopkins will be the most senior female executive at Lucent since Carly Fiorina left last year to become chief executive of computer maker Hewlett-Packard.

Lucent is in the process of restructuring its operations, disposing of its slower growing businesses and concentrating on growth opportunities - such as optical and data networking equipment.

Like Boeing, Lucent is seeking to rebuild bridges with the investment community after a poor performance partly caused by constraints in manufacturing. Analysts said that Lucent would benefit from Ms Hopkins' turnaround skills. They said she had brought discipline to Boeing's financial management systems.

"She was instrumental in forcing down excess inventories of supplier parts and that sort of thing," said Paul Nisbet, an analyst at JSA Research.

The group's treasurer and vice-president, Walter Skowrinski, is to take over her duties on an interim basis. During her full year at Boe ing Ms Hopkins earned about $1.25m in basic pay, bonus and other compensation. Lucent refused to reveal how much they had agreed to pay her. Ms Hopkins said: "I enjoy the passion and velocity of a hi-tech company and Lucent is at the centre of one of the fastest growing industries today. When I was offered the opportunity to join Lucent and Rich McGinn's senior team, I couldn't pass it up." Ms Hopkins will be the most senior female executive at Lucent since Carly Fiorina left last year to become chief executive of computer maker Hewlett-Packard. Lucent is in the process of restructuring its operations, disposing of its slower growing businesses and concentrating on growth opportunities - such as optical and data networking equipment. Like Boeing, Lucent is seeking to rebuild bridges with the investment community after a poor performance partly caused by constraints in manufacturing. Analysts said that Lucent would benefit from Ms Hopkins' turnaround skills. They said she had brought discipline to Boeing's financial management systems. "She was instrumental in forcing down excess inventories of supplier parts and that sort of thing," said Paul Nisbet, an analyst at JSA Research.

webTitle: Retailers told to lose youth fixation

fields.headline: Retailers told to lose youth fixation
fields.trailText: A population decline during the next 10 years in the generation that is watching Friends and reading Bridget Jones will be bad news for household goods and do-it-youself retailers but a boon for computer and mobile phone sellers.
fields.body:
A population decline during the next 10 years in the generation that is watching Friends and reading Bridget Jones will be bad news for household goods and do-it-youself retailers but a boon for computer and mobile phone sellers.

According to research by the retail consultant Verdict, profit-squeezed retailers will be forced to abandon their fixation with the 25 to 34 year-old sector, traditionally suckers for brand names, and instead focus on older, more mature customers whose numbers are rising rapidly.

"They [older customers] are affluent, demanding and very poorly catered for. The prize is very significant. The penalty for trying to adhere to the old order could well be terminal," says the Verdict report published today.

The consultant believes that retailers will have to be more focused - producing more brands and ranges over the next decade to accommodate demographic changes.

Verdict, studying population trends and consumer usage of the leading retail companies, finds some good news for fashion and personal care sectors on the basis of an expected 9% rise this decade in the youngest band of customers, aged 15 to 24.

However, while this group is wealthier than any young generation since the 1960s, Verdict points out that the buying behaviour of the group is more difficult to predict with any accuracy for retailers because of the "notoriously fickle" nature of the changing fashions and trends.

With 20 to 30 year-olds decreasing in numbers, Verdict notes that the number of fortysomethings will increase over the course of the decade as the 1960 baby boomers hit middle age.

Although it will be another 10 years before these reach their 50s, Verdict predicts that this "generation of greys" will be different to those of previous decades.

None will have experienced the frugality of the war years "but many will remember the boom times of the 1960s and 1980s".

Improvements in health mean members of this group are likely to be more energetic and have a higher level of disposal income.

Verdict acknowledges that a 10-year time frame might be long, but insists that it is legitimate given the extended property leases retailers are often locked into.

The retail consultant makes its predictions against what it characterises as a weakness of consumer demand - not because of less affluence but because customers are spending their money elsewhere.

webTitle: Services sector feels squeeze of strong sterling

fields.headline: Services sector feels squeeze of strong sterling
fields.trailText: Sterling's strength on the foreign exchanges is squeezing profits across British industry, with only four out of 23 sectors recording an increase in the final quarter of last year, according to a survey out today.
fields.body:
Sterling's strength on the foreign exchanges is squeezing profits across British industry, with only four out of 23 sectors recording an increase in the final quarter of last year, according to a survey out today.

The survey, by the research company Experian, shows that continued strength of the pound is swamping attempts to improve productivity.

Across the whole economy, the average return on capital fell for the third consecutive quarter, to 13.14%, in the final quarter of 1999, after peaking at 14.18% in the first three months of the year.

"Throughout the last year the Corporate Health Check has highlighted the productivity gains made by companies as they have attempted to remain competitive in overseas markets," said Peter Brooker of Experian. "With the effects of higher interest rates and the recent surge in the price of oil, corporate profitability now appears to be firmly in decline."

The most worrying aspect of the downturn was that it was affecting all parts of the economy, including the previously resilient services sector.

Of the 23 sectors analysed, excluding financial services only four had increased profitability in the last quarter. These were building and construction, alcoholic beverages, food retailing and utilities.

"The effect of the acquisition of Asda by Wal-Mart has not yet had an effect on the food retailing sector's profitability, but it remains to be seen whether it can maintain this high level of profitability in the light of the price-cutting that has ensued," Mr Brooker said.

Among the big losers in the final quarter of last year were textiles and clothing, where profitability fell to 7.94% from 8.41%, information technology 25.99% (28.42%), non-food retailing 16.24% (17.66%) and transport 7.73% (8.17%).

"The performance of the IT sector may appear anomalous but the survey does not include new-economy internet companies, which have high market valuations but, with few exceptions, low sales and little profit, if any.

"The IT sector in the health check comprises predominantly hardware and software manufacturers - which are, on average, almost twice as profitable as the all-industries average." But many would have been affected by the postponement of major investments until after year 2000 preparations were completed.

Regionally, only the West Midlands and East Anglia registered an overall increase in profitability during the last quarter.

Experian's survey is based on the audited financial results of 2,000 of the largest companies in the UK.

fields.headline: Just say No
fields.trailText: Why repeat the government's and the drug tsar's favourite lie about Dutch heroin use? Problem drug use and deaths in the UK are at least double those of the Netherlands (MP campaigns for cannabis cafes, April 22). No wonder the Police Foundation report said they were "impressed" by the Dutch success of separating soft and hard drugs markets.
fields.body:
Why repeat the government's and the drug tsar's favourite lie about Dutch heroin use? Problem drug use and deaths in the UK are at least double those of the Netherlands (MP campaigns for cannabis cafes, April 22). No wonder the Police Foundation report said they were "impressed" by the Dutch success of separating soft and hard drugs markets.

The Dutch have a stable group of ageing problem drug users, a high proportion of them in treatment and the lowest ratio of drug-related deaths in Europe. Here, hard drug use and deaths are at record highs and our treatment facilities are derisory. Stop misrepresenting the Dutch success. Let's learn from them and reduce all drug harm.
Paul Flynn
MP

fields.headline: What's best for Elian
fields.trailText:
So, "once Castro goes, stand by for change" (Leader, April 24). What sort of change? An end to a system which provides free health care and education to all? Replacing it with a "democratic" one like the US model? Sensible reporting of the case of Elian Gonzales might include more about the achievements of the Cuban revolution in spite of 40 years of an economic blockade which is responsible for the suffering of many Cuban children. Where is Elian better off? In a country with more doctors and educators per head of the population than any other in the world, and where ordinary people stand for election and end up in the national assembly? Or a country where children shoot their classmates and you have to be a multi-millionaire to run for political office?
Richard Roques
London
Richard.Roques@ukgateway.net

 The last paragraph of your report (Bush adds his voice to Elian chorus, April 24) says that Elian Gonzales "fled Cuba with his mother". This suggests that the boy was in danger in Cuba and that he took the decision in the matter, which would be surprising in a five-year-old.

In fact, the departure for the US was organised by his mother's boyfriend, Lazaro Munero, a convicted criminal, who coerced her into risking the journey. Survivors of the trip have reported that Elian started crying and asking to stay in Cuba, Munero threatened his mother, saying: "You shut him up, or I'll do it myself."
Rod Prince
London

The details should have been rehearsed again and again to make sure the focus of the drama had a human dimension. There could have been any number of machine guns all round the house and even by the bedroom door, but surely not pointing straight at the child with a naked finger close to the trigger.
Dr Frank Heller
London

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Japanese firms expect upturn
Gloom surrounding the Japanese economy lifted yesterday despite the release of figures showing that firms expect overall capital spending to decline by 4.7% in the year to March 2001.
fields.body:
Japanese firms expect upturn
Gloom surrounding the Japanese economy lifted yesterday despite the release of figures showing that firms expect overall capital spending to decline by 4.7% in the year to March 2001.

Companies expect capital expenditure in the first half of the financial year ending in September to rise 6.1% year on year but then decline by 15% in the second half, according to the survey.

However, finance and insurance companies expect to see capital spending for the period increase by 18.7%.

Overall, companies still expect business conditions to improve in the half to September, with the index of business confidence increasing from four in the quarter to March 2000 to 12 and then to 29 in the following two quarters.

Bug may bite switchboards
Businesses throughout Britain were warned yesterday that they could be struck by a telephone switchboard bug generated by recent number changes.

Hundreds of offices in areas affected by Saturday's local number changes may be unable to receive or make telephone calls as the country returns to work after the Easter break.

The bug can affect businesses which use alternative network routing - a facility that allows companies' switchboards to choose between different telephone companies for local, national and international calls.

If the switchboard has not been reprogrammed to handle the new local numbers, employees or customers using the eight-digit local numbers without the new 02 area code will not be able to get through.

It is estimated that 60 to 70% of medium and large businesses use switchboards with the capacity for alternative network routing. Local numbers were changed in London, Cardiff, Coventry, Portsmouth, Southampton and Northern Ireland.

Blue Circle set for Greek buy
Cement manufacturer Blue Circle yesterday received authorisation from the Greek competition authorities for its €597m (£373m) acquisition of Calcemento, a holding company which owns Heracles and Halkis Cement.

Blue Circle - which is the target of a takeover bid by French rival Lafarge - said the announcement "emphasises the tremendous value in Blue Circle and the paucity of the Lafarge bid".

BT keeps Dutch option open
British Telecom yesterday refused to rule out the flotation of shares to fund the growth of its Dutch mobile unit, Telfort.

BT European director Pat Gallagher said that while BT has enough cash to finance Telfort's growth the company "absolutely does not say no" to an initial public offering for the Dutch subsidiary.

Telfort will also bid for a universal mobile telecommunication system, or UMTS, licence in the Netherlands in the government auction planned for this summer, Mr Gallagher said.

He added that BT is prepared to make "large investments" in order to expand the Dutch unit's growth prospects.

fields.headline: Feeling a bit rejected
fields.trailText: Like Simon Regan (Thanks, but no thanks, April 22) I have been a collector of rejection slips for 40 years and recognise all his experiences with agents and publishers. As a former Faber author I agree with him that Faber reject with "the utmost kindness and encouragement", having had identical letters from two publishers signed by the same person.
fields.body:
Like Simon Regan (Thanks, but no thanks, April 22) I have been a collector of rejection slips for 40 years and recognise all his experiences with agents and publishers. As a former Faber author I agree with him that Faber reject with "the utmost kindness and encouragement", having had identical letters from two publishers signed by the same person.

My favourite rejection, which I have actually pasted on a wall, is of what I intended to be a serious philosophical study. I had submitted it through a friend, so the editor might have been unusually frank. He wrote "...it is certainly a provocative study of these very difficult concepts. On his own admission, Mr Jones is dismissive of much contemporary philosophy, and since we are the UK's largest publisher of contemporary philosophy, I hope you see the difficulty".
GO Jones
Oxford

fields.headline: In praise of older teachers
fields.trailText: Thanks for the contribution to the debate on teacher performance-related pay, (Leader, April 22). I imagine that those teachers you describe as clapped out will be most gratified to hear of themselves described thus, after perhaps 25 years of grinding out interesting, challenging and Ofsted-approved lessons, day after day, year after year, with no respite, little reward and diminishing public regard.
fields.body:
Thanks for the contribution to the debate on teacher performance-related pay, (Leader, April 22). I imagine that those teachers you describe as clapped out will be most gratified to hear of themselves described thus, after perhaps 25 years of grinding out interesting, challenging and Ofsted-approved lessons, day after day, year after year, with no respite, little reward and diminishing public regard.

Look, you say, at what performance-related pay has done for Manchester United. Roy Keane is paid, let's say an awful lot of money. By my reckoning, if he and I start work at the same time on a Monday morning, by Tuesday lunch time he's earned as much as I will in one year. Give all teachers that incentive, and watch performance rocket. But £2,000? How about it Roy, fancy a bit of teaching?
Jeff Cherant
Westerham, Kent

 The reason most teachers are opposed to the introduction of performance-related pay is because they do not trust that it will be directed at the most able classroom practitioners. This belief is reinforced by comments in your leader that infer that older teachers are "clapped-out" while younger recruits "bring fresh vigour". Teachers, like many professionals, generally improve with experience, particularly in the area of class-management skills, which benefit from practice.

As a mature entrant to the profession, with 10 years experience as a manager in industry behind me, I am still amazed at the dedication and hard work most teachers bring to their work.

I know many teachers close to retirement who have laboured long and hard over the last two years to successfully, and enthusiastically, implement the numeracy and literacy strategies in primary schools.

Similarly, most teachers within successful primary schools contribute to the management of the school through their work at weekly staff meetings and as subject coordinators.

What teachers want to see is reward for all and not just the few. Adding an extra point to the top of the pay scale would do this, while im plementing the performance-related pay scheme will not. If, for example, 100% of teachers at a school are performing well above expectations, will they all be rewarded? I think not.
Pat Gibson
Kendal, Cumbria
pat_gibson@lineone.net

 I write more in sorrow than in anger having read your offensive remarks concerning clapped-out, clock-watching, uncreative time-servers. Of course you would know all about life in the modern classroom.

Many of these clapped-out geriatrics have coped with many changes imposed by successive secretaries of state and their advisers. They have taken on extra responsibilities through a sense of vocation, without constantly demanding the financial rewards expected by inexperienced, fast-track graduates. Contrary to your expert opinion, a graduate with one year's training is no substitute for an experienced teacher.

New young blood generally stamps its dear little feet and demands an extra scale point for anything extra and quite often another bright young thing known as a headteacher cave in to their whims and off loads the extra work onto - guess who?

As a reward for slogging on, Buckinghamshire county council has just informed the clapped out geriatrics that, should they consider leaving the profession early, then they will forfeit a percentage of their pension. Presumably this will pay for the Golden Hello brigade.

You are welcome to visit this pathetic geriatric's classroom to see what actually goes on but I doubt you could stand the pace.
Elaine Fisher
Aylesbury, Bucks
ITCO@bearbrook.bucks.sch.uk

fields.headline: Hair shirts v bubbly
fields.trailText: Francis Wheen's New Labourish defence of "champagne socialism" against the charge that food and wine writers have no place in the New Statesman (G2, April 19) seems to have completely missed the point.
fields.body:
Francis Wheen's New Labourish defence of "champagne socialism" against the charge that food and wine writers have no place in the New Statesman (G2, April 19) seems to have completely missed the point.

Of course hair-shirty, puritanical objections to any indulgence in the pleasures of life are rightly criticised, but an enumeration of famous lefties who liked their food and, especially, their drink, is completely irrelevant to the basic point that there's a large constituency of the very people Labour was born to represent who simply don't have the means to indulge in such pleasures - and for whom "the sound of a popping cork, or the taste and texture of a perfect peach" would be a rare treat indeed.

Sustain has calculated that an average family living on benefits falls £30 a week short of being able to maintain a "modest but adequate diet". A couple of bottles of wine to Mr Wheen or a week's fruit and veg for four.

As to Gramsci's maxim; optimism of the will is easy for champagne socialists - it's pessimism of the intellect that seems to suffer.
Anna Dempsey
Ripley, Derbys

 Francis Wheen' s seductively argued article about Lorraine Hewitt and other leftie vegetarian "killjoys" comes at such an appropriate time. What fun we've had watching those high-art video images of the Ethiopian famine. What price a perfect peach or a decent drop of Bolly in Harare? We look forward to discussing this with him at the next anti-fascist street action. Or will he be otherwise engaged - trying the calves' brains in embonpoint sauce at that wonderful new inner-city restaurant?
Tony Moore
Whitstable, Kent

fields.headline: Patriotic traditions
fields.trailText:
Unlike the patriotic Scots, Welsh and Irish, as a true, proud Englishman (Forever Ingerland, April 22) I celebrate my culture by traditionally ignoring St George's Day.
Trevor Hopper
Brighton
trevor.hopper@unisonfree.net
fields.body:
Unlike the patriotic Scots, Welsh and Irish, as a true, proud Englishman (Forever Ingerland, April 22) I celebrate my culture by traditionally ignoring St George's Day.
Trevor Hopper
Brighton
trevor.hopper@unisonfree.net

 Our national day passed with hardly a reference to St George. Wouldn't it make popular sense to abandon attempts to make April 23 meaningful as St George's Day, and celebrate it officially as Shakespeare Day instead? He is more popular than ever, and was voted Man of the Millennium.
Michael Harvey
Blackpool
harveymike@supanet.com

 The tree-lined boulevards of Paris have more in common with Southport than Prof Hughes believes (Paris: the Southport of the South, April 24): they are also miles from the sea and both live in the shadow of a big tower - Eiffel and Blackpool!
John Hamlett
Manchester
johnhamlett@mac.com

 There is some confusion, surely, over the Colchester road sign (Red alert over election fever, April 24). This must be New Labour signage, not Lib Dem, since it shows "Diversion" (dictionary definition: deviation, or perhaps US circus), is not red, and points right.
Tim Searle
Dronfield, Derbyshire
t_searle@longacre.demon.co.uk

 I am glad to hear that Posh Spice was so amply compensated for BA's mistake (Compensation for Posh bags, April 24). When British Airways lost my property on a flight to Prague back in September, I received not even an acknowledgement, despite writing to complain three times. Obviously only certain customers are always in the right.
Alison Ismail
London

fields.headline: La belle Southport
fields.standfirst: Lord Street inspired an emperor
fields.trailText: An imaginative local historian claims that Napoleon III was so impressed by Lord Street in Southport - where he lived prior to the 1848 revolution - that he ordered the great engineer Baron Hausmann to model the boulevards of Paris on it. If so, the revolting students on the Boulevard Saint Michel in 1968 have to thank the enterprising and big-thinking landlords of 1830s Lancashire for their ability to out-manoeuvre the police.
fields.body:
An imaginative local historian claims that Napoleon III was so impressed by Lord Street in Southport - where he lived prior to the 1848 revolution - that he ordered the great engineer Baron Hausmann to model the boulevards of Paris on it. If so, the revolting students on the Boulevard Saint Michel in 1968 have to thank the enterprising and big-thinking landlords of 1830s Lancashire for their ability to out-manoeuvre the police.

That had not been the original intention, of course, since Prefect Hausmann designed with riot suppression in mind. Since, presumably, the emperor (which he became in 1851) had not seen horse-drawn cannon manoeuvring on their way to quell the freemen of Formby - yeomanry were out of favour in the county after their antics at Peterloo in Manchester in 1819 - Hausmann must have added a few metres extra width for good measure.

But does Southport really need Paris for its self-esteem? Myopia is a local affiliation, to be sure - you have to screw your eyes up tight if you are ever to see the sea (the tide goes a mighty long way on the Mersey mudflats). But the delights of this Victorian town, child of the coupling of railway travel and sea-bathing, are not hard to find. Among them is Sir James Brunlees' 1860 pier - which, of course, needs its 1,211 yards' length in order to get anywhere near the aforementioned sea. Then there is the British lawnmower museum, 200-plus examples of grass-cutting's finest. If only Napoleon had planted grass in the Tuileries.

No, Southport needs no foreign buttress. As for those other examples of affirmation by foreign comparison, we can dispense with them, too. Let no one ever again say Edinburgh is the "Athens of the north", as if the view from the Parthenon could compare with the vista across the Forth from Calton Hill. And Birmingham - "more canals than Venice" - as if the Rio Foscari could hold a candle to the splendour that is Gas Street Basin.

fields.headline: Happy, but not necessarily clappy
fields.trailText: Stephen Bates describes St Martin's church in Birmingham taking on the role of urban centre, providing and coordinating a range of help and advice, physical and psychological, even religious when required (The vicar, his parish and a church in crisis, April 22). A role which, as an atheist, socialist, secularist and humanist, I would wholeheartedly support, as a greatly needed service in our fragmented and isolating society.
fields.body:
Stephen Bates describes St Martin's church in Birmingham taking on the role of urban centre, providing and coordinating a range of help and advice, physical and psychological, even religious when required (The vicar, his parish and a church in crisis, April 22). A role which, as an atheist, socialist, secularist and humanist, I would wholeheartedly support, as a greatly needed service in our fragmented and isolating society.

The only thing that is wrong with this model is that the church just cannot surrender its moral ownership, and vicars cannot go the last step and "do good" without the dog collar.

The role is needed, and the church has the people and the premises - often beauti ful buildings paid for originally by everyone through tithes and taxes, and in every area, urban, suburban, and rural.

Anyone associated with such projects has the right to their own personal beliefs and motivations, which may or may not be relevant to the individuals seeking help. Religion is but one item on the possible agenda of problems, as the Rev Newman readily admits.

If the church could find a way to retain its role, and further enhance its value by decoupling the religious strings, it would deserve all our thanks. If the church is to survive, perhaps this is the best way for it to do so - without the religion!
Suzanne Lord
Berrys Green, Kent

 It was such a pleasant surprise to read Stephen Bates's fair and objective article (Happy-clappy way to satisfy hunger for truth, April 24). My wife and I, as evangelical Christians and longstanding Guardian readers, are sometimes teased by our Christian friends for reading a newspaper generally perceived as unsympathetic to the Gospel. At least we can now show this article to our friends!

By the way, the term "happy-clappy" is somewhat pejorative and misleading. Our evangelical Anglican church, like many others, is only "clappy" during the children's slot. We certainly are a happy church but, none-the-less, confront very serious issues.
Gerry and Barbara Muldowney
Reading

fields.headline: Teachers divided
fields.standfirst:
Unity at the back of the class, please

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The National Union of Teachers' (NUT) conference ends today and the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers (NASUWT) begins in earnest. True to their Easter tradition, the first two, the Association of Teachers and Lecturers and the NUT, disappointed their leaders. Both were more interested in looking back than forward. Both resisted moves to modernise pay. Once again behaviour in debates at the NUT - heckling and booing the schools minister - descended to a level of disrespect which the union's president acknowledged would not be tolerated in the classroom. Some of the militancy is prompted by intense competition for members between the three, each affiliated to the Trades Union Congress. Is there a chance in this new century that a single union for all classroom teachers will emerge?
fields.body:
The National Union of Teachers' (NUT) conference ends today and the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers (NASUWT) begins in earnest. True to their Easter tradition, the first two, the Association of Teachers and Lecturers and the NUT, disappointed their leaders. Both were more interested in looking back than forward. Both resisted moves to modernise pay. Once again behaviour in debates at the NUT - heckling and booing the schools minister - descended to a level of disrespect which the union's president acknowledged would not be tolerated in the classroom. Some of the militancy is prompted by intense competition for members between the three, each affiliated to the Trades Union Congress. Is there a chance in this new century that a single union for all classroom teachers will emerge?

Sceptics have plenty of evidence to support their doubts: the adamant opposition of Nigel de Gruchy, leader of the NASUWT, the second biggest union; the unions' inability to unify their own memberships, let alone all teachers; and antagonism between the NUT and NASUWT going back almost a century. Yet there are grounds for optimism.

The unions are united on their single biggest grievance, which is not pay but work-loads and bureaucracy. This emerged in the Guardian poll published last month: it showed half of all teachers expected to quit within 10 years. Asked why, 75% pointed to increased work load and extra paperwork; 20% pointed to poor pay. There is widespread agreement on the need to reform the school funding system and end disparities between different authorities - which even ministers say are indefensible. There is a need for concerted action to promote the rewards of teaching - watching children develop. Most teachers still join to work with children and get that satisfaction.

The advantages of a single union are obvious - large administrative savings, a more coherent voice and stronger political influence. Doug McAvoy, NUT general secretary, spoke in favour of the move at a Guardian debate in 1998. This September the General Teaching Council, a new regulatory body, is launched. If the unions are not careful it will replace them as the voice of education. An obvious first step would be to federate existing unions. It may be too early for a single body, but a federation is surely feasible.

fields.headline: Crime is city business
fields.standfirst: Beware rural pleading that stinks
fields.trailText: A load of palpable nonsense has been talked about rural crime since the verdict in the Martin case. Those most at risk from burglary were, are, and will remain low-income council tenants on inner city estates. Shotgun owners living in detached houses in the country are not the usual victims of break-ins. That is the fate of jobless single parents in city blocks: detached dwellings, including isolated fenland farmhouses, are about half as likely as flats to suffer burglary. Burglary, afflicting one household in 20 a year, is an urban affliction, though the rate has been falling since the mid 90s, along, incidentally, with incidents of violence inflicted by strangers.
fields.body:
A load of palpable nonsense has been talked about rural crime since the verdict in the Martin case. Those most at risk from burglary were, are, and will remain low-income council tenants on inner city estates. Shotgun owners living in detached houses in the country are not the usual victims of break-ins. That is the fate of jobless single parents in city blocks: detached dwellings, including isolated fenland farmhouses, are about half as likely as flats to suffer burglary. Burglary, afflicting one household in 20 a year, is an urban affliction, though the rate has been falling since the mid 90s, along, incidentally, with incidents of violence inflicted by strangers.

The Martin case raises teasing questions about self defence and the protection of property, into which Ann Widdecombe yesterday typically hurled herself without pausing to engage her brain. This case has further to run since the police are investigating allegations of jury intimidation and Mr Martin's lawyers say he will appeal. But let us be very clear: the epitome of crime in modern Britain it is not. Martin is probably not even relevant to the question of policing rural areas. Government ministers would be well advised to squash any attempt by the Tories or those professionals of panic in the rightwing press to boil it up into some farmyard-odiferous "rural crisis".

Since 1997, Labour has found itself on uncertain ground in the shires, seemingly unable to distinguish genuine causes (the fate of hill farms, the disappearance of village amenities) from extravagant claims by vociferous lobbies for fox-hunting and a socially exclusive "rural way of life". Blairite modernisation rhetoric seems to favour the end of traditional forms of life, including further shrinkage of agriculture and branch banking. Yet Labour has shied away from the consequent pains. Despite its urban roots, the party had always been the Tory-supporting farmers' most generous friends and Tony Blair has kept up the tradition.

So spending arguments have been salted with anxiety about the countryside, taking that loose term to include the welfare of those who, living in villages and on farms, do most to preserve the topography townies love. Worrying over how best to compensate such big, open counties as Lincoln, Devon or Cumbria for the extra travel costs of, for example, their police and fire officers, is not new. Indeed the annual debate about how much local authorities deserve in revenue support grants regularly pits social need caused by sparsity against the extra costs of public services in the densely populated cities.

The intractability of such calculations means that the much-criticised "standard spending assessment" will live on, a monument to how little we still know about who deserves what public service. A special problem with preventative services is how to relate numbers of officers and less crime or fewer fires. There is no simple cause and effect. Things get even more tricky when you try to measure fairness. Studies show more police spending goes on poorer districts - but that may simply register the fact that police are called more to low-income households.

If the Home Office is convinced by good evidence that extra police numbers are justified for Norfolk or Lincolnshire on the basis of an equitable formula, so be it. Of course it will then be up to the councillors and magistrates who make up their police authorities on how any extra money is spent. But the government's decision-making on countryside matters needs to be closely scrutinised.

fields.headline: No more Mr Nice Guy
fields.standfirst: According to one ex-girlfriend, Tony Blair was a sweetie. Kind and thoughtful and ... zzzzzz.  Bonnie Greer on why women love bad boys
fields.trailText: According to one ex-girlfriend, Tony Blair was a sweetie. Kind and thoughtful and ... zzzzzz.  Bonnie Greer on why women love bad boys
fields.body:
The other day I ran into a friend, a successful theatre and TV director I hadn't seen in over a year. After the usual air-kisses, we started catching up. It turned out that beneath her girl-about-town facade was the quivering wreck of a female torturing herself with that age-old question: "Should I call him?"

Her furious chainsmoking and Sea Breeze-slurping was the direct result of missing someone she was desperate to see. I suggested she call - after all, her mobile was in her hand and she could use the excuse that she was drunk. But not even inebriation could erase the cold, hard facts. The reason she wasn't calling was simple: "He's a bastard."

I interrupted her litany ("He doesn't call, he only wants one thing, he's got a girlfriend" etc) to ask whether, in spite of all this, she still wanted to see him. She was silent for a moment, then said quietly: "Yes."

I dialled the number. Amazingly, he was in, catching up on his beauty sleep before another night of conquest. He invited her round. It was all right because his lady was away. And could she pick up some fish and chips? He already had beer. My friend rang off and said: "See what I mean?" I asked what she was waiting for. She finished her drink and was off. We both knew she was not involved with a nice guy.

Mary Harron, director of American Psycho, may feel her experiences with Oxford men informed her characterisation of the self-obsessed yuppie axe-murderer Patrick Bateman. The exception among the dreaming spires, it has just been revealed, was her boyfriend. He was "nice", she said, "very good-looking in a kind of sweet way, and wasn't at all predatory." The name: Tony Blair.

The Oxford Dictionary defines "nice" as "kind, considerate, friendly". It is a term of which we North Americans (Harron is Canadian) are fond. "Nice" is welcoming lights, home-cooking and Sunday school. A nice man is not a gunslinger or gambler. He will marry you in church, bring home the bacon, keep his nose clean.

Yet bad boys are infinitely more interesting and we know it. They can hold up to the mirror of consciousness what is suppressed within us. They are our shadow. A bad boy is attuned to the dark recesses. His focus is on females - and not as they are cleaned up to be. He senses that beneath the lotions and the potions, what we yearn for is chaos.

Now, I know this sounds utterly retrograde. Women have fought to be taken as rational human beings, full of wisdom and restraint. But guess what? Human beings aren't rational. How else do you explain war, William Hague, the return of the Playboy bunny? This desire for chaos is the reason Sex And The City is so good. Take "Mr Big". Big is the ultimate Not Nice Guy, the true "toxic bachelor", striding amid the wreckage of all who have tried to land him. We all know he will never commit. And that is what Cary wants. That's why she's with him. Big puts her in touch with who she really is.

The nice guy allows us to collude in notions of right and propriety that may help civilisation chug along, but we human beings are here to play, to mess up and find our way out again. Frank Dobson is a nice guy. He could make a good mayor for London. Look at him. His eyes are benign, his beard avuncular, his voice steady and sure. He's got nice policies, nice plans and the backing of Nice Tony. Yet according to the latest polls, the majority of us will not be voting for Nice Frank. If you were registered at a video dating agency and Frank came up on the screen, your head would tell you yes, maybe your heart would, too. But if Ken popped up on the screen, you know which one you'd choose. Trouble makes the world go round.

 Bonnie Greer's novel Hanging By Her Teeth is published by Serpent's Tail.
