She finished her drink and was off. We both knew she was not involved with a nice guy. Mary Harron, director of American Psycho, may feel her experiences with Oxford men informed her characterisation of the self-obsessed yuppie axe-murderer Patrick Bateman. The exception among the dreaming spires, it has just been revealed, was her boyfriend. He was "nice", she said, "very good-looking in a kind of sweet way, and wasn't at all predatory." The name: Tony Blair. The Oxford Dictionary defines "nice" as "kind, considerate, friendly". It is a term of which we North Americans (Harron is Canadian) are fond. "Nice" is welcoming lights, home-cooking and Sunday school. A nice man is not a gunslinger or gambler. He will marry you in church, bring home the bacon, keep his nose clean. Yet bad boys are infinitely more interesting and we know it. They can hold up to the mirror of consciousness what is suppressed within us. They are our shadow. A bad boy is attuned to the dark recesses. His focus is on females - and not as they are cleaned up to be. He senses that beneath the lotions and the potions, what we yearn for is chaos. Now, I know this sounds utterly retrograde. Women have fought to be taken as rational human beings, full of wisdom and restraint. But guess what? Human beings aren't rational. How else do you explain war, William Hague, the return of the Playboy bunny? This desire for chaos is the reason Sex And The City is so good. Take "Mr Big". Big is the ultimate Not Nice Guy, the true "toxic bachelor", striding amid the wreckage of all who have tried to land him. We all know he will never commit. And that is what Cary wants. That's why she's with him. Big puts her in touch with who she really is. The nice guy allows us to collude in notions of right and propriety that may help civilisation chug along, but we human beings are here to play, to mess up and find our way out again. Frank Dobson is a nice guy. He could make a good mayor for London. Look at him. His eyes are benign, his beard avuncular, his voice steady and sure. He's got nice policies, nice plans and the backing of Nice Tony. Yet according to the latest polls, the majority of us will not be voting for Nice Frank. If you were registered at a video dating agency and Frank came up on the screen, your head would tell you yes, maybe your heart would, too. But if Ken popped up on the screen, you know which one you'd choose. Trouble makes the world go round.  Bonnie Greer's novel Hanging By Her Teeth is published by Serpent's Tail.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: Why be coy? | Rather a woman than a hamster |
fields.body:
Despair, wrote novelist Graham Greene, is the price one pays for setting oneself an impossible aim. And Sidelines is indeed despairing at the shattering of some tender literary illusions. It has now been revealed that Greene, who brought us such pathos-ridden classics of thwarted desire as The End Of The Affair, communicated with his wife in a curious baby language. Fifteen children's books by Beatrix Potter, due to be auctioned at Bonhams next month, are inscribed by Greene to his wife Vivien in a childish idiom in which he called her Puss or Kitten and referred to himself as Wufth. Surely it's not The Heart Of The Matter that all lovers - even those who write the depths of moral complexity - secretly yearn to use baby animal monikers? That there is an Ickle Fufflum-Poos within all of us, blindly seeking a Nibbety Snook Puddle. Why be coy? Wearing nappies around the house is at least more honest.

 Readers who suffered unwanted boozy attention over the bank holiday should spare a thought for the hamster. New research claims it is an essentially antisocial animal which prefers to live alone and is so terrified of human contact that it takes 20 minutes to calm down after being touched. Stroking a hamster's fur increases its heartbeat by a plasma-juddering 50 times per minute. Imagine, if you will, the poor wee mite swilling a Bacardi Breezer in a crowded weekend bar, or even attending an uplifting Easter mass. The unalloyed horror offers a fresh perspective on the eternal gripe about the public places space invader. Rather a woman than a hamster ... unless you're on a wheel.

 And remember: Easter is a time not only of celebration but of contemplation, too. If you haven't sorted your life out by this morning, you're a bit pathetic really.

webTitle: Livingstone: the model of a postmodern politician

fields.headline: Livingstone: the model of a postmodern politician
fields.standfirst:
He has learned to turn the politics of rejectionism to his own advantage

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone is the acme of a postmodern politician. Though old of pedigree, he's the man of our time. Far from being a rebel against contemporary political norms, which is the reason many people think they will support him when voting starts on Thursday, he perfectly personifies them. Whereas Tony Blair, who has presided over the making of these norms, is far more substantial than they make him seem, Livingstone, who affects to despise them, could not succeed without them.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone is the acme of a postmodern politician. Though old of pedigree, he's the man of our time. Far from being a rebel against contemporary political norms, which is the reason many people think they will support him when voting starts on Thursday, he perfectly personifies them. Whereas Tony Blair, who has presided over the making of these norms, is far more substantial than they make him seem, Livingstone, who affects to despise them, could not succeed without them.

They favour image over substance, sound-bite over content, perception over reality, personality over programme, movement over party. Each of these priorities has been laid at the door of Blairism, and not exclusively by its enemies. There are loyal but anxious members of the Labour party who think this roughly sums up what Blair's politics have become, an impression they receive largely because the Blair machine has been so damned proficient at the business of spinning, otherwise known as news management, to pre-empt opinion. Spin persistently makes Blair seem a less substantial politician than he really is.

But the prevalence of this view of politics has been the making of Livingstone. He is good at sound bite, image and personality, so good that he's excused from the rules and penalties of the old politics. He's a bright face in a dull world, a cheeky chappy defying the robots. He can say that capitalism has killed more people than Nazism, and nobody turns a hair. He can take the side of rioters against the City, and the City scarcely lifts an adjective against him. In this unserious world, frivolity and cynicism are combining to promise him a landslide. His most perfect postmodern trick, a brilliant insight, was to turn to his advantage the lies he told about never leaving the Labour party: yes he's a liar, the people said, but he's the first politician ever to confess to lying. What a miracle of honesty this liar is!

In democracy, however, the people are seldom wrong. At any rate, their decisions need to be taken seriously, especially when these are so emphatic, in the teeth of a great deal of recorded damage to Livingstone's reputation, as the London vote looks set to be. Since there is no question of vote-rigging or strong-arming or other corruption, there have to be different explanations.

One is that this isn't a very serious vote anyway. The irrelevance of the mayor's power gives the maverick outsider support he would never get if people knew he could get his hands in their pockets. That is certainly part of the answer. He is a good vehicle for the showbiz vote, on the one hand, which likes to make a pious show of its right-on independence, and the radical lefty vote on the other, combining with the Tories to give Blair a bloody nose. The set-up offers the easiest free ride to every kind of anti-regime protester, unburdened by the need to secure support for a constructive agenda.

Alternatively, people could be reacting just as was always intended. Perhaps they are doing the duty Blair had in mind when he went for the mayoral system, which he has said he will go on supporting for other cities whatever happens in London. Maybe the loosening of centralised power, which mayorism is ultimately intended to produce, is hereby matched in the collective subconscious by a rejection of things that help build up this power, such as the tired-out party system. At the grand level, Livingstone might come to be seen as a battering-ram for the Blair experiment: a loveable rogue, a charlatan maybe - but one who inflames public demand for a newer new politics, and thereby becomes a historic hero.

Somewhere in the support for this rootless opportunist, both these elements are at work. They might even offer consolation to Mr Blair for the coming calamity. On the one hand, the Livingstone mayoralty can be dismissed as the trivial gesture of bloody-minded Londoners, making trouble where it won't really count. On the other, it could be elevated into a serious statement, vindicating what the prime minister always said he wanted to achieve, albeit rather more slowly.

In fact neither of these comforting explanations meets the case. Baser factors are at work, about which Blair has every reason to be anxious. They cannot be shepherded into a London ghetto. They say something systemic about the state of Britain and the state of politics, and the future the leader has to guard against.

Although the mayor has little power to act, he has a big platform from which to speak. A stroppy mayor can make hay with his own impotence. Livingstone will be that mayor. He's a posturer and grandstander supreme. The very emptiness of his pocket will provoke his righteous demand to raid the chancellor's. If he had real power, he would have to be really accountable: if he had real power, he would never be elected. With the little bit of power he does have, which is the power to grandstand and complain, there is no reason to doubt he will use it to make war not love with central government. Constrained elsewhere by the London assembly - on the police and transport, where local power will matter - that's the only choice before him, and he has already indicated which one he will make.

To some people, this is an attractive prospect. Could there be a better way of rubbishing Blair, and declaring against the system he controls? Control-freakery is the easiest count against him. He made a big mistake when he approved Millbank's twisting of the electoral system to keep Livingstone out and would do well to apologise, as he already has done for making the same mistake in Wales. Meanwhile, doesn't the anarchic nullity of Ken offer sweet revenge? The Tories are getting ready to play this to its maximum. Awaiting the day when Mayor Livingstone seeks readmission to the Labour party, they win both ways - either the loony lefty returns, or the control freak rules.

But excessive control is not, in truth, the source of Blair's biggest vulnerability. Much worse would be his failure to persuade the British public that he has been engaged for three years on a serious project. He is a very serious politician, whose energies, as far as I can see, are devoted entirely to the public interest. He has a driven but selfless view of his job. If spinning is artifice verging on mendacity, he needs less spinning than any prime minister in the past 30 years. Yet he has employed more of it than all of them put together, and thereby helped engender the raucous disbelief in politics that has put Ken Livingstone where he's about to be in London.

A vote for Livingstone is, at a deep level, an entirely negative act. The other candidates are an indifferent lot, but even the more plausible ones, such as Steve Norris and Susan Kramer, are nowhere. Rejectionism rules. It is the sea change that must most disturb a prime minister who least expected it.

fields.headline: Rafiq Haj-Yihyeh
fields.standfirst: Mayor of Taibeh and champion of Arabs living in Israel
fields.trailText: Rafiq Haj-Yihyeh, who has died of a heart attack aged 51, was one of the most colourful and mercurial champions of Israel's million-strong Arab community. Mayor of his hometown of Taibeh in south Galilee between 1989 to 1998, he played a significant national role for the Palestinians of Israel, as deputy head of the National Committee of Arab Local Authorities. For one tempestuous year, he was a representative of the Labour opposition in the Israeli Knesset, but resigned just before the elections that returned Labour to power.
fields.body:
Rafiq Haj-Yihyeh, who has died of a heart attack aged 51, was one of the most colourful and mercurial champions of Israel's million-strong Arab community. Mayor of his hometown of Taibeh in south Galilee between 1989 to 1998, he played a significant national role for the Palestinians of Israel, as deputy head of the National Committee of Arab Local Authorities. For one tempestuous year, he was a representative of the Labour opposition in the Israeli Knesset, but resigned just before the elections that returned Labour to power.

Haj-Yihyeh was born into a powerful Palestinian hamula (clan) and although he astutely exploited his familial ties, his irrepressible individuality and modernity made him more than just a traditional figurehead.

After graduating in Hebrew language and education, he taught at an agricultural secondary school from 1971 to 1980, and then was a reporter for Israel Television, where his sonorous voice and good looks were assets.

He became mayor at a particularly sensitive time. Taibeh's economy was in tatters, and the Palestinian intifada threw into sharp relief Israeli Arabs' dilemma - loyal citizens of a Jewish state, yet ethnically and politically tied to their cousins in the territories. Haj-Yihyeh responded by stimulating Taibeh's enterprises, while simultaneously lambasting the yawning discrepancy between municipal allocations to Jewish and Arab localities.

Within Taibeh, he fought a fierce battle against the rival Massarwa clan. He even masterminded an alliance with the Islamic movement - although religious extremists torched his car in 1989 and 1995. Ever the populist, Haj-Yihyeh enthusiastically supported Taibeh's football squad (another hamula fiefdom) and once lashed out at a police officer during a particularly heated match.

Violence was his Achilles heel. In 1994, he was convicted for assaulting an insurance inspector at a petrol station; he also attacked a press photographer while mayor; and in 1995 blew his chances of becoming Israel's first Arab ambassador (to Finland) when he admitted hitting his wife.

He certainly raised the status of Taibeh nationally. Unfortunately, economic fervour spawned a crime wave, and his overspending saddled Taibeh with debts.

Mercifully, Haj-Yihyeh was chosen to replace a former minister, Moshe Shahal, as a Knesset delegate in March 1998. He served on the finance, internal affairs and environment committees, but he never liked toeing the party line. When Labour sought to bring down the right-wing Netanyahu government, with a vote to draft orthodox Jewish rabbinical students, he broke ranks and sided with a coalition of Arabs and right-wing Zionists. He even called on municipalities to launch an intifada to force the building of better roads in Arab areas.

Nor was he scared of standing up to Arab rulers. In 1997, he accused Egypt of mistreating victims of a minibus from Taibeh which had crashed en route to Cairo. In 1998 he secured the release of four Taibeh residents whom Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority had summarily imprisoned for allegedly killing Hamas activists.

Haj-Yihyeh became increasingly disillusioned with Labour. He resigned from the party, only to see another Taibeh resident, Husniya Jabarra, becoming the first Arab woman elected to the Knesset in June 1999. Undaunted, he mounted extra-parliamentary campaigns for Arab rights, blending his insider's knowledge of Labour politics with a keen feeling for the "Arab street". Had he survived, Haj-Yihyeh might have helped Israel make peace at home, as well as abroad.

He is survived by his wife Farida, six children and two grandchildren.

 Rafiq Haj-Yihyeh, teacher, broadcaster, politician, born 1949; died April 16 2000

fields.headline: It's a dirty job...
fields.standfirst: So Cherie Blair is taking the eco-friendly route and plans to use real nappies on her baby. Good for her, says  Joanna Moorhead, but does she really know what she's letting herself in for?
fields.trailText: So Cherie Blair is taking the eco-friendly route and plans to use real nappies on her baby. Good for her, says  Joanna Moorhead, but does she really know what she's letting herself in for?
fields.body:
For the Real Nappy Association, it's the stuff PR dreams are made of. Imagine: from next month, every time the cameras are invited into the Downing St garden to record the visit of a foreign dignitary or some historic announcement, a row of white nappies will be fluttering on the breeze.

If the photographers arrive early, perhaps from time to time we'll be treated to pictures of the PM sharing his parenting responsibilities and pegging a few out before turning to shake hands with Bertie Ahern or Vladimir Putin.

Because, we are told, Mrs Blair this week committed herself to eschew the convenient but ecologically costly disposable nappy for the eco-friendly cloth variety. Good for you, Cherie: it's a laudable step, especially given that 7m trees were felled last year to make the 3bn nappies we used in the UK. Trouble is, it can be easy to forget those 7m trees when you're knee-deep in festering nappies at midnight and you realise you've got to wait up for the washing machine to finish so you can put them on to dry or you won't have any for the morning.

Just over a year ago, I gave up disposables for my then nine-month-old. It was a good decision: I enjoyed seeing those white nappies floating in the breeze in the garden, as Cherie - and hopefully Gordon on the other side of the fence - no doubt will. There is, too, something strangely satisfying about unpegging them and stacking them up in your airing cupboard, smug in the knowledge that they're best not just for your baby's bottom, but for her future as well.

What's more, as Cherie will find to her delight, it's good for cash flow. The initial outlay of £50 or £60 for all the paraphernalia may seem steep (nappies are just the start - you need pins, plastic pants, bucket with tight-fitting lid, nappy liners, cleaning fluid...) but apart from the cotton wool, you never need darken the baby aisle in the supermarket again.

Even if Cherie is tempted to go for one of the pricey washable- pant type nappy alternatives available (these include a German version with real wool outerpants) she shouldn't be out of pocket compared with what she'd be shelling out on Pampers for the next 24 months.

But, as she'll also find, there is a definite downside. For me, it wasn't so much the annoying leaks (though occasionally we did have to change the family bed in the middle of the night), and it wasn't the extra machine loads of washing when, goodness knows, you've already got enough to wash. No, for me it was the bucketloads of nappies waiting to be washed, sitting festering in the bathroom or next to the washing machine: a constant reminder, in scent as well as sight, of yet another job to be done when you've finished the 25 other things already on your list.

There was also, for me, the fact that my husband withdrew all support as a protest that using real nappies was bringing ecology far too close to home: scraping poo off a nappy was something he hadn't bargained for, and hadn't been forewarned about on the obligatory NCT parenting course. He spent more time in the office where the air was sweeter, and I spent more time on my own at home changing nappies.

So in the end I slunk back to the supermarket for the Pampers. I'm not proud of giving up on real nappies: whenever I see the plastic pants in the bathroom cupboard I feel a stab of guilt that, after six months of doing the right thing, in the end convenience lured me back to disposables. Good luck with your pledge, Cherie: but you'll need a lot more than luck to carry on without disposables as you juggle life as a barrister with life as a mother of four in an increasingly-cramped top-floor flat.

Still, at least you should have the support of your husband. After all, there's an election looming: and you can't get a cuter picture than a baby in a real, fluffy, white nappy.

Just over a year ago, I gave up disposables for my then nine-month-old. It was a good decision: I enjoyed seeing those white nappies floating in the breeze in the garden, as Cherie - and hopefully Gordon on the other side of the fence - no doubt will. There is, too, something strangely satisfying about unpegging them and stacking them up in your airing cupboard, smug in the knowledge that they're best not just for your baby's bottom, but for her future as well. What's more, as Cherie will find to her delight, it's good for cash flow. The initial outlay of £50 or £60 for all the paraphernalia may seem steep (nappies are just the start - you need pins, plastic pants, bucket with tight-fitting lid, nappy liners, cleaning fluid...) but apart from the cotton wool, you never need darken the baby aisle in the supermarket again. Even if Cherie is tempted to go for one of the pricey washable- pant type nappy alternatives available (these include a German version with real wool outerpants) she shouldn't be out of pocket compared with what she'd be shelling out on Pampers for the next 24 months. But, as she'll also find, there is a definite downside. For me, it wasn't so much the annoying leaks (though occasionally we did have to change the family bed in the middle of the night), and it wasn't the extra machine loads of washing when, goodness knows, you've already got enough to wash. No, for me it was the bucketloads of nappies waiting to be washed, sitting festering in the bathroom or next to the washing machine: a constant reminder, in scent as well as sight, of yet another job to be done when you've finished the 25 other things already on your list. There was also, for me, the fact that my husband withdrew all support as a protest that using real nappies was bringing ecology far too close to home: scraping poo off a nappy was something he hadn't bargained for, and hadn't been forewarned about on the obligatory NCT parenting course. He spent more time in the office where the air was sweeter, and I spent more time on my own at home changing nappies. So in the end I slunk back to the supermarket for the Pampers. I'm not proud of giving up on real nappies: whenever I see the plastic pants in the bathroom cupboard I feel a stab of guilt that, after six months of doing the right thing, in the end convenience lured me back to disposables. Good luck with your pledge, Cherie: but you'll need a lot more than luck to carry on without disposables as you juggle life as a barrister with life as a mother of four in an increasingly-cramped top-floor flat. Still, at least you should have the support of your husband. After all, there's an election looming: and you can't get a cuter picture than a baby in a real, fluffy, white nappy.

fields.headline: No: 1622 Kazakhstan
fields.trailText: Age: The ninth largest country in the world, the Kazakhs first emerged as a distinct ethnic group at the end of the 15th century, gaining independence with the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991.
fields.body:
Age: The ninth largest country in the world, the Kazakhs first emerged as a distinct ethnic group at the end of the 15th century, gaining independence with the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991.

Doubtless a country of fine and noble tradition, worthy of international respect. Unless you want to mention shooting bears.

Not entirely in keeping with the British love of all things ickle and fluffy. What would Joanna Lumley say? Don't blame me, blame the white, middle class Cambridge graduate aka Sacha Baron Cohen, who whipped up similar controversy with his yoof-from-hell Ali G.

Is it cos he's black? That is so last series. This time it's cos he's Kazakh. Channel 4's ubiquitous wind-up merchant has caused an international incident with his latest character, Borat, a fictional Kazakh reporter who is currently doing the rounds of the posh and pompous, on a mission to understand the subtleties of English society.

But someone's failed to see the joke? Bigtime. The Kazakhstan embassy in London will this week complain to C4 about the portrayal of their countrymen as hugely moustachioed animal-haters, with a penchant for prostitutes and naked women wrestlers.

Nothing wrong with a bit of girl-on-girl action, surely. So long as it's done tastefully. Not according to Talgat Kaliyev, the embassy's first secretary: "We understand we are in a foreign country and everyone has the right to express their opinions. But he is absolutely nothing like the people in Kazakhstan."

Well, he would say that, wouldn't he? And plenty more besides. Worse still, the moustache is all wrong. "He looks like some Turk or Arab," bemoans Kaliyev.

Do say: "Kazakhstan - isn't that that wonderful country where they love animals and treat the horse as a saint? We must go!"

Don't say: "You're having a party? Great! When do the prostitutes arrive?"

Not to be confused with: Kazak-Staines.

fields.headline: Six desperate men
fields.standfirst: Captain Scott dropped them off on the Antarctic coast to study penguins - but never came back for them. With no winter clothing and just seven weeks' rations, the team managed to survive for eight and a half months before reaching safety. Now, 90 years on, their doctor's blubber-stained notes are to be auctioned.  Angelique Chrisafis  on a brilliant feat of endurance

With no winter clothing and just seven weeks' rations, the team managed to survive for eight and a half months before reaching safety. Now, 90 years on, their doctor's blubber-stained notes are to be auctioned.  Angelique Chrisafis  on a brilliant feat of endurance
fields.body:
Six sheets of blubber-stained notes on the subject of happiness have been put up for auction at Christie's in a lot valued at £18,000. The writing is 90 years old and neatly pencilled. Happiness, say the notes, is largely a matter of contrast. "After a wretched day," they read, "the comparative comfort of the evenings enhanced by the stimulation of hot food makes us happy as sand boys."

These notes were written by the light of a seal blubber-burning lamp, crudely fashioned from an Oxo tin, under an Antarctic snowdrift during the winter in 1912. The so-called "ice cave manuscripts", which have never been published and have yet to be crawled over by scholars, describe in optimistic terms perhaps the most brilliant feat of survival in Antarctic history.

In the last months of his final polar expedition, Captain Robert Falcon Scott dropped off a party of six men to study penguins on the Antarctic coast, while he and the rest of his crew pressed on to the south pole. The penguin party was kitted out with summer sledging clothes and enough rations for seven weeks on the ice. Scott's ship was due to pick them up in six weeks' time - but the ship never came.

Somehow, those six men survived for eight and a half months, through the Antarctic winter, living in an ice cave 5ft high, dug out of a snowdrift on what was later called Inexpressible Island. They lived off seals killed with a pocket knife. Then, when spring came, they sledged 200 miles in four weeks to reach the British polar base, where they learned Scott had died.

The ice cave manuscripts were written by Murray Levick, a surgeon and zoologist Scott chose for his expedition because "he cheerfully accepts any amount of chaff". The blackened set of notes and two of Levick's journals (the latter were sold at Christie's last week for £94,000, three times the expected price) offer a fascinating insight into the penguin party's months on the ice.

The notes are not the only existing accounts of the venture, but William Mills, chief librarian and keeper at the Scott Polar Institute in Cambridge, says that they are important because "as a surgeon, Levick could write well of the psychology of men in adverse conditions". Early on, in the lead up to their confinement in the ice cave, Levick's neat handwriting reveals the bitchiness, boredom and bad temper suffered by a group of men forced to spend months in each other's company. Even before they were stranded, the six men (Levick, lieutenant Victor Campbell, geologist Raymond Priestley and three sailors) had spent a year and a half together in a small Antarctic hut. "Campbell is not a bad chap," Levick wrote in the hut. "But he is hopelessly out of place as a leader, being much too self-conscious and lacking sadly in guts. I feel rather a beast sometimes when Priestley and I get away together and crab him to each other whilst all the time he and I remain outwardly friendly."

Campbell provided Levick with his first study of "polar ennui" after sulking for two days following an argument. "I said, 'Look here, Campbell... the dullness is beginning to get on your mind and, to put it plainly, you have got the hump.' Many a fine chap has been taken the same way before and it is nothing out of the common." Levick gave him a medicinal tonic and noted that he was much more cheerful afterwards.

Later, when they were stranded waiting for Scott's ship, eating one sea biscuit a day, some men staying in their sleeping bags for two weeks at a time, the tone of Levick's notes changes dramatically. He writes of "fake hopes", nightmares of drowning and endless mirages of ships. Camped on the ice, the men held out hope for the ship's return for four weeks. Then, in gale force winds, Campbell and two others began to hollow a cave 9ft by 5ft out of a snowdrift, insulating it with ice. Levick and the rest made a tent out of skis and, with completely numb feet, walked two miles a day to hunt for seal meat. "Whatever we went through later on I am sure we were never all of us so thoroughly depressed as at this time," writes Levick. "Such is the effect of uncertainty and disappointment."

Levick's men butchered 100 penguins and eight seals and installed themselves in Campbell's igloo creation. They melted down blubber for lamps and a stove and, without a chimney, lived blackened by soot. Food consisted of oil-laden blubber and seal meat soup and a few mouthfuls of biscuit a day. Preparing a meal, Levick writes, was "a fearful business". The meat froze as soon as it was stored and the men hacked at it with a geological hammer only to watch the splinters fly off in the gale. They lived in almost perpetual darkness and dinner was served at 3.30pm.

Strangely, Levick's notes from inside the cave seem quite cheerful. "The only thing we have in abundance is time for reflection," he writes. Each night by blubber lamp, he read the party a chapter of David Copperfield. Then the men would "chew upon their mental cuds" occasionally thinking of a sentence worth saying, in which case the men would nose it about and discuss it "from its centre to its frayed edges".

Levick mulled this cheerfulness over and explained it psychologically in the consolation of several cakes of tobacco and some good pipes to smoke it in. Several degrees below zero, he writes: "My pipe is in my mouth and, as I puff slowly, I am sensible of a feeling of calm comfort and enjoyment and a tendency to look on the bright side of things."

Unlike alcohol, which Levick claimed cheered but dulled the mind and prompted people to forget the seriousness of their position, a pipe provided a philosophical state of mind "able to regard steadily the small roughnesses on the road which might otherwise have shaken it".

Levick found that discomfort can be tolerated remarkably well if the sufferer is a good person, a philosopher or a smoker. "No doubt as I write some wretched member of my club in London is miserable because one of the coasters is off the only available armchair in the smoking room," he says. "Perhaps that gentleman would be surprised to hear the figure I would give for that chair as it stands. The leather would make a pair of windproof trousers of which I stand badly in need, with enough to spare, perhaps, for moccasins. And then I could smoke the stuffing."

The rest of Levick's sooty ice cave meditations are a fragment of a short story set on a Mediterranean beach. Two soldiers are eating figs in the sun and discussing Scott's insane Antarctic mission. "All mad," says one of Scott's men. "And I daresay it's as cheap to send them there as to keep them locked in an asylum, though how they manage to pass any sort of medical exam before they go, I don't quite see." But Levick thought the officers who did not join the hapless Antarctic explorers displayed their own traits of lunacy.

By enforcing exercise and keeping food to an equal ration of meat and blubber, Levick managed to keep all six men sane in the cave. One of the sailors had a breakdown after returning to camp, but he recovered. "What, after all, are a few months of darkness and blubber lamps," Levick asks, "when we have an allowance of a couple of pipes a day to console us?"

fields.headline: Irina Alberti
fields.standfirst: Campaigner for anti-communism
fields.trailText: Irina Alberti, who has died aged 75, dedicated her life to supporting, with intensity and passion, not only such world figures as Alexander Solzhenitsyn and Andrei Sakharov, but also countless lesser-known people, especially those persecuted by the Soviet authorities for their religious convictions.
fields.body:
Irina Alberti, who has died aged 75, dedicated her life to supporting, with intensity and passion, not only such world figures as Alexander Solzhenitsyn and Andrei Sakharov, but also countless lesser-known people, especially those persecuted by the Soviet authorities for their religious convictions.

Emotional though she often was in her personal dealings, she combined this characteristic in a remarkably successful way with a lengthy tenure of the editorial chair of La Pensée Russe (Paris), a weekly published in Paris in Russian. Her fight was to print the truth about Soviet communism, and she did this with integrity, especially during the last 20 years of her life, never abandoning objectivity. During the few years before the advent of Mikhail Gorbachev, her paper was forbidden, but avidly sought, reading.

The collapse of communism saw a dramatic change in her life. In the teeth of unending financial crises, endemic in such work, Irina Alberti oversaw the establishment of a Moscow office for her newspaper in 1993.

New opportunities for distribution in Russia ensured that the publication shone as a beacon of democracy and religious liberty in the murky world of Russian journalism. Despite her advancing age, she spent her last seven years commuting monthly between Moscow and Paris.

Political turbulence made Irina Ilovaiskaya, as she was born, into a true European.

Her Russian parents emigrated to Yugoslavia, where she was born. Although brought up within the Russian Orthodox tradition, Croatian Catholicism influenced her from an early age and she came under the spell of the beauty of Catholic worship and architecture in Dubrovnik. When in Belgrade, she remarked on the positive relations between Orthodox and Roman Catholics there, before the second world war and communism worked their damage.

She and her mother were briefly imprisoned during the war, mistakenly identified as fleeing Jews, when they tried to reach Dubrovnik to care for her ailing grandfather. Once more, in 1945, the family fled from communism and reached Italy. Ilovaiskaya married an Italian diplomat, becoming devoted to the culture, language and religion of her adopted country.

Immediately there followed the second defining moment in her world outlook. The Albertis were posted to Prague in 1948, where Irina witnessed another communist takeover. After three years, they were expelled because of her husband's support for the persecuted democrats. Back in Italy, she devoted her life to exposing the truth about communism, translating Russian texts into Italian and eventually becoming the distinguished Rome correspondent of Radio Liberty, the American Russian-language station. This gave her a superb opportunity to develop her religious interests and to support the cause of Christian unity.

After the death of her husband in 1975, she was free to accept an invitation from Solzhenitsyn, soon after his expulsion from the Soviet Union, to move to Vermont, as his secretary, where she worked with him for three years. Part of her responsibility was to communicate during that difficult time with the Russians who administered the Solzhenitsyn Fund for the relief of political prisoners and were themselves persecuted for their activities.

She was by now a world authority on Soviet dissidents, and was ideally placed when she returned to Europe in 1978 to take over the editorship of La Pensée Russe, which already enjoyed a reputation as a mouthpiece for the true voice of Russia speaking to the West.

Irina Alberti had the means at her disposal to devote more space from the mid-1980s to Gorbachev's perestroika than almost any other publication, although not even she could have imagined that this would lead to the collapse of the Soviet Union and the resulting new opportunities in Moscow. There was still campaigning journalism to be done - for example, exposing the story of the expulsion by the Patriarchate of Fr Martiri from his central Moscow church. Not content with printed journalism, she also helped set up an ecumenical radio station, the Christian Channel, working closely with an Orthodox priest, Fr Ioann Sviridov.

Additionally, she had to keep up personal contacts with those who funded her enterprises, and she was at the headquarters, near Frankfurt, of her great supporters, Aid to the Church in Need, when she collapsed and died, at the end of a vigorous working day.

A son predeceased her, and two daughters survive her.

 Irina Ilovaiskaya-Alberti, journalist, born December 5 1924; died April 5 2000

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Richard Adams
fields.trailText: • Satirising New Labour and its acolytes gets harder all the time. Just take a look at this website [www.howarddawber.org.uk] set up by Howard Dawber, a puppy who failed to win the nomination for the Ashton under Lyne seat. "Howard has been engaged since Labour Conference 1999 to Jessica," the website says. "The happy news was announced at a fringe meeting by Peter Mandelson." How much more romantic could you get?
fields.body:
 Satirising New Labour and its acolytes gets harder all the time. Just take a look at this website [www.howarddawber.org.uk] set up by Howard Dawber, a puppy who failed to win the nomination for the Ashton under Lyne seat. "Howard has been engaged since Labour Conference 1999 to Jessica," the website says. "The happy news was announced at a fringe meeting by Peter Mandelson." How much more romantic could you get?

 The Daily Telegraph's editorial pages are a well-known refuge for fruitcakes, but it still manages to print letters to the editor that leave one's gob well and truly smacked. On Friday, Peter McGregor (of Longworth, Oxfordshire, but he doesn't say which planet) wrote that if Jesus had not been a Jew, then the Jews would now be "a relatively insignificant tribe of troublesome peasants... without any kind of developed civilisation". Deep breath, I'm afraid there's more. "As Jews celebrate Passover, I have a question for them: if God got them out of Egypt by miraculous intervention, what was he doing when Hitler tried to exterminate them?" A fascinating question, but alas not an original one: Nazi concentration camp guards would ask Jewish inmates: "So where is your Jehovah now?"

 Letters like Mr McGregor's do at least make Boris "the Jackal" Johnson sound sane, even when he drones on in both the Telegraph and Spectator about how the real problem with asylum seekers is the corrupting influence of Britain's welfare system. Boris's solution is to let all the refugees in, but to not give them any benefits. A brilliant idea - as long as you don't think about it for longer than two seconds.

 While gun-totting farmer Tony Martin would probably have a better chance of getting elected mayor of London now than Frank Dobson does, dear old Dobbo is currently inspiring new works of art:

"Dobbo #96 - representations of Frank Dobson within a politico-cultural context", it says on the back of the preview card from the Gordon Reece Gallery in London.

 Oh dear, another leak. This time it's from the Labour party's resource centre at parliament. "Dear colleague, it has been brought to our attention that emails have been sent to Labour MPs supposedly from the prime minister personally," write Veronica Martell and Liz Shannon. "It's quite clearly a spoof, so please ignore it if you receive it." Yes, clearly a spoof, as we all know that Mr Tony Blair can barely even use the internet that he so often bangs on about. fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite cable and digital
fields.body:
The Spanish Prisoner (David Mamet, 1998) 8pm, Sky Premier
Mamet is back in House Of Games mode, and he's built a veritable tower block of con-trickery this time. Campbell Scott's Joe Ross is the whiz behind The Process - a top secret wotsit with a hefty commercial value - and is drawn into an odd relationship with wealthy, enigmatic Jimmy Dell (Steve Martin) after an altercation over a camera in the Caribbean. Scott, as the dupe of an intricate, infinitely complex scam, is too anodyne to be sympathetic, but it's a vastly entertaining intellectual exercise.

Smoke (Wayne Wang, 1995) 8pm, FilmFour
Harvey Keitel is the Brooklyn tobacco store manager around whose shop a series of troubled characters work out their crises: most engaging is Forest Whitaker's garage owner, while William Hurt plays an author called Paul, presumably related to the scriptwriter, novelist Paul Auster. A long way from the melodrama of Wang's The Joy Luck Club; although the final shift from Hamlet-advert-melancholy to Grand-Havana-triumph is very satisfying.

White Mischief (Michael Radford, 1987) 10pm, Living
Down in Kenya's Happy Valley, a bunch of rich Brit ex-pats while away the war until a murder spoils the show. It's hard to feel sorry for this self-indulgent lot, plucked from James Fox's novel about the real-life murder of Lord Erroll. Greta Scacchi's Diana weds old Sir Jock (Joss Ackland) for the money and beds Charles Dance's Erroll on the side. Tripe, but highly watchable tripe.

Ms 45 (Abel Ferrara, 1981) 12.15am, FilmFour

A story about a rape victim turning vigilante could be a premise for a probing look into feminist agendas. But Driller Killer director Abel Ferrara is not renowned for his subtlety, so a beautiful mute girl (Zoe Tamerlis) gets raped twice and robbed, all in one day, providing a plethora of excuses for Ferrara to stick his camera in where it really isn't wanted. Tamerlis then goes on a murder spree, wreaking bloody vengeance on any man who pushes his unwanted attentions on her.

fields.headline: Any part in a storm
fields.trailText: Harbour Lights | Cor, Blimey! | Lost Gods Of Easter Island
fields.body:
The first series of Harbour Lights (BBC 1) was a bit of a switch off. It is clear that several heads were put or banged together before a second was commissioned.

Nick Berry, wreathed in whiskers, returned to Bridehaven, a seaside resort once noted for fresh air and fun, but now in the cruel grip of a lawyer, an accountant and - in case they don't frighten you - a psycho.

You knew things had changed because people kept saying "Things have changed", then changing the subject.

This sort of thing used to happen to Gary Cooper a lot. He would come back and find the heavy mob were selling Tombstone as holiday homes. This was the plan at Bridehaven. The psycho, to whom one insensibly warmed, had an even simpler plan. Kill everyone in alpha betical order.

Nick Berry did not flinch. Shaving off his beard, he stood revealed as our hero.

As we reeled towards the end, the hard work of the make-up department was evident. Nick's wounds were decoratively stitched. There was a good selection of broken arms and legs. The harbourmaster was wrapped in duct tape and lashed to the rafters. The lawyer, driven by Nick, fled with his ill-gotten gains and the psycho, pursuing as ever his own beautifully simple agenda, put a bomb in their car. ("I've wired the bomb to the CD player. You know he's always playing that poncy Tosca stuff? When the bird hits the really high note, it whacks off. Kerboom!")

As Nick strangled the lawyer in the pounding surf, the fat lady sang.

Cor, Blimey! (ITV) was about the affair between Bar bara Windsor (Samantha Spiro) and Sid James (Geoffrey Hutchings) and, coincidentally, about comedy, despair and death.

It was like a Punch and Judy show with the fell sergeant, death, waiting in the wings with his truncheon. To Sid James, middle-aged and married, Barbara Windsor must have seemed like the bright, little ball that bounces along the lyrics in panto, getting a singsong going just when he thought the party was over. Their dialogue was most effective when least pretentious. "Can't we talk about the weather?" "It's raining and I love you." "Change the subject." "It's still raining and I still love you."

Terry Johnson, the writer, treated the 25-year age difference between them as a serious stumbling block. He could not have anticipated that this month Barbara Windsor would marry a man 25 years her junior.

It took a while to get used to the minimal but enormous difference between the actors and the originals. In this sense, it was a bravura, extended edition of Stars In Their Eyes. At the end Barbara Windsor appeared herself to put a showbiz gloss on life."I think 'eaven's being alone with a Steenbeck in the edit suite. You sit in front of your life and you're allowed to re-edit it. Cut the rotten bits. Loop the sex. Make it better every time and eventually make it perfect." Kenneth Williams (Adam Godley) replied with the terrible last line of his diary "Oh, what's the bloody point?" The Carry On team are demonstrable proof that funny is not happy.

I was particularly tickled by the uncomplicated Eddie (Kenneth MacDonald), a bouncer hired by Barbara's underworld husband to keep an elephantine eye on Sid. "I've got a messge from Ron. He told me to tell you it's not so much the money and its not so much you shagging his wife. It's more you shagging his wife when you owe him so much money. He feels that's taking the piss somewhat."

Lost Gods Of Easter Island (BBC 2), oddly enough, had a story about an easter egg. When birds roosted off Easter Island, young men used to compete to bring an egg back to their clan leader. The first to receive one became the incarnation of god for a year and an Easter Island statue would be erected in his honour.

The fate of Easter Island is a salutary tale. The landscape is now lunar. The islanders cut down all their trees and could no longer build sea-going canoes to fish or escape. When Capt Cook arrived, as he invariably did, they were so wretched they traded their sacred carvings for anything. David Attenborough bought one at auction, not knowing its provenance but feeling its power. It is the image of their creator.

The moral of this story is that against stupidity the gods themselves are helpless. Oh, and always trust your instinct in the auction room.

fields.headline: Getting personal with... Jim O'Rourke
fields.trailText: Answer me
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? Yes, as part of the US government's witness relocation program.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? Only my mental age.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Lonely heart wishes to find someone to keep it that way.

What was the last illegal thing you did? Used a phone line in a department store to answer this.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? Helped a small child free himself from a New York sewer.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? To pick one would be proof of extraterrestials, so I'll pick a few: Sam Prekop, Phil Bonnet, Sonic Youth folk, Pitta and Fennesz, Sean O'Hagan, everyone from 1998 and 1999.

What are the initials of the least nice person you've ever worked with? I'm not falling for that one...

Has a critic ever made you cry? Yes, tears of blood.

What would you advertise without a fee? Cyndi Lauper, Leann Rimes, Baby Spice, Mac powerbooks, Manley electronics, furbies, analogue systems electronics, Kate Winslet, Doepfer electronics, child disc, Serge electronics, Mego, Beyer microphones.

What would you never advertise? Meat, Domino's pizza, and Pokemon.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning? Well, I'm still awake, but, running out of coffee at 4 am is pretty scary.

What takes you to a "happy place"? Coffee, cigarettes, and my powerbook.

 Jim O'Rourke is touring the UK and Ireland from May 2.

fields.headline: The strange story
fields.standfirst: It was - if only briefly - the greatest and strangest soap opera ever to grace our screens. But it vanished as quickly as it came. And whatever happened to its stars? As the first series returns,  Danny Leigh reports on the curse of Twin Peaks
fields.trailText: It was - if only briefly - the greatest and strangest soap opera ever to grace our screens. But it vanished as quickly as it came. And whatever happened to its stars? As the first series returns, Danny Leigh reports on the curse of Twin Peaks
fields.body:
With hindsight, I blame Ruffles. That was the final nail. Barely had the credits rolled on the last ever Twin Peaks, and there was Kyle MacLachlan, dolled up in his FBI macintosh, hawking crisps in a TV ad. The cryptic, cerebral Agent Dale Cooper, baffled by Ruffles' cheese and onion ridges: it was a sad end to a strange story.

Rewind 18 months, to early April 1990. The debut episode of David Lynch's absurdist take on Peyton Place, which returns tonight, had just premiered, and the world was freshly smitten with the quintessential American small town behind whose soporific theme tune lurked soap opera the like of which we'd never seen before. You wanted log ladies? Backwards-talking dwarves? They were yours. Twin Peaks had the lot: sex, death, doughnuts and damn fine coffee. And right in the middle was Cooper, homing in on whoever did kill Laura Palmer between regular endorsements of the Dalai Lama.

Of course, in among a cast of relative nobodies, MacLachlan had the plum gig. Except he was never the main attraction; that was always Lynch. Despite directing no more than six of an eventual 30 episodes, the show was forever his: designed after his sardonic gosh-darnit persona; informed by his obsession with diners and dirty little secrets; made off the back of his bona fide cinematic kudos.

Because, back then, the elaborately coiffed figure of the series' creator was sufficiently iconic to warrant attention when he deigned to step down to the small screen. Which represented at least half the battle in persuading viewers more used to Dynasty to sample Lynch's procession of doppelgangers and cherry pie. Sure, it wasn't as if Blue Velvet or The Elephant Man (or, God knows, Dune) had set box offices alight; but the mere idea of an arch-hipster dabbling in a genre hitherto devoted to frocks and bitch-fights proved pure media catnip.

And so Twin Peaks became - briefly - inescapable. Phenomenal. Wall-sized guides were given away with tabloids, the frozen image of Laura's corpse was everywhere (even if it had been lifted from Tim Hunter's mordant teen-flick River's Edge), the merchandise (books, board games, coffee mugs) flowed abundant. After decades of drizzly obscurity, the Pacific North West suddenly got fashionable - two years before Nirvana made their debut album - as tourists queued for Twin Peaks burgers in the tiny real-life set of Snoqualmie, Washington State. Ratings were good; critics lathered up comparisons to Molière and Shakespeare.

Weird. But not as weird as what happened afterwards.

You see it's a little-known fact that - after the messy business with Laura Palmer meandered to its conclusion - the second series of Twin Peaks was better than the first. Little-known because no one ever watched it. As the tone drifted from amiably zany to dangerously eccentric, so viewers in droves turned over to Cheers. Blame it on the initial PR overkill, blame it on the show's increasingly baroque tendencies (one episode, directed by Diane Keaton, featured a cadre of ethereal Nazi troops just, you know, hanging out), but last year's Must-See had somehow been transformed into this week's Just Can't Be Bothered.

The rest was ignominy: summary cancellation, ill-fated protests from Lynch himself, and a movie prequel, Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me (opening scene: an axe hacking up a TV set), so reviled that David Bowie's accent was seen as the least of its flaws. And that, in essence, was that.

For stars and svengali alike, it was a long, hard fall. Reading the cast list now is like looking at an autopsy of mass professional suicide: Sherilyn Fenn, Madchen Amick, Sheryl Lee, each marooned in the dank career hinterlands of straight-to-video (although special mention must be made of Jack Nance, who wound up dying a very Lynchian death in a Pasadena doughnut shop). MacLachlan, meanwhile, having entered the show as leading man-elect of 90s cinema, left it as a bit part-to-be. Ironically, the single biggest name to emerge from the show was - and you can bet Kyle saw the funny side of this - David Duchovny, formerly Peaks' transgender Fed Denise, latterly Fox Mulder in The X-Files. And Lynch? Well, his reputation tarnished by accusations of misogyny and irrelevance, he saw out the decade in pottering oblivion, finally reclaiming his artistic lustre with last year's The Straight Story. You can't help feeling the hardcore of TP obsessives, ardently clamouring for a belated third series at their annual Snoqualmie fan convention, have a long wait left ahead of them.

Which is a shame. After all, over and above the singular details of its rise and fall, Twin Peaks took TV somewhere it had never been before: beyond the prosaic confines of living room furniture, and into somewhere - to quote an early instalment - strange and wonderful. I remember watching the final episode as a teenager and thinking it was the greatest hour of television I'd ever seen. I watched it again last night; it was every bit as good.

Kyle MacLachlan's Ruffles, on the other hand, have probably gone a bit stale by now.

• Twin Peaks, tonight, 8pm, Sci-Fi channel

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
One of our cherished myths centres on the idyllic hush in which folk went about their lives in earlier centuries, with the lark's song only interrupted by the distant clip-clop of hooves. You have only to embroider the picture to suspect its improbability. One account from 1584 managed to list more than 30 separate urban annoyances. In Lend Me Your Ears (9.30am, Radio 4) Fiona Shaw (pictured) imagines what would have assaulted the average Tudor ear.

The second of Bridget Kendall's election-year surveys of the United States tracks the remarkable growth of its Latino population. Within five years, Latinos will have overtaken blacks as the largest "ethnic" minority and the two groups together will outnumber the white population. But there are few signs of the Latinos adopting the Anglo culture. As Kendall reports in Manifest Destinies (8pm, Radio 4), one politician thinks the time has come for English-speakers to start learning Spanish.

In Lend Me Your Ears (9.30am, Radio 4) Fiona Shaw (pictured) imagines what would have assaulted the average Tudor ear. The second of Bridget Kendall's election-year surveys of the United States tracks the remarkable growth of its Latino population. Within five years, Latinos will have overtaken blacks as the largest "ethnic" minority and the two groups together will outnumber the white population. But there are few signs of the Latinos adopting the Anglo culture. As Kendall reports in Manifest Destinies (8pm, Radio 4), one politician thinks the time has come for English-speakers to start learning Spanish.

fields.headline: Armchair rebels threaten Labour hopes
fields.standfirst:
Local elections: Party workers fear disillusionment and apathy as expected low turnouts prompt experiments to woo the voters

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour is bracing itself for big losses in local elections on May 4 for 3,360 seats on 153 English councils. But in what is likely to be the last national poll before the general election, the party's main battle will be persuading its own sceptical supporters to turn out and vote.
fields.body:
Flicking through the bulging pile of canvass returns before pounding the streets of Sunderland, the small Labour campaign team has learned from bitter experience never to take promises for granted.

National opinion polls may give the party a commanding lead over the Tories and Liberal Democrats in the run-up to next week's local elections in England, when 3,360 seats on 153 councils are being contested. But activists know that support for the government in the big cities and the old industrial heartlands is more tenuous, with electors often disillusioned or plain apathetic.

Labour is bracing itself for losses as it begins the long slide away from the heyday of the mid-90s when John Major was at the height of unpopularity. Up to 500 losses will set alarm bells ringing, with fears that core voters in Sunderland and elsewhere are on strike.

After studying local byelection results over the past year, some analysts even put the Tories marginally ahead of Labour. And in Sunderland's Hendon ward, like other former Labour strongholds, they know the result will be tight.

Dirty campaign

"See that pile," sighs Bryn Siddaway, former leader of Sunderland city council, eyeing the returns nervously. "Two thousand promises and only 650 turned out last time. Turning Labour supporters into voters is bloody hard." He should know. Last year, against all expectations, Mr Siddaway was defeated by a Tory in Hendon by two votes. "They flooded the place with workers," he laments. "I wasn't so upset by losing - that's democracy - but it was a dirty campaign."

Everyone agrees that Labour has one big problem - the armchair rebel. "The Tories and the Lib Dems can always pull out their people," says a middle-aged worker in the Hendon team. "We find it much more difficult."

"I joined the party when I was 19, or 20, and now I am 41 and I am still one of the youngest people in the party in Sunderland," volunteers Kevin Marquis, chairman of the Hendon ward and agent for the Sunderland South Labour MP, Chris Mullin. "That tells you something."

"Local democracy is in crisis because no one wants to stand as a councillor, membership is stagnant, and practically no one wants to go on the local panel of candidates," says another campaigner.

In truth, democracy in Sunderland, and other big cities, is dying. Last year the best ward turnout in the city was below 30% while the worst was down to just 12%. The pattern was repeated from Birmingham to Liverpool, Sheffield to Newcastle, and in the subsequent Euro elections one Sunderland polling station in the Central ward recorded a 1.5% turnout, probably the lowest in British electoral history.

Colin Anderson, leader of Sunderland council, insists he has "democratic legitimacy" on a miserable 17% turnout when he was relected in Central last year. But he adds cautiously: "The fact that 83% did not vote says something about the legitimacy of the overall political system, but I do not blame the people who have not voted. This is one of the country's poorest wards. If your daily life is struggling to survive... voting is not a top priority."

In Liverpool's Walton constituency the MP Peter Kilfoyle, who resigned as a junior defence minister in protest at Labour ignoring its heartlands, tells a similar story after spending last week campaigning.

Voters, he says, are turning away from Labour "in droves... they see nothing in it for them". He fears the worst next week.

Scare stories

Nevertheless Labour strategists are determined to prevent a repeat of last year's Euro elections when they were defeated by the Tories on a miserably low turnout after ignoring William Hague's strong Euro-sceptic campaign. Unashamedly, they are sidelining council affairs and concentrating on scare stories, such as a Tory threat to "privatise" the health service, in the hope of bringing core voters back on board.

But councils are also fighting apathy. In an attempt to breath new life into town hall politics, Sunderland is joining 31 other authorities in piloting new electoral systems to persuade more people to vote. The idea is to spread the process over one week, rather than just one day. From Friday until Tuesday, the city's three main libraries will double as polling stations while "mobile polling" will be introduced for the first time. Election officers will take ballot boxes to 35 old people's homes before the official polling day. Manchester is introducing early voting, next Saturday and Sunday, in shops in each of the five constituencies with an additional polling station in the city centre. Councils such as Bolton, Eastleigh, Norwich, Stevenage and Doncaster are experimenting with an extension of postal voting in some wards by giving everyone the opportunity to vote by post.

In Watford, where Labour has a majority of two, the council has decided to scrap the traditional Thursday poll, on May 4, and spread its main election over two days the following weekend. It is also experimenting with early voting in an Asda supermarket next Thursday, Friday and Saturday and taking ballot boxes to 100 old people's homes.

Vince Muspratt, leader of Watford council, hopes the introduction of Continental-style voting will excite a generally apathetic electorate; last year, 64% stayed at home. "If 4% more people voted (taking the turnout to 40%) I'd say 'great', and if it went to 50% we'd have taken it to European levels," he said.

Nationally, Labour has talked about losing half the 1,553 seats it is defending, most of them last contested in 1996 when John Major's government hit rock-bottom. In Trafford, Greater Manchester, Tories need two seats to gain control from Labour while the Liberal Democrats - building on their success in capturing Sheffield last year, and Liverpool in 1998 - have an outside chance of winning Oldham. In the West Midlands, Conservatives need only two gains to win overall control of Solihull, while in the south Tories have high hopes of winning Torbay from the Lib-Dems.

Tory doubts

But despite losing ground in its heartlands, Labour privately believes that the Tory recovery could be modest. Even to match last year's performance they need to win 200 seats. But they should be aiming for 400 gains to reach a lead that opposition parties generally have over a government at this stage of the parliamentary cycle.

Tories say that two factors will count against a significant recovery. Firstly, a far higher proportion of seats are being contested in Labour's heartlands - with 52% on metropolitan or unitary councils compared with 16% last year. Secondly, a lower proportion of councils have all-out elections with every seat up for grabs. This makes it more difficult to win back control of many councils.

Yet Labour's heartlands are still in danger of slipping away, which explains why ministers are planning initiatives to win back core voters. Party organisation may be patchy, but ministers know that the Tory machine is in a more parlous state.

fields.headline: Ethiopia's Jews wait for exodus
fields.standfirst:
Israel has withdrawn its welcome to new citizens from the Horn of Africa

Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: Even at 75 and with a body so worn out that it requires every ounce of strength just to cross from one side of the ramshackle hut to the other, Gadamu Kassa still clings to his lifelong dream.
fields.body:
Even at 75 and with a body so worn out that it requires every ounce of strength just to cross from one side of the ramshackle hut to the other, Gadamu Kassa still clings to his lifelong dream.

He and his wife are Jews and when they left their village in north-western Ethiopia two years ago for the capital, Addis Ababa, their land was taken and their house burned down, leaving them with nothing but their dream of a new life in Israel.

Mr Kassa points to the Star of David carved on the door of his hut as proof of his faith, and fingers a photograph of his son who he says now lives in Israel. His wife is baking unleavened bread in preparation for the Passover festival, which celebrates the flight of the Jews from bondage in Egypt.

Now thousands of Ethiopians are pleading with the Israeli government to allow a new exodus of Jews across the Red Sea to the Promised Land.

Israel has been reluctant to recognise the right to citizenship of people such as Mr Kassa because it suspects many Ethiopians of claiming Jewishness to escape economic hardship at home.

Doors close

Earlier this month the Israeli interior minister, Natan Sharansky, who himself emigrated to Israel from the former Soviet Union, went to Addis Ababa to assess their claims. He sympathised with the wretched conditions in which many Ethiopian Jews were living, saying: "I can only compare them with the punishment cells of the Soviet Union in which I spent many years."

But despite Israel's Law of Return, which guarantees citizenship to Jews anywhere in the world, Mr Sharansky said, "we cannot open up the doors for everyone who wants to come in".

As many as 70,000 Ethiopian Jews already live in Israel, most of them airlifted there during Operation Moses in 1984 and again during Operation Solomon in 1991. But more than 20,000 remain in slums in Ethiopia, waiting for their own exodus.

They trace their ancestry back to the fifth century BC, when Jewish traders went down the Nile to its source in western Ethiopia, converting communities. Successive Christian rulers launched pogroms to wipe out the Falashas - as the Ethiopian Jews became known - or force them to convert.

Some converted and adhered to Christianity. Others converted in name only, out of fear, while others stuck to their faith.

In June 1990, just months before Operation Solomon, the Israeli embassy drew a distinction between the Falashas and what they termed the "Falash Mura". Falash Mura had converted to Christianity, they said, and were therefore not eligible for citizenship.

But a decade later tens of thousands of Falash Mura meet every day at compounds in Addis Ababa and the northern Ethiopian town of Gondar run by the North American Conference of Ethiopian Jewry (Nacoej), which supports their claims. Here they practice contemporary Judaism to prove their pedigree.

Schoolchildren learn Hebrew songs and begin the day singing the Israeli national anthem. The wooden posts and bars surrounding the compound are painted in the blue and white of the Israeli flag and on the wall of each classroom is a sign which reads: "Let's Go Home."

More than 65% of those who meet daily at the Beta Israel compound in Addis Ababa have close relatives in Israel. According to Andy Goldman, Nacoej programme director, the Israeli government's refusal to grant them citizenship is "the first time that people with traceable Jewish ancestry are being turned away".

Racist refusal

Mr Goldman says he suspects that racism is behind Israel's refusal to allow the Falash Mura into Israel. He is angry that while Ethiopian Jews are left to fester in poverty forced on them when they left their homes to go to the capital to seek evacuation, Jewish agencies scour the former Soviet Union for the descendants of lapsed Jews, who are then invited to settle in Israel.

"At a time when more than half of the emigrants to Israel from the former Soviet Union are non-Jews, it seems ridiculous for Israel to deny entry to Ethiopians of unquestioned Jewish ancestry," said Joseph Feit, a former Nacoej president.

Rabbi Michael Meheret is a Jew of Ethiopian origin who now lives in Israel. He was evacuated from a refugee camp in Sudan in 1984 during Operation Moses.

During 16 years in Israel he has seen a flood of Russian immigrants and wonders why his fellow Ethiopian Jews are not as welcome. "They are white and educated, while we are black and poor. That is the only reason I can give."

fields.headline: Scots clash over debt recovery
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive may face a backbench revolt this week over efforts by the hard-left MSP Tommy Sheridan to abolish a controversial method of debt recovery.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive may face a backbench revolt this week over efforts by the hard-left MSP Tommy Sheridan to abolish a controversial method of debt recovery.

Mr Sheridan, a Scottish Socialist party MSP for the Glasgow region, already has the support of six Labour backbenchers and three parliamentary committees for his member's bill on the abolition of warrant sales, to be debated on Thursday.

The executive is expected to favour reform of the system rather than abolition, which it fears would effectively create a debtor's charter. Under the system, sheriffs' officers conduct a "poinding" at a debtor's home, sometimes forcibly entering to value goods before they are auctioned at a warrant sale. In 1998, 251 people had their possessions taken, half for unpaid tax.

Warrant sales became deeply unpopular during the anti-poll tax campaign of the early 1990s. Mr Sheridan was jailed eight years ago when he defied a court in campaigning against the sales being used on poll tax evaders.

The issue is also politically sensitive. The Scottish Socialist party has established itself as a political player, coming fourth at the Ayr byelection, ahead of the Liberal Democrats, and selling itself as champion of the heartlands that Labour forgot.

Mr Sheridan predicts a major rebellion. "Three committees have recommended support for this bill, and they are going to be ignored by the executive," he said.

fields.headline: Iran's conservatives gag reformist press
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: The conservative Iranian judiciary has closed 12 progressive national newspapers and journals which support President Mohammed Khatami, a move which is certain to weaken the reform movement and threatens to undo years of slow but steady progress towards social and political change.
fields.body:
The conservative Iranian judiciary has closed 12 progressive national newspapers and journals which support President Mohammed Khatami, a move which is certain to weaken the reform movement and threatens to undo years of slow but steady progress towards social and political change.

The closing of the newspapers before publication yesterday morning capped weeks of a conservative campaign to even the score after the reformists' victory in the parliamentary elections on February 18.

Conservatives on the guardian council, which supervises the polls, began three weeks ago to invalidate the results in at least 10 constituencies where reformist candidates won.

Hardliners in the judiciary then began to jail reformist journalists. Akbar Ganji, the country's most outspoken commentator, was imprisoned on Saturday. Last week the dean of Iran's progressive press, Mashallah Shamsolvaezin, who has started four newspapers - all now banned - began a 30-month jail term.

"[The election results] angered the extremists and they want to change the atmosphere in the hope that they can affect the composition of the new parliament," said Hamid Reza Jalaiepour, an editor at Asr-e Azadegan.

The 12 newspapers were closed, according to the official news agency IRNA, for publishing material that "disparaged Islam and the religious elements of the Islamic revolution".

Among those closed were the popular Fath and Asr-e Azadegan. A court order delivered to Fath's offices said it was closed "until further notice", but its editors said they assumed their publication would remain closed. The crackdown was sanctioned on Thursday by Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who said some reformist newspapers had been turned into "bases of the enemy".

"This is not the end of the reform movement, because it depends on society. But this will definitely slow down the reforms," said a senior editor on one reformist newspaper, who wished to remain anonymous.

The closures angered Iranians as they woke to the news yesterday morning. A group gathered around a newsstand in front of one reformist newspaper, Sobh-e Emrouz, which was allowed to remain open, expressed their frustration. "The right faction wants to create tension and chaos," said Karem Korbanzadeh. "They want everyone to take to the streets, but people are more mature now."

Special police units were deployed throughout Tehran's streets. There were threats of attack by hardliners on two pro-reform newspaper offices, where worried editors huddled behind locked doors.

Despite the crackdown, reformist leaders discouraged public demonstrations to avoid violent retaliations by the Islamic militias and the police.

The obstacles to a comeback for the reformers are formidable. Even if the newspapers are licensed again, the most senior editors will be in jail.

webTitle: Poor stung by malaria's hidden cost

fields.headline: Poor stung by malaria's hidden cost
fields.trailText: Malaria is taking a far greater toll of the economy of many developing countries than has been previously understood, leaving them up to 20% worse off within 15 years than similar countries without serious infestation, according to a report from the World Health Organisation (WHO).
fields.body:
Malaria is taking a far greater toll of the economy of many developing countries than has been previously understood, leaving them up to 20% worse off within 15 years than similar countries without serious infestation, according to a report from the World Health Organisation (WHO).

The report, by Jeffrey Sachs of the Centre for International Development at Harvard University, and colleagues at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, says: "The cost of malaria is substantially greater than economists have previously estimated."

Previous estimates have taken account of only the immediate short-term costs, such as the loss of labour and the costs of treatment and prevention. But the longer-term costs are even more devastating to the country, Dr Sachs says.

"Malaria may impede the flows of trade, foreign investment and commerce, thereby affecting a country's entire population.

"Tourists shun regions with high malaria, as do multinational firms choosing the location of foreign investments."

Repeated bouts of malaria damage children's mental and physical development and play havoc with their schooling. This encourages parents to have more children, increasing population growth, impoverishing families and preventing women from joining the labour force. All these are hidden costs not usually taken into account in estimating the economic damage malaria causes.

The publication of the Sachs report coincides with the opening today of the first summit of African heads of state - in Abuja, Nigeria - to address the issue of malaria. The leaders are expected to commit themselves to a WHO programme.

"Malaria traps the people of Africa in poverty," said the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo. "It stops adults earning a living and children from going to school. Each year families spend the equivalent of several months' earnings on malaria treatment and prevention.

"It does not have to be like this. Malaria is preventable, treatable and curable."

David Nabarro, head of the Roll Back Malaria programme, said the work of the economists had shown how malaria control was not just a health matter but a development issue. "The language of the 80s where we saw health and education as a luxury was wrong," he said.

"Between 1965 and the present, the economic growth rates of African nations have been reduced by 40% as a result of malaria and its consequences. We're moving towards an awareness that disease is not just a suffering illness issue but a massive brake on economic and human development.

"My personal view is this. The way forward, says the WHO, is through programmes that incorporate all the best practice in malaria treatment and control, such as pesticide-impregnated bednets and combinations of drugs to counter the resistance that now exists to medicines like chloroquin.

But the notorious pesticide DDT is still the only way to keep down the malaria-bearing mosquitoes in houses in the worst-infested regions of the poorest developing countries, Dr Nabarro acknowledges.

"If we don't use DDT the results will be measured in loss of life. The cost of the alternatives tend to run at about six times as much as the cost of DDT." Environmentalists have been campaigning for a total ban on DDT.

fields.headline: Orthodox reaction
fields.standfirst: Move to ban novel of 'sexual' Jesus
fields.trailText: Attempts to ban a novel which portrays Jesus Christ as a philander who finds it hard to resist Mary Magdalene intensified yesterday as religious zealots ran amok in an Athens court.
fields.body:
Attempts to ban a novel which portrays Jesus Christ as a philander who finds it hard to resist Mary Magdalene intensified yesterday as religious zealots ran amok in an Athens court.

As the protestors shouted "blasphemer", lawyers for the author, Mimis Androulakis, were granted a postponement of the hearing to decide if the bestseller, M to the Power of N, should be banned throughout the country.

Last month sales were stopped in northern Greece to prevent violence after the Greek Orthodox church declared it blasphemous.

The book seeks to explore the theme of misogyny. Its opponents have taken particular exception to passages that allude to Jesus's simmering sexual desires.

The Orthodox church's governing board said: "Our religion may teach love but we will never speak to Mimis Androulakis again".

Mr Androulakis, a former MP, said: "I cannot understand all the fuss. We are not a theocratic regime, we are a European country."
