webTitle: German parents to subsidise the sound of music

fields.headline: German parents to subsidise the sound of music
fields.standfirst: For the first time since its inception in the 13th century, the Thomaner choir is about to charge fees
fields.trailText: The world renowned Leipzig Thomaner boys' choir, which Johann Sebastian Bach directed for more than a quarter of a century, is to ask parents to contribute for the first time to the upkeep and musical education of its choristers.
fields.body:
The world renowned Leipzig Thomaner boys' choir, which Johann Sebastian Bach directed for more than a quarter of a century, is to ask parents to contribute for the first time to the upkeep and musical education of its choristers.

The decision, which the administrators say has been forced on them by local government spending cuts, coincides with Leipzig's commemorations of the 250th anniversary of Bach's death.

It is symptomatic of the financial difficulties encountered by many arts institutions in the former East Germany, where the culture of subsidies is only slowly giving way to one of fundraising, sponsorship and promotion.

"In this area there is still a big difference between east and west," said Stefan Altner, the choir's bursar. "In the former GDR [German Democratic Republic], you did not make personal contributions to cultural institutions."

Mr Altner said he would be asking parents to pay about 100 marks (£35) a month, half of what they get from the state in the form of child allowance.

"We are the only choir of our kind left in Germany where the parents do not have to pay for anything," he said. "[But] we are in danger."

The fact that the Thomaner choir has survived at all is remarkable. It was founded in the 13th century in the church of St Thomas, from which it takes its name. "The Nazis and the communists both tried to split the choir from the church," Mr Altner said.

A bastion of Protestantism, it is an unlikely institution to emerge from the ruins of communism. The 90 boys still perform in sailor-suits, and they live in conditions only one remove from spartan. The city has built them a new boarding annex, but even so, up to the sixth form they sleep eight to a room in beds packed head to foot.

A Thomaner chorister is awoken at 6.15am and must cram in an day of normal school lessons by 1.45pm.

After lunch he has household chores to do before beginning three and a half hours of intensive rehearsals.

The recompense is a unique opportunity to immerse himself in music and see the world.

Sven Schönborn, 17, from Reichenbach, near the Polish border, has visited nine countries, from the US to Japan, since joining eight years ago.

"At the beginning it is very hard to cope with being in such a big community, even if you come from a family with lots of children," he said.

"But after a while you get used to it, and towards the end of the holidays you can't wait to get back."

Like some of the other choristers, he was encouraged to join the Thomaner by his local pastor. Others are entered by musically or religiously minded parents.

"My father wanted to join the Thomaner choir when he was a boy, but his parents wouldn't let him," said Gregor Praetorius, 10. "One day he brought me along to a school open day and I liked it."

Earlier this month a dozen or so families with young sons gathered for just such an open day in the hallway of the elegant neo-classical building near the centre of Leipzig where the choir is based. By the end of the last audition only three prospective choristers remained, and one of them had decided that the tough life of a semi-professional choirboy was not for him.

As well as a good voice, boys entering the choir must be able to sight-read music and play an instrument.

Georg Christoph Biller, the choirmaster, acknowledged that it had become harder to recruit choristers.

"Society has become less musical, less aesthetic," he said. "But we are getting over the worst. It became particularly difficult after the fall of the Berlin wall, because people became much more self-centred and materialistic."

Asking for fees could further increase the difficulty and undermine the choir's tradition of excellence.

"The budget for the choir is already so small that every successive cut puts it in greater danger," Mr Biller said. "The water is not yet up to our necks, but it is already round our knees."

fields.headline: Parents' plea to kidnapper
fields.trailText: The parents of a Briton snatched at gunpoint in the US by his girlfriend's jealous former lover yesterday made an appeal to the kidnapper to tell them their son's whereabouts.
fields.body:
The parents of a Briton snatched at gunpoint in the US by his girlfriend's jealous former lover yesterday made an appeal to the kidnapper to tell them their son's whereabouts.

Greg Marcinski, 23, from New Jersey, has been arrested and charged with abduction and impersonating an FBI agent after he handcuffed computer consultant Paul Gale, 28, from Erdington, Birmingham, and took him from his hotel in Florence, Kentucky, last week.

Mr Gale's parents issued the appeal from their family home urging Marcinski to say what had happened to their son. The couple spoke of their torment as the days passed without any news.

Mr Gale's mother, Elsie, said: "We just want him to answer one thing: what have you done with our son?"

Her husband Jeff, 58, said: "It has been a nightmare, a living hell. We just don't know what's happened. Paul would have believed that [Marcinski] was genuine.

"Paul's done nothing wrong and would not have put up a fight. He would have gone along and tried to sort it out. That's his attitude to things."

Marcinski has admitted to FBI officers that he was "very angry" after learning that girlfriend Darla Guidie had been seeing Mr Gale, and that he wanted to meet him face-to-face. He said that he posed as "FBI special agent Trimble" so that he could take Mr Gale from the hotel.

But Marcinski has insisted that he dropped Mr Gale in a hotel car park near Cincinnati airport in neighbouring Ohio after driving around Kentucky for more than two hours.

Mr Gale's twin brother, Peter, said: "We need to get some information as soon as possible. The only way to get that is from the guy [Marcinski] or members of the public."

fields.headline: Falklands commander dies at 66
fields.standfirst: Obituary
fields.trailText: One of the most admired soldiers of the 1980s, Major General Sir David Thorne, has died of prostate cancer aged 66, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
One of the most admired soldiers of the 1980s, Major General Sir David Thorne, has died of prostate cancer aged 66, it was announced yesterday.

The army chief of staff, Major General Sir Michael Walker, paid tribute to his "boundless intellectual abilities" and "special brand of leadership - often in the aftermath of disaster".

As the army's director of infantry in 1988, Sir David won an internal battle against a proposal to dilute its battalion and regimental system. He took charge of supplying the 1982 Falklands task force and was knighted after serving as the Falklands garrison's first peacetime commander.

Earlier, he was renowned as the brigadier who put an epaulette on the table in front of Margaret Thatcher while briefing her after the IRA Warrenpoint bombings which killed 18 soldiers in 1979. The badge, he indicated, was all that was left of one of his senior officers.

Shortly before his illness he wrote a memoir warning against the influence of inner "magic circles" in military and institutional life. He died at his home in Framlingham, Suffolk, on Sunday.

Sir Michael said he had left "the legacy of a true understanding of military leadership. He never spared himself, inspiring confidence and raising morale wherever he went".

fields.headline: Museum rewrites hymn sheet
fields.trailText: The Royal Armouries Museum in Leeds was forced to alter its main millennium celebration - a choral mass which premieres at the Royal Albert Hall tonight - after copyright problems threatened to halt the performance at the last minute.
fields.body:
The Royal Armouries Museum in Leeds was forced to alter its main millennium celebration - a choral mass which premieres at the Royal Albert Hall tonight - after copyright problems threatened to halt the performance at the last minute.

Keeper of the Armouries, Guy Wilson, rewrote part of the libretto, which will fit together with music already composed for the sell-out concert, in order to avoid breaching copyright on the work of first world war poet Maurice Baring.

The rewrite followed the discovery that the text by Mr Baring, a member of the banking family and a Royal Flying Corps officer, had gone back into copyright after changes to the law.

Mr Baring's work became freely available in 1995, 50 years after his death, but then went back under copyright for a further 20 years, in line with a new European 70-year rule.

The Armouries would not comment on the details of the problem, but it is understood that negotiations with the poet and novelist's estate came too close to the deadline to risk a gap in the piece.

A score had been composed by Karl Jenkins, a former band member of Soft Machine, to accompany the words of Mr Baring's In Memoriam AH, an elegy for his RFC colleague Auberon Herbert, Lord Lucas.

"Karl's setting was simply too good to lose," said Mr Wilson, whose words will now fit between extracts from Kipling and the Mahabharata.

fields.headline: Le Pen loses MEP seat
fields.trailText: The declining influence of the far-right National Front was accelerated at the weekend by a government decision to ban its leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen, from sitting in the European parliament, of which he has been a member since 1984.
fields.body:
The declining influence of the far-right National Front was accelerated at the weekend by a government decision to ban its leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen, from sitting in the European parliament, of which he has been a member since 1984.

Mr Le Pen, 71, whose party split last year after he was involved in a power struggle with his deputy, Bruno Mégret, said he was "mad with rage" after reading the banning order, signed by the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, and published in the official state bulletin.

The national assembly's approval of the decree is considered a formality, but Mr Le Pen said he was preparing "a long and hard judicial battle" for reinstatement.

The timing of the ban, a week before the first congress of the diminished Front, appeared to be an attempt by the government to discredit Mr Le Pen before a series of Front celebrations, including the national Joan of Arc march in Paris on May 1.

Mr Le Pen, who five years ago was seen as a possible member of a coalition government, has been struggling to regain his position on the right since he assaulted a Socialist woman candidate during campaigning for local elections in Mantes-la-Jolie, west of Paris, in 1997.

He received a three-month suspended jail sentence and was disqualified from public office for a year. His mandate as a regional councillor in Marseille was removed in February, detaching him from the strongest area of the Front's anti-immigrant crusade.

He also faces possible prosecution by the European parliament for the revisionist views on the Holocaust he expressed during a visit to Germany.

His troubles have been compounded by the drift of far-right voters towards the breakaway Gaullist movement led by the former interior minister Charles Pasqua, who once said that his political views were close to those of Mr Le Pen.

Last month Mr Le Pen said he would stand for president in 2002, for the fourth time.

fields.trailText:
Schemes of work
www.standards.dfee.gov.uk/schemes/music/

****

Aimed at: teachers

fields.body:
Schemes of work
www.standards.dfee.gov.uk/schemes/music/

****

Aimed at: teachers

Everything a child must learn about music in primary school: pitch, singing rounds, performing together and 17 other units. The schemes are available in Word and Acrobat formats and include suggested musical scores and songs.

The Musicland
www.themusicland.co.uk/

**

Aimed at: everyone

Could become a very useful resource, but possible technical difficulties when you visit - non-existent pop-up windows, poor navigation - may deter you. Key stage 3 onwards are among the resources, but you need an email address to see them.

Resource site
www.bobchilds.co.uk/mtrs/

***

Aimed at: teachers

With MIDI files, lyrics, vocal and instrumental rounds, lesson plans and equipment reviews - mostly supplied by the euphonium-playing editor, Rob Childs - this simply needs more contributors to make it valuable. Email your musical queries to one of nine experts, but sending in new content as well would, I imagine, be very welcome.

Association of Music

www.name2.org.uk/

**

Aimed at: teachers

New and yet to establish itself. If you want to join and/or attend the annual conference in July, try it.

Arts Inspected - Music
www.ofsted.gov.uk/artsinsp/pages/music/index.htm

***

Aimed at: teachers

Find out how 13 primary, secondary and middle schools impressed Ofsted with the quality of their music teaching. Very useful if the inspectors are coming, and inspirational. It comes with sound files and lesson plans.

Tweenies
www.bbc.co.uk/education/tweenies/

****

Aimed at: parents and children

Includes a large Song Time section. Pre-school children are invited to sing along with She'll Be Coming Round the Mountain, the programme's theme tune, various other tunes and to practise their music skills with activities, based on that day's TV broadcast.

Fun Music Ideas
www.funmusicideas.com/

***

Aimed at: teachers

A US-based online newsletter, it holds contributions from readers on different themes each month. Scrappy layout but you can feel the authors' enthusiasm. Remember music is taught very differently in the US.

Lyrics Server
www.lyrics.ch/

***

Aimed at: everyone

62,000 lyrics on one site, although Macs may have problems reading some pages. It links to www.songfile.com which claims to hold more than two million songs.

Piano on the net
www.artdsm.com/music.html

***

Aimed at: everyone

An interesting concept with its series of online tutorials by a music teacher. Uses QuickTime video and audio, and step-by-step instructions. Helpful for reinforcing music lessons and you only need a cheap internet link.

Energy in the air
www.tqjunior.advanced.org/5116/

***

Aimed at: everyone

A young person's online guide to the orchestra, it describes each instrument, provides sound clips of its music, and explains how to make some basic noise-making devices.

 You can find more music sites at www.educationunlimited.co.uk/ netclass or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Register plan for donor births
fields.trailText: Children born from anonymous sperm donation could be listed on a separate register, allowing them access to details of their genetic origins and make-up.
fields.body:
Children born from anonymous sperm donation could be listed on a separate register, allowing them access to details of their genetic origins and make-up.

Ministers will consider the plan in the next two weeks. Children born through donor insemination or IVF treatment, 2,000 a year on average, would have details of their genetic background written on their birth certificates.

The register is among proposals in a Department of Health working paper on donor insemination and parentage. Many children born by artificial means feel confused and insecure about their parentage. However, some donors - who are paid on average £15 - fear the emotional, financial and legal consequences of their identification years on.

The 1990 Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act guarantees anonymity for sperm donors. When the children are 18 they can apply for limited, "non-identifying" information on their origins.

Last night Tim Hedgley of Issue, a charity supporting infertile couples, said the plan could mean an end to sperm donations.

webTitle: World's tallest top hat goes on show

fields.headline: World's tallest top hat goes on show
fields.trailText: The world's tallest top hat went on show yesterday at Hat Works, Britain's only museum devoted to headgear.
fields.body:
The world's tallest top hat went on show yesterday at Hat Works, Britain's only museum devoted to headgear.

The topper (right), 18in high and with rakish brim, was made in 1913. "It's probably just a fun piece," said Steven Miller, manager of Hat Works. "I'm not sure anyone would have worn it." He moved on to admire a wild piece by a modern milliner, Philip Treacy, consisting of a couple of scarlet eyebrows and eight hoops - striking, but not much use for keeping your head dry at Ascot.

The £1.3m museum, housed in an 1830 mill in Stockport, Greater Manchester, can boast a slightly tattered number allegedly worn by the Duke of Wellington, and something discreet once owned by Queen Victoria. The displays tell of Stockport's role in the hat business - the last local factory closed only three years ago - but a scarlet Austin Mini helps explain how changing hair fashions and small cars with low roofs did irreparable damage to the industry.

"People have always worn hats for ceremonial reasons, for warmth, or for protection," said Mr Miller. "We want people to leave here thinking of hats in a different way. We are not a museum about a particular period; we want to be a national archive of hatting, and we'd love to be given the hats of famous people - Elton John, for example."

fields.headline: Making music
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor helps to make sense of .wav files, MP3, PCM and MIDI
fields.body:
That enchanting purr from your Mac or PC when you switch it on is the least of its musical powers. For many people, that means playing the odd CD while they work, or hastily turning down their speakers if the boss appears. But for teachers and parents, it means an array of multimedia possibilities.

Adding noise to your own site is fairly easy, especially if you download sounds from the rest of the internet. A step-by-step guide is available at www.builder.com/Authoring/Audio/?tag=st.bl.7275.plbl

Listening to other people's music files is also fairly easy. If the filename ends in .wav or .au, the browser should play it as soon as you click on the link. If it ends in .ram, visit www.real.com and download the free version of the RealPlayer - more advanced versions can be bought, but the free edition is adequate. If it ends in .mpeg, then it's an MP3 file - a super-compressed piece of audio and the format some people think will eventually force the music industry to move away from CDs (hotwired.lycos.com/webmonkey/multimedia/audio_mp3 is a good place to start if developments in web audio interest you).

Most questions on MP3 are answered at help.mp3.com/help. And you will soon read about "rippers" - downloadable programs that let you record CDs onto MP3 (and then play them on portable MP3 players). But this is nearly always illegal.

Many schools are equipped to record MIDI files. But quality is relatively low because MIDI records the time of events rather than the sound. Simon Rees, a former music producer, explains: "A PC sound card normally has a basic MIDI synthesiser [recorder] on it and you can connect a MIDI cable to a keyboard to allow you to record to it."

Cheap software such as Evolution Audio (available for just under £20 at www.evolution.co.uk) enables you to edit MIDI files using a PC keyboard. Digital sound files (often called PCM audio) usually demand more expensive editing software. Rees recommends Cool Edit, Sound Forge and Steinberg Wavelab, but most packages cost at least £200.

It's worth trawling the audio section of download.cnet.com to see if any of the shareware and/or free software is of use.

Bear in mind that online music and sounds are not just for music lessons. The ease of creating and sending files means flute solos and violin practice can be sent to relatives or dubbed into an existing recording.

Language teachers can use the audio files on foreign TV news sites as listening practice; dance, drama and aerobics lessons have another source of music; and 20th-century history can be enhanced with recordings of key speeches.

fields.headline: Out and about
fields.trailText: English Heritage is grandly billing the end of this week as: "The first May Day Bank Holiday of the New Millennium".
fields.body:
So, sick of Easter eggs, never want to see a piece of chocolate again in your lives? (No, of course you're not, that's just the sort of tedious rubbish adults feel compelled to spout.) English Heritage is grandly billing the end of this week as: "The first May Day Bank Holiday of the New Millennium".

For some reason this seems to have provoked an outbreak of all-out warfare, possibly as a reaction to all those bunnikins and fluffy chickens last week. At Helmsley Castle in north Yorkshire it's the recklessly named Have-a-go Archery - 14th-century bowmen introduce visitors to the art of archery, it says, and I say the bowmen have only themselves to blame.

At Bolsover Castle in Derbyshire it's military vehicles and the Home Guard. In Herefordshire the dashing Wardour Garrison will attempt to resist Colonel Birch and his tediously virtuous Parliamentarians as they try once again to sieze Goodrich Castle. And at Grimes Graves, Norfolk, a wonderful but slightly specialist site, Stone Age man will show how to make axes and arrowheads.

There's more: the Duelling Association is promising a Regency Murder Mystery, at Walmer Castle in Kent, with sword fights in tight britches - it doesn't say anything about a Colin Firth-lookalike wet shirt contest, but I suppose somebody might fall into the moat. And at Totnes in Devon it's Echoes from the Past, four centuries of warfare, no less, seen through the eyes of a soldier.

All this mayhem is at English Heritage properties. And so it is with relief that we turn to the gentlefolk of the Historic Houses Association, and Pashley Manor in East Sussex. Pashley has just won the association's garden of the year award. "Always snows the day we present it," they moaned, and I scoffed, on a spring day hot enough to sunbathe. Three days later, on April 6, they presented the award - and it snowed.

Anyway, on April 27 Pashley starts its annual five-day tulip festival. Which might sound a bit soppy, but I know some real toughies who were so impressed by the blaze of colour from the thousands of flowers last year that they're going again this year. And it has a nice tea-room. But there's no getting away from it, it's a blood'n'guts sort of week. At the Barbican in London, there's the Art of Star Wars, yes, with light sabres and animatronic robot soldiers.

But if I had to choose one knight in armour out of the troops hanging around across the UK this week, to give my glove to as a favour to wear in his helm, it would probably be at Leeds. When you see pictures of knights on horseback they're usually wispy creatures on horses no more sturdy than a rocking horse. If you look at real suits of armour you realise this can't be true.

Leeds is holding an Easter Tournament every day until May Day, where knights will fight on foot, with tremendous clashings of ironmongery, and on horseback. Each fully armoured knight weighs in at around 20 stone: horses have to be built on a similar scale.

And finally, the V&A has a startling event on Saturday, April 29 - a chance for people to add their tattoos to a national collection. Wearers will not be expected to donate an arm or a leg, but will merely be photographed. The museum is interested not just in a trendy, contemporary tank top/short shorts line in butterflies and bluebirds, but also in tattoos the wrinklies acquired in their own reckless youth. There will be lectures on tattoos, and a historical display. If you're planning to donate your own tattoo to the nation, and bringing a parent, do please break the news to them first, instead of provoking an instant heart attack when the Pokémon fleece comes off.

Further information

 Free English Heritage diary of special events this year: 01793 414910  National Trust children's events pack, tel: 020-8315 1111

 Trusty the Hedgehog website: www.trusty.org

 Museums, inc. children's museums: www.24hourmuseum.org

 The Royal Armouries, Leeds: 0990 106666

 Pashley Manor: 01580 200888

fields.headline: It's a long job, guv
fields.standfirst: Citizenship
fields.trailText: Citizenship
fields.body:
If you travelled on a bus today or had your hair cut recently, then you took part in a legal contract. Like all contracts it had three stages. You were offered a service, you accepted it, and you gave something in exchange for that service - all very simple. But sometimes people are dishonest or incompetent and occasionally what we expect turns out to be a let-down or worse. The haircut that was to have renewed our beauty leaves us looking like a yeti. What then?

This is where consumer rights come in. In 1266 the Magna Carta made an early attempt to regulate the marketplace by setting down the correct measures for such things as wine, beer and bread. The battle to stop tradesmen from cheating or harming customers has not stopped. Nowadays several key laws lay down what we can expect when we buy things and what we are entitled to when a contract is not fulfilled.

The Sale of Goods Act (1979) and the Supply of Goods and Services Act (1982) govern the quality of what we hire or buy and set down rules on labelling. Other statutes (laws) include the Consumer Protection Act (1987) and the Trade Descriptions Act (1968) both of which are enforced by Trading Standards officers who work for local councils.

Despite all these laws, every year thousands of people lose out to dodgy tradespeople and consumer TV programmes are full of their tales of woe. Builders, garages and holiday firms often top the lists in customer complaints. Growth of internet business has also seen fraud move on-line.

Labelling still creates problems. For example, how some products are described as "organic" has been found to be very misleading. To help the consumer, a Kitemark label is available for goods and services that pass quality assessment by the British Standards Institute. The BSI also draws up codes of good practice covering everything from night-club bouncers to skateboard safety.

In law, people under 18 may not make certain kinds of contracts such as taking on a mortgage. If they do, the contract is described as "unenforceable". But this does not mean you can travel free on the bus. When you step aboard, the contract is enforceable because the service on offer is considered a "necessary" - something fitting a young person's needs.

But with rights come responsibilities. It is your responsibility not to put up with poor treatment. You also have to act reasonably and follow instructions. You cannot expect compensation if you decide to swallow the contents of your pencil case or demand a refund just because of a change of mind.

And does owning things necessarily lead to happiness? And where did that idea orignally come from? Shopping as a leisure activity is a modern thing and big forces are at work to keep us consuming. Our buying decisions are heavily influenced. Companies spend fortunes trying to win new customers and they are increasingly targeting young people to make them part with their pocket money.

Every few months there is a new "must have" phenomenon, be it Buzz Lightyear or Pokémon. But it is not only specifically children's goods which are promoted to the young. Business has realised that children and teenagers can be their allies, pestering adults to take certain holidays or buy specific models of cars.

Another worrying trend is the influence businesses now have in schools, from placing their vending machines in canteens, sponsoring exercise books or even encouraging headteachers to reward good behaviour and achievement with vouchers that can be exchanged for hamburgers.

fields.headline: Suits you, sir!
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock  wonders how he can hide from the people in suits
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock wonders how he can hide from the people in suits
fields.body:
I just don't know who people are anymore. I went away for the Easter break, but when I returned people in college seemed different. All the familiar old faces were there, but so were unfamiliar, new ones.

My new colleagues do not swear at pieces of paper they have just pulled from their pigeon hole, or kick the photocopier when it jams. In short, they are not acting normally. They wear a vacant look, wash up their coffee cups in the staff room and adopt a calm voice when talking to students.

Of course they were there before I left. Only I had not noticed them. Now they have multiplied. They walk the corridors with a bland smile and underarm files. They have a sense of purpose and authority. They wear a distinctive style of suit - it is modern, stylish and fits.

Persons in suits like emails and memos. They can take away your parking privileges, or tell you that Friday is now Monday, except on alternate weeks when there are no Fridays and it is perpetual Wednesday.

Here is the latest diktat to light up my computer screen: "Please note that form B52/97 should always be filled out before attempting to fill out any other form. There are to be no exceptions. Please flush. Always wash your hands. This means you. Regards, Murray Whelk."

I don't know who Murray Whelk is as my college directory is out of date. He is not there in the gallery of staff mugshots. My own photograph seems to have been re-photocopied four times. I am represented by two white eye-holes in what looks like a gorilla's bottom.

But come to think of it, there are several of the older staff I don't really know either. Take Ted Ledbury for example, who has been around college for longer than anyone can remember. In his photograph he looks like a mati nee idol, a sort of Victor Mature of the local amateur dramatics scene.

But no one knows what Ted does anymore. More importantly, the persons in suits haven't rumbled him yet. We all know that he completes the Guardian crossword everyday and follows cricket, but we are not sure what he teaches.

Successive principals and finance managers have managed to overlook Ted. Lucky bugger.

"What does he do?" I asked Colin from maths.

"Nothing really," replied Colin. "And he intends it to stay that way until he retires."

"He speaks to you then?"

"It was the only thing he said to me last year."

Ted doesn't seem to appear on timetables, although some students commend his quirky teaching style. However, I'm not sure what it is he teaches. One student claims to be in his sociology class while another swears blind that he teaches her German.

Occasionally an ex-student will drop in and ask if Mr Ledbury is around. Ted always seems to get wind of their visits and scuttles off to the toilet with an old edition of Wisden until the young person in their smart, building society uniform leaves.

I wish I could hide from the persons in suits. But it is too late. They know I am here. I made the mistake of going to meetings, joining committees, turning up to staff development sessions. My fate is in their hands. They know who I am. But I haven't got a clue who they are.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: My child has come home with what seems to me to be a lot of homework to be completed over the Easter "break". Do you have any advice as to what is a "reasonable" amount of work for a child to do over (supposedly) school holidays?
fields.body:
My child has come home with what seems to me to be a lot of homework to be completed over the Easter "break". Do you have any advice as to what is a "reasonable" amount of work for a child to do over (supposedly) school holidays?

Alwyn Morgan is a trainer and education department consultant in "out of school hours" learning.

If you go away during a school holiday, it's inevitable that your child cannot complete the same amount of homework that a child who doesn't go away could. Notifying schools as early as possible can help teachers when planning work to be set over the holidays.

For young people in their last year at school, this is "crunch" time, with the start of revision or completion of exam syllabuses. It's not unreasonable, therefore, to expect them to strike a balance between leisure time and studying over the holiday period.

This isn't so with younger pupils, but if children - or indeed, adults - see homework as a burden, this highlights the need for a new attitude towards out of school learning. After all, no more than 13% of a young person's life is spent in school in a year! This leaves a lot of time for the rest of us to help teachers, who cannot take sole responsibility for educating young people. An African proverb illustrates this: "It takes the whole village to teach a child."

This means rethinking the activities that young people undertake when they're not in school, similar to the "family learning" materials on the BBC website, for instance. These are aimed at all the family and include enjoyable games, tasks or challenges, linked to the national curriculum.

This also reinforces the current advertisements that encourage parents/guardians to use their environment and everyday situations to help children with their literacy and numeracy skills. This is all part of a wider drive towards a continuum of learning between home, school and community. A teacher is generally confined to a classroom, and a child is just one amongst many trying to get the teacher's attention. As a family, you can give one-to-one attention to your child, and use the home and world around us to extend and enrich what happens in school.

In the past, it has been argued that middle-class children do better at school because they are more likely to be taken to museums, etc and have greater access to learning materials around the home. The government is placing considerable emphasis on the promotion of a range of after school and "summer learning" schemes to help close this divide. Pilot "summer learning festivals" last year encouraged a range of activities, from Samba drumming to orienteering.

Again, this is part of a general shift towards a wider context for education and the idea that learning can - and should be - fun, fun, fun. When teachers, parents/guardians and the wider community become actively involved in the education of children, we will see a genuine rise in standards, and a more positive attitude towards learning as a whole.

Alwyn Morgan's tips:

Older students will need to continue studying over school holidays, in order to revise for exams and cover prescribed syllabuses. Younger pupils may also have more traditional tasks - it's a big help if parent/guardians work with, rather than against, teachers in this. Try to stimulate a dialogue with your child(ren) about what is happening at school. This isn't always easy, but show your child(ren) that their education involves you just as much as it does their teachers.

This last point is an important one. It's everyone's responsibility to take an active role in educating our young people, and parents/guardians are key players. Take every opportunity to explain, stimulate and learn with your child(ren), in an informal, constructive and non-threatening way. And, remember, think fun at all times!

fields.headline: A hot snap
fields.standfirst: Alex Benady on a field trip with a touch of real adventure
fields.trailText: Alex Benady on a field trip with a touch of real adventure
fields.body:
The National Curriculum stresses the value of "residential experience in education", but the tropical languor of the Atlantic Hotel in Banjul is probably not the type of residence or experience it has in mind.

Banjul is the capital of The Gambia and the Atlantic is the sort of joint where international businessmen stay to set up deals of varying degrees of legitimacy, while local women hover around, eager to assist them in any way they can.

It is also the place to which Chris Moiser, a zoology lecturer at Plymouth College of Further Education takes his parties of teenage biologists every year, for a "Chapmans", the non- alcoholic fruit cocktail for which the hotel is famous. "It's education in the broadest and deepest sense," says Moiser who has been taking groups of GNVQ and A-level students on "crocodile safaris" to The Gambia for 10 years now. They go primarily to study the wildlife first hand, but also to gain a new perspective on different cultures, as well as a greater insight into their own, he explains.

"We do a lot of hard field work and observation, particularly of crocodiles, and the students get the chance to act as research assistants on real-life academic projects. They even get to touch crocodiles. By the time we arrive at the Atlantic they have earned a rest. Besides it's part of the colonial experience, like having a Gin Sling at the Raffles hotel in Singapore," he says.

Moiser organised his first trip in 1990 because he thought it offered the perfect opportunity to pursue his own research interests and provide a safe but stimulating learning environment for the students - a key consideration when you are taking parties of 10 to 20 teenagers to the third world.

The Gambia is "intrepid lite" he says. "I want to sell science. The Gambia is relatively safe and has lots of wildlife, but nothing really dangerous. I had visited before and realised the potential for students to do original work in an environment that wouldn't put them off."

So how does he square handling crocodiles with his definition of safe? "The local crocs only grow to nine feet which is the maximum size before they can't get enough nutrition from fish and have to start eating meat. So they are quite safe," he explains.

He argues that the very act of asking the question about the safety of crocodiles shows how even ideas that purport to be objective "scientific" fact, such as "crocodiles are dangerous", are actually culturally determined. "We see crocs as dangerous man-eating killers. But in Africa south of the Sahara, they are revered as symbols of life. Crocodiles only live where there is a constant supply of water. In an environment where water is scarce, crocodiles therefore became associated with fertility and birth."

But Moiser concedes that taking a large group of excited teenagers to Africa does require a very firm touch - although he prefers to administer it lightly. "One condition of going is that they have to attend a health briefing which deals with issues like immunisation and anti-malaria strategies."

Acknowledging the potential for teenage high-jinx, he also gives a take-no-prisoners legal briefing on the dangers of drink, drugs and sex. "I warn them that getting drunk in the tropics where there is 50% humidity will result in dehydration and at best an appalling hangover, at worst death. I assure them that if they try to bring back cannabis, I will tell customs and I warn them that if you pay less than a pound for a prostitute, you radically increase your risk of catching Aids."

Despite these restrictions, his students seem to think the trips are worthwhile. "I've been to the continent for holidays. But this really did give a taste of different cultures. The chance to get up close to wildlife and look at Africa was indescribable, just amazing. I'd go again tomorrow," said 16- year-old Helen Duffin who went on the trip earlier this year.

The trip is open to anybody in the college, not just those on life-science courses. At £500 all in for just a week, it certainly isn't cheap. But given the intensity and scope of the learning they provide, Moiser's crocodile safaris seem very good value indeed.

fields.headline: Undertaking
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: Undertaking
fields.body:
Er, hello? Come on in, you'll catch your death out there.

Thanks. It's perishing. Leave the gags to me, if you don't mind.

Sorry? I've already lost the plot. I said "Leave the gags to me." If you want to be an undertaker you're going to have to learn to be a lot more sensitive in the way you deal with the public. You meet people from all walks of life, most of whom are in a highly distressed state. So you have to be warm, tactful and reassuring, while making them aware of all the different options.

You've gone rather serious on me, haven't you? I notice you didn't say grave. You're catching on fast.

Better late than never. Steady now.

OK. So where would I begin? A new recruit to the business generally starts with the more routine duties, such as driving, or cleaning the body.

I bet you need a stiff drink after that. Stiff is not a word we use. But yes, it is important that you are not of a squeamish disposition, as there can be unpleasant sights and smells involved.

What about the fancy stuff, like embalming? Embalming is a separate profession that is sometimes carried out by qualified undertakers. Besides, there is no legal requirement for someone to be embalmed unless the body is being taken overseas.

So what else is there apart from driving and cleaning? A great deal. Death is an extremely bureaucratic process. It's all very well for the deceased, lying there doing nothing, but there's a whole heap of paperwork for their families.

And that's where we step in? Discreetly, of course. Once we've been notified of the death by family or friends of the deceased, we collect the body and gather the personal details of those involved. All the other details are agreed between the funeral director and the bereaved. You will advise on choice of coffin and whether the body is to be buried or cremated - an increasingly popular option - and then make all the necessary arrangements with the clergy and crematorium staff. You may even order the flowers and arrange the wake.

Great. I love a good party. Can I dress up? All your tasks should be approached with a professional attitude, which should also be reflected in the dress and manner of an undertaker. In other words, stick to the tea and biccies and don't be seen dead, if you get my drift, in anything other than funeral clobber of top hat and tails or black suit.

Sounds OK. When can I start? As soon as you like. There are no formal entry requirements, though some employers do prefer someone with the odd GCSE. Training is often provided on the job, but you can also take a Diploma in Funeral Directing run by the British Institute of Funeral Directors, provided you are working for a firm of undertakers and have GCSEs in maths and English, or, alternatively, pass a preliminary exam set by the National Association of Funeral Directors.

Thanks very much. Not at all. Have a nice day.

What remains of it. Aaaagh.

 National Association of Funeral Directors (NAFD), 618 Warwick Rd, Solihull, West Midlands, B91 1AA

Telephone: 0121-711 1343

 British Institute of Funeral Directors, 140 Lemington Rd, Coventry, CV3 6YJ

Telephone: 01203 697160

fields.headline: The age of consumerism
fields.standfirst: For education to improve students must become influential customers, says  Caroline Mager
fields.trailText: For education to improve students must become influential customers, says Caroline Mager
fields.body:
Britons have been traditionally reluctant to complain about bad service. How many times have you been to a restaurant, had a truly terrible meal and when asked by the waiter "is everything alright with your food" simply nodded in begrudging agreement? We would rather leave the restaurant vowing never to return than say to the waiter "well actually the food tasted like old boots". We, in the UK, are generally not powerful consumers, particularly when it comes to the services provided by the state.

Up until now that is. A new trend is creeping into public policy. We are being asked to question the value for money we receive for goods and services provided by both the state and private enterprise. This may be enough to bring a blush to the face of every restaurant goer in the UK.

Early evidence was in the health service, which began publishing waiting lists. It encouraged people to question the efficiency with which the service was managed. It was followed by the Department of Trade and Industry and its white paper, Modern Markets: Confident Consumers - which spurned the popularly known Rip Off Britain campaign. This encourages us to complain about bent plumbers and dodgy second-hand car dealers. Or, in the words of Kim Howells, Minister for Consumers and Corporate Affairs, "We don't whinge much in this country as consumers - we're pretty bad at it."

"I certainly want people to complain more about goods."

Now it is the turn of post-16 education and training. The Learning and Skills Bill creates a system that is demand led. The Bill ensures consumers have more say in the type of courses they have in a local area. It paves the way for learners to be able to access more information on what choices are available. It also creates a local "fair and competitive market" amongst school sixth forms, sixth-form colleges, further education, voluntary and community organisations and private training providers.

In effect, the bill could turn students into informed consumers who will be offered more choice at the age of 16 and throughout life.

But, is education and training ready for consumerism? Asking learners and employers to exercise choice is all right; but providing them with the necessary information is essential. Learning, of course, is far more complex than buying a meal. It requires feedback that can be measured and evaluated. Measuring customer satisfaction might be one option. Focusing on the satisfaction of the learner does not mean that we believe that learning is endless fun - we all know that effort is needed. As I tell my 15- year old son, he will have to learn how to conjugate French verbs and learn grammatical patterns.

Systems for measuring satisfaction will need to focus the attention of customers like my son on whether they feel they are being taught efficiently and effectively, whether they are clear about what it is they are learning and why. This begins to point towards a relationship between the teacher and the learner that is uncommon. It requires a dialogue about the best way to learn something, the sort of effort that they are willing to make and the kind of learner they are inclined to be. This requires reflective learners and responsive teachers.

It is in this way that learners will become not just customers but influential customers. As I say in The New Learning Markets, about to be published by the Further Education Development Agency and the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR). "The influential customer is essential in raising the quality of provision in any sector of the market. In a service as vital as education, a typical response of choosing not to consume a product, is not an acceptable solution." Welcome to the age of consumerism.

 Caroline Mager is Policy Unit Manager at the Further Education Development Agency. The New Learning Markets will be published by Feda and the IPPR on 19th April. Copies are available from Feda's Publications Department on 020-7840 5400 priced £10.

fields.headline: Monster moment
fields.standfirst: Our universities should lead Europe in setting up a research area to rival the US, urges Roderick Floud
fields.trailText: Our universities should lead Europe in setting up a research area to rival the US, urges Roderick Floud
fields.body:
There are now more radios in the US, and possibly the UK, than the population has ears; cables thread the streets; and half the population uses mobile phones. Yet no one is satisfied with the quality of material sent down the line. If we are to reap the benefits of the knowledge economy, we need to switch attention from hardware to content.

This is a hard lesson to learn. Until 1800, most people grew food. For the last 200 years, and to the great benefit of our standard of living, we have been making things. Now the very success of manufacturing means that fewer of us need to do it; more of us, by contrast, provide services, for business and for leisure. This is the content of the knowledge economy.

Just as fundamental research underpinned technology in the 20th century, so it must support services in the 21st. It already does. BBC TV's stunning Walking with Dinosaurs depended on palaeobiology as much as on multimedia and animation. The derivatives traders of the City of London exploit basic mathematics. Tourism is being transformed by virtual museums and art galleries.

That is why it is essential for Britain, and its universities, to seize a new opportunity. Last month in Lisbon, stimulated by Philippe Busquin, the Commissioner for Research, the European heads of government demanded urgent action to set up a European research area as a viable international competitor for the US. The first actions have to be planned by June and underway by the end of the year.

Crucially, the presidents and prime ministers realised that we have to build up capacity for research across the board. They want action to attract and retain research talent.

There is to be, by the end of 2001, a high-speed electronic network for universities, libraries and even schools. European and national research programmes are to be brought together. Barriers to mobility of staff and students have to be removed. There is even to be a system for assessing, across Europe, research excellence and success in developing good researchers. All this gives Britain an opportunity to demon strate its wide-ranging research strengths.

These new actions go far beyond the limited aims of the existing Framework programmes of the European Union. British universities have done well from Framework 5 and its predecessors, securing £143m from EU sources in 1997-98, part of the overall spending of about £2,000m. Britain has taken part in many more projects than any other European country. So it is crucial that higher education and the government together help to shape future activities.

It is particularly important to be imaginative. Britain is good at IT, the biosciences and engineering, all of which have figured largely in the Framework programmes. We have even done well in librarianship, stimulated by digitisation. But whole areas of research in which Britain also excels have so far played little part.

Take the creative industries. They employ over one million people in Britain and generate about £60bn in revenues. Growing rapidly, they depend on art and design schools turning out tens of thousands of graduates, many of whom are finding jobs in the rest of Europe. Film, television and publishing depend on them to develop new techniques and products.

Or take the social sciences. In the early Framework programmes, the social sciences had either no place or a subordinate role; they were there to help society cope with the consequences of scientific and technological change. At worst, they were there to persuade an unwilling public that there were no dangers from such change.

Now, their role has to be much more positive. The European heads of government recognised the importance of research in achieving employment and social cohesion. Understanding social and economic problems is the first step to solving them.

David Blunkett recently emphasised the need for British government policies to be underpinned by good social and economic research; now this needs to be done on a European scale. As one example, work at the Institute of Education and Essex University has shown the potential for the analysis of social exclusion of longitudinal data sets allied to new analysis techniques; these can be applied across Europe.

Then there are the humanities. If there is one area of research that should be at the heart of the "knowledge economy", it is surely the accumulation of understanding of how people think and behave. What is the internet but a vast encyclopaedia - though without sufficient quality control? Historians and literary critics, with university libraries, should be at the forefront of providing learning resources with a quality seal.

Science and technology remain vital to Europe, but they are not the whole story. Traditional areas of research have dominated Britain's response so far to Busquin's ideas, but it is in Britain's interest to think more imaginatively and to seize the full benefits of the knowledge economy.

webTitle: But is it the right policy?

fields.headline: But is it the right policy?
fields.standfirst: John Crace  reports on unease about the government's drive towards inclusion
fields.trailText: John Crace reports on unease about the government's drive towards inclusion
fields.body:
What was widely forecast was duly delivered. As further education lecturers and the media were tucked away in Belfast for the Association of Teachers and Lecturers conference, and the rest of the world was winding down for the Easter break, the Further Education Funding Council released the annual enrolment figures that showed a decrease in total student numbers of 0.3% in further education colleges between November 1, 1998 and November 1, 1999.

For a Labour government that has committed itself so publicly to lifelong learning, a drop in student numbers for the second year - the first time this has happened for over 20 years - is nothing short of a public relations disaster. Small wonder, then, that at the committee stage of the Learning and Skills Bill in the House of Commons last week, the Lifelong Learning Minister, Malcolm Wicks, was on the wrong end of a scathing attack from both the Tories and the Lib-Dems.

There is little doubt the government has been wildly optimistic in its forecasts for student numbers, but there is also widespread concern within the sector over the implementation of its social inclusion initiatives, such as the New Deal, to get the 170,000 16- to19-year-olds, who are neither working nor studying and have dropped out of the educa tion system into further education.

Which is why Chris Wilson, honorary secretary of the further education committee for the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, was last week instrumental in amending a conference resolution from "warning the government that its enthusiasm for inclusion must not do a disservice to children in mainstream skills" to the much tougher proposal that the government must "ensure that its enthusiasm for inclusion is both realistic and achievable".

Which in Wilson's opinion it isn't, unless some hard cash is delivered to make it work. "Tracking students in the New Deal is immensely bureaucratic," he says."Not only do you have to keep records of every class attendance, you also have to report regularly to a New Deal adviser on the students' progress. All of this is both time-consuming and expensive, and the money just isn't forthcoming."

Wilson's point is well made. Despite the recent injection of funds, colleges are still strapped for cash, and according to Wilson many haven't been able to implement agreed pay rises. Moreover, if inclusion is to mean something more than good soundbites, lecturers are also going to need retraining to learn how to deal with the more difficult students, not least because only 50% of further education lecturers have professional qualifications.

But even if the inclusion initia tives were up and running properly, there is still a problem. The concentration on low attainment groups has worked to the detriment of the middle level groups and John Brennan, director of further education at the Association of Colleges, thinks there needs to be a shift in recruitment focus. "It's not just about the money," he says, "though it is undeniably more cost- effective to target middle rank attainment groups. In comparison to our European neighbours, our middle rank groups lag behind in skills and qualifications so we do need to improve in these areas, too."

All in all, you can't help thinking that Malcolm Wicks has probably had better weeks.

fields.headline: We are the future
fields.standfirst: Hugh Pitman argues that we already have the means to train a world-class workforce
fields.trailText: Hugh Pitman argues that we already have the means to train a world-class workforce
fields.body:
Most people would agree that we value the academic over the vocational more in theory than in practice; after all, when your pipes burst, it is the plumber not the philosopher you want to see coming through the door. The world of academia has its place, but in order to keep the wheels of industry and commerce turning as we race into the information age, our country needs the best trained, best qualified and most highly skilled workforce achievable.

Right now - with the experiments of the past behind us and a huge amount of experience accumulated, particularly over the last 20 years - our relatively young vocational training industry is well place to deliver to employers and individuals the quality of practical education and training that both groups of customers respectively demand and deserve.

The present model of work-based training has been achieved by taking the most successful models from other countries and then - over 20 years of trial and error - moulding them to meet the particular requirements of the United Kingdom and its employers.

The work-based method of preparing young people and adults for employment opportunities, and upskilling and developing them within their careers, has proved beyond any doubt to be the most successful and cost-effective system in existence. A structured and supported plan of learning for the individual, coupled with real work experience on an employer's premises, enables the learner to develop their own capabilities in the world of work with the employer giving them their own particular slant on the skills and the culture required for their enterprise. This concept is supported and actively encouraged by government, industry and commerce - and it works.

The Association of Learning Providers (ALP) was born last December, when a group of providers and representatives of established networks spontaneously decided to join together as a unified voice for all public, private and voluntary sector training organisations.

It is a "network of networks", able to work closely with the government and government departments, both with employers and the large number of other agencies concerned, to drive forward solutions to strategic and policy issues, and to help achieve a truly world-class workforce for the United Kingdom.

The only two criteria for an organisation's involvement with the Association of Learning Providers are that it should be delivering work-based training and that it should be in pos session of contracts with one or other of the government funding agencies. The association is totally inclusive, embracing the best interests of all providers and of the many hundreds of thousands of young people and adults for whom providers are directly and daily responsible. It concerns itself as little as possible with institutional structures, but devotes its energies to addressing the issues of the day.

The Learning and Skills Council will soon replace all Training and Enterprise Councils (TECs) in England and will be operational by April 2001 with its 47 local outstations, all of which will work to a common pattern. This entirely new structure will have a £6bn annual budget and amongst many other responsibilities will be the government agency for managing vocational education and training in England for young people over the age of 16. There will inevitably be slightly different arrangements in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ire land, with Scotland currently undergoing a review of its training and enterprise agencies.

The actual delivery will be in the hands of the 2,500 providers, covering both geographical areas and the vast array of skills required by employers.

Many of these learning providers are very small and make invaluable contributions in niche markets, covering every skill imaginable within their own local communities - from upholsterers to signwriters; from wood turners to beekeepers; from photographers to silversmiths.

The largest work nationally, with many thousands of young people and unemployed adults on their multiplicity of programmes. Providers deliver programmes varying from help for the disadvantaged or those with special training needs, right through the spectrum of National - or Scottish - Vocational Qualifications at level 1 up to level 5 (degree standard). They come from the public, voluntary and private sectors; all basically delivering the same series of products and all with a part to play.

It is, over the years, the providers, working with others, who have developed all government programmes; who are the interface with schools and the careers service, and who recruit unemployed and employed clients - knocking on doors and going out into the highways and byways to involve employers large and small. They carry out induction and careers counselling; arrange work placements with employers; match clients to the jobs available; and in particular engage small businesses in the training process, with local labour market intelligence being updated daily.

The providers create job opportunities, and act as the normal recruitment agency for young people, on behalf of hundreds of thousands of employers, mostly small businesses, and deliver the entire training, assessment and internal verification processes, working with other agencies and acting as de facto training managers for small businesses. They develop quality and best practice in every aspect of their work; provide all administration and pastoral care for clients from 16 to 65 years of age -soon to be from age 14 due to changes in the national curriculum. They work in partnership with employers towards successful outcomes, normally jobs and vocational qualifications.

There is no need to look for the new next big thing. We already have the delivery system in place. All we need to do is to use it.

 Hugh Pitman - whose family has provided leaders in vocational skills training for individual development and business improvement since 1812 - is Chairman of the Association of Learning Providers.

fields.headline: A victory for pupils
fields.standfirst: An academy that caters closely to its pupils' needs? Easy, when the parents have set it up themselves. By  Alan Combes
fields.trailText: An academy that caters closely to its pupils' needs? Easy, when the parents have set it up themselves. By Alan Combes
fields.body:
The desire of Wendy and Les Hutton to found the Victory Academy was born out of their dyslexic son Nathan's miserable experiences at state school.

"If a child is learning but unhappy at school, you can address that. If he is happy but not learning, then you can provide support. But if the child is unhappy and not learning, then his schooling is nothing more than an elaborate baby-sitting service that's not working," says Wendy.

During Nathan's primary school days in inner Leeds, things had been promising, with a dedicated teacher and a reasonable environment, but transfer to secondary school proved to be a different matter.

Wendy says: "It took them two terms to assess his needs and then all he was offered was an hour a week during English and some help at lunchtime. He got a scholarship for performing arts, but he was upset at making no academic progress."

Then there was the trouble on the bus home, even with a teacher on board: fighting, swearing, torn coats, threats with broken bottles. The Huttons began to seriously consider educating both their son and 10-year-old daughter from home.

"We weren't starting from nothing as we had friends who had home-schooled their kids as well as some American connections, and did some net surfing to improve our knowledge," says Wendy.

They talked over their intentions and two other Leeds families said they, too, were unhappy at their youngsters' progress in the conventional schooling system and could they join the project? That made eight children from three families in all, and by the education department's definition, more than five children is a school, provided they are from more than one family.

As anyone who has ventured along this road knows, there are four basic requirements: children, premises, teachers and curriculum. This last was a tricky problem, in that they did not want to concoct more of the same dull brew that was already associated with failure for their children.

"There were lots of good schemes like English for seven-year-olds and science for key stage 2, but we didn't want something like a patchwork quilt," says Wendy. "We wanted something that put minimum bureaucratic pressure on the teachers. The main possibilities were North American and we eventually settled on the School for Tomorrow curriculum, which is used by 7,000 schools internationally".

For the £650 initial contract, the school receives manuals, literature and one week's residential training for five people.

"What the parents liked best," says Les Hutton, "was the diagnostic testing we were able to carry out on our pupils after this training. We looked at five basic subjects and some people were shocked to find their youngster was up to four years behind".

Rosemary Foster, a friend of the Huttons, had been a special needs co-ordinator at a state school before retiring in December 1998. Having seen what the Huttons had managed thus far, she offered her services for free as their principal teacher, and she and her husband John offered their house in central Leeds as a base for the school.

"At first the plan was to convert the living room to a classroom for our eight pupils, but as people heard of our progress, the eight went up to 12," Foster says.

By the time the Fosters went away for a week's holiday last summer, the school's roll had grown to 17 pupils, now housed in two bedrooms and the living room. For those seven days the house was like a set of Changing Rooms, as parents and grandparents set about the conversion financed by £3,600 of the Huttons' money and a favourable deal with MDF for building materials.

"None of these are well-off parents," Wendy Hutton remarks. "They are making huge sacrifices to make sure the school works."

As it reaches the end of its second term, the Victory Academy has seen an HMI visit (encouraging words in January but as yet no written report) and its staffing capacity has risen to one full-time and three part-time teachers, working for free.

"Yes, we need a science lab, an art room and a drama studio, but these are matters which will be addressed when we have a new building, hopefully an old pub, church or hall sited on the route of the inner-city circular bus," Wendy Hutton says.

In the US funding follows the child, but in the UK it is different. The funding for these 17 pupils goes to their neighbourhood schools even though the places have not been taken up. The Huttons' only hope is that some benefactor who recognises the experimental value of what the academy is doing will magically appear.

"We need £50 a week per child to cover the cost of the building and one teacher, but the only hope we can see is in the nursery voucher system, where the £1,000 per child might extend into our school."

And what of the children themselves and the quality of learning? The uniform is a yellow sweatshirt and each pupil has an individual office that they are free to customise.

One of the mothers is a doctor and she teaches practical science on Tuesday afternoons. PE is focusing on swimming this term, but there are also generous helpings of horticulture, textile crafts and even library visits. No wonder there is now a waiting list of 34 pupils, including the two children of the newly arrived next-door neighbour.

From age five to 15, the children mark their own work in an organised and impressive manner, knowing exactly how to access the answer books in the filing system. No two pupils are doing the same work simultaneously except cooperatively during afternoon group sessions (when the individual offices ingeniously convert into joint working space).

"I'm just so much happier than I was in my other school a year ago," Kelly says, "more relaxed with my friends."

I asked James if he missed the company of other 15-year-olds now he was in a four- to-16 school.

"No", he answers without any edge, "all that fighting and swearing I got into at that school doesn't happen now. But best of all, I understand what I'm doing and how to improve."

In a week when Summerhill School was fighting for its experimental life and reputation in the courts, perhaps the last word should fall to Les Hutton, formerly a builder and now an ordained minister.

"There are two important issues. First, it's amazing to see what the programme of individualised learning has done for these kids, how it has given them responsibility and control of their studies. Second, the merit system. You should see the kids on a Friday afternoon when the merits are added and they can win things like a trip to Pizza Hut or time out. Other schools have merit systems, I know, but the question is "does it buzz the kids? Ours does."

No wonder there is now a waiting list of 34 pupils, including the two children of the newly arrived next-door neighbour. From age five to 15, the children mark their own work in an organised and impressive manner, knowing exactly how to access the answer books in the filing system. No two pupils are doing the same work simultaneously except cooperatively during afternoon group sessions (when the individual offices ingeniously convert into joint working space). "I'm just so much happier than I was in my other school a year ago," Kelly says, "more relaxed with my friends." I asked James if he missed the company of other 15-year-olds now he was in a four- to-16 school. "No", he answers without any edge, "all that fighting and swearing I got into at that school doesn't happen now. But best of all, I understand what I'm doing and how to improve." In a week when Summerhill School was fighting for its experimental life and reputation in the courts, perhaps the last word should fall to Les Hutton, formerly a builder and now an ordained minister. "There are two important issues. First, it's amazing to see what the programme of individualised learning has done for these kids, how it has given them responsibility and control of their studies. Second, the merit system. You should see the kids on a Friday afternoon when the merits are added and they can win things like a trip to Pizza Hut or time out. Other schools have merit systems, I know, but the question is "does it buzz the kids? Ours does."

fields.headline: The price of progress
fields.standfirst: Labour is investigating additional fees for elite universities, reports Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Labour is investigating additional fees for elite universities, reports Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
The prime minister's advisers have privately urged elite university heads to draw up proposals for charging students top-up fees. It is the strongest signal yet that the Labour government will allow universities to charge different levels of tuition fees for undergraduates if, as expected, they secure a second parliamentary term.

Officials drafting Labour's election manifesto are facing a dilemma over the future financing of the higher-education sector. On one hand, they are keen that major international research centres, such as Cambridge and Oxford, are able to compete with the best universities overseas in recruiting leading academics. On the other, they want to support the efforts of new universities which are attracting more students from poor areas - still largely excluded from degree courses.

Convinced that discoveries and developments from the academic world will underpin the successful businesses of the future, Chancellor Gordon Brown is expected to announce extra cash for university laboratory facilities when the current Whitehall spending review concludes this summer. But most of the grants will be channelled into the country's top research-rated university departments.

Approximately three-quarters of all government research budgets are allocated to researchers working in the 20 large universities with medical schools, known as the Russell group.

However, teaching grants are distributed much more evenly among universities, and ministers would rather increase support for the former polytechnics, which are improving access for students from under-represented groups in higher education. One solution being mooted is to allow the academic elite to generate their own private teaching funds by charging students extra fees. This would represent a radical departure from existing arrangements, where all universities charge the same flat rate of £1,050 a year for students.

"The real dilemma," said one vice-chancellor, "is how to get more Treasury resources into universities that are trying to compete worldwide with the best universities overseas - without giving Treasury money that would seek to favour the privileged over the less privileged."

Tony Blair's education adviser, Andrew Adonis, has urged vice-chancellors in the Russell group to explore the options for removing current government controls on the number of students recruited and the fees charged by universities. The group also recently arranged to meet David Milliband, the head of Number 10's policy unit.

Academic economists are carrying out a study on the funding implications of deregulating tuition fees and allocating core government teaching grants through open competition. But some academics have already raised concerns that the move would deepen the educational divide between the rich and poor, alienating students from under-privileged backgrounds from the top research universities.

However, others argue that the taxpayer should not foot the whole bill for students studying at prestigious institutions such as Cambridge who then go on to enjoy much more substantial lifelong financial returns than graduates from other universities.

The Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, meanwhile, which is carrying out a wider analysis of the future funding options for universities in general, told MPs this month that the extra funds required for higher education could not be raised through donations from businesses.

Last week education minister Baroness Blackstone told the House of Commons education committee inquiry into student finance that she welcomed the CVCP review.

At the same time she stressed that the government retains powers to claw back any additional funds from universities generated by top-up fees, and that there were no plans to change the current arrangements.

fields.headline: The Red Fox Gang
fields.standfirst: Or how one library is winning new readers. By  Julia Eccleshare
fields.trailText: Or how one library is winning new readers. By Julia Eccleshare
fields.body:
"I liked it because of the battles and the blood and I learnt a lot about how to kill people in different ways."

"It's good. There's a lot of dying in it from diseases."

Ten-year-olds Thomas and Jamie never tire of gore and so were delighted with Dark Knights and Dingy Castles, and The Measly Middle Ages, from Scholastic's best-selling Horrible History series, just two of the books Lesley Cowan, librarian at Marshalswick Library in St Albans, had offered to her Red Fox Reading Gang as part of their journey to "Past Worlds". The Gang meets once a month, on the floor in a corner of the library, for a reading session that is supported by a pack of materials from Red Fox, the publishers.

Structured but unschooly, it is designed to give children the chance to enjoy a wide range of reading and to share their thoughts about the books. At Marshalswick, there are about a dozen regular members from different neighbourhood schools, perhaps untypically more boys than girls, and they clearly enjoy the chance to talk about books they like and to be introduced to new books.

"We get the best books and the best authors here. That makes it special," says Thomas.

The Gang have been reading for their "Past Worlds" theme and there is initially lots of chat about what makes a book good - action, violence, lots of plotting - as well as why some of the books had been a disappointment. It requires good leadership to keep the group together, as listening to others talking is never as much fun as talking yourself and there's a lot of fidgeting and background chat while Anthony gives an enthusiastic and lucid account of Philip Pullman's The Subtle Knife, and Richard explains what he liked about Terry Jones's The Saga of Erik the Viking.

All are silent, however, when Lesley starts reading aloud. She has chosen two historical novels from different periods and asks them to look for clues about which era each comes from. Leon Garfield's Smith produces some wild guesses, including almost every period from Tudor to the most nearly accurate, "like in Scrooge because of the gas lamps". Rosemary Sutcliff's Blood Feud, with its more easily datable wattle and daub hut, is quickly identified as Viking. More importantly, the bloody background proves to be a huge draw and everybody dives on the few copies available. Not bad going that; 10 new Rosemary Sutcliff readers in three-quarters of an hour.

There's some filling-in of the certificates Red Fox have provided and the group disperses, armed with piles of books for their next month's reading. "The ones who come are mostly keen readers already," says Lesley, "but having the Gang gives them the chance to extend their reading on a given theme. It's a great addition to the work of the library."
