fields.headline: Whitehawk's big splash
fields.trailText: Whitehawk Primary School in Brighton and the River of Words
fields.body:
Scroll down the list of the "2000 River of Words" finalists, and in amongst the names of young people from all across America you will find mention of one Josh Coomber, aged seven, of Whitehawk Primary School in Brighton, and his haiku:

"Cool, fresh rain water,

Runs off aunty's umbrella

Then makes a big splash."

This poem was one of thousands of entries on the theme of "Watersheds" into what is the world's largest annual children's poetry contest, organised by the International Rivers Network. Pamela Michael, director and co-founder of the project, says of the entries that "Children's . . . poetry has a vitality and spontaneity that aims right at the heart. This wonderful work constitutes a compelling view of the natural world as seen through the eyes of its children."

The International Rivers Network is a non-profit making, voluntary organisation that was set up in 1985 to support local communities working to protect their rivers, and to campaign to stop destructive river development projects whilst promoting equitable and sustainable methods of meeting a community's needs for water, energy and flood management. Fears for the future of the dolphins that play on the Yangtze river, threatened by the Three Gorges Dam, inspired Christine Yin, aged 13, of Guangzhou in the People's Republic of China to write the poem that won this year's International Grand Prize.

John McKay, a teacher at Whitehawk, came across the competition when he took part in an exchange visit to San Francisco two years ago, and has been encouraging his pupils to enter the annual competition ever since. First the children studied the Japanese haiku as a form - a haiku usually consists of three lines of five, seven and five syllables each. In order to write a haiku for the competition, they then began to think about "watery" words. Over Christmas, the young poets got their thinking caps on.

Josh's mother says that he enjoys reading, and his sister likes to write her own rhymes, but Josh took partic ular pleasure in "telling everyone that he had written a haiku, and then having to explain what one is". When he received the letter from America, informing him of his success, Josh was overcome with disbelief.

All 20 entrants from Whitehawk will get a certificate, although Josh's will be a bit special as befits his achievement, and he will also receive a T-shirt and other prizes. The contest's grand winners win a trip to Washington DC, where they will be honoured at an awards ceremony and public reading at the Library of Congress on April 29.

As the competition is open to all young people from kindergarten to upper sixth, Josh and his classmates still have plenty of time to hone their poetic skills and win that trip across the pond.

 For further information about the International Rivers Network, visit their website: www.irn.org

fields.headline: Class notes
fields.trailText: • There was some quick thinking by the Association of Teachers and Lecturers at its annual conference in Belfast. After listening to Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, leaders of the third largest of the classroom unions tried to sign her up. Until last month, the association's constitution would have forbidden the recruitment of anyone but a serving or trainee teacher. But now it is about to launch a drive to sign up classroom assistants, nursery nurses and other para-professionals. Morris, a former teacher and longstanding member of the rival National Union of Teachers, prevaricated when an application form was thrust into her hands. Perhaps she will think again when she hears more of the campaign by John Monks, TUC general secretary, to bring some unity to the warring teaching unions.

After listening to Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, leaders of the third largest of the classroom unions tried to sign her up. Until last month, the association's constitution would have forbidden the recruitment of anyone but a serving or trainee teacher. But now it is about to launch a drive to sign up classroom assistants, nursery nurses and other para-professionals. Morris, a former teacher and longstanding member of the rival National Union of Teachers, prevaricated when an application form was thrust into her hands. Perhaps she will think again when she hears more of the campaign by John Monks, TUC general secretary, to bring some unity to the warring teaching unions.

 Delegates in Belfast were surprised to hear Tony Blair was in the city. There had been months of discussion about the possibility of Blair speaking to the ATL. It would have been the first time that a serving prime minister had addressed a teachers' union. In the end, Downing Street dropped the plan because of the uncertain state of Northern Ireland politics. Strange, then, that Blair visited Belfast during the ATL conference in a bid to re-invigorate the peace process. "There's a piquant irony in that. But we received a charming letter of apology. He was right to come and it was for the same reason we did - to show confidence in the peace process," said general secretary Peter Smith.

 It was a moot point whether the ATL's presence did contribute to peace. Smith was accused by Frank Bunting, northern secretary of the Irish National Teachers' Organisation, of having a "colonial attitude" towards the province's teachers. After Smith said they should be eligible for the same £2,000 performance bonus that is to be available in England, Bunting said he was "fed up to the back teeth with people coming over and acting as colonial governors." Smith confined himself to parading his impeccable anti-colonial credentials. His Irish great-great uncle was imprisoned in Broadmoor for running an illicit "hedge school" in County Monaghan.

fields.headline: The Guv'nor
fields.trailText: While most people understand the governor's supportive role, very few are aware of the need to act as a 'critical friend'
fields.body:
"It's all very well telling me to ask challenging questions, but I wouldn't know one if I fell over it!" a new governor said to me recently.

People volunteer to be governors with some understanding of their supportive role. They may also be aware of discussion and decisions about curriculum policy, appointing staff, finance and maintenance of premises, but have no idea about the extent to which the governing body is held accountable for performance.

Governors are often not aware that they must act as a "critical friend", which the education department defines as "critical" in the sense of its responsibility for monitoring and evaluating the school's effectiveness, asking challenging questions and pressing for improvement.

If governors are to make any sense of the information coming through to them, questions will need to focus on academic standards attained, year-on-year progress, current performance compared to similar schools, and how various departments and subject areas vary in performance.

The bottom line is proving to their satisfaction that the efforts made by the teacher are making a difference, and that difference translates into clearly defined improvements in pupils' learning.

Two governors from a school in special measures recounted to me their headteacher's report to the governing body of a very significant improvement in pupils' assessment reports at the end of key stage 2. Naturally, the governing body was delighted. A glow settled around them, until their attention was drawn to the fact that they were still in the bottom 25% of schools in their national "family" of similar schools.

So, while "how is our school performing?" is important, "how is our school performing in comparison with similar schools?" is crucial.

The school development plan provides a regular opportunity for the headteacher to report on progress and provide evidence of improvement in pupils' learning. Two of the key questions here are "how will we know when we have achieved our goals?" and "What is success going to look like when related to pupils' learning?"

Headteachers place a high value on a governing body that has the experience and knowledge to act as a sounding board and engage in strategic decision- making and planning. "Where are we trying to get to?" and "what are the key priorities and why?" are questions that must be answered.

So it's back to the right questions. "Why" will always elicit information and justifications for action. "Can you explain" will assist in understanding the issues. "What do we need to do in order to . . . ?" will provide insights into how the headteacher intends to manage change. But asking challenging questions can appear threatening if time hasn't been spent in developing a healthy partnership.

 Mary McKay is the governor training manager in Warwickshire and a governor of a primary school.

fields.headline: Faith in our schools
fields.standfirst: Why are parents today so concerned about how religion is taught to their children?  Karen Gold  looks at current issues
fields.trailText: Why are parents today so concerned about how religion is taught to their children? Karen Gold looks at current issues
fields.body:
The Parable of the Good Shopper is what children learn in their French and German lessons, argues Alison Farnell of the Stapleford Centre, a Nottingham-based Christian educational trust that recently began publishing secondary school textbooks. "When you learn French in school, you learn what to say in a cafe, or a railway station, or a market," she says. "The whole content of foreign language teaching in England assumes you are a tourist, or a spender, or a consumer."

The Stapleford Centre's new GCSE textbooks for French and German are rather different: "We do all the same grammar, but we set it in a different context. We look at the faith beliefs of people in France and Germany. We look at light as a symbol of hope. We look at the way people held candles when the Berlin Wall came down. Our French books show how to buy bread in a patisserie, but they also show bread as a symbol in Christianity and in Islam."

The centre, which has links with St John's Theological College in Nottingham, now publishes GCSE-level textbooks in science, maths, French, German and English. They cover the material required by the national curriculum, but from a spiritual point of view. Ordinary GCSE maths books, for example, often teach percentages by asking children to work out how much interest they will gain on money deposited in a bank. Stapleford's maths book asks children to calculate the percentage of their future income they might give away.

Next month, the centre brings out textbooks in the same five subjects for younger secondary students. History, geography, technology and Spanish books for both age groups are also planned. The books, written by Christian teachers, have proved very popular: almost the entire first run of 9,000 copies have been sold. Church secondary schools have bought about a third of them; the other two thirds have been bought by ordinary, non-religious state schools.

So why would these local schools buy religious textbooks for teaching maths or science from an avowedly Christian publisher? The answer lies in the law, which - surprisingly to many parents and pupils - not only permits but promotes the presence of religion throughout the English state education system.

Since 1992, schools have been under a legal obligation to "promote spiritual and moral values throughout the curriculum" . The demand for the Stapleford books, published under the name "The Charis Project", is a direct result of this, says Alison Farnell. "Our books enable teachers to bring out spiritual and moral issues. They are not for use in teaching RE; they are for languages, or maths, or science with a spiritual and moral dimension."

Spirituality throughout the curriculum is only one of several religious obligations on state schools. What most schools call "assembly" is actually defined in law as "daily collective worship", compulsory for all pupils (unless their parents withdraw them) up to the age of 18. This must be "wholly or mainly of a broadly Christian character" except in exceptional circumstances. (An opt-out for schools where children are predominantly Muslim, for example.)

All state schools must also provide religious education for all pupils up to the age of 18. This includes 14- to 16-year-old pupils who drop other subjects. It is possible for some pupils to replace science and languages with vocational-style courses, for example, but their school must still insist they study RE unless their parents withdraw them from it.

All of these regulations apply to the three-quarters of state schools that have no official link with any religion. In the other quarter, the schools that are affiliated to particular denominations and for which the state pays 85-100% of the running costs, religion will be more overt still.

Several governors of these schools will be chosen by the church or other religious group. Children may be offered or denied places on the basis of their parents' religion and/or attendance at services. The school itself may become a place of worship: at St Aidan's Memorial C of E primary in Hartlepool, for example, parents are invited to communion services held by the local vicar in the school.

St Aidan's, like many Anglican schools, serves a catchment area taking in children from Christian and non-Christian families alike. Many rural primary schools are in this situation - a fact that is causing a stir in Leicestershire, and may lead to a case being taken to the European Court of Human Rights.

Eric Goodyer lives in the village of Hathern, Leicestershire, where the local C of E primary school is the only one in the village. Included in the school's aims is the phrase "to promote Christian values". Goodyer has protested at this, and at the requirement for parents to support it in the home-school agreement.

In a one-school village he cannot exercise his right to freedom of religious expression, which from next year will be his under European and English law, he argues: "If the church is going to impose Christianity when the school is the only one in the catchment area, then that denies people the choice of having their children educated in a pluralist environment."

But pluralism is not the current trend. Until 1997, virtually all state religious schools were Anglican or Roman Catholic. These were justified as the product of history. (The churches had a 19th-century school system long before compulsory state education). Applications from other religious groups to set up state-funded schools were turned down by successive government ministers as smacking of separatism.

However, since May 1997, the government has approved the first two Muslim state primaries in Birmingham and Brent, two Sikh schools in Middlesex, a Seventh Day Adventist school in Haringey, five Jewish primaries and three new Roman Catholic schools. The first Greek Orthodox state school, St Cyprian's, is due to open in Croydon later this year. Various London communities are drawing up plans for four more Jewish primaries, a non-Orthodox Jewish secondary school, and the first state Hindu school.

But it is also true that in recent months, as well as protracted haggling with the bishops over how sex and relationships education should be taught in state schools, ministers have signalled a new enthusiasm for religious schools. Blunkett recently called for the church to take over failing inner-city schools.

For the first time since 1970, the Church of England has set up a review of Anglican schools, with an expansionist agenda. Its conclusions are due by the middle of next year - but even as it was announced, the secretary of the church's board of education, Canon John Hall, was pointing out that current Anglican provision, particularly at secondary level, falls far short of demand.

He spoke of church schools turning away "large numbers of potential pupils for no other reason than lack of space" and of doubling the current number of C of E secondary schools to 400 (there are currently 198 secondaries, and 4,550 primaries) over the next 10 years.

If Anglicans achieve that expansion, they will overtake the Roman Catholic provision for 11-18s - there are 363 RC secondaries, and 1,760 primaries. Both churches are talking of the need to train more Christian teachers and headteachers; no one knows how many there are at present, but 40 of the 104 teacher-training providers are church foundations.

Humanists and secularists are shocked by this resurgence of religion. They argue that religious schools are divisive, that as religious schools assert their excellence, then local non-denominational schools will be perceived as second best. Parents may be able to withdraw children from assemblies and RE, but they cannot withdraw them from an all-pervasive "ethos", they say. Families are increasingly faced with travelling long distances to find a pluralist school, or acquiescing to teachings they reject, according to both the National Secular Society and the British Humanist Association.

One BHA member, Julie Norris, set up a support network for parents who were faced with incidents like the one in which her son, having been told by his parents that he did not have to put his hands together and close his eyes during prayers, was "poked by a teacher who said 'you think this is all a joke, don't you?' "

Children's rights of access to an equal curriculum are also infringed in some religious schools, argue their critics. They point to the Kent C of E primary school in which the head recently denounced the best-selling "Harry Potter" books on the grounds that they subverted biblical teaching.

Yet religious schools are immensely popular with parents. Most of them turn away some children; many could fill their classrooms twice over. Some of this may be to do with perceptions of orderliness and discipline. But according to Ofsted evidence, church schools do achieve a higher level of moral and spiritual input to children than non- denominational counterparts.

And that may have far-reaching effects. For there is unpublished research evidence, funded by the Teacher Training Agency, which suggests that standards of teaching and learning appear to go up in line with a school's spiritual input.

University researchers have been monitoring an experiment in a Bristol C of E secondary school, St Mary Redcliffe and Temple School, in which pupils, teachers and parents discussed core values - justice, truth, forgiveness, stewardship - and then introduced them overtly into teaching.

So in a series of science lessons on the circulation of the blood, St Mary's teenage pupils began not by learning facts about red cells and white cells, but about the American pioneer of the blood transfusion service, Charles Drew, who died after a whites- only hospital refused him a blood transfusion because he was black.

In geography lessons about the structure of Bristol, they began by looking at the effect of second world war bombing, and compared them with the bombing of Dresden. Discussion about forgiveness followed, before they returned to geography.

This may be valuable morally and spiritually anyway. But the reason why the TTA and ministers are watching St Mary's lessons carefully is that its pupils also appear to be reaching higher standards. Teachers are more thoughtful about what they are teaching; pupils see the point of what they are learning and are more motivated to learn it, according to St Mary's deputy head Richard Badley.

"What you get is the motivation that comes from challenging people about real things, real issues." St Mary's, which is vastly over-subscribed, restricts its intake to the children of practising Christian families. It might take longer to establish core values in a school where views were more diverse, Badley believes, but the relevance of the issues would be the same.

You may be bringing in Christian values, you may be bringing in secular humanism - but that is a belief system, too. Nothing is value-free."

fields.headline: How juries are nobbled
fields.standfirst:
Legal Correspondent Clare Dyer explains the background to today's investigation into allegations of jury 'nobbling' in the Tony Martin murder trial

Investigation begins into 'nobbled' jury
fields.trailText: Legal Correspondent Clare Dyer explains the background to today's investigation into allegations of jury 'nobbling' in the Tony Martin murder trial.
fields.body:
Court officials met today to decide whether to investigate allegations that jurors at the trial of Tony Martin, the farmer convicted of murdering a burglar last week, were "nobbled" or intimidated into bringing in a guilty verdict. They decided to take no action.

The accusation was made by a woman caller to a local radio station, who claimed to have been on the jury.

If the allegations had any substance, they could have been one of the grounds cited by Martin's lawyers in his forthcoming appeal against conviction.

Nobbling could have prevented a fair trial if it influenced the outcome by persuading jurors to return a verdict they thought was unjustified.

Jury intimidation is not a new development. Its origins go back centuries, when it was known as the offence of "embracery." It was a rash of attempts to intimidate jurors which led to the introduction of the majority verdict in the Criminal Justice Act 1967. This allows a conviction if 10 out of 11 or12 jurors (or nine out of 10) agree.

In most nobbling cases, family or associates of the defendant try to intimidate jurors into finding him not guilty. The nobbling alleged in the Martin case - attempts by those on the victim's side to try to influence the jury to convict him - is more unusual.

In the early 1980s at the Old Bailey there was an outbreak of jury nobbling and several trials, including one which had lasted for seven months, had to be stopped because of attempts to bribe or intimidate jurors..

As a result, juries were made to sit at the back of the court, out of view of the public gallery and brown paper was pasted over the doors of some courts to stop people looking in. Jurors were warned to eat only in their canteen and to stay away from nearby pubs and cafes.

In 1983 eight people convicted of trying to bribe jurors received jail terms between eighteen months and seven years. The judge who sentenced them said: "Let those who try to nobble jurors beware."

The Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994 also brought in a specific offence of intimidating or causing or threatening to cause harm to a juror or witness, punishable by up to five years in prison.
